330ml bottle from Cheese & Wine Shop Darlington. Poured into Orval glass. Hazy sandy golden brown colour, with complex aroma yeast malt honey and thick foamy tan head. Initial sourish fizzy dry earthy deep resinous notes with slight lingering bitterness, layered against a smooth malty mouthfeel. Quite drinkable

November 1, 2012; 6.9% abv, 330 mL bottle, rock glass, BTL: 04/08/11
Aromas mostly of sweet raisin malt and a bit of booze.  Pours a hazy copper with a nice large off white fluffy head. Sweet malts dominate. Raisin bread with some fruity esters. Finish is a smooth herbal with light spice. Thick mouthfeel that is extremely smooth. Delicious.

Orange red color with head with big bubbles. Aroma of  white wine,  a bit of alcohol.  Taste is bitter and really dry, its like champagne but not in a good way really.... the end is too dry for me.  There is some fruitiness as well. Not big fan.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2014 Pours muddy orange to amber with medium frothy of white head
Aromas of oranges, belgian yeast, bread
A bit thin palate. Low bodied, medium bitter, alcohol is also present.
Taste is aromatic but a bit too sour. Not the best trappist ive had

Atari is sour and a little alkali. Appearance is orange with a neat white head. Taste hint at sweet, but the dryness leaves a light fruity sour taste. Dryness dominates the palate. But also full of froth.

Poured golden with lots of carbonation.  Lemon, grassy, spice and yeast in the nose.  Heavy carbonation on the palate with a very dry finish.  Sourness is subtle and quenches like no other.  Noble, earthy hops, lemon, grain and spice on the tongue.  A true classic and one of my favorite Trappists!

Cloudy yellow pour. Tall white head with moderate lacing.

Smells yeast and hops. 

Tastes a little underwhelming. Lemon, bitter hops, belgian yeast. Lots of carbonation. 

Its good but I was definitely expecting more. Maybe this batch wasnt a winner.
Smells lemony and yeasty.  Pours a cloudy orangish gold with thick white head.  Tastes like lemon pledge with a sour ale element to it.
Probablement la meilleure trappiste du monde, malheureusement car il devient de plus en plus difficile den trouver...
One of the best trappist beers. Nice lemon aroma is followed by dusion of different tastes.

Poured from a bottle purchased in a grocery store in Ghent, into a Duvel fluted glass.  Clloudy gold, half a finger of head with many large visible bubbles left very little lacing.  Nose is very hoppy - very flora.  Very champagne-like, slightly sour with lots of hops.  Bubbly and tingly on the palate.  Alcohol definitely present despite the relatively low 6.2 ABV.

Bottle from Belgian Beer Shop.com. I drank this one cooled in the fridge. This gives the beer a lot more freshness. Its a wonderful thirst quencher. The color is hazy amber with a nice off-white head that leaves lots of lacing.
The aroma is very hoppy, fresh with a touch of fruitiness (citrus). The taste is perfectly balanced between the hop bitterness and the fruity sweetness. The beer is also yeasty. This is by far my all time favorite. A true classic that can be drunk on every occasion.

bottled may 2011: very hazy dark pale pour with large fluffy white head and particles floating around. Good lacing a head retention. Aromas of hops and almost a lemon lime soda smell when first poured. Chalky grain taste, biscuit,  with a sour dough quality to it and a  dry floral hop character to it. Good mouth feel. I feel like this beer is in a transition from the fresh orval taste to a well aged orval taste.

Head seems to last an eternity. Big yeast and lemon aroma - perhaps the best yeast scent I have come across yet. Well balanced Brettiness, sharp lemon citrus, and breadiness in the flavor. Glad I finally got a bottle of this legendary brew.

Apparently there are many dedicated Orval enthusiasts. I tried 1984, but the words not the numbers, and found it a bit dull. Animal Farm, the allegorical novella not the rude flick, was ok, nothing great. Down and Out in London and Paris was brilliant, full of tramps and fine dining. And then Homage to Catalonia, which contributed to my world view and made me think of big things as I chomped on tapas in Barcelona. Not bad for a bland bottle that hides a big secret. I may write Homage to Belgians, but It would be full of strange references to Creature With the Atom Brain and such things.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2016
January 1, 2016. Bottled february 17, 2010. 
Six years, great smooth funky and bretty 
 November, 17. Bottle from Systembolaget. 
Very hazy amber with a white head. Aroma is citrus, wheat, mild cloves, belgian yeast, hay. Taste is sweet, with some sourness to it. Medium bodied with a tangy finishing bitterness.
8-3-8-4-15=38

11/17/2010 bottle. Pours deep gold with a thick pillow of white head that clings in swatches to the glass. Aroma is slightly funky, a bit citrusy, some apple and pineapple. Taste is dry and tart. Not all its cracked up to be.
From bottle. Deep caramel color gives way to a hoppiness that I was not anticipating, but it adds a nice dryness to it.
Notes of caramel, raisin, orange peel, faint spice and herbal hops.  Mild and pleasant bitterness.  Tangy and dry.  One is not enough to fully appreciate it.

De couleur abricot, une mousse digne la coiffe et dessine une belle dentelle serrée. Des arômes fruités; de raisins vert, de poires en émanent, accompagnés deffluves houblonnées et dun alcool doux. Très plaisant pour le nez, cest bien dosé. En bouche, on reste surpris par sa détermination, comme si elle nous donnait tout ce quelle a dun coup. Cest acidulé, cest fruité, cest amer et ces trois principales caractéristiques forment un tout très bien amalgamé, donc, un bel équilibre, où lalcool se fait discret. (Embouteillée 15-12-2011) (436-021112)

8 months old bottle. Really cloudy brown to orange. Foamy white head which lasted forever, good lacing. Aroma of orange peel, grapefruit, dark fruits, earth. The taste was more yeasty and something i believe is brett. Light bitterness. 
Creamy texture and average carbonation, perfect to me.
Cloudy amber/orange colornwith hardly any collar. Sweet warm fruity smell. Taste is much stronger compared to its looks and its soft and warm smell. Penetrating citrus with flavours of licorice

Pours a big orange/brown head. Aromas of pear, raisins, citrus and herbs, quite bitter flavour, thinking of almond and pear. creamy texture. Drying mouthfeel afterwards. Flavours are too closed for me, having a hard time getting much out of it.
Poured into Orval chalice, thick velvety head lasts forever. Smooth taste balances all the ingredients perfectly. Very drinkable, even with the higher ABV. This is close to a perfect beer.
Large frothy head that subsided relatively quickly.  Complex flavoring with a tiny bit of a bitter finish.

Seems very refined, like a fine cognac. Certain members of their field seem a step above everything else in a certain way... Grace Kelly or Cary Grant in acting, for example. Orval is like that for me, and dry and sour at the same time, the only time Ive experienced this in a beer.
Sabor ahumado equilibrado, fuerte olor, adecuada con acompañada de comida. Excelente presentación

Finally getting around to rating this.  The bottle may have been too fresh? i guess.  Tasted to me like apple juice with a fair amount of sweetness and some light grassy hop notes.  Was not funky at all like I remember.

Pours deep amber with orange highlights and a fluffy off white head. Raisins, plums and yeast on the nose. Taste is initially sweet fruit, followed up by a bitter note cutting through. Very solid body with rich malt. Lingering slightly sweet palate. Overall, a pretty awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 Bottle at home (from Spar Popperinge) 20/10/12.
Hazy orange/amber with a large frothy white head that collapses after a few minutes.
Nose comprises Belgian yeast, hops, spice, floral tones, fruit.
Taste follows nose, a little grass, earhtyness, fruity.
Medium bodied with soft carbonation and a little bitter in the finish.

1st rating:- 7; 4; 8; 4; 14.

Re-rate, 3 years aged 6.2% at Gainsbar, Kortrijk - 22/03/13.
Clear dark amber, good sized beige head that retains well.
Nose is earthy, funk, yeast, citrus, grass, spice, orange, wood, dark fruits.
Taste comprises light yeasts, dark fruits, earthy farmy tones, herbal notes.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, smooth and massaging on the palate.
Great beer with lots of depth for 6%. New rating carried forward.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Thick, "spritzy" head -- with a tart, spicy, earthy aroma... Champagne-like, I guess? Flavor is sweet at first, finishing drier. A lot of spicy hop flavor. Always enjoy the strong-yet-smooth bitterness I get from this beer.

Une bière dexception quil faut savoir déguster, des arômes très riches dune finesse incomparable. Attention à ne pas la tuer en la servant trop chaude ou trop froide : saccomode mal dune erreur de température !
Bottle pour to goblet.  Nice gold-orange color.  Dry, slightly sour; slightly hoppy.  Goes down smooth; very good.

Does not quite fathom this. There are many flavors to contend for that spot. Some are sour and bitter but I also feel a fresh sweetness. The acidic part unfortunately takes the upper hand and it gets a little stale, however, will save a bottle for storage to see if it can improve the taste.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2012 A different one. Nice copper colour with a creamy head. Smells like Brett and other complex phenols.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
pour moi, une perfection déquilibre ... tout trouve sa juste place dans cette bière, les arômes sont subtiles, lamertume ne prend pas le dessus, pour moi lune des meilleures trappistes
Flaske kjøpt på polet i vika. Fargen er rød/rav med et tykt lag skum.smaker både fruktig og bittert
Bottle from Post Office Vaults; good way to cap off the evening of great beer drinking dry complex maltly in an Orval trappist glass as well :)
Some dark fruit, gorgeous yeast. Lovely froth. Im not one to be full of froth. Froth. Good word that. Froth.

Bottle at A la Mort Subite, Brussels.  Strong, sweet, very yeasty aroma with a hint of banana.  This looks great - a cloudy orange/brown with a big, foamy head.  The taste is a slight let down by comparison - thinner and more watery than expected; bitter, slightly sour like a sweetened lambic, short finish.  Good - but not one of my favourite Belgian brews.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2013 Bottle at Huppel de Pub, Den Haag.  Poured a slighly cloudy straw colour with a huge frothy, long-lasting head.  Theres a yeasty,  fruity, spicy aroma with a hoppy bitter taste and a hint of sourness with some slight bitterness on the palate.  I should drink this more often!

Enjoyed via a bottle listed as (5/6/2008) in the cellar. Pours a golden orange with champagne-like carbonation and a medium white lacy head.Smells effervescent with a slight wet spring grass/hay quality and peach. Perhaps a little rice cereal as well. Taste is light with some white peach and then a dry and bitter finish from the hops on the back of the unguent. Very well balanced - not overly sweet, carbonated, watery or dry.

Sötét borostyán színű erős,tartós habkoronával!Illata citrusfélékre emlékeztet azok közül is a narancsra.Íze a méz és a karamell keveréke,amely hosszú lecsengésű komlós-savas utóízzel búcsúzik!Nagyon keserű sörök közé tartozik!
Igazi legenda!!!

hay, cereal, caramel, barnyard, earthy, copper/orange, hazy, rocky head, light sweetness, medium bitterness, salty, umami, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, lively carbonation in the mouth, astringent, long lasting bitter finish

A very different beer - be sure to pour leaving approx 2cm of liquid in the bottle.  Remaining yeast poured out in a shot glass an enjoyed separately from abbey goblet with the beer.  It pours a nice copper with lively thick foam.  Head dissipates gradually leaving nice lacing.  Aromas of the country side - earthy/grassy/barnyard - my first known exposure to Brett yeast.  Taste is very slight on the sweetness with light salty bitterness.  A thin sip, but carbonation intensifies in the mouth creating a lively mouthfeel.  A dry astringensy with medium bitterness in the finish.  Bitterness lingers, but diminishes in intensity quite quickly.  A very unique brew - I like it.
11.2 oz bottle pours a hazy amber with a full head.  Aromas of fruit some burnt sugar and yeast.   Flavor is balanced but a bit on the sweet side.  Body is medium and finish is a little sweet.
Sour apple aroma. Washing up liquid head, quickly disappeared. Sweet fruity taste with little finish. Easy to drink but too watery for my taste.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2013 2007 bottle from PaulHegedus.  Aroma is hard to describe... salt and sour cherries?  Hazy dark amber with dark bits of sediment.  Dry, slightly sour taste, reminding me of a lambic, with a soapiness that is not unpleasant.  Finish is both clean and dry.  Now Im interested to see what a 2012 bottle would taste like.  Update: tried a 2012 bottle.  Better, but not miles better.

Five year old bottle shared by kevinsenn, bottled 2007. Initially I smell garbage. Then it turns into a sweet mix of candy and sour cherries. Little flakes/chunks of  very dark sediment in the bottom of a cloudy pink-amber pour with a light head. Lambic type flavour, with a bit of garbaginess in there (that might be cilantro), with some fairly pleasant beeriness behind it. I really dont know what to think of it. Maybe five years is a bit too much? It is three days past the date stamped on the bottle... 

After a bit of time it begins to grow on me. I couldnt drink a ton of it, but its internesting.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2014 Cloudy, amber colour. White very, very foamy head. (Rated from the past, doesnt remember much) But it is quite good and memorable. Bottle.

Bott. da 33 cl. Bello laspetto con un bel colore ambrato carico schiuma fine compatta e molto persistente di color nocciola. Delude un pò al naso e al palato con sentori di malto e una percezione dellalcool un pò troppo accentuata, buono il finale bello secco.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2012 Hazy and bronze pour, puffy and lasting eggshell head. Aroma of must, caramel, bubblegum, and flowers. Taste is malty and a little bitter with a mild fruitiness. Medium bodied and a little dry. Not personally that impressed considering the hype.

from bottle. pours a pale, hazy orange colour with a beige, two-finger frothy head. lots of sweet yeast, spiciness and hoppiness characterise the aroma: notes of fermented apples, pears and citrus fruits. surprisingly the orval also smells a bit like green pickled olives. overall the aroma is a bit too musty in my opinion. but maybe that is just a subjective impression...however,  the body is medium and the carbonation is above the average. it tastes sour and bitter and definitely lacks - the expected - complexity. i am kind of suprised by the other good ratings. anyway, I do like the dry mouthfeef, reminding me of white wine. but i am still a bit disappointed.
Bottle. Cloudy amber colour, big offwhite head. Aroma floral hops. Taste initially medium bitter, very light sweet. Towards the finish indeed dry, light heavy floral hoppy bitter. Good one.

Bouteille 330 ml. 6.9% Couleur ambrée un peu opaque, mousse beige.Arôme de malt, houblon et levures. En bouche, wow, douceur, peu de levure belges,épices, malt, houblon et emrtume en finale. Excellente.

Pours a deep hazy orange with a thick white cloud like head. Aroma of hops, slight funky Brett notes. Taste follows, dry and hoppy, nice Brett characteristics easy to drink yet crazy complex. This might be my favorite Trappist beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Not like most Belgians you drink. Hoppy and dry!  Aromas of sour apple, asian pear and interestingly enough, urine but not in a bad way....clove notes hit the palette; excellent mouthfeel. ...almost a little spicy...the most extraordinary fluffy, pillowy cavernous head ever to grace a glass!  Light and cloudy like a boggy day in Scotland...no Belgian tastes like this.  Amazing complexity and ultra dry.  Could easily incorporate this beer in my daily drinking routine.  Hell yeah; cherish the uniqueness and craftsmanship that goes into this truly remarkable classic!
29/02/2012 Fresh example, very little Brett influence besides the loud pop and foam. Superb pale ale.
Heerlijke bittere smaak. Alcohol warmte aanwezig ondanks de slechts 6.2%. Mooie grote kop. De toegepastedryhopping proef je. Heerlijk Bier

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2013 Specifieke smaak van de orvalgist en hoppig aroma. Bittere nadronk. Romige schuimkraag
#rerate gent dit keer een zeer jonge orval, deze is zeer kruidig/peperig
UPDATED: OCT 25, 2012 Had this one before, but it was a fresh bottle. I didnt get it. This bottle is two and a half years old and really has some nice Brett complexity.

Bottled,very unique with a required taste which can be a bit too much for some people.. I happened to like it the first time I tried it,was a bit shocking but very interesting and like nothing else Ive tried before...Pours golden orange with a puffy off white head.The aroma is pretty hoppy,spicy and complex. with flavors of cob-webs,basement,mothballs,cough drops,perfume,alcohol with a dry-bitter finish..

This rating is for a 1.5 year old bottle that I found at the back of the cellar. Never could have held it up for that long otherwise! :) Pours golden like no others it has a small funk component in the aroma that is a lot less intense than I remember it being. Well carbonated (look at that head!) and easy drinking. Taste is where the age (?) did the most. It still felt dry (like your regular Orval) but it had a lot less of the funk so an honey-like flavor came through. Quite enjoyable at this age so I will most likely age a few and try to space out my tastings to every year or so, Im sure it will be worthwhile!

Hazy orange with a big white head. Notes of banana, spice, clove, candi sugar, wood and orange zest on the nose. Taste is dry, yeasty and even a little sour with very little of the fruit/spices in the aroma or any sweetness  discernible . Mouthfeel is very lively, finish is bitter and zesty with underpinnings of dried fruit. Very different to the other Belgian Ales Ive tried. Interesting, but not my favourite.
Malgrado i 99/100 non mi fa impazzire....per me molto sopravvalutata...a parte un naso particolare in bocca non mi dice granchè......

330ml bottle. Hazy, dark orangey golden colour with huge, firm, frothy, moderately lacing, off-white head. Sweet, caramel malty aroma, minimally spicy and herbal, fruity hints. Taste is dry and slightly sourish, grassy, herbal. 
Has almost no resemblance to the other Trappist Ales, is by far the worst of them all in taste, hence absolutely overrated in my opinion. Try to understand the enthusiasm about it for over 20 years now but still cant take part - it simply doesnt match my taste.
Two finger head, mostly diminishing, active carbonation, light brown amber, small bubbles white, sweet aroma, malty body.
great beer.....few speeches and glass ready!!!!! skal.......................!!!!
beautiful head, effervescent, color of honey. Fruit, wood odors,  complex flavor of bittersweet fruit and a long finish.

perfection in a bottle... not much point describing Orval on here, surely everyone who reads this site is familiar with it!  Very different at different ages, at two years old for example has far more Brett flavour than fresh orval does.

Aroma elegante y fino. Principalmente notas herbales y florales en virtud del lupulo utilizado. de Igual forma se perciben caracteristicas frutales.

A la vista, cerveza de cuerpo redondo, color naranja con ligera turbiedad. Carbonatación media, corona de espuma abundante y de larga retención.

En boca destacan principalmente notas cremosas, amargas y secas.

Al paladar, diferente que el resto de cervezas trapenses. Se dejan sentir ciertas notas citricas. Posteriormente destacan caracteristicas ligeramente acidas, dejando paso a un amargor agradable y un final seco y de mediana intensidad.

En general una cerveza trapense diferente, pero buena. La cual se debe disfrutar ligeramente a una temperatura ambiente, y la cual para alcanzar su gran esplendor, se debe tomar poco a poco.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2016 ...a bunch of bottles later: this is a beer that really changes with time. Good as fresh, bit dried hops-y dryish belgy, but gets more farmy, horseblankety intense after a while .. month, years.. Thoroughly enjoyable all the way though.

Bottle.Orange, hazy. With a good deal of foaming and yeast layer. Nose is malty, bready, with green hop leaves and tones usually found in sour beers (some hay).  Body has some tart, green hops, medium body. Lots of malts, Long finish, dry. Nice brew, different. Not your normal double/tripel/etc trappist, but a rather (continental-) hoppy, with a lot of complexity and gueze-like tones. Feels like a geuze that hasnt soured yet.

Bottle.  Best before 07. DEC 2016 
caramel, roasty, herbs, banana, leaves, brown, hazy, white foam, rocky head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, creamy, sticky, soft carbonation, long finish,

bottled  9/12/2010 drank 31/8/2012
pours darkly amber, smells unexpectedly chemicaly-kind of sweetness, . tastes quite the same , sweet ( caramel, candi, sugar ) definetly better than other trappists ( witch im not the greatest fan of ) but not shocking. drinkable and more complex than the average. 
downside is that the cap looks realy , realy filthy ! the inside is covered with a very thick layer of brown sticky stuff, and so is the bottle ...

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 Bottle 33cl @ cafe pelikaan in Antwerp, foamy white medium head, dark golden chestnut not clear body, sweet fruity banana smell, medium to high sparkling tinteling carbanation, hoppy pineapple taste, hints of koriander and a nice sharp bitter finish

A- beautiful orange bit of haze and the most wonderful frothy pillowy head that you can imagine that VERY SLOWLY turns to some really nice lacing.

S - Brett, sweet sour fruit, funk and a small shovel full of dirt.

T - Very well balanced tart and hoppy to begin with. Gets down to EARTH towards the end. Musty, earthy with a hint of funk and a clean aftertaste.

M -good carbonation, goes down smooth but not exceptionally, I like to let it sit for a moment adn find it a better drink after resting .

D - I could drink this all night. the bitterness and funk and Earthiness all, remarkably, leave the palate fresh and clean for the next taste of what ever you are having.
FANTASTIC!

Orange-amber body.   Large white fluffy head.  Spotty lacing.  Nose is full of wet hay, orange peel, Belgian yeast,and  light brett,  Flavor mirrors the nose but adds a bit of intensity.  At a year out, there is a mild funk developing.  Medium bodied, assertive carbonation, mellow funky, zesty finish.  A true classic.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a tulip.

A: Pours a dark golden color with strong yeast haze and a translucent shine near the bottom of the glass. The head is a two finger offwhite color that settles down to one finger, leaving thick clumps of lacing on the glass.

S: Subtle spicing (such as ginger and coriander), along with a bright malt background and pleasant barnyard funk. A little weak, but a solid scent otherwise.

T: Quite bready, but not sweet at all...in fact, its a little bitter, especially in conjunction with its predominant funk note. Exhales give off light fruit esters such as pear. A bit of an acquired taste; the first sip is slightly off, but once the impressive complexity and light accumulating funk do their work on the tongue, it becomes quite balanced and nicely nuanced.

M: Somewhat heavy, with a finishing dry astringency. Its not as carbonated (or as bloated) as some Belgians are, giving it nice drinkability.

O: Great beer, but this stuff really needs to be paired with some good cheese to allow its character to truly come through. This really isnt for everyone, so keep that in mind - it gets high marks more for its craftsmanship than anything.

Bottle @ home.... It pours murky dark golden with a large long lasting tan head.....The aroma is fruity, spicy and citrus...The flavor is very Belgian yeasty, hoppy, sour sweet with a bitter finish......

11.2oz bottle to Orval trappist glass, bottled 6/10/2011. Tasted at 52 degrees F. Pours hazy orange with high carbonation. Nice off white head about an inch in the orval glass leaving laces as it slowly fades. Nose is oranges, citrus, fruity pineapple, some sourness, not as assertive of a nose as i expected. Medium bodied. Mouthfeel is full of carbonaton foaming on the palate. Not too bitter but very sour with a fruity pineapple long dry finish. Every aspect of this beer is complex with flavors and aromas that are new to me; hard to identify, but very enjoyable. Very impressed and i have been waiting to try orval for sometime now!
Aroma of lemongrass, spice, grain. Medium bodied, high carbonation. Flavors replicate the nose. Medium bitterness. Finishes dry and bitter. Not insanely complex, but a damn fine, tasty beer.
Pours dark amber with medium off white head.  Alcohol and cirtus aroma.  High carbonation and foamy, creamy mouthfeel.  Soft citrus taste and medium bitterness.
Bottle from Stilebridge, Maidstone. A complete and utter classic beer. My only criticism is slightly too much co2. Sweet and delicious, like a top Belgium beer should be.
2012.08.20 - 33Cl - Lovely beer, well-known to the most of us - the ship of commercialization arises at the horizon, alas.

Light citrus hop smell with some pine and yeast. Two finger head, beautiful lacing. Sweet citrus dry hop taste with yeast finish. Lightly bitter aftertaste. A little frothy carbonated mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Smell: Spicy, fresh yeast, tart fruit.

Mouthfeel: Creamy, medium, lively carbonation, foamy head that lasts.

Taste: Gently tart fruit, citrusy. Bitter.

Finish: Dry, hoppy, bitterness that fades very slowly.

Overall: Great beer, hoppy and bitter, not sweet at all.

Orange pour w/ lasting soapy, white head. Inviting smells of orange, a little bit of spice & that wonderful Belgian/ Brett yeast funk. Barnyard, slight sourness, tangerine, hop bitterness. Complex flavors, including more citrus, some allspice, pine. I get different notes on each sip. Almost creamy mouthfeel, but still somehow light & refreshing. Very dry finish. As close to the perfect beer as I can imagine!

Bottled on 20/02/2008, best before 20/02/3013B. Four and a half years old. Little 11.2 oz bottle into a tulip glass at cellar temperature.

A - Dark clear amber body. Massive fluffy head with a rather ugly light tan color. Massive bubbles that took a nice swirling to clean up. Tons of lacing and retention.

S - Perfect. This is the definitive Brettanomyces aroma. A barnyard funk that is pleasant but approaching offensive, light grass and lemons, just a touch of biscuity crackers and ripe apples on the finish. Some warming alcohol as well.

T - Funky hay, rich cheese, lemon grass, pears, crackers, chalk, sweet caramel and a subtle minty herbal finish. This beer is just so complex. Im just getting so many odd and unique flavors that Im struggling to pinpoint them all. Yet it comes off as well balanced and simple. Its just...Orval. Ive never had a beer taste like this. Mouth feel is effervescent and well carbonated.

O - Theres nothing quite like this beer. Matilda and Rayon Vert may be homages to this beer, but they just cant compete with the insane complexity and high drinkability of this. Age has also turned this into a brett bomb. World class for sure.
Pours a hazy gold color.  Aroma is strange, a bit sour and fruity.  Taste is nice but different, mild sweetness and some tartness.  Really a unique beer that has a dry finish.

Unique beer, very complex, hard to point any special trait above others. Brown colour, plenty of foam which stays a long time. Quite sour and citric, very dry. This one needs to be appreciated slowly and meticulously.

Ma bière préférée, mon graal. Complexe, une palette très large daromes, légére. Une belle mousse onctueuse, riche. Une couleur ambrée, amertume très prononcée.
Une bière à découvrir absolument.
Interesting aroma, nice amber color, delicious taste worthy of its place among trappist beers, however leaves a little lacking at the finish. Still a dynamite brew.

Hazy amber color.  Huge 4 finger head.  Nice funky aroma.  The beer is dominated by hop bitterness and barnyard funk.  Finishes bone dry.  Slight flavor from the brett.  Very good balance, very good beer.
Hazy amber with a large white head. Complex beer that have a balanced mix of malty sweetness, a bretty tartness and a bitter ending. This results in a full bodied yet refreshing brew.
a great beer for everyone wife loved it. it was a great all around beer simple but it has enough hints of spices to keep you interested and wanting more.

Un archétype de la bière. Une référence absolue, ou encore ce que lon pourrait appeler une
mesure étalon.
En matière de bière trappiste pourtant, elle est tout à fait particulière en terme de goût et elle
occupe une niche à part entière.
Mais elle est réellement trappiste dans lapproche qualitative, dans certains aspects visuels
tels que la mousse dite « à cratères », cest-à-dire une mousse épaisse qui donne un peu
la consistance du blanc doeuf battu, et dans laquelle se forme des creux en cercles qui 
ressemblent à des cratères de volcan.
Volcanique est un qualificatif qui conviendrait bien à cette bière, parce quelle est très vivante
à louverture de la bouteille, et dans le verre (celui de la maison bien entendu) elle présente 
une vivacité énorme avec des bulles très rapides et qui se comptent par milliers : impressionnant...
Ses arômes très typés sont également dune générosité extraordinaire.
Ils embaument vraiment la pièce où vous dégustez, et ils sont dune typicité phénoménale.
Comme je le dis personnellement, cette bière sent lécurie. Dans le bon sens du terme 
évidemment, à savoir la paille fraîche et une certaine odeur de cuir que le cheval dégage.
Une odeur également avec une certaine âcreté dans des proportions très agréables, et une
pointe dacidité, du type ammoniaque mais en proportions pharmaceutiques.
De la pharmacie du Bon Dieu, sans aucun doute, puisque les saints pères se sont penchés sur 
son baptême. Et ils prennent soin du divin enfant avec une patience et une rigueur énorme.
Avec un soin de bénédictin et une qualité dans les ingrédients, qui relèvent presque de la 
charité chrétienne, tant cette bière est naturelle et pure.
Je lai choisie soigneusement pour ma 100ème critique parce que nulle autre bière ne peut
être considérée comme une référence de ce type.
Pour moi, bien que située en Gaume, elle fait partie des fôrets de la Semois, avec le cerf
qui les parcourt et qui brame quant vient lautomne.
Elle est vraiment une perle dans lart du brassage, et une valeur à nulle autre pareille dans 
la qualité de conception et du goût.
Je ne souhaite pas détailler ce goût, tant il est riche et complexe. Il doit réellement entrer 
en vous par la dégustation que vous faites de cette bière, et il constituera nécessairement
une référence qui vous permettra dévaluer dautres bières.
Donc avis à ceux qui lont goûtée un peu distraitement : il faut y revenir, mettre tous ses 
sens en action, tous les compteurs sur « on », et on aura immanquablement une base de
travail et dévaluation pour les bières dans leur ensemble.
Une bière hors catégorie donc, comme certains cols du tour de France, qui est une valeur
en soi, et pour laquelle les chiffres ne veulent rien dire.
Si vous en voulez un, alors disons le nombre détoiles quil y a dans le ciel....

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2014 Pours copper with a very nice pillowy white head, aroma is floral hops and slightly sour. Taste was kinda dissappointing, pretty plain, floral hops, some malt, kind of bland honestly. Meh

 Re rate. Maybe my first try of this was young. i bought another bottle, now 14 months old. Same pour, gigantic pillowy head. Very bretty aroma, nice. Taste is also heavy with brett, some funky hay, a bit grassy, nice dry finish. Im gonna go grab the other 4 bottles now.
33cL bottle.  Good earthy aroma.  Copper color, opaque, beautiful stable head.  One of the more bitter trappists, not overly malty or sweet, but I like it for what it is: unapologetic and delicious.

Press pale amber with loose white head. Aroma is slightly sour, died flowers and grapes. Flavor is almond, a dry floral yet somehow white wine-y vein through, with a powdery dry finish. Pleasing light carbonation, very good subtle fruity notes in the finish - very nice, if a little too dry for my tastes.
0.33l bottle. Orange body, nice beige head. Bready, grassy, caramelly aroma. Very intense taste with caramel and a lot of grassy hops. There is some yeastyness as well. Awesome beer.
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2013 Good aroma, appearance, taste and palate. Decent, memorable. Rated from the bottle.

From bottle to chalice.  Yeasty, hoppy aroma.  Doughy, grassy, sprucy, cheesy,  hide, boozy, zesty.  More aroma comes out after the head fades away. Hazy copper-orange color. Taste is bitter, some sweet and sour towards the end, but not much.  Overall, not really what Im into.  It is quality, but not my style.

Pours a slightly hazy orangish amber with a two finger clean white head. Abundant lacing visible along the sides of the glass. Smells of citrus and flora with a hint of pine. Seems to be a medium-bodied brew at first but finishes light, very dry, crisp, and clean. Tart citrus rind and grass dominate with dry, fruit tones throughout. Fantastic dry Belgian pale ale. Definitely one of the very best available.
UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 It has a really shocking appearance with that grey colour, but the flavour is more commonplace I supposed

Bottle from local Sake Marche. Aromas of yeast, soured grapes, mowed hay, a tingling ripe fruit. Burnished orange-gold color and a constant 1-2cm white head. Tangy, smooth, dry, tsukemono (pickled vegetables) flavors, with a strong final hit of bitterness that rises and falls slowly. Crisp, dry, and very refreshing. No other beer quite like it. Had it many times before and, although its not really my favorite, one cant discount the real craft that goes into making it.

Bottle to oversized snifter.  Looks good; a hazy brownish-orange with lots of off-white head.  Smells pretty good; both hoppy and malty with a noticeable presence of Belgian yeast and hints of booziness.  Tastes solid; hops with a good body and great finish.  I love the dryness.  Very good beer!

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a very full white head. The nose is sweet and welcoming - honey, some melon notes, raisins and sultanas, a little honey. I could sit and sniff this all day, but eventually in the mouth Im getting sultanas and raisin again, more honey, resins and pine notes. The mouthfeel is a little slick, but the finish is erring on dry. Theres a hoppy bite to this imparting some grapefruit and zest. Really interesting drink and I could sit and play with it all day.

33cl bottle. Clear, orange colour. Big white tiny bubble head. Aromas of yeast, citrus and some earthy notes. Taste is fruity, citrus like, a bit tart with a bitter finish. Very well balanced. Medium body.

330 ml bottle, best before date 6/10/2016, from Whole Foods Market, SoMa, San Francisco, CA.. The legendary Orval, at last. Pours a bright hazy orange color with a huge white frothy head that lasts for long. Aroma is fruity and yeasty with notes of red apples, strudel, light citrus and Sauvignon Blanc grapes. Taste is slightly tart which comes as a surprise. Apple and citrus come as the most obvious flavors. Its similar to a Demi-Sec Sparkling Wine. Intensely tasting but smooth highly drinkable Trappist. Almost no carbonation. Its a good, refined Belgian Ale but its maybe a little overhyped.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2013 
Pours hazy dark orange with a long-lived, creamy and beautiful off-white head. The nose is a complex interaction of notes of citrus, flowers, grass, spices, toasty bread and a little funk. Flavors include bitter orange and flowers up front, followed by taosted white bread and biscuit notes; a little funky yeast coming through. Tastes a bit roastier than the nose would suggest. This is a bone dry, gently bitter and quite tannic beer. The carbonation is medium-high and the texture is very smooth. The finish is solid; very dry, bitter and tannic. Unique and very intriguing.

Hoppier than many other Trappistes and consequently not as high up my list. Normally there are plenty of black fruit and liquorice notes to offset that but the bottle I had recently was chilled too much meaning that the other flavours were lost, leaving only the bitterness lingering.

Pours a hazy, light-orange colour that looks a lot like shanty with a frothy head. The aroma is of light orange and citrus hops with some earthy undertones. The taste is very dry and slightly fruity - again, somewhat orangey - with slightly sweet notes towards the back of my mouth. It also tastes fairly yeasty in a not particularly pleasant way. Not the worst beer Ive ever had, but it tastes strikingly similar to the orange-and-honey "wine" that Ive made a few times using bread yeast - a little too similar...

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2015 Limpido color the discretamente effervescente, con un velo cremoso di schiuma beige chiaro piuttosto persistente. Aroma fresco ed erbaceo arricchito da sentori di spezie, mela verde e lieviti belgi. Gusto secco e amarognolo, maggiormente luppolato nel finale che presenta anche lievissime note tostate. Corpo medio-lieve, struttura setosa ed effervescenza vivace la rendono una birra rinfrescante perfetta per ogni stagione; abv non percepibile, complessa ma beverina. Birra dal carattere variabile, bevuta più volte offre sempre qualche sfumatura differente, in ogni caso memorabile!
pours a brilliant gold with a foamy white head.fruity ethanol on the nose but the flavour is earthy, floral and fruity with a solid malt backbone with hints of bread and toffee. pretty damn good

11.2oz bottle. Huge foamy off-white head. Mostly hazy amber color, with some continuously ascending bubbles on the inside. Good lace. Very nice lighter carbonation, crisp with a very smooth texture, all at the same time. Dry finish. Nice toasty malt aroma, with good earthy hops, wheat, spices - an interesting, complex, but balanced aroma. Nice light bitter taste. Very nice aftertaste. Awesome brew. Bottle labeled at about 6.8% ABV.

Color orange yellow. Aroma esteri oils (from the hops), yeast. Taste nice balance, refreshing. Palate dry, some bitter. Overall very nice trappist, very good aperitif
Appearance is beautiful. I was very excited to drink this beer. Great aroma, aftertaste. However, left a weird texture in my mouth that is hard to get past.

I don't like writing descriptions! I'm suppose to be drinking but instead I'm required to write a little a somin.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is citrus hoppy with also excotic fruits: at least bit mango. Geen apple also. Has also slightly dark toffee. Lots of nuances. Good aroma. Hazy amber with big frothy head that is long and leaves lacing. Bit small bubbling going on in glass. Appearance cant get better than this.  Taste is abundant  and rich in nuances. Aromatic spices, dark fruits and green apple, sweet toffee, yeast. Bit tart. Nice long finish. Palate has volume and creamy softness but also balancing  fizzy carbonation. This has lots to analyze this beer. Strong personality. Lots to like. Perfect appearance. Delicately nuanced flavors and aromas. One to savor. True classic.
Heel lekker bier.   Zeker de moeite

Poured from 330mL bottle into goblet. Pours hazy amber with big frothy head that settles to thick film and lots of lacing. Aromas are intriguing with fruity ester like fig, green apple, and orange mixed with some phenols. Flavors include a tart citrus mixed with dry hops and spicy phenols. Mouthfeel is medium, a bit light than expected with high carbonation and a dry finish. Overall its a good trappist brew, but not my favorite. 

--- Cheers
Easier going than most of the other trappists, lighter aftertaste and body. Quite good.

Bottle.  Amber color.  Big three finger head.  Aroma is spicy with some orange peel and coriander.  Light sweetness, light bitter.  Dry finish.  Ave carbonation.  Creamy texture.  Slight bitter finish.  This has a lighter feel than most Trappists.  Very much enjoyed.
330ml bottle. Hazy orange color. Medium off-white head, stays. Citrus, grassy, hops in aroma. Medium carbonation. Mild bitter, citrus, hops, faint yeasty caramel in flavor.

I enjoyed this beer on a 92 degree afternoon in Gubbio, Umbria, Italy.  The color was a lovely orange and the flavor was slightly bitter.  The price, 4 euros, was right.  I would order Orval again, if I find it.  This is not sold in other places I have been.

Bottled 05/08/2009

A: Hazy burnt orange color. The head is massive and has many different sized bubbles surrounding a meringue crest. Awesome lacing. Also, there is a notable effervescence that emanates from the bottom center of the glass and resembles an underwater volcano.

S: Belgian yeast and a slight funky that smells nice. Also getting a bit of an outdoor, grass, farm aroma.

T: Interesting to say the least. I dont think one could ever describe Orval as dull or uninteresting. Immediately upon tasting, I get a funky, dry tartness that remains prevalent throughout. Its not the type of funk found in a wild ale, lambic or gueuze. What a cool brew. There is a slight alcohol note in the finish, but its subtle enough and fits in nicely.

M: Funky Belgian yeast, good carbonation, slight alcohol in the finish. Pretty good feel.

D: Its unique, tasty, and a beer to sniff, sip, and savor. A must try for any beer aficionado.

I fell in love. With a beer. And I didnt even see it coming.

Its just a perfect blend of all things good with a beer.
Punt damargor ideal, molt fàcil de beure i a sobre no cansa. Es pot demanar algo més?

트라피스트 맥주 시작하시는 분들께 추천드립니다. 낮설지 않은 향과 맛.
하지만 트라피스트임 강하게 주장하는 깊은 맛이 정말 대단한 맥주입니다. 마치 시골집의 아주 오래된 조선간장의 깊은 향을 맡는듯한 느낌이랄까요. 추천합니다!

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange-straw color, with a foamy head.  Aroma is yeasty and bready, with some hints of spice.  The flavor is quite dry, as advertised.  Some hints of citrus and spice.  The hops contribute more bitterness than flavor.  Yeasty and a touch bready.  Well-balanced, but ultimately not too interesting - probably the weakest of the Trappist beers.

Poured from 330 ml bottle at Yangshuo Village Retreat in Yangshuo, China.  Bottled "20/07/2010.". 6.2% ABV

Head filled entire glass.  When it settled a bit it revealed a slightly hazy golden amber liquid with to tons of foamy lacing. 

Aroma of pear and apple, herbs and light yeast. 

Taste of funky yeast with strong citric notes and a slight touch of light sweet caramel.  Slightly sour with a somewhat bitter aftertaste. 

Medium body and light carbonation. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy orange amber with a persistent tan head. The aroma is floral while the taste is citrus in nature. The mouthfeel is medium with a nice balanced of carbonation on the backside.  The hops give it an enjoyable crispness. Will buy and drink again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

330 ml Orval bottle. Pours orange with a medium head of large bubbles.  Aromas of bread, leather, citrus, and cloves. Distinctive grassy/yeasty flavor with cereal and  champagne notes. Lots of carbonation and very dry finish.
Pours a cloudy amber with a large white head and fair lacing.  Aromas of yeast and citrus. Typical body for a Trappist, and a little dry as advertised.  Light flavor with just a hint of hops.
Butterscotch. Strong aroma hit the back to your through. Good taste for a beer supposed to be served warm 12-14C

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2012 From cask in a bar in Liege. Smells of citrus, pine, belgian yeast and some peach. The taste reveals more belgian yeast taste, but also hints of bread and hay. Its medium bodied and quite easy to drink. A very good beer that I would easily buy again if I got the opportunity.
Very good beer, very different than any other beer. This is still brewed in the pure tradition of the priests. In addition the brewery is open to the public
Hops dominate everything (in a good way) with aroma and bitterness, Some cereal aroma. In the complex it is really nice, for my taste lacks a bit of body and some more sweetness.
Maybe we have problème with his genre, but this is a great beer that se cannot find in the markt.
UPDATED: APR 2, 2015 Tasted it during the visit at the brewery. Wasn´t impressed at the time but after I got used to the taste later on.
Incredibly big head on this one. Typical nice belgian beer with that balanced taste between slightly sweet and bitter. Hazy and natural.

Poured from an 11.2 oz. uniquely shaped bottle into an Orval chalice.

Pours a slightly hazy orangish amber with a two finger clean white head. Abundant lacing visible along the sides of the glass. Smells of citrus and flora with a hint of pine. Seems to be a medium-bodied brew at first but finishes light, very dry, crisp, and clean. Tart citrus rind and grass dominate with dry, fruit tones throughout.  Fantastic dry Belgian pale ale. Definitely one of the very best available.

Light aroma mostly of grains and yeast with a hint of citrus or green apple. Pours a hazy light gold with a light low head. Flavor is bitter for the style with some sweetness. Light bodied with lets the alcohol bite. Finishes sharp and a tad bitter.

Havent had this in a while and Ill throw in a rating for it. Good-looking pour into Maudite glass. Lightish gold. This is probably the most accessible of the Trappist beers. Its not as aggressive in palate, not as funky (but has enough), and not as strong. I love all of the Trappist beers, and this one is no different. I also like that Orval has just the one beer available. Plus, the bowling-pin bottle is cool. (Worth another more detailed review at some point; this one is from memory from a shared bottle yesterday.)

Bottle from Systembolaget, Sweden.
Dry and spicy aroma with a hint of hops.
High and white head that slowly goes down and leaves a thinn lace. Clowdy orange color. Malty and hoppy taste with dry finnish.

A - Beautiful bright orange. Dark Carmel look. 2 singer dark white head. Nice creamy bubbles. Incredible head Lacing

S - rich caramel. French oak. Almonds. Light cheese and a barnyard horse smell

T - Whoa. This is no normal Orval. Incredible discreet bitterness. Like a very dry champagne taste. Grape skins. Minor bit of grapefruit hop character. White wine and dried raisins. 

M - 100% carbonation. Incredible dry fleeting finish. Hoppy bitter finish

O  Ive never enjoyed fresh Orval. With only one year on it, the taste is incredible. One of the best Trappist beers Ive had. Delicious. 4.5/5.

Slightly cloudy light orange pour with huge white head. Aroma of yeast and a bit of hops. Taste of yeast and a bitter hop finish. High carbonation and very dry. Very one dimensional. This has to be the most overrrated beer I have tried to date. Dont understand the high rating except people might be inflating their rating because it is a trappist beer. There are thousands better including all of the other trappist beers. No need to try again.

330ml bottle, bottled 30/12/2009. Pours a deep, cloudy amber color with a huge white head. Aroma is yeasty, funky, citrus, lemon.  Medium on the palate with Lively carbonation. Flavor is sweet, bready, yeasty, a little funky, with a tart, Brett finish. Delicious.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2013 Very nice and unique beer. Beautiful orange colour and white foam. Very bitter and dry.

330ml bottle. Russet shade with a big, fluffy trappist-style head. Complex aroma of earthiness, spices, raisins, orange peel and malts. Doesnt jump out of the glass but still demands attention. On the tongue it has some of the classic creaminess of a quad without the heavy mouthfeel, and Belgian yeast is very prominent, particularly as it finishes. A very intriguing beer, hard to categorise and difficult to decipher at times, but it did enough to win me over.

(Abfülldatum: 19.10.2010, Testdatum: 28.11.2010, MHD: 19.10.2015) Die Schaumkrone hält recht gut fällt aber ungleichmäßig ineinander. Es riecht sehr herb fast wie ein IPA dazu leicht nach frischer Limone! Geschmacklich ist es im Antrunk sehr herb und frisch-grasig. Später ist die herbe nicht mehr ganz so intensiv (immernoch weit überdurchschnittlich) und das grasige verfliegt fast vollständig, dafür kommt eine mild säuerliche fruchtige-citrusnote zum Vorschein, so das es herb und leicht säuerlich schmeckt. Im Nachgeschmack schmeckt es immernoch herb und die anderen Aromen sind kaum noch zu schmecken da sie übertünscht werden. Ein leckeres frisches Bier das schon fast an ein IPA erinnert. Ich muss es nochmal in einer älteren Version testen, blöderweise kommt man an ältere Biere schlechter ran als an frische! Fazit: Sehr Lecker!
	
Test vom 28.11.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 12,13,12,12,12,12 - 12,15
Malty, dry, hazy beer with a wild white head. Fizzy and dry. Taste like bread, farm and wood as well. Delicious in the sunshine.
Bottle. light in color, slightly cloudy, and has a large, foamy head. There is a complex aroma of leather, spice, and many other earthy components

Bottle from Purvis Cellars in a tulip glass. Thick, pillowy, two finger head with great retention. Rich golden orange colour.  Malty aroma. Malt notes up front carry over from the aroma, a slightly bitter middle, and a creamy aftertaste. Lively carbonation and a slightly dry feel.

330ml bottle. Aroma is very fruity, light cherry aroma. Appearance is dark cloudy amber with a small white head. Taste is sour and light bitter. A medium carbonation, a light bitter mouthfeel and a long sweet finish. Overall a very good Trappist beer.
golden with white head. tight longlasting fizz. smells of metal and bubblegum. taste of citron, lightly sour. fine beer
Orange. Intense nose of yeast, herb, spices. Bitter, dry. Incredible drinkability. Slightly acid, pleasant and refreshing. A masterpiece.

Good. The nose is a little barny with notes of fruit and light floral hops. The beer is a unique copper orange with a lasting white head. The taste is fruity with biscuitike malts and floral hops and some underlying barnyard notes. The beer is very dry and crisp.

Born on 8/18/11. Cannot believe I have not rated this-I bought 1/2 case at the brewery back in 98 for $13 (plus glass!!) and havent looked back. Pours with a big fluffy head and dark copper hazy. Nose is full of brett yeast with a nice spunkiness. Taste of a bit of honey, a little spiciness, with a bitter sharpness and above-average carbonation to keep your mind on things. Just an absolutely enjoyable beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 2009 bottle. Pours a bright amber with tan head that falls to blanket. Smell is interesting and complex, cherry, sour notes, yeast. Taste is slight sour, tart fruit, some band aid sneaking in there. This 3 year old bottle isnt as good as some of the 1/2 year old bottles.....hmmm

Did this as a bit of an experiment - aged for 5 years.
Poured in to a Duvel tulip glass, poured a dark orange - a little sediment crept in. Head was thick but dissipated fairly quickly - good carbonation.
Aroma is very sour, hits you as soon as you open the bottle.
Tastes sour yet earthy, alcohol a little more prominent than a younger version. Sweetness of the malt has mellowed but still quite dry.
Very interesting stuff.

Ahhh the Belgian ale trappist,One of my fav trappistes (havent had them all yet sadly enough). Nice dark transparent color with a fruity aroma, same goes for the taste. fruity with hints of citrus. very nice a beer you can drink all year round
Very complex beer. Serious aroma of mezcal. Flavor is remnant of nicely aged tequila and orange pez.

Cloudy dark orange pour with a nice head that lingers a while.  Fruity aroma, citrus, berries, and raisins.  Taste is fairly sweet, fruity, yeasty, very dry and very carbonated.  It has an acidic finish that Im not a fan of.  An interesting beer, almost like champagne in a way.  A good belgian ale but not my favorite.

Oct 2006 (and I still have those two for later!): I have two more in my garage, so this review may change after a further tasting, but I was not impressed at all with this bottle. The worst beer a monk has ever made for me! 

Slightly cloudy, an off orange colour. 

Smell was of sour apples, no head, just a wisp, which went almost straight away. 

Tasted of the same sour apples as the smell, sharp and fizzy. 

If it had been a blind tasting, I would have said it was a rough Cider or a really poor Geuze.

The best Belgian Ale I ever had, and for sure the best out of the 7 trappiste ones. Amazing crispy aromas and a great appearance in its glass. 
Very nice crispy taste, full of yeast and a very good hoppy aftertaste.

Bottle, as pictured.  First time having this, actually, AFAIK.  Not really impressed with it, to be honest.  Has an almost acidic feel to it, surprisingly....not sure if thats intended or this is a below-average bottle.  Smells slightly spicy and peppery,  Despite the acidic taste, has a sweet aftertaste and is very light in the mouthfeel.

Love the bottle and fish logo...feel more dignified just drinking something that came out of that bottle. Copper pour. Earthy aroma - yeast, malts, grass. Near perfect Belgian yeast flavoring. Malts swirling with a touch of citrus and spices/funk at the end. Medium carbonation and body that makes it a nice sipper. Great trappist (I mean, is there a bad one?), great classic beer.

Bottle, 2007 vintage, 04/28/2012.  Pours amber copper, hazy, pillowy one-finger head with great retention.  Light aroma of tropical fruit with yeasty barnyard musk, dry peppery malts underneath.  Taste carries the same pleasant citrus/tropical notes, light sweetness leading to bready dough, moderate bitterness and brett in the finish.  Sparkling palate, dry finish, easy drinking.  Amazing beer, what more can be said that hasnt been already.

Bottle at Tilt, Oslo. Pours a fromage of a white head. Jewelish color. Aroma of sugar, yeast, leaves and woodwork. Due to flavour it is more of flower and yeast. Sweet!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33cl bottle from ABCBeers.
Decent white head.  Slightly hazy blond pour.  Nice bitterness.  Yummy!
Bottle at eulogy in PHL, not the first time tried, first time rated. Amber color, 2 finger slight off white head. Sweet nose, medium bodied. The monks have figured this one.
Tipica trappista. Il gusto inizialmente pare vinoso ma subito si dissolve nellaroma di cereali e nel sapore fortemente luppolato. Schiuma cremosa e abbastanza persistente.

Have I really waited this long to rate Orval? Man. Bottle pours hazy, light brown with a huge, four-finger white head. Dissipates rather quickly, leaves some nice foam floating around on top. Nose is subdued candy sugar, yeasty, biscuity, with a bitter hop note. Soft, lively carbonation. Effervescent mouthfeel, with an herbal earthiness, just-dug-up fruit. Tart, fleeting finish.

2012.04.23 - 11.2oz bottle in tulip glass.  Pours an orange copper.  Very thick foamy head persists and breaks in clumps.  Aroma has a Belgian character for sure.  Taste is quite smooth.  Almost reminds me a bit of Allagash Four but it's not as sweet.  As others noted, it's a dry slightly bitter finish.  And that may be to its detriment.  Can't find anything really wrong, it's well done... Just probably wouldn't drink a lot of it.  A bit more alcohol warmth than 6.9% would imply.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2014 330ml bottle from Bierzwerg. Flavour is dark amber colour with 4 finger head. Aroma is yeast, really fruity. Flavour is yeast, fruit. Superb!
Retest: 3 years old bottle. Still tasty but bit different compared to fresh bottle.
Ottima birra dabazia, anni fa da profano della birra mi sembrava una medicina tanto è particolare e complesso il suo gusto! Ora posso dire che è una grande birra!

11.2 oz bottle pours amber with a white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and yeast.  Taste is sweet up front with a dry finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour deep hazy deep orange, with an average white head. 
Aroma of Dark fruits, belgian  yeastie dough and hay, caramel and finkieness. 
Taste is rather sweet, with some Dark fruit niceness going on. 
Medium body, with a slight fizzy carb
En belgisk liten pärla. Lite metalisk i smaken. Karamell, frukt, grapebeska, örter.

Classic Trappist Beer !  Love this one.... pours a golden orange color with great aromas of sweet malts, pear, floral grassy hops and a bit of funky earth.  The flavors bounce as well with a good carbonation that sends the crisp bitter hop flavors into round balanced mouthfeel with rich dried plum, toffee and herbal notes that hit the mid palate... then fall into a swift finish.

Looks gorgeous - ruby/pear with frothy dollops of off-white goodness. The first thing that I notice on the nose is some kind of white wine character - grapes, bitter fruits, etc. Plenty of hop presence with some estery goodness in there. Certainly is a unique tasting beer. Not quite as vibrant as I was hoping. The notes that build the aroma just arent here on the palate. This one has a year on it, so I guess this beer might just be in an awkward phase because the look and smell suggest something greater and more pronounced. Perhaps my least favorite of the Trappists, which isnt saying much at all.

Bottle pours a brownish orange. Smells tastes of orange spices yeast banana. Not bad bit dry bitter pretty good I think maybe a bit over hyped or could be really good conspired to others in the style. I will revisit this one again and see how I think about it again.

Ganska diskret doft men trevlig smak av kola och toffee. Fin fyllighet men eftersmaken är lite tunn. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours amber hazy, light beige foam head.
Smells fudge and hops.
Very similar palate and equilibrium to DUVEL but 2% ABV lighter: same bitterness, same acidity, similar aromatic profile.
Lack of length, dry short finish.

Bottle. Dark hazy amber with a huge fluffy head. Lavender. Thyme. Heather. Citrus pith and zest. Mulchy sour. Herbal bitterness. Lightly sweet in the middle but finishes bone dry. Wonderful and unique.
Appearance is a yellow with large white head. Aroma is a sweet citrusy malt. Taste is a strong citrus and grain malt. Overall a pretty good Belgian.

330 mL bottle. Pours a hazy, dark gold with a huge, off-white head and nice lacing. The aroma is toast, apples, grapefruit, earthy and grassy hops. The flavor is bitter, citrus sourness, and fruity sweetness. The palate is medium, a little syrupy, grainy, and dry. Overall, this is a very complex beer, with great aroma.

Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. (10 years old. Bottled on 3/14/02). Thanks DSG. Pours cloudy with stuff in it and minimal foam. Stinky, yeasty, murky and limestone aroma, tastes poisonously sour. A little burning, flat, heavy body. Difficult.
UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 A refreshingly unique beer. You will be hard pressed to find another brew that tastes like this one

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 (First Taste, Home, 330mL Bottle, Vintage Aug. 2011, Tulip, 6.9% ABV, Cellar Temp, 06/04/12. #36.)


Appearance (5/5): Pours a cloudy, medium honey-amber hue. Frothy, off white, three finger, lasting head with good lacing. Light sediment. Extremely attractive.

Aroma (9/10): Dominant orange and grapefruit, perfume, cinnamon, and a little black pepper; a little caramel, wood, and some yeasty notes of dough and barnyard. Very, very nice. The citric-perfume is noticeable the moment you open the bottle.

Taste (8/10): Dry aromatic citrus sums up this beer. Begins with sweet citrus and caramel, quickly turning to a moderately bitter, spicy finish. The yeast comes out at the end to give a slightly acidic feel to the finish. 

Palate (4/5): Medium body, lively carbonation, oily, then very dry texture, dry and ever so slightly astringent finish. Very smooth and enveloping mouthfeel. Even though its quite bitter, it doesnt feel harsh at all.

Overall (18/20): This is a very good, very well balanced, very sophisticated beer. Everything works together perfectly. Very unlike the other Trappist ales; dry, hoppy, relatively light body. Definitely has its own unique wow factor that i cant quite describe.

Drinkability: 3/5. Character: 5/5. Buy Again: Definitely Yes.

It doesnt get much better than this. Trying to define what makes it so special is not a light task. I just find the unique aroma so amazing. The taste is stunning and the beer works for every occasion. Truly a work of art - Ill just leave it at that.
With a crisp and hopy aroma this trappist ale pours brown with little head. It has a bitter flavor with a slick texture.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, Storo. Pours hazy amber with a white head. Malty aroma with hops, spices and yeast with some brett. Fresh and fruity with a nice dry and slightly bitter and citric finish. Quite refreshing.

Drank this one a year after bottling. Dark orange with a creamy and very durable head. Aroma is biscuity malt, yeast, a huge load of fruit (orange, apples, tropical fruit), citrusy hops, some subtle vinous-tart elements, elderflower and of course the typical brett barnyard aroma. High carbonation, flavour soft from the malt and fruitiness (lots of orange), lightly tart from the brettanomyces, with a sharp, dry, hoppy-spicy-barnyard finish. The moderately strong bitterness has also a herbal character. Impressive and different. Will have to try a shelf-aged version in some years.

Pours a cloudy amber with a HUGE head. Aromas of belgian yeast, dark fruits, and butterscotch. Tastes a bit smoky, very dry, and has a lingering bitterness. A bit fizzy on the tongue and the brettanomyces is in full effect. This is an interestingly odd concoction but it is a rather unique experience considering I dont really find anything from the aromas in the taste.

Bottle. Amber, average to large and mostly lasting head. Moderate, malty - faintly wheaty and sweetish aroma, fruitiness - some honey, herbal hoppyness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, fruitiness with light honey, herbal hoppyness. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweetish, some fruitiness, some herbal - grassy hoppyness. OK Belgian ale, but "Dont believe the hype".
Pours a cloudy, amber with small foam head. Hop & citrus flavours with a long bitter finish. Enjoyable

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Mooi dik schuim. Koperkleurig, tikje troebel. Ruikt fris, beetje rinsig, citrus, hop. Smaak is vooral drooghoppig, bitter, maar er zit ook een zuur appeltje in. Iets notigs, eiken. Droogbittere afdronk. Vrij licht bier. Doordrinker.
Quite a floral nose to this beer.  Taste is subdued compared to most belgian ales, but it is nicely hopped.  I would almost say this is a belgian ale with training wheels.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2013 This was fairly interesting. I was expecting a really strong flavor, as is common with Belgians, but ended up with something different. This beer is actually rather light on the palate. Rather hoppy for the style as well. Not too sweet. I might have to pick up another one of these and get a second tasting. Unfortunately, I might not be able to get myself to spend $5.50 on another one so soon.
Pours hazy dark orange with big white head. Aroma is hops, citrus/fruits and pine. Flavor is malts, citrus, and hops. Decent.
Bel colore dorato con schiuma molto persistente.Profumi di luppolo e miele con un po di legno e cuoio.Molto beverina e finale amaro.

Light brown, not quite amber with a thick white head, nice lace down the sides.  Damp earth and leather with some spice swimming in the background; alcohol is present but not overpowering.  Balanced taste through the middle with medium malt sweetness and even, but persistent hop assertiveness.  Dry and bitter snap at the end.  I think this beer will be different every time I drink it.
UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 Hazy orange/brown color. decent compact white head. Smell malts hops some cinnamon.. taste malts some fruits (cherry) little sweet drank at buitenlust.
Mörk orange lätt grumlig öl med ett snabbt försvinnande vitt skum. Dofter av frukt och honung. Nötter, mandelsmassa och torkad frukt i smaken en torr munkänsla. Ett mycket trevligt trappistöl.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2015 04-08-2012 / Bottle 330 ml [2011]. Appearance: Pours dark orange with a medium long lasting beige head. Aroma: Orange, slight brett, spices, yeast and fruits. Taste: Spices, yeast, fruits and a medium bitter finish that leaves the mouth dry. Overall: Very nice unique belgian ale. Refreshing and complex. 8-4-8-3-15

18-11-2012 / 3½ years old bottle. Dark golden with a medium creamy white head and nice lacing. Aroma is wonderful: strong brettanomyces, fruits and lemony notes. Taste is of lemony, brett (far less than in aroma) with a fainted bitter finish. Mouthfeel is a bit thin. Dangerously drinkable! Its impressive to see the evolution of this beer... 9-4-8-4-17 = 4.1

28-04-2014: Bottle (330 ml) @ De Heeren van Liedekercke. Best before 2005. Clear bright golden with a medium creamy off-white head and good lacing. Aroma is of brettanomyces, herbal and floral presence, mineral notes and some oxidation. Taste is of mild brettanomyces, oxidation notes, light bitterness, herbal presence and a light alcohol touch. Light body. A tad watery. Medium carbonation. Dry finish. Still pretty good, but its going downhill (since a couple of years already). 7-4-7-3-13 = 3.4

Bottled 8-18-11...6.9ABV
Pours a dark orange with light tan head.....large....required multiple pauses and pours into tulip.
Aroma is very fruity, clean, light...orange, pineapple, pear mix
Taste is surprisinglt not as sweet as the scent...dry, bitter,sour....hops present themselves towards finish....
Complex...wonderful.

Bottle at home. Dark orange, thin off-white foamy head which recedes quickly. Nose of mango, citrus and honey, delicious. Remarkable flavours, marzipan, nuttiness, honey, almost a dryness, quite excellent. Nice, not overbearing fizz. Good, good stuff.
A very delicious treat.  Not on the same level as Roch 10 or Berny 12, but wonderful nonetheless.
A fine beer, unique in taste. Its been on our drinking list for many years and we consume it every beer tasting evening.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2012 Bottle 330ml [2009]
Better at 3 years old than fresh. Bretts are blatant at aroma, but more shy taste-wise. Other aspects not extremely changed.
Bottle 330ml. [8/3/8/3/15]
Pours hazy golden, with good white head and interesting lacing. Aroma is of hops, citrus, orange peel, yeast, sweetness, malt. Taste is citrus, malt, sweetness (over residual maybe), yeast. Sligth bitter finish. Overall: Good balance, somewhat thin. Not my favorite Trappist, but still very good.
good color and head retention. lots of cinnamon, straw, spices, and slight bits of acid. Good stuff

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2012 6.2% bottle in Spain (6 months old) - hazelnut orange with a thick white frothy head. Citrus nose of grapefruit with sweet fruitiness like melon yellow kiwi. Medium thin body. Frothy. Unique taste of orange/lemon citrus, cinnamon,wood with a brittle acidic and slightly alcohol finish. Dry sour/bitter hops with a sweet fruitiness. Felt a little strong but would defiantly try again.  The 6 month Orval feels less strong and more fruity.   

18months - The fruitiness melon smell is much stronger. Lost the hops smell. Dry smooth body. Very smooth. Citrus elements, stronger woods. Crisp and dry. Alcohol is almost gone. As it ages the citrus and and alcohol taste diminishes and the central woody cinnamon fruit taste becomes stronger. Need to try an older bottle.
Pours amber with a huge 3" head.  Nice aroma with malt, raspberry, lychee and hops.  Smooth palate with a medium body.  Not as "funky" as I thought it was going to be.

Nice amber colour with a good white head which leaves a nice lacing. Looks great. Tastes of bread, yeast, bit sweet (little caramel). Ends bitter (grapefruit) and a little dry. I really like this beer, it's special and nice. A real treat.

Aldus Huubs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Light amber coloured and hazy with a big creamy and stable head. Smell of citrus, grapefruit, grain and flowers. Tastes quite bitter, again citrus and grapefruit, then a bit caramel and malt. Full bodied, a bit sour at the end.
Some people claim this is one of the best beers in the world. It is pretty darn good. A Belgium almost to perfection...

Pours a clear dark amber with a great head. Leaves tons of lacing. Aroma is yeast and some fruit. Taste is yeasty, nice hops, and some bread. Really nice bitterness and dry finish. Nice carbonation. Good beer.
330ml bottle. Pours golden orange body with a marvelous off-white head. Plenty of hops that throws the aroma down your nostrils. Undefined Belgium beer taste. Long lasting aftertaste

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2012 Che birra fantastica! Il monastero in cui la fanno è di origini calabresi. Complessa come poche. Ogni volta che la provi cogli sapori che prima non avevi notato. Quando la versate nel suo bicchiere (stupendo) non versatela tutta, ma lasciate un pò di birra sul fondo della bottiglia. Bevuto il primo bicchiere, poi, versatevi ora quella che avete lasciato. E come bere una birra diversa. Per trovare una birra migliore (per me e per ora), bisogna andare in qualche altro pianeta della Via Lattea. Alcuni dicono si sia imbruttita durante gli anni di produzione. Beh! per me è sempre una sicurezza berla. Alla faccia di tutti.
Arome de malt fruité. Belle robe orangé coiffé dune mousse blanche très savonneuse. Goût de petits fruits et de céréal. Texture assez sèche avec une longue fin de fruit amère.
Pours beautifully into its glass. Lovely foamy head with strong hints of citrus. Nice hoppy balance. One of the most under appreciated trappist beers but truly one of the best.

25-FEB-2012, bottle @home, from "Superbest".
Orange with huge off-white head that lasts long.
Yeasty and fruity. A touch of brett.
Quite high carbonation. Very bitter ending.
Fine brew.

6.2%, as you can see this looks very good but in my very humble opinion, I am sad to say that I think the name of this beer was spelt (spelled) wrong and it should be AWFUL, it is made by monks and all I can think is that they are doing some sort of penance.

Pours a hazy dark gold with a big cream head. Lots of lacing and good retention. Smells floral with a lodd smell of cloud berry, or is it tulip? Taste is clean and strong. Slight hops taste with a very dry finish. Interesting taste. Fruit and floral.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Out of a bottle in a chalice.  Pours a deep gold/copper with a massive khaki head.  The head is full and chunky like the moon surface.  Biscuit and cracker nose.  Some slight cereal graininess.  Mouthfeel is slightly slick and then finishes bone dry.  Lip smacking dry.  Some nice herbal and earthiness with goldenrod meadow flavor.

Doesnt have a strong scent.  Looks a golden yellow with a shimmery head.  Carbonated well, stings a tad at the beginning.  Very crisp taste but a single flavor, doesnt change character throughout the tasting process.  Taste one flavor that is ever so slightly acidic apple, very faint.  Its very drinkable.  Not my favorite beer or style so its pretty good for what its supposed to be.
good aroma with a medium color and good head. orval has a very complex and balanced taste.
Transfering data from personal beer file. I drank this beer a long time ago. Ill update this rating if I have the chance to drink it again.
Bottle. Nice head, lovely muddy appearance. Mild hops and malty aroma. Taste is bitter with hops and very mild fruit tones, no hint of alcohol. Amazingly balanced beer, one of my all-time favorites.
amber, hazy, white foam, dough, caramel, roasty, herbs, medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, bitter, medium sweetness, very bitter,
golden, amber, cloudy, white foam, hay, cereal, citrus, light sweetness, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, bitter,

From notes.  First reviewed 5/14/2009.   Poured into a tulip.

While pouring this, I moved from pouring slowly down the side to dropping the beer in the center, and the head simply exploded, Duvel style. The carbonation keeps replenishing while there is still beer in the glass as well. This is a nice dark orange and copper color, with a monster head that leaves all kinds of sticky lacing on the glass. Very nice.

A little bit light in the smell department. Some citrus and apple aromas, along with a variety of spices.

By far the best aspect of this beer is the taste. I get some strong tart flavor with the malt up front, mostly apple and maybe some grape. A nice blend of nutmeg and even a little cinnamon is present throughout the sip. The hops are fairly light and citrusy in nature, leaving me with more of a tart than a true bitter taste on my palate. Quite tasty and definitely unique.

The mouthfeel is actually a little bit light, which I would not have expected from the darker color. A nuanced breadiness stays on my tongue, giving it a little bit of texture.

Very easy to drink. After what seemed like just a sip, I looked down and I was almost done with the glass. Very smooth, propped up by a nice level of carbonation and a crisp, balanced flavor. 
After my first try, I think that I will have to sample a few more of these, in order to accustom myself to the different taste. I did not feel it was "dirty" or "funky" as a few other reviewers thought, but maybe I will get those senses next time I drink it.

Pours a hazy dark gold with a big cream head. Lots of lacing and good retention. Smells very floral with a little baked bread. Taste is clean and strong. Slight hops taste with a very dry finish, and when you think its over, you get hit with a solid malty smack to the tongue. Interesting after taste. I like this a lot, and the bone dryness seems to make this one stand out amongst other Trappist ales. Good. Maybe not my go to Trappist ale though.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2013 Bottle. Pours hazy golden with a medium white head. Aroma is very fruity, tropic fruit, peach, yeast, light hoppy notes. Flavor is lots of fruit, yeast, dry end. I understand why people like this beer.

Seriously loved my first experience with Orval.  The color was fantastic and inviting.  The aroma enticed my taste buds for what was to come.  Surprisingly, the taste exceeded my expectations.  I guess theyve pretty much perfected this recipe.

Sorry for the german rating, but this is a lousy rating from my "newbie" time (2007-2009), and its not worth of being translated. I just added it for the statistics, and to complete my backlog!

Im Glas leuchtet das Bier trüb orange-gelb mit stabiler, langlebiger Krone. Der Geruch ist säuerlich-zitronig und angenehm hefig-fruchtig.  Es schmeckt fruchtig, säuerlich, nach Zitrone. Etwas Hefe kommt raus, und ein undefinierbarer, aber guter Eigengeschmack. Der Nachgeschmack wird etwas getreidig-grasig. Könnte etwas mehr Kohlensäure vertragen, aber für 6,2% Alc trinkt es sich doch sehr angenehm.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2012 ***Bottled on 5/20/11. FRESH: This is one of the best beers. It says something that Orval makes one beer for the public. Its almost Buddhist in terms of focus and perfection. The pour is a cloudy pale copper similar to apple cider in color and consistency with a thin frothy head that proves to be quite resilient. The palate, crisp and clean, med-light bodied, finished with a fizz. I found the taste to be fronted by a light hop followed by tart apples, bright fruit notes, a little muted hay taste, and bitter finish that mellows back to a sweet fruit - the perfect aftertaste in my opinion. 
***ONE YEAR OLD *** Acidic smell, fruit and spice, with a hint of cinnamon. Very frothy head over a medium brown pour. Light and silky palate. Nutty flavor with a spice note, acidic lemon aftertaste. A bit different than a year ago.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 2012-11-29
33cl. Bottle. 
Poors hazy orange with firm white head. 
Aroma citrus, peach, hopy fruits, some yeast. 
Taste some sweet, some bitters and some sour. 
Mouth-feel thin/dry.
Still in love with this complex beer. 

2012-01-12
Aroma: Nice fruity sweet aroma.
Appearance: Dark hazy orange with firm head. 
Taste: Sweet complex medium sweetness. Some Bitter. 
Palate: Complex full body. lively. 
Overall: I like this beer.  First time ever. Not to heavy.
Dark copper with a thick off white head. This retains and laces beautifully in an Orval stemmed goblet. Banana and dark fruit on the nose. Malty, but in good balance with hops.

Young bottle enjoyed at home
Copper hazy, massive tanned head. Smells of tart apples, malts and some fruits. Taste has very nice balanced malts, good sweetness and some very nice acids as well from the brett. Also some fruits. Playful carbonation-. Nice bitter finish. Totally a very descent beer

Bready, hay and fruity Belgian aromas.
Pretty light amber color with a nice frothy head.
Tastes of a very good golden Trippel, but with the awesome addition of Brett yeast.

I love this stuff, and its only my first taste of it.

Pours a cloudy golden amber with a very big off white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with some pine & citrus notes. Flavor is rich earthy malts with a hoppy bitterness that slides in at the finish (theres a little black pepper in the finish, as well). What a wonderfully smooth beer. Everything seems really well balanced and the alcohol (6.9%) is not noticeable.

Pours an amberish brown with a big frothy off-white head. Aroma is yeast, alcohol, apple and other unidentifiable fruits. Taste is medium sweet with an awesomely subtle bitterness in the background. Finish is mildly bitter. I dont think Ive had a belgian with this much bitterness-- its a really fantastic contrast to the sweet frutiness Im used to. Palate is full with a nice amount of carbonation. Great beer.

[ASPETTO] 			
color ambra scuro, con riflessi aranciati, velata			
[SCHIUMA]			
color bianco, fine ed abbondante, media persistenza,  residuo persistente			
[OLFATTO]			
media intensità: profumi floreali, lieviti. Base maltata e un accenno leggero di alcohol			
[GUSTO]			
malto nei primi istanti, con note leggermente dolci frenate da un pizzicore dovuto alla carbonazione, per poi dare subito la stoccata con amaricanti corposi checonducono fino alla fine. Accompagna nel tragitto un fruttato fresco, senza arivare ad essere acidulo. Finale secco, retrogusto con un amaro deciso ( vegetale, radice) e persistente che si mescola con leggere note alcoliche.			
[TEXTURE]			
corpo medio-basso, carbonazione iniziale pungente, percezione alcolica moderata			
[COMMENTO FINALE]			
un classico, sempre allaltezza, con una luppolatura generosa e caratteristica che la rende molto beverina, fresca. Forse una carbonazione sopra le righe soprttutto allinizio. Una "trappista" commercialmente omnipresente. Una sicurezza al momento dellacquisto. ho letto commenti riguardo a bottiglie lasciate riposare anni  o alle differenze (qualitative)  fra produzione  datate e quelle più recenti. non sarebbe male provare a lasciarne qualcuna in cantina.. se si resiste alla tentazione;  temo però per la luppolatura e il dry-hopping.
