The first thing thats remarkable: the spicy smell. It has a heavy bitter taste. The aftertaste is spicy. The bottle looks nice and is very typical.

Bottle from 99.Hazy orange-gold pour with a tall, rocky, off-white head leaving heavy lace. Nice Belgian malt nose with noticeable Brett aromas. Medium body and sharp, fine carbonation. Toast, clove, Brettanomyces, citrus and white pepper. Finish is dry, bitter and umami. Defines the style and rightfully so: its just about perfect in every way. I could drink this every day.

03-02-11 Bouteille 2011: Très belle couleur caramel, trouble, avec une mousse blance abondante qui réduit lentement et  avec un mince filet de mousse qui reste recouvrant la bière, sans effervescence. Arômes très légers dhoublon, de poire et de brettanomyces. Petite touche de sucrée, avec une amertume bien présente, sans être agressante. Bien balancée avec une bonne base maltée et légèrement caramélisée. Corps moyen avec une texture moyennement ronde. Se boit aisément et offre une belle panoplie de saveurs fruitée, maltée et houblonnée. Finale asser astrigente, mais tout de même raffraichissante. Bière très complexe à essayer à différentes température et différentes années de vieillissement.
Hazy orange/red/brown color, nice white head. Hoppy tasting; especially bitter and also kind of fruity
Nice hazy amber pour, with a thin bright white head.  Herbal/citrus aroma.  Taste is excellent, lots of citrus and hops, with a refreshingly dry finish.

Bottle. Hazy ligh amber color with a foamy white head. Rich aroma of fruity hops, sweets and plum. Flavour is yeast and sour berries. At first I tasted it straight out of fridge which was too cold for this beer. Better let it warm a bit. Lively carbonation.
Dark amber colour. Very balanced. Notes of yeast, brett, and hops. Dry bitter finish. Great beer!

Bottle 330ml. January 25th, 2012.

Bottled on 04/08/2011 6.9% Alc./ Vol.

Orange hazy color with thick white head. Citrusy and little hops aromas. In mouth, citrus and herbal dry hops flavors. Really nice beer !

Ratings # 35

Hazy gold color with copious white head.  Lemon citrus, yeast esters, light biscuit, mild candy.  Flavor is gentle citrus followed by solid floral hop bitterness.  Ends dry and bitter.  Some lingering candy and lemon.  Crisp profile.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2015 Bottle. Hazy orange color with a big, eggshell white head. The aroma s subtle, some lemon, wood, spices, barnyard, some sugar. The taste is light, delicate, floral, some citrus, marshmallow. Tart, soft finish. This beers very dry. Hoppy. Certainly unique amongst the trappists. The palate is very accomplished. Medium/light body. Lively carbonation. Smooth. Overall, very nice. I havent had this in years, Im enjoying it much more this time around.
Metallisk, kraftig, parfumeret, blomsteragtig duft. Middelfyldig smag, markant humlebitterhed.

(Flasche) Es hat ein hellbraune, haselussähnliche Farbe mit leichtem Rotstich, eine weiße Schaumkrone und es ist nicht filtriert. Das Aroma besteht aus einem weichen fast rotweinartigem Körper mit einer Honigsüße und einer leichten säuerlichen Fruchtigkeit. Der Geschmack ist recht schlank, leicht erdig und im Abgang kommt eine starke, breite Bittere die lange anhält. Der Geschmack ist leicht samtig fast sandig. Retronasal kommt dieses Rotweinaroma wieder leicht raus. Es ist recht stark karbonisiert . Alles in Allem ist es immer wieder ein Erlebnis ein Orval zu trinken
caramel, spruce, barnyard, bubblegum, rotten eggs, banana, brown, sparkling, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, salty, soft carbonation, sticky, bitter,
Dark amber black. Arome thich head. Aroma. fruits floral  Texrture medium fantastic. Afte finish dry shoit, lame.

100th review in two months, not bad. 

Pours somewhere between blond and amber. Theres a lot of carbonation on this. Great three fingers white head, really good lacing and retention. 

Very crisp smelling. Maybe its the Belgium yeast, but it almost smells sour. 

Again, very crisp, hoppy. Slightly sour, very balanced. Very carbonated. Super rich. Most unique Trappist Ive had so far.
Fantastic beer! And its taste is really original and unsurpassed! This is one of the few!

The Orval has an opaque, brown appearance. The aroma is very complex; it has a bit of  earthy yeast, hops, apple, cherry, and some other aroma I cant put my finger on. The taste has a good balance. The palate is strongly bodied, and for how complex the hops are, not too astringent. I dont love this beer as much as some others do, but make no mistake, its still a high quality beer, and I would definitely try it again.
Bottle. Extremely fruity smell. Nice white head. Mildly fruity and mildly hoppy taste. Lots of carbonation. Nice reddish color. Very likeable, balanced beer.

This beer is amazing! I got a huge aroma of red fruit, especially strawberries and some orange, it took me by surprise to be fair. Lots of herbal notes on the nose and some hoppiness too. Lots of fruitiness on the palate followed by some hop bitterness. Some grassy herbal notes as well. Great carbonation. Drying mouthfeel that is really enjoyable. Fucking awesome!

Served from a 11.2 oz bottle from Barrons. Bottled on 10/03/2011, consumed on 01/11/2012. The appearance is a deep golden hue with some red undertones. Nice white head on the top. Sweet lemon and Brett to the nose with some floral hoppy tones. The flavors have s nice light floral hop, butterscotch, some breadlines, a bit of an earthy wooden tone too. The mouth is over-carbonated for my taste. Sits to big in the stomach. A solid brew. I put down a bottle for some time to see what else this brew does.

Bottle.  Pours a light brown color with a big white head. Smells of dried fruit and a bit of bread.  Taste is lightly bitter and much drier than your usual Belgian.  If you like IPAs and Belgians.. this is your king brew.
Una birra allaltezza della sua fama e dallottimo rapporto qualità/prezzo. Aroma ricco e profumato con prevalenza di frutta fresca. Secca e decisa al palato con un gusto persistente.

330ml Bottle from Peckhams, Glasgow:
Some nice citrus to begin along with an overwhelming orange aroma. There is a good flowery smell that follows this and some yeast as well. Right at the end I can also detect a little banana and even apricot.

Dark amber to orange colour with a uneven, foamy white head that is about a thumb-width tall and has excellent retention.

Quite a hop filled, spicy flavour to begin with, this is a very nice beer. There is a mild flowery taste along with very light banana and clove. The drink is rounded off with a dry, yeast like taste.

The light side of medium on the body with good, strong carbonation and smooth, dry finish.

A great beer that was not at all like what I had been expecting, the floral notes alone where a big surprise but a pleasant one.

1001 Beers To Try Before You Die:

Purchased at Breeze Thru Liquors in Milwaukee, WI; enjoyed while nursing a bum elbow after a long day at work...needed a nice treat.  Appearance is like a magical potion, dark orange/amber with a rich, frothy white head, tons of tiny carbonation bubbles rising to the top.  Aroma has a lot going on.  Theres a flood of fruity esters mixed with floral hops, mixed in with a complex Belgian yeast, also has a sour/stinky cheese like quality in the nose.  Outstanding smell.  Taste is extremely complex.  Starts slightly tart, becomes increasingly bready, finishes with a slight citrus hops flavor but retains the tart/bread qualities.  Theres not much anyone could change about this brew, its been brewed for the better half of a century to near perfection.  For my style it doesnt get a 5, but it definitely is one of the best all around beers Ive ever had.

Pours hazy amber with a one finger white head that dissipates quickly.  The nose is some bread, cheese with citrus and herbal notes.  Some caramel thrown in as well.   Taste is not your typical trappist.  Its quite bitter compared to other trappist beers.  There is an earthy funk to it as well, similar to what you get with brett.  Mouthfeel is slick, crisp and long lasting.  This is not in my opinion the best trappist beer, however, it is my favorite!

11.2oz bottle poured into a goblet.

Appearance is a hazy dark orange with a 2 finger thick white head. Retention is awesome. The head simply refuses to fade away!

Smell is very orangy and yeasty with also a bit of juniper.

Taste is citrusy up front with apple and orange. Orange being predominant. There is also a woody note along with a slight tartness from the yeast. Bitterness is present throughout but really becomes noticeable toward the finish. The beer finishes with a long lasting dryness.

Overall this is a unique beer. Maybe not the the best Belgian out there but it is different from other ones and a beer that everyone should try.

Beaucoup deffervescence dans une robe orange trouble. Beaucoup de parfums, provenant des houblons combinés au caractère de la levure, sen échappent. En bouche cest savonneux et extrêmement sec avec le houblon qui laisse une amertume robuste et plutôt florale.
color oscuro ambarino, aroma dulce, de sabor suave y continuo, dulce pero evoluciona a ser mas fuerte en adelante dejando un regusto duradero. muy buena
Pours a dark orange amber color. Very dry aroma. Intense hopped dry flavor. Good beer. Finishes like no other beer i know. Very carbonated

Un bel équilibre.   Belle apparence légèrement trouble, arômes fruités, malt caramel ou biscuit , belle présence en bouche avec une belle amertume moyennement longue.  Facile à boire, mais pour une trappiste je mattendais à plus darômes, dépices...  Elle est toutefois un bel exemple déquilibre.  Très accessible.

Bottled 28/10/10. Appearance is amber in colour with a volatile head. Aroma of orange, marmalade, hops. Taste is fairly sweet and tingly on the tongue owing to the carbonation, but dominated by the bitterness of the hops which follow through into the finish. Pretty good stuff.

This may be my favorite beer of all time.  I feel as though I could identify Orval in a glass next to a dozen others by the head alone.  

Orvals delicate balance and expansive singularity set it apart as a world class beer, and belongs elevated on high with such masterpieces as the Ghent Altarpiece, the Pantheon, and Port Ellen.

Orvals quiet dominance of subtlety and complexity will always set it apart.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2015 33 cl. bottle @home. Hazy amber/orange with a big white head. Aroma is funky and hoppy. taste is tart and lively. Finish is bone dry and long lasting.
Due to the wild yeast there a lot of variation in taste and aroma but every individual bottle is always the best I ever had, be it a young or a relatively old one.
My all-time favorite beer.

Poured from a small bottle bottled on 10-3-2011 into my tulip glass.

A: Hazy orange brown, almost like carbonated iced tea. Carbonation bubbles plenty floating up to meet a light tan white head that is slowly dissipating on the side but staying up in the middle making a mound.

S: Light floral and citrus with some juniper berries. Very pleasant and inoffensive.

T: Very fresh tasting, floral notes take the cake here, but I notice some citrus hints here with a slight yeasty taste to it.

M: Rather light bodied with a lot of carbonation makes this very easy to down.

O: This is my first Trappist beer and I like it. Very easy to drink with a nice flavor to it. Ill be trying more.
Very good beer. One of my favorite. Not too strong. The beer that makes me love beer.
Large white fluffy head. Dark orange body with a wonderful citrus aroma. Excellent body with a medium to lively carbonation. Light hints of peach and citrus on the body.

Appearance >>an amber color for the body with a lot carbonation and a big bubbly head

Smell >> fruity aromas 

Flavor >> The presence of the Belgian yeast is huge; Meaty and very citrusy, fruity 

Mouthfeel > extreme  carbonation and very light
Bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a decent sized white fluffy head. Well carbonated. Hops on the nose. Hops, yeast and bitter fruit flavour. Nice bitter finish. This is good stuff.

Ooh my.  My first $5, 11.2oz bottle was an October 10th, 2010, consumed on December 6th, 2011 (14 months).  It was hands down the best beer Ive ever had, for many reasons:

-Smells like a complex fruity wine
-Pours a reddish brown with TONS of fluffy foam
-Tastes of fresh fruit, quite a bit of hops, some fruity acidicy, medium-long finish turning slightly bitter in the end.  Unlike anything else Ive tasted.  Its like the first second of an IPA but for 5 seconds, then finishing without the overwhelming bitterness.  This is the most well-balanced thing Ive had, and the head is ridiculous.

The second bottle I had was a 20/05/2011 consumed on 8/12/2011 (so, a bit under 7 months old).  I can really taste the difference between this and the 14-month old bottle I had before.  This one isnt quite as complex, but has a bit of a metallic flavor.  Still very well balanced, but Id really encourage you to find an older bottle or wait it out, based on what Ive tasted here.  This younger bottle has more acidity and a bit less pillowly carbonation.  Im also getting more fresh dough at the end.  Definitely good and very drinkable, but again the older bottle was out of this world whereas this bottle is more similar to other things Ive had.

These go well with a well-aged Sartori Sarvecchio parmasean cheese.  This is my favorite beer.

33cl bottle. Cloudy amber with an energetic head. A world of hops in the nose with some malt. Flavour is (again) a world of hops with spicy belgian east and brett. Bitterness picks up in the middle and maintains through to the finish. A wonderful and very distinctive Belgian beer.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 Rerate. I love it finally!

24-01-2012 Rerate for the online mass tasting: First rating was in a bar after a few other beers. This tasting is at home. But again, I can?t figure out why this beer has so many high ratings...First rating was 3.0

Hazy amber, small head. Medium carbonation. Disappointing taste, bitter, some licorice, little bit of dried fruits. Very dry and fairly thin bodied. I expected more from this trappist.

Date: December 2, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: AV3 Description: Semi-opaque orangish brown pour that was cloudy, a ridiculous amount of head, strong aroma of citrus, yeast, brett, and spice.  Taste was somewhat of a let down, citrus, a little bit sour with spice, dry and slight bitter finish, thin bodied.  Bottled July 2010 at 6.9%.  Finally got around to trying this and was not overly impressed.

Orval pours a dark orange with a delicious creamy white head.  On the nose I find caramel, praline, oak and citrus.  Seriously aromatic.  Toffee apples, oranges, slightly sour, creamy and dry in the mouth.  It has pretty decent carbonation and a very pretty bottle.

Bravo....
Orange and citrus fruits; pours beautiful orange and slightly murky, big white head; sweet and slightly bitter, quick finish with spry carbonation, medium body.
Frothy thick head, kinda like sea foam. Somewhat cloudy appearence. Spritzy taste hopped just right. Very good.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2014 Ruikt naar frisse peren en appelmoes, hoog opstaande stevige kraag. Smaak is tevens fris, met rokerige, bijna bittere afdronk. Weinig zoet, ondanks de toegevoegde kandijsuiker. #2 ook wat banaan in aroma. Smaak toch diepe zoetigheid van pruim. Toch geen hogere rating. #3 ook appelschÃ¶rrle (wel eten erbij) in smaak. Minder zoet dan hiervoor.

Ultra dependable, available almost everywhere in Belgium and still one of the best beers in the world. Amber orange with white frothy head of small bubbles. Aroma is funky brett. yeast, herbal, doughy. Beautiful taste, always finding something new in there after having it so many times. Spritzy, crisp and delicious. I cant describe why its great, but it just is.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2012 A wonderfully complex Belgian Ale. At first sip, I didnt know what to make of it, or if I even really liked it...but as the beer started to open up, It quickly became one of my favorites. Very nice beer, with a unique finish. Dough and fresh bread scents.

Bottle in Rome, Italy; 05/05/2011. Pour is a cloudy, orange, bubbly haze with a nice thick head. For me the nose is overwhelmingly a lightly citrus bubblegum that is very sweet. A good swirl gives it some deeper, grassier characteristics. Taste is a sweet, slightly sour citrus bubble gum with the a slight bitter taste that lingers nicely.  A fantastic mouthfeel, one of my favorites. Really the main thing that sticks with me for this beer is the tangy bubblegum and in a good way. I am new to the world of beer having just started trying many different types of beer over the past year or so and this is definitely one of the best I have had. A truly great beer.
UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 Bottle. Hazy amber colour with a huge head. Yeast and some spices in the aroma. A bit fruity flavour, with some citrus and caramel notes.

Murky red/amber, large fluffy head. 
Smells malt fruit, caramel.
Caramel balance burnt malts and hops. Almost Vienna like.
Quite thin, carbonated.
Lovely but could have more depth or intensity.

bottle: tasting of 2 different vintages of Orval 11 and 06. 2011, hazy orange, huge frothy head, A: Dusty, light brett, Sweet orange, orange peel, caramel, yeast, dusty hops, faint dried fruit, light floral, clover, hay, T: dry, crisp. light hoppy, orange peel, light brett, light farty, grassy, orange, light caramel, very balanced, light bitterness, =4, 2006: hazy orange, huge frothy head,  Aroma: Loads of Brett!! overripe pear, barnyard, horse blanket, rotten apples, fruity, light sulfur, dusty hops, hay, straw, spiced belgian yeast, candy sweet, floral, T: Brett, clover, bubblegum, candy like, nice bitterness, light msg, dusty, melon, astringent, farty, overripe pear, hay, yeast, WILD, caramel, very dry, nice bitterness, lacto acid, woody, =4.2

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 Bottle. Pours with a gigantic head in my glass, which isnt exactly a belgian chalice. Smells great, the first thing I think about is tangerines. Golden orange color, huge head with beautiful bubbles. Aroma is citrusy, as mentioned, with notes of banana and bread. I also get a slightly sour brett-ish aroma, but not in a barnyard kind of way. Nice mouthfeel, an overall wonderful first impression here with great balance, a definte note of brett/lambic-ness, if one can say that, but its far from overwhelming, very slightly sour, dry, citrus, tropical fruits, green apples in the finish. Quite wonderful, easy to drink, great balance, great aroma/flavor, standing on a nice foundation of very subdued brett/sour ale characteristics.

pours cloudy orange with a frothy tan head. sweet, yeasty, spicy aroma. taste starts sweet and aromatic, but quickly develops its bitterness. there are citrus notes, and quite a high carbonation (which further enhances the bitter qualities). the finish is quite long and aromatic, but for me its too fizzy.

bottle in a pint glass - pours misty caramel in color with rich white froth, providing some lacing.  Nose is yeast and spices.  Aroma is more spices, some light hops (spruce or pine), and faint caramel malts.  Taste starts almost sour, then bitter and ends sweet but also quite bitter.  High Carbonation.  Body is medium to full and texture is sticky but thin.
Bottle, pours hazy yellow with white head, Sweet aroma with orange, tart and some yeast. Taste is sweet with some citrus and mild betterness. Good but not a big fan of belgians

Bottle at home. Still very young. Murky orange/brown/yellow, thick creamy head eventually dies down. Big grassy, peppery nose, hints of bubblegum, something sourdough, something chemical/boozy/minty also. Palate is dry, slightly tart, spiced, some funk, very dry. Really complex, tastes different with each sip. Finish is spicy hops, hint of booze. Really good.

0.33 bottle, 9 months old. Unclear orange\amber color with some particles in suspension and big off white head very long lasting. Syrupy nose. Aroma is complex, first of all ill say theres lots of "amaretto", then grapefruit, orange peel, other citrusy blends. Light cherry notes, spices, brandy, and massive amount of grassy hops. I sense some burnt coffee and pepper in the finish. On the bad side theres something soapy and alcohol. Long bitter finish, extra dry as description said, medium bodied, foamy texture, heavy and lively carbonation, fizzy. Good connoisseur beer, but personally i prefer smoother ones.
Pours a hazy amber with a mild head. Sweet citrus and grapefruit aroma with little yeast, quite dry. Taste is dry, lightly yeasty, fruity, hoppy. Very nice.

Year old bottle.  A hazy amber beer with a medium white head.  Sweet, slightly tart aroma  of hops, citrus (mostly grapefruit), malts.  Taste is mild sweet, mild bitter, with a lot of citrus.  Hoppy finish.  Light-medium body with a ton of carbonation.

Bottle.  Kind of a two toned pour.  Ruby red grapefruit color on the bottom and brownish orange on top.  Great aroma.  A lot of sour funk along with some cranberry and green apples.  Taste up front is really dry and bitter.  You need to sip this.  There are also notes of sour grapes and some slight sweetness.  Medium body and carbonation.  Really enjoyable.
330 bottle, looked like a hefeweizen. Great fennel smell, got strong hints of hubba bubba. Tasted lots of roasted malts, started sweet but finished very bitter. Unlike anything Ive ever had before.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 One of my favorite beer before discovering the amazing world of artisanal breweries... Try to wait at least three months before drinking it.. In the chalice glass, this orange beer fully developps complex flavours and aromas, with a dry taste.  Ideal with the Orval Cheese and the "paté gaumais".

From a bottle into a tulip glass. Ambered blonde, almost going on orange. Looks somewhat cloudy, yet relatively translucent. Very thick and long-lasting white, somewhat yellowish head. Subtle sweet taste in mouth. Slight, pleasant bitterness in aftertaste. It gets sweeter after every sip, which is highly pleasant. Alcohol is almost imperceptible,even though it says 6.9% on the bottle. Very good blonde ale!

This beer was served in a goblet. 

Ar- A very pleasing blend of sour, tart citrus. The citrus is played against cloves and peppery yeast.

Ap- The beer looks very nice in my goblet. Nearly orange colored body. The head was thick and rocky white in coloration. No real retention noted from the head. Thick lacing noted on my glass.

P- Nice smooth light and well carbonated. Very active bubbling carbonation. 

O- This beer is pure beer drinking pleasure. A very satisfying beer. I wonder why I pass up on this beer?

Fles 33cl.
Kleur: Amberkleur. Brede witte schuimkraag die instabiel is.
Geur: Fris fruitig.
Smaak: Licht zoet en fris.
Bijzonder bier

0,33 bottle. Pours dark hazy gold with white medium head.
strong sweet aroma, lots of dried grapes, brandy and red fruits.
taste is absolutely not sweet but a litte bitter and umami with strange salty aftertaste. pleasant hints of alcohol and fruitness. Lively carbonation and dry finish

medium cloudy amber, generous head and lacing.  Taste begins like Dr. Pepper (soft drink), but quickly succumbs to a wheat bitterness that balances beautifully.  A full-bodied trappist ale without  the usual caramel malt.  Excellent.

Tasted from bottle into nucleated pint glass. Poured a beautiful copper color with billowy off-white head, long-lasting with excellent Belgian lace. Amazingly, there was still a thin but solid layer of bubbles at the end of dinner. Delicate aromas of flowery, earthy hops, rising dough, fresh baked bread, mildly spicy yeast esters. Complex malt-sweetness perfectly balanced by bittering and flavor hops, notes of mild malt, caramel, toast, slight roasted nuts, raisins, plums.  Light-medium body, well-rounded, spritzy mouthfeel, above average carbonation. Significant alcohol percentage, but its completely undetectable. High yeast attenuation combined with dry-hopping makes for a very sophisticated, bitter-sweet, subtly fruity aftertaste which finishes to complete dryness. An exquisite masterpiece. One of the greatest beers of all time.

33cl bottle. Amber colour with a thick off-white head. Aroma is bready, fruity, citrus and yeasty. Flavour has notes of citrus, as the aroma, but also malty and spicy. The finish is moderate bittery with hints of lemon. Medium carbonation, the body is medium-high and the texture is oily.

Hazy sun-kissed golden pour with a mountainous, pillowy white head and fine cascades of carbonation. Sweet, champagne-like aroma. Slightly phenolic at first, with some white grape and a very dry fruitiness. Also some clove and a modest Belgian yeast aroma. Taste is spicy, but well-balanced. Fruity apple esters melt into a very dry finish. Grassy hop flavor. Perfectly carbonated, very clean finish and very easy to drink. Like a medium-dry wine, it pairs well with just about every food on the planet. Delicious.
Cloudy amber color with a large head which slowly disappeared. Mild hop aroma with some earth notes. Taste is carbonated with a little spice. Maybe some nutmeg. Overall pretty good beer.
pours orangely to the glass. very dry...I mean really dry but theres a hoppy aroma. Ive got no words for this. properly good beer

Pours sunset orange with an enormous, fluffy white head. Smells like malts and yeast, sweet and earthy, with a strong hop nose as well. Tastes like citrus, bitter, with a bit of an earthy flavor and some sweetness from the malts. Light-bodied with a smooth texture (partially from the creamy head) and lots of mouth-carbonation, Orval finishes crisp with a hint of citrus and a soft lingering bitterness.
Dark golden colour, almost amber. Malty smell and maybe some sweetness. Rather bitter taste with some fruit. Relatively harsh taste. Good beer with strong bitterness and some fruitiness.
For sure one of the best beers in the world - prefer it with a bit of age but is awesome whatever the age.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2013 Bottled 11/17/2010, this makes it almost 1 year old.  Pours a cloudy amber with a ridiculously large head.  I pause to reflect upon it, this miracle in a glass... I wonder, do the monks (or whoever makes this) know how many peoples lives have been changed for the better by drinking this beer?   As this thought passes my mind, I throw caution to the wind and pour the entire bottle into the glass, dregs and all.  I get two dark brown lumps on the top of the pillowy head... one for me and one for you.   Now it is down to just me and the beer.  I swirl the glass ever so slightly and place my nose as close to the head as I can without touching it, and what I smell is just...magical.  It is like Gods perfume.  Citrus, apple, hay, funk and yeast make up this magical medicine.  I raise the glass to my lips expecting the world to end once I taste this elixir and... well the world can just go on turning without me because I have fallen in love with this sweet, indulgent fluid.  Words cannot describe  what has happened here.  This could be the best beer on the planet.
Color ambar con espuma ligera aromas a levadura con un final sutil a lupulo, clasico entre las trapistas.
October 21, 2011; 11.5 oz. bottle.  Amber pour, creamy head. Aromatic, fruity, dry, bitter.  Lovely (if pricey!) Belgian ale.

Got this after my friend unwittingly bought a round of Jupiler, and boy, does that showcase the difference between a lager and a proper beer. Pours slightly foggy brown with small head. Fruity/malty aroma, taste is malty with a quite lively carbonation. Good, but not fantastic.

Young bottle dated June 2010. Colour is somewhere between straw and amber, with an impressive, well-retaining white head. Enticing bouquet: Peach, citrus, apple and perfume alongside wilder, mustier aromas of barnyard and straw. Unique amongst trappist beers, but also unique among Belgian sours Ive tried - unlike sweet Flemish reds and browns it is bone-dry, and unlike lambic its brett sourness - while being undoubtedly present - is kept on a leash and isnt allowed to overwhelm the other flavours. Carbonation is heavier than usual, which helps carry the unusual sour qualities. Medium body. A bit drier than my usual taste, but a must-try.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2015 Bottle from corte ingles, lisbon. Great beer. Dark gold color. Thin head. Medium sourness, light to medium sweetness. Barnyard, fruity, hops, spices, herbs aroma.

Pours clear/hazy light copper. Extremely intense head. Doesnt look really think, though. Good retention.
Aroma is mainly yeast -- apple esters galore! -- and herbal hops. Taste is more balanced than what aroma suggests : much more malty, actually. Really dry -- a summer trappist, actually?
Problem is : never, ever drink this one cold. Extremely thin body + a cabonation that seems to kick a lot at cold temperature makes if for an extremely bland experience. This is a beer thats better drank over 10 degrees, and, really, dont waste time drinking it cold. So, a good hour after the first sip... much better, but still a bit too thin for my tastes. Overall --- its good, but I was disappointed.

Poured from a 11.2 ounce bottle into a Chimay goblet. Bottled on April 22, 2010 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours a hazy orange caramel color with a huge 4 finger thick and creamy off-white head. A touch of sediment pools right on top of the billowy head. The head was so big it rose a full 2 fingers above the rim of the goblet. Perfect head retention. Halfway through the glass and its still got a 1/2 finger head. Excellent lacing.

Smell: Strong funky notes with some sweet apple and pear coming through as well.

Taste: Crisp tart fruitiness up front followed by funky "horseblanket" notes in the middle before ending with a grassy hop bitterness at the finish. Aftertaste is funky, mildly phenolic and very dry. The dryness of the aftertaste lingers for long time.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. The mouth puckers much the same as it does when eating an unripe persimmon.

Drinkability: High drinkability. Goes down smooth. While I wouldnt want multiples, drinking one is a pleasure.

Overall: Very good beer overall. This is probably the most unique of all the Trappist beers. Orval is funky in a good way. Definitely recommend giving it a try.

Bottle. Pours clear amber with a big fluffy foamy head that slowly fades to more foamy film and lacing. Aroma is yeast bubblegum and some spice/white pepper. Taste is spicy and belgian yeast with some bubblegum florals and bitterness. Palate is medium/thin with plenty of carbonation and finishes dry.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2016 I guess Im one of those who fell for this beer. I just love it. I used to drink it everyday. The aroma is very yeasty but you can dig the citrus hops without much effort. I must say that the appearance makes this beer look like somebody didnt much care about looks. I like it flat so I pur orval in a ruff way in a humid glass so it loose a bit of the carbonation : I use for it a much larger glass then it should be. Otherwise there would be to much foam in my mounth. There is so many things you might say about the first taste : well balanced light sweetnes and freshness of hops but you forget quickly after you swallow because its the grapefruit taste that dominates. When you take a year old bottle then allready on the beginning you feel much more the sourness and very interresting bitterness. Overall this beer has allmighty grapefruit like aftertaste and when you get more then 4 bottles of it you still don"t feel like you had enough of it (contrary to a grapefruit itself). 
This is my best beer. If I add to this that this beer contains no sugar left after fermantation and you gor yourself a great everyday beer. Unfortunatly even here in belgium you might have troubles to find it regulary on the shop shelves.

Colour - Medium brown, cloudy, slightly carbonated, maintains a very thin head. Aroma - Sweet, yeasty. Initial taste - hint of caramel, tiny hoppyness, slightly grassy and nutty. Further drinking - gets slightly dry upon further tasting, very nice and clean on the palate.

Bottle. Pours a pale amber with lots of heqd. Aroma is musty Belgian yeast. Taste is slightly month at first, giving way to a strong but subtle hop presence with leathery undertones. Finishes slightly dry with a medium body.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2013 20130904 I think my last description was quite spot on. Wineous sourness. Banana. New score: 7-4-8-4-15=3.820111002 Pours light brown. Some slight yellow head, which outlasts the beer in the glass. Flowers, hay and yeasty aromas. Some hop and spice (pepper) as well. Hint of candy. A bit on the sweet side. Quite thin mouthfeel. Good. 7-2-6-3-12=3.0

Pours a yellow/orange hue with a huge growing head thats lasts forever as a pillowy white tower.  Aroma is of faint ripe fruits, yeast and lemon/orange zest.  Taste is of spice, lemony citrus, some earthy barnyard from the brett.  This is light refreshing and nicely dry.  Although light, the flavors are nice and complex and I can see why this is highly thought of.  And I am glad that its availabilty and lack of rareness still have it scored highly.  Cant believe it has taken me so long to try.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2012 In bottle at de Het Kathedraalcafe, Anterp. Pours a golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, treacle, pepper and yeast. Similar flavours with some lemon also. Quite dry overall especially to finish. Mild carbonation with a little CO2 prickle. A little thin also. Tried this again for the mass online tasting. Bottled date 10/08/2011; BB 10/08/2016. Pours a golden amber colour with a rocky beige head and a thick turbulent stream of small bubbles. Beautiful aroma of pineapple and Brett! Quite fruity overall with flavours of plums, passion fruit and a lovely bone dry finish. Im really enjoying this, much more than previously. Brett is definitely present but Id love more. Mouth-feel is still chewy with a little lingering caramel also. Moderate carbonation. Really drinkable, I wish I had a couple more of these to compare this too. Time to stock up the cellar.

08 Bottle of Orval shared by Jared @ Woodshop Classix. You were probably one of the few people actually sticking to the theme! A true classic, and a vintage no less.  Pour is a fairly clear hay yellow with an almost pulpy orange juice appearance -- only much lighter. Delicate sea foams form, which is always a plus with an aged bottle, but they quickly rejoin the body with almost no retention or lacing. A light creamy film swirls over the top of the beer like creams in coffees. Smell is a little bit of sour dough with some gobs of honey, spices, and perhaps juniper (struck me as gin-like). Taste is really light and mellow -- perhaps some faded orange or lemon zest, but its so very light. Mostly bready biscuity malts that seem too light and mellow to ever rise in an oven. Still very crisp and drying though. I thought this drank pretty well considering the age, I didnt think it would be quite like this. This really hit me quite differently from what I can remember fresh, but I do know that Ive enjoyed this beer in both forms. I surprisingly good beer to age, but Id love to try this ultra fresh on location someday.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2012 had this from draft and in a chalice type glass. Had a good head to it along with a really good dark orange color.

nicely aromatic with tones of oranges, pears, some malts, and a slight touch of citrus hops. very well balanced and aromatic.

the aromas are backed up by a real smooth and delicious medium/full body. good depth on the flavors as well with the flavors mostly being more oranges and bits of citrus hops+malts.

its been a while since Ive had an orval. This reminded me quickly that my next one should be a lot sooner.

Finally got around to tasting this one.  It was a very nice beer but different than I expected.  It seemed to have a lot in common with the saison style with a very dry finish.  There was a slight hoppy flavor to it which also wasnt expected from such an ale.

Very interesting and I highly recommend to fans of the saison style.

Aroma is a slightly less musty than many in this style with a hint of hop aroma and hints of fruit, most notably banana. The taste is crisp with a slight spice and hiding in the background is a slight sour from the brettanomyces. Overall this is a close to perfect beer.

Odd but spicy bubblegum first came to mind when I first tried this brew. The flavors in this one are many rolled into one and each vying for their own moment in the spotlight. Intense but very well-balanced and very much enjoyed and savored. This is definitely a brew to sit back and enjoy ice cold and then savor the flavors as they change while the brew slowly warms. This is also a very aromatic brew that had me wishing they would make a dangly air freshener made with this scent! (yeah odd, random thought there) This is a great brew to try if one has not gotten into Belgian Pale Ales.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2012 Bottle bought @ Systembolaget and consumed on September 21. Pours yellowish brown with a big white head. Smell is a bit funky with some citrus notes, there is also some almonds and figs. Taste is dry, pleasantly bitter and a bit sour. There is a bready maltiness and some lemon. I also detect some dried fruit but its hard to pinpoint the different tastes with this much going on. Incredible and unique beer.Re-rate. Many bottles later. Amazing farmhouse ale. Great all around.
4/5 in darkness. Smells hoppy and fruity. Tastes sour, sweet, abit oak and malty with a similar finish.

330ml bottle.
Cloudy, brownish orange pour with a good amount of fluffy white head.  Herbal hop aromas with some spice - flavors of earthy brett, slightly sour, sweet, and bitter.  Very unique.
Golden in color, nice head. Lemon with a nint of funk in the flavor. Very light on the palate, dances on the tongue.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Tulip.

Appearance: Cloudy but bright orange with an enormous billowing off-white head that does not go away and clings to everything.

Aroma: Musty fruit, banana and clove. Hard to describe but dry, musty and tart overall - actually this seems to be the horse blanket smell I have heard described before.

Taste: Very earthy malts with lots of clove and general Belgian funk. A little fruit is present as well. Turns ever-so-slightly bitter and peppery at the end of each sip.

Palate: Very high carbonation, light-medium body, very dry finish.

Overall: This and Duvel are by far the best Belgian Ales that fall on the paler side of the spectrum. Orval is a true original - refreshing and complex.

This is one of my favorite trappist beers. While it has such less alcohol in it (which I like) its so complex. First off, I dont like this beer cold, give me the cellar temperature which doesnt kill the taste as a fridge does. Orval has a huge difference when its older. Even after 1 year it is much better. If you can get your hands on an older one (6m-1year), please do so. Amabassadors from Orval need to provide you with cellar ones and older ones, so just pay those 2 extra or so, its definitely worth it!
As for the taste, its a bitter one, but a very complex bitter one. While bitter IPA style beers are amongs my favourites, this is certainly just another bitter one!
I also tried one from 1989 which wasnt good anymore, i guess 1-5 years is best for this superb beer.

From notes: bottle poured into Chimay glass.  Poured a bubbly orange-amber with a thick, off-white head.  Complex nose- some orangey citrus, biscuity yeast, and a slight spice note as well, possibly a note of honey.  Medium-bodied, but deep, with a slight thickness.  Orangey citrus taste that has some biscuity yeast show in the finish.  As it warmed, the yeast became stronger and a mild spice note, maybe clove, developed.
UPDATED: SEP 6, 2011 33cl bottle, Chimay glass. Pours dark golden with thick head. Smell of citrus and bread. Hints of lemon, flowers, ans hops noticeable. Nice body and ending

En trappist som sticker ut. Drar åt det vinösa, spontanjästa hållet. Syrlig, härlga stallaromer plus citrus. Ändå en beska som biter men som nog snarast kommer från jästen. Fantastiskt gott. Drack den tillsammans med en Mikkeller It´s Alive som kändes som en starkare kopia (vilket den ju också är). Orginalet var minst lika gott.

Uppdatering: drucken igen. En snart tre år gammal flaska. Ännu torrare, komplexare och geuzeliknande. Helt fantastiskt. Om jag bara fick dricka en enda ölsort resten av mitt liv skulle det bli denna.

Pour is a hazy caramel with a rocky sightly off white head. Aroma is fresh flowers with a hint of lemon. Clean laundry, if you can believe that. Taste is a little bit of vanilla, very light and fresh with a champagne body. Dry finish with a hint of lemon on the finish as well. Really refreshing. Now this is the champagne of beers.

It is about time I had this very popular Belgian!  Light floral aroma.  Dark gold pour.  Dry, astringent, fruity, yeasty.  The flavor is not that rich for a Trappist ale.  The aftertaste was irritatingly bitter.  Maybe the bottle was past its prime, or my palate was acting up a little, but I was not that impressed with this stuff.  I will give it another try someday.
Good light belgian/trappist ale with lemon essence in the finish. Of the seven trappist ales this may have the lightest flavor
Bottle pours rich in foam. Brown hazy color. The classic standard for a trappist beer.

Enormous white head that stuck around. This beer is as hoppy as an IPA but much more complex. It has a subtly vinous and lemony aroma. The flavour is slightly tart with hints of cider, citrus rind and grass and a hoppy bite. Its really different from the other trappists Ive tried.

bottled pours the color of dark urine, with a huge off white head. aromas are suble with a little bread, yeast and herb. has a bit of salt to the taste. lightly sour with a crisp fruitiness. medium bodied fizzy. finishes with the crisp acidity on the palate. i enjoyed this the more i drank it. it really grows on you.

Bottled. amber, cloudy, minimal head, 
Aroma really complex. Dont keep the first sensation. Mooth have to learn some minutes but after, shes really interesting.

Pours a reddish brown color with a huge white pillow head that lasts forever. The aroma is amazing and complex. Fruits, bread, and all sorts of yeast funk on the nose. The taste is very nicely balanced. Its got a decent amount of hops and its slightly bitter but the hops are mostly there for flavor and aroma. The taste has raisins and bread and that familiar belgian yeast flavor. Mouthfeel is extremely dry with light carbonation. Very good.

Pours amber with a medium head.  Aroma starts with Belgian yeast, but also citrus and maybe a little cinnamon.  Taste starts out sweet, but with some hop bitterness and a little sour taste in the finish.  Another Trappist classic.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2012 Bottle. 6,2%. Beautiful white high foam. Amber haze.  Good basement notes. Spruce pine earthy aromas as well. Dry with crisp fresh finish.  Fruity slight sour taste banana melon. Oaktree brettt notes. Genuine classic brew. Rerated 23/10-12.

33cl bottle. Not quite the same as having it at the cafe after touring the monastery ruins but will have to do. That being said its stil the same beer. Hazy amber with a huge off-white/light tan head that leaves incredible lacing. An interesting sour/funk aroma, bit of barnyard, grass, some belgian spices, very fresh and light. Well carbonated, somewhat sweet, cinnamon, nutmeg, light but not thin, funk on the finish along with a hint of citrus. There is a lot going on in this beer - worth trying.

Abfülldatum 10.04.2003. Das Bier ist also auf den Tag genau 4 Jahre alt. Das "Schätzchen" entdeckte ich mit einigen anderen bei meinem Getränkehändler. Gut so. 
Heftig schäumt das Bier auf. Man erkennt eine schön goldene Farbe. Im Geruch lambicartige säuerliche Züge mit einer moderaten Holzigkeit. 
Prickelnd der Antrunk. Es folgen heftige Nussaromen im Verein mit gut gesetzter Herbe. Hefiger Übergang zum etwas früh einsetzenden Abgang. Über allem schwebt eine portweinartige Alkoholnote, welche kaum glauben läßt, daß dieses Bier nur 6,2% Alkohol besitzt. 
Herrlich lange gereiftes Bier mit einem breiten Aromaspektrum, das man allerdings mögen muß. Andernfalls ließe sich sagen Orval riecht und schmeckt ziemlich streng. Von mir aber nur gute Noten.Test vom 10.4.2007, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Very very hoppy for a belgian, and also relatively light alcohol level for a belgian.  Champagne bubbles and a lot of them.  very hoppy and golden, light, and super quick, slightly bitter aftertaste thats quick and clean.  Very refreshing.
Pours hazy yellow-brown. String pineapple flavour with lemon. Some mild peppery yeast esters. Tasty

Cerveza con muy buena espuma,toques de levadura salvaje,lúpulo....
compleja, buen final seco.
Cervezaque mejora con el tiempo.he probado envejecidas y están mejor a partir de  un año,De las mejores trapistas!

This has a really interesting aroma slightly reminiscent of a delicious herbal washing-powder.  Doesnt SOUND good, but it works!  Good head, lovely mouthfeel, light.  Right amount of alcohol for several.  Complex flavours abound.  Terrific dry finish.  This is my first choice when I want something reliably good.  Singular and perfect, good young and even better aged.
Lots of ester character in this beer, pineapples and peaches on the nose. lively head and complex body, at first sweet then dry, lemon sources and shortbread sweetness. complex finish.

Bottle. Murky amber pour with a large off white head. Nose is lemon, pepper, yeast, and Brett. Somewhat carbonated palate. Taste is similar to aroma - I still get Brett in here. Flavor definitely changes as it warms.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2012 Bottle from Central Inn @ Gateshead - 220312  2 year old bottle for only £2! - No tasting notes at the time but more cidery aroma and taste..sour notes...complex....I gave the taste a 9....this is really very very good 
Bottle from Peckhams & Rye, Hyndland Bottled 09/06/2011 3 months old Appearance - Very hazy orange/amber, big white rocky head. Aroma - Bready yeast ,citrus, hint of apple, spicy hops, unusual, good aroma. Taste Bread, yeast, peppery spicy hop, citrus, some pleasant sourness / tartness, well-blended, unusual and complex. Palate - Very carbonated champagne feel in the mouth which carries the flavours in the mouth very well and cleans the palate, particularly dry yeasty finish. Light to medium texture and smooth. Dances around in the mouth perfectly. Overall - I did a previous review with an aged beer which was nowhere near as good as this (probably oxidised). Simply a world class beer and so well made. Must try one a year old!
UPDATED: JUN 25, 2013 Re-rate June 25, 2013. Aged a bottle for about 2 years. Great sweet bubblegum aroma, yeast, sweet fruit. Quite a dry taste, almost a touch of rhubarb. Fabulous beverage.
330ml bottle. Cloudy orange colour. Aroma is yeasty. Flavour is yeast and citrus with a little hops.

Orval pours a hazy orange with a magnificent head thatll take some taming. Lots of sweet orange, spice, and lemon zest in the smell.

The taste is very unique. Lots of champagne qualities. Quite sour and a big bitter hop bite at the back end. Theres quite a bit of lemon and pepper in here, too. Most of the flavor is coming from the hops and yeast, as Im not getting much malt here. You wont find many beers with this much carbonation, either.

Exceptionally complex and interesting. Ive never had anything quite like Orval.

Cloudy copper with a large pale head that leaves behind significant lacing. Aroma is of grapefruit with a hint of peach and wood. Taste is an interesting combination of sour and bitter with a hint of sweetness - sour apple and grapefruit a dry finish. An interesting beer but to be honest I prefer the other Trappists.

Reputo questa belgian Ale, la birra diniziazione, ovvero quella che mi ha fatto innamorare perdutamente di questo meravigliosa invenzione. Ricordo la prima volta di aver pensato questa è proprio diversa. Ora penso che come gusto siamo un pò in fase calante, comprata allabbazia e bevuta recentemente però è ancora splendida.

Trappist glass. Pours a rich orange, full of bubbles and a sudsy white head. Lacing was messy, and again very white - adds a nice contrast to the dark orange (hazy) body. Smells light and floral, pleasant hops and spices with a mellow yeasty aroma is very enticing. Initial taste is grapefruit with a well-rounded bitter foreground. The finish is dry and bitter, with a lingering caramel sweetness.This beer is extravagant in that it is very hoppy, yet smooth and dry from the ongoing high carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2015 A very good Belgian Ale and a decent Trappist. Its Aroma contains  nuts, toast and overall Alcohol which with its low percentage of alcohol feels a little strange. Nice red/brownish with great foam.

33 cl bottle, bottled 28/10/2008, BBE 28/10/2013
Aroma has ripe banana and some earthy notes. Sourish flavour has some banana, flower and peppery spices. Foams a lot in mouth. Pretty unusual stuff, very complex and good.

Tasted on 7/21/11 from a 330mL bottle purchased at Lush West Town, bottled on 29/07/2009.  Pours hazy bright orange with a humongously massive and rocky white head that slowly recedes to very thick, frothy lace, leaving a bunch of thick lace along the inside of the glass.  The nose is very interesting with some caramel and bread malt jumping out, along with some spicy hops, and very dry brett funk and a slightly vegetal aroma.  The flavor is, once again, very dry with the maltiness more subdued and taking a back seat to the dry brett funk and spicy hops flavors.  The body is medium with average, lightly stinging, carbonation and a long funky dry brett finish.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 Deep, opaque amber in color with a huge, bone-colored head. The aroma contains huge notes of spices and citrus (grapefruit and orange peel) and also has yeast, a sweet, caramel malt backbone, along with a bit of hop bitterness. The taste is sweet, bitter and sour, with lots of fruits (citrus, mostly, but also some apple, as was pointed out before), malts, yeast, and gentle hopping. It really depends on the age. Very young bottles are boozier, their aroma less balanced, and their body overwhelmingly carbonated. Id go for one with two years, at least..
Bottle @ Malja, Kuopio. Originally rated on 28.5.2009. Great and well balanced belgian ale with a nice finish.

330ml Bottle - Amber/orange with a foamy head. Marmalade,lemon and apples and a hint of spice in the aroma. Hoppy and dry taste with some tart notes and hints of caramel,apple,jam and marmalade. Interesting and like a cross between a pale ale and a lambic. I can see why this beer is appealing to so many beer geeks as it seems to be a rather complex brew.

AROMA: always reminds me of a granny smith apple
APPEARANCE:  golden, but cloudy, pours a large head that quickly turns into a consistent thing layer
TASTE: lightly bitter,  medium to heavy sourness
PALATE: full body, slick feel, lively, long aftertaste with great balance in bitterness and a bit of sweetness left in the mouth
OVERALL: one of my favourite trappist beers, this one really stands out with its own character

Bottle. An orange-brown colour with a large tanned head. An aroma of yeast, fruit, herbs and citrus. The taste is light sweet and has a bitter finish. A medium body and avarage carbonation. A favorite among beers
Clear orange vast rocky white head. Fresh hoppy smell. Nice bitter taste. Ok body, good carbo for 6.2% ABV.
Aroma of wheat, lemon and a bit of banana.  Pours thick and orange with a big fluffy head.  Tastes of wheat, pilsner malts and a little roast nuts.  No alcohol whatsoever.  This is an easy drink.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2012 Young bottle at North Bar, Leeds. Pours a deep amber with a big head with lots of retention. Wonderful aroma, fruity, Belgian yeast, almost banana like at points, along with the tropical citrus and perfume. Taste is brilliant, sweetness and fruitiness brilliantly mixes with the bitter hops, citrus taste is preserved. Lovely. Extremely dry, even in mouth before the finish. A touch of breadiness on the finish tops off this brilliant beer. Look forward to trying an older bottle. Highly recommended.

For as many times as Ive had this, I just assumed I had reviewed it at some point. Alas, I have not and now is the time. Poured into a snifter. Bottled 01/06/2010, about a year and a half old.

4.5 A: Plenty of carbonation in this one. The first pour yielded 80% head. Hazed medium orange color. Second pour gave me a full glass. Three fingers of pillowy white head with excellent retention. Rather than just lacing, there are gobs of head permanently stuck to the sides of the glass. 

5.0 S: Wonderful! Loads of funk in here: horse blanket, musty basement, and old socks. Peppery spiciness, perhaps a touch of clove, lemongrass, old hay, peach, and wild apple. 

5.0 T: Again, wonderful! Barnyard funk, horse blanket, dank wet basement, and wet hay. Below that is pepper, clove, and tumeric spiciness. Mega earthy overall. Hints of what were grassy and earthy hops. Peach fruitiness again with crab apple. Sweet in the middle and drying on finish. 

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. A bit too much carbonation, but it is happily very spritzy and super smooth. 

5.0 D: Ive yet to have a bottle of this at any age that wasnt good, but it seems like 1.5 years is a pretty good place for it. Lots of funk without any hints of being "stale" or whatever you want to call it. Probably the best single out there.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-14-2011 20:49:00

UPDATED: APR 5, 2013 Rerate during Orval appreciation day(s) 2013. Bottle @ home. Slightly hazy orange colour with a big white head. Smells sweet, very fruity, herbs, cinnamon, nice. Tastes malts, sweetish, cinnamon, herbs, very fruity. Great balance, medium body. Quite a lot of carbo, but not too much.
Hazy dark golden with a solid white head - aroma is of malts and spicy belgian yeast - taste is oslo the same with malts, yeast and perhaps hints of citrus - good, but was expecting a little more

33 cl bottle from Passione Birra. Beautiful sunrise orange colour whit a big white, non persistent fluffy head. Very fruity aroma. Just the perfect carbonation make this beer one of the easiest drinkable ever. Such a lovely one.

Bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Pours a golden orange with a thick beige head with large bubbles, also slightly cloudy.  Aromas of fruit like peach and banana, but hops are present to keep it smelling balanced, also a little spice.  Taste is dry and hoppy, but with fruit notes.  Very tasty brew.  Classic!

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 Bottle.  Pours murky copper with huge foamy head that takes forever to go away.  My first sense on the nose was lemon followed by yeast, orange, sweet candy.  Taste is an awesome balance of sweet & spicy with a very slight bitterness.  Slightly dry finish.  Simple yet delicious.
A realy complex beer with a little acidic taste and a good balance between bitterness and sweetness.

Deep orange and cloudy in appearance with a thick white head. Begins with a bubbly bite followed by a surge of fruitiness and then descends into a delightfully sour and dry finale. Orvals sour flavor characteristic is quite prominent and perhaps unusual, but makes for a very interesting experience.

Served out of a bottle into snifter. Pours an unclear muddy yellow orange with a large slightly off white head. Smell of belgian funkiness, hay, and sweetness. Tastes much the same with a good bit of sweet and bitter citrus notes, tangerine like and some light tartness. I caught some subtle berry flavors too, maybe from the yeast, like raspberry but not quite.  Has a fairly prominent sugary profile with loads of carbonation. Funky yeast and a dry hoppy finish linger for a long time, like dry cut grass and dry hay with the yeast sticking to it. Great to sip or tip back this lives up to being a great belgian beer.

Served at Beer bistro. Pours brown/yellow in colour. Aromas are spiced fruit, orange flint, sweet brown sugar. Tastes surprisingly fruity and has a never ending finish. kind of tart.An interesting brew but it was served a little bit too cold.

Hazy orange colour, thick white rocky, long lasting head. Acidic fruity flavour. Great maltyness. Somewhat sour, not as a geuze but it kind of reminds me of one. Some hints of peach/orange in finish. Refreshing.
herbs, cough drop, orangepeel, golden, hazy, frothy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, fizzy,
The second time Ive had this and it lived up to the great memory.  A kind of initial floral perfume thats taken over by subtle bitterness. Drank in a 33 cl bottle in Taiwan.

Bottle (rating a fresh one).  Vibrant hazy orange thats quite bright, ever-so slightly off-white head.  Lots of nice hopppiness in the aroma, and I always love the juxtaposition of the yeastiness, fruity and funky aspects of the aroma.  Touch of funk and earth, yeasty, nicely acidic and hoppy.  Bone-dry finish, medium with sparkly carbonation.  Yes, Im an Orval fan and I dont mind admitting that :).

Very sour and dry, like champagne.  This one is a very unique Trappist given the sourness.  It reminded me a bit of some of the geuzes ive had.  It has a bit of a fruity flavor as well, like sour apples.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2013 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a hazy orange with a large, very bubbly white head. A sweet and sour funk fest on the nose. Lots of belgian yeast, citrus and spices are present. Loads and loads of spice in this one. Coriander and ginger the most prominant ones. Starts sweet and finishes sour and slightly tarty. Fantastic beer
UPDATED: JUL 28, 2014 Bottle at De Paas.  Golden with large white head.  A very different Trappist beer due to its slight sourness

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2011 Bottle @ home. Very cloudy, slightly brown, orange appearance with a fluffy orange/ivory head. Slightly sour, funky, sweet, Belgian yeasty, citrus fruity nose. Mildly funky and sour, citrus fruity, dry, yeasty, floral, bretty flavor. Finishes dry, lightly sour, fruity, and funky. Very nice brew!
Pours hazy, golden-amber with thick white head.  Typical Belgium flavor (excellent) Good balance, complexity, and carbonation mix.   Dry finish.  A must try for all beer drinkers!
look good, smell good, but something is missing when you taste the beer, however it is a really good beer to try.

Pours a hazy amber into a Gulden Draak goblet with a MASSIVE 4 finger head.  Aroma is sour funky french oak barrel, brettanomyces, citrus peel, and some mild grain lurking in there somewhere.  Taste is wild yeast funk, barely detectable caramel sweetness and a lasting funky, grainy finish.  Body is initially sticky but high carbonation leads to an immaculate dry finish.  I have never had anything quite like this beer-- the bartender told me this brewery only makes one beer because thats all it really needs to make.  I agree. This is a beverage of such sophistication and refinement that I believe that I am not even capable of appreciating it to the degree it deserves.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Bottle in Belgo Centraal, London. Pours tawny amber with big foamy white head. Aroma is amazing. A lovely fragrant sugary sherbet aroma with light hoppy fruits: apple, berries, and then some spice. Taste isnt quite as strong but theres some nice fruit notes, with cinnamon spice. Surprisingly light and hoppy for a Trappist beer.

Bottle. Two years old. Pours golden with a long lasting white head. Bretty nose with a hint of pineapple. High carbonation with champagne-like sparkling. Dry mouthfeel with a bit of tartness. Some complex fruity aromas and hop-bitterness but no sweetness. Number one within the style.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2013 33 cl, bottled. Pours slightly hazy orange with a beautiful, long-lasting irregular white head. Aroma: Sour apple, apple pie, berries, malt, clove. Taste: Moderate sweetness (citric sweet), amusing sourness and pleasant bitterness. Vanilla and pepper. Palate: Medium body, average carbonation. Dry. Overall: Lovely stuff. This is the beer that I would take to an isolated island. Its like a new awesome beer every time :)

Bottled 20.4.2010. Cloudy, dark amber with a huge, pillowy, white head. Aroma is clove, perfume-like sour apple, dried apricot, fermented apple. Taste is sour with hints of cloves. Theres also apple, a lot of cereal maltiness and dry. Palate is light, perhaps even a bit watery.
Do not over chill this ale!! Best served at a nice cool cellar temperature between 50-54 f!!  nicely hopped and velvety with a nice dry finish with  aromas of spruce, chocolate,  caramel, and coffee.

Pours an opaque, dark tan, full of sediment and tiny bubbles and monk-like secrecy.  The head is a sight to behold, huge and hearty and nigh-impenetrable.  Smells like apples and red wine and oak barrels and earth.  Nice opening act, Orval.  The taste smacks you with yeasty tartness that mimics red wine, only to fade into the soothing warmth of a dunkelweizen.  Finishes like a slice of fruitcake. Bubbly yet smooth, this beer lives up to its kudos.  Delicious.  (2/21/09)

This one has it all. Trappist beers are a personal favourite of mine but still.. wow. When you look at the bottle with its distinguished shape and the glass that almost winks at you. Be careful not to cool the Orval down to fridge temperature. When I drank it it was chilled to the bone and that wasnt doing the Orval much good. After warming it with my hands it evolved into a whole different beer. It has aromas of candy sugar that gives it a royal sweetness, followed by a tasty hopbitternes finish. Again, this beer is best enjoyed just below room temperature and really not on fridge temperature. So store it in the cellar, the attic or the garden shed or whatever. Good one!"

Bottle. Well, finally tried it. Pours hazy gold with a big white head. Aroma is soapy/cheesy hops, spicy brett, fruity notes. Flavor is dusty, brett spiciness, more soapy hops. Palate is bitter, high carbonation, somewhat astringent.

A surprisingly long-lasting fizz is heard when I remove the cap from the beautiful bottle, and when carefully pouring the dark amber beer into my trappist chalice I understand why: this is one aggressively carbonated brew! An enormous, creamy, off-white head builds up extremely quickly, and I need to take several breaks in order to fit all of the beer into the glass. Initially the body looked rather clear, but I guess the long pouring process and the high carbonation caused some sediments to be whirled up, so the beer ended up looking rather cloudy. The aroma is amazing and very unusual (at least to me): hoppy with flowers, pine and apple, along with dark spices, wine and oak. Light sweet and light bitter taste with a light to moderate bitter finish. The flavour is dominated by the dark parts of the aroma: oak, fermented apples and leather. Medium body with a very dry texture, and the carbonation ends up as rather average. The dryness and the oak and fermented apples actually reminds me of a brut nature champagne Great stuff, although not at the very top, but I suspect this will grow on me on time. So, Orval, are you ready for a re-rating in a few months time? 
[33 cl bottle, from Vinmonopolet, Vika, Oslo]

Very fine head, high and lasting, grey yellow.
dark spiced nose. Brett?
Medium body and some length,
sweetness but also some wellbalanced bitterness. Dried fruits, fruitcake.
Now this is a very drinkable Trappist beer. Taste is light, very floral, slight caramel notes.

A cloudy orange beer with an amazing offwhite head. Aroma is sweet citrus fruit and some spices. Taste is also sweet orange and other citrus fruits with underlining spices like cinnamon. There is a beautifully pronounced bitter finish with some sourness. Fantastic!

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2011 fantastica birra!ma chi dice che non è cosi facile da bere!!forse per uno che prende in mano per la prima volta una birra puo trovare fastidioso il delizioso amaro !
color arancione grande testa bianca di grande allacciatura ,scompare in media durata ma rimane sempre una velatura cremosa sopra
odori vinosi ,arancio e luppolo
in bocca lamaro si fa subito sentire ma ottimamente bilanciato dal malto e dai caratteristici lieviti.finale lungo lungo lungoooo

potent head and strong hoppy aroma with a little bit of sweetness in the aftertaste. nutty brown colour and cloudy because of the bottle fermentation. little more dry. great with some cheese and barbequed red meat (at least i drank it with that and it was awesome). full body and bitter finish. one of the best trappist

[330ml bottle, Brasserie dOrval, Belgium] The Queen of trappist beers pours nut brown with an enormous fluffy peaked white head. Looks extremely regal  aromas of spice and coriander, sweetness from the sugar. Lovely bitterness on the palate, the spices compliment this perfectly. Hops in there as well, not too much alcohol  its one of the most sessionable 6%+ beers around. The finish is bitter and slightly sour. Classically different from the other Trappist houses because of this, the rich sweetness is paired down. Awesome stuff, just a fabulously complex beer [18082010]

33cl bottle. Pours an autumnal orangey-brown with steady bubbles and a very large head. The nose is distinctly hoppy like an IPA - pine and grapefruit pith. The taste is of more zingy pine and grapefruit which is rounded off with a yoghurt zing at the end. The palate has medium structure, a creamy texture and a zingy finish. Overall, this is a great example of hops and yeast combining, though it is definitely not a sessoin beer.

Caramel-like in appearance with a huge bubbly head that left a ton of lacing. Yeasty nose with more spice than fruity tones also noted some leather. Taste is surprisingly un-sweet for a beer with candi sugar added. Its good but not great. I have tried this beer on many different occasions and I just dont get the hype that it receives.

delicate aroma of tart citrus, yeast, bread, hay, raspberries, and a distinct barn-funk.
pours a hazy light amber tops with tons of fine eggshell froth.
mild flavor is a balance of slight sweetness, sourness, and bitterness. medium body, high carbonation, dry and slightly astringent.

Hazy amber orange pour decent sticky lacing off white head .... aroma of lemon and sweet fruits .... taste is fruity yeast lemony with light sour notes and a light bitter and floral hop a smooth brew dry malty and fruity finish ... not the best trappist but excellent and smooth

Bottle into Tulip. High carbonation, like a soda. Nice aroma of fruits and some hop. Flavor was similar with nice dark fruits and a refreshing nature. Had this one a couple times with a nice turkey sandwich which paired incredibly well.

(11.2oz bottle-bottled 5.19.2010).  Pours a hazy apricot color with a chunky white head and active carbonation.    Nice lacing.    The beer is almost one year old and seems to have lost its hop aroma.  Im mostly getting some sour, funkiness with some berries.  Taste is tart-not quite sour-but the hops are there, albeit faint.  Medium bodied with creamy texture.  Finish is bitter and dry.  My tastes have changed a great deal since I last had an orval and I like it much more now.  Its taken a loooong time for me to get into sour (or sourish) beers.

Bottle. Medium gold color with white head. Wonderfully complex sour nose, especially as it warms, of citrus, cherries, yeasty bread, clove spice, and an overall astringent sour funkiness. Flavor follows, though is a little sweeter and maltier than I expected from the aroma. Dry and tart throughout, especially in the finish. Fantastic stuff, glad it lived up to the hype.

Hazy golden with foamy, over the top head.  

Complex and rich aroma.  Sour bread and white wine scent in it.

Wonderfully complex taste as well.  Bready, spiced pears, flowers.  Sharp edge from the carbonation and maybe an herbal hop.  Wonderful.  Refreshing and fulfilling.

Bottle. Outstanding. It took a while to check this beer off my list. Definitely an original beer. The head is white and thick. You could probably float a brick on it. Beautiful lacing on the glass. Aroma has that funk that is so welcome in a great Belgian. Taste is well balanced, with great floral hop flavor. Great beer.
Bière blanche de 6.9 % dalcool. Elle possède un genre de goût de savon. Arrière-goût bizarre. Léger goût dagrume, surtout de citron. Bonne froide, mais un coup réchauffé ça se gâte.

Cloudy amber pour with an immense rocky light tan head.  Interesting hard tp plave aroma.  Smells similar to many sour beers Ive had.  Medium bodied mouthfeel with ample carbonation.  Wonderful complex but subtle flavors with a dry finish.  A unique and interesting beer.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2013 Appearance: Bottle into a Westmalle Trappist glass. Pours a cloudy golden orange with the biggest, most dense head Ive ever seen from a beer, leaving intricate lacing on the glass and quite the longevity. The head is a multitude of colors...some off-white pinkish/yellowish/goldish colors.

Aroma: VERY sweet, STRONG creamy scents of vanilla, overripe banana, and lingering strawberry. Scent of hops and the slightest tinge of booze. My brother remarked that it smelled exactly like wine. This one is very fruity smelling. Quite a sour whack in it too, much like a lambic.

Taste: Vanilla, candi sugar, caramel and a very oaky flavour. Quite hoppy for a Trappist.

Palate: Light, dances around the mouth without a care and has a creaminess to it, which is kinda weird. Strong bitter aftertaste.

Overall: Awesome beer, and quite unique. Like the rest of the Trappists, its nothing short of amazing.

Pours a three-finger white head that takes forever to fade leaving a good lace.  Hazy amber color. Strong carbonation and medium bodied.  Nose is tart and woody, flavor is tart fruit with a lingering tart aftertaste, only an OK Trappist ale.   Pricey at $5.99 for a 330ml bottle from Kappys Fine Wine & Spirits Peabody, Ma. Bottled on 4/22/2010.
Pours cloudy brown, big lasting white head. Malty taste, slightly citrus/sour. Some noticable bitterness. Short finish. Palate is carbonated and dry. Overall an OK ale.

0,33 l. bottle - yes, surprise: The iconic bottle. From Vinbørsen, Copenhagen. Poured into a trappist glass. Orange-brown colour with a massive, white head that slowly shrinks. This is one of the most complex beers, I´ve ever stuck my nose in: Yeast is present, but also sweet fruits like apricot and raisins, only weak hop aromas. The aroma is very powerfull. Medium sourness in taste, but also some saltyness!  Light body, but long lasting finish. This beer has a lot of followers, and no wonder: There is something mythical about it, every time you taste it, the beer brings something new to your senses. Given the taste, the history and the complexity of this beer, Orval deserves a high "overall" rating. I will be returning to this beer again...

Bright orange brown with an impressing white, pillowy head with good retention and nice lacing on the side of the trappist glass. Complex spicy aroma, fruits, yeast, hops, only slight sweets. Orange, dark fruits, apple, cardamom, liquorice, even some anise. Flavour does right to the complexity of the aroma. Slightly sweet, but balanced with a good hop bitterness and a slight sour twang. Citric notes, spices, cinnamon, cardamom, and more fight for attention. Strong bitter finish. Great trappist.
(from 33cL bottle)

Poured out of the classic bottle into a Trappist glass. Pours bright orange with a HUGE off-white, pillowy head! Thats got to be the frothiest head Ive ever seen!!! Aroma is grapefruity, peppery, with a nice hoppy zest to it. Flavor is much of the same with a nice mix between the bitterness and the sweetness. I can definitely sense that Brett funk too, but it works. Mouthfeel is pretty thin and dry, but the flavor makes up for it. Overall, not the best of the Belgian Trappist brews and not an everyday drinker for me, but certainly worth trying! Id like to let this sit in the cellar for a while and revisit it sometime!

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2012 When I first tried this beer I did not remotely understand what the attraction to it was. I took my second bottle, which I mostly despised, put it in my cellar, and left if there to sit for over a year. In a minor cellar vetting, I decided to drink that bottle to free up some space. Well, this beer is a whole different story to me now. I do get it. Pours golden color, massive, lasting head, sweet aroma of peaches, and spice. Flavor is Belgian pale, with a very nice balance of malt and hops. Relatively dry to my palate; I find nothing sweet about this beer. Has a lingering bitterness that is not aggressive at all. Overall taste seems refreshing, crisp, spicy, slightly hoppy. Very easy to drink. Its won me over, and I could see me learning to like this even more down the road.
che dire? forse x i miei gusti troppo frizzantina,ma come lega lolfatto al palato,è strabiliante,fantastico lamaro che lascia in bocca anche dopo aver finito di bere....

bottled on 19/5/2010, aroma is grapefruity with some fresh hops in there as well first taste is grapefruity, then goes to a slight sour sweet bitter blend, that is very reminiscent of a saison, overall pretty good beer, gotta make sure you mix up the yeast on the bottom, or it is rather bland

Poured from the classic bowling pin bottle into a tiny plastic stein at Brew Fest in Athens, GA. Clearly, this was not the ideal way to sample a classic ale, and the experienced suffered for it. This came off as too frothy, too peppery, and too thin to live up to its legend. In fact, it probably only seemed that way by comparison with the tripels, dipas, and other delights alongside which I drank it. I must return to this at some point when my palate is fresher to evaluate it more fairly.

11 April 2011, bottle. med orange and very hazy, like metamucil. gorgeous nose! really tart cherries, sharp yeast and alcohol. very distinct. med/full body and moderately fizzy with a noticeable wateriness. i have to say, i expected more from the nose. it doesnt taste very sour, nor is there much alcohol in the flavour. there is an earthy yeastiness with a bitter, nutty finish. i was expecting sweet and yeasty. decent.
roasty, grass, leaves, golden, brown, clear, minimal head, medium bitterness, medium body, thin feel, lively, bitter, clean and abrupt finish. Outstanding ale!!

I cant praise this beer enough.  Incredibly dry due to bottling with Brettanomyces.  Wonderful earthy, citrusy hop aromas combine with the citrus and barnyard yeast notes.  The taste is more of the same with the dryness lifting the citrus and bitter hop flavor up off the palate, making this beer refreshing despite the ABV.  I would love to taste some of these 3-5 years after bottling.

Excellent strong and lively trapist. The taste of hops blends with the yeast you can see still working a nice combination of bitternes and acidity. Best for finishing a beer tasting.  Always ask for an original Orval glass.

Shared bottle courtesy of tarjei. Clear golden with a flufffy, tanned head.
Spicy, berries brett aroma. Acidic, light bitter and a hint of sweetness. Heavy carbonation. Medium body. Dry mouth.

Hazy-ish light amber with a generously big, albeit sloppy head.  Aroma is strange and curious.  A mix of orange peel, sour cherries, zinfindel, and gentle peppery hop.  Maybe some lemon juice as well.  Taste is not sour at all, to my surprise.  Nose smelled kinda sour.  Flavor is somewhat fleeting.  Medium bodied but with a finish that leaves nothing behind.  It all happens so fast.  Some pepper, some yeast, some sourness, some caramel.  Its all so balanced that nothing really stands out too much.  But pretty citrusy.  Much too dry of a finish, like a white wine.  Not bad in of itself, but not my kinda thing, and certainly not what I expected from such a highly rated brew.
Bottle.  With over 2600 ratings you should know this beer by now.  If you dont, best hop in the old car head down to your nearest liquor store and pick one up.....

**100th Rating! Woohoo!** Bottle.  My one hundredth review, so I figured Id grab a beer Ive always wanted to try. And oh wow!  Heres a beer for ya!  Pours hazy with an amazing head.  Aroma of spice and flowers.  Needs to be said just how wonderful the aroma is.  Ive been whiffing it for a while now and just loving it, but alas it needs to be drank!  Has a sour, bitter taste to it.  Citrus and some caramel in there. Yeasty, somewhat peppery.  The spices here are absolutely wonderful and perfectly blended in...nothing to me sticks out so much, it all just seems perfectly balanced to create this unique flavor.  If it had anything that was overly obvious it would be the mostly sour tone that just kinda envelops your tongue...first few sips I was taken back by it, not in a good/bad way I guess, just...more surprised than anything!  I wish I was a bit better with words, or could quite place what Im tasting because it definitely reminds me of so many things, but I cant quite put them down right now.  Ill update this if it comes to me.  All in all, this is one of my absolute favorite beers Ive had; and I mean ever.  A bit prohibitively priced around here (5 bucks a bottle - Im seeing people say this is the ultimate session beer and I suppose Id agree in *theory*, but theres no way in hell Im buying a bottle of this unless its a special occasion, ha!), but otherwise I have nearly nothing bad to say about this beer.  World class.  6.9% alcohol (says 6.2% on here, bottle claims 6.9% so Ill go with that).
Just under a year old. Big bubblegum aroma. Taste is light and refreshing with fruity tang and dull hops. Quite a nice beer. Has qualities of a saison.

Hazy chestnut pour with thick, stubborn beige head. High carbonation. Very complex nose: sour lemon, barnyard, some biscuity malt. Flavors of leather, sour lemon or cherry (complex), a little bit of baking spice (likely from yeast), hay/ straw, dusty - I would to try this beer in a fresher condition. The sour character fades with warmth and the classic Euro hops come out to play in both the flavor and the aroma. Very dry, quite bitter finish. This is one complex beer - have had it twice now and am still trying to get my head around it.

Re-rate on Orval Appreciation Day 2011. Hazy orange golden with a big and fluffy head if poured right. This head disappears a bit quickly though. The aroma never gets boring. Grass, grapefruit, fresh wood, leather, barnyard, spice notes and herbal notes. Deliciously dry and bitter, with complex flavour notes of fruit, herbs and funk.  The one I had today also had a bit of caramel sweetness. Nice touch.

Slightly hazy, medium amber, big white head. Spicy, malty nose, lots of hops and brett, earth, barnyard, lemon peel, dried fruits. Dry, medium bodied, medium to hig bitterness, lively carbonation. Malty, spicy, hoppy taste, a distinguished acidic brett note, earth, dried fruits, hay. Long, tart, bitter finish. Complex. (2011-02-21)

bottle-bottled on 9/2008 and consumed 3/2011; very hazy brown on lees with large tan head; aroma-yeast, alcohol, caramel, herbal ; taste-light sweetness , medium bitterness with heavy carbonation, diluted finish.
