I wasnt that impressed-but I think I might need a fresher batch as I really wasnt impressed with the hops presence.

Bottle at Patricks. Pours cloudy amber with offwhite head. Aroma, in this particular example, was a mix of the belgian yeast and basement with some american hops thrown in for good measure. Light sweet, light bitter, very light sour. Medium body, thin, lively carbonation. 20110310

Always a favorite, looking forward to my next meeting with this one.
Brewed by monks. Awsome light beer. I love it. Light overall beer. Great taste

Bottle to chalice (Re-rate, will have to go back to the backlog to see how this one compares).  Hazy dark yellow burnt caramel pour with a ton of head that takes a good while to fade.  Leaves a 1cm creamy froth on the top, with very nice lacing.  Nice looking beer.  Aroma is citrus, a touch of grass, some hay, floral and citrus hops.  Light sweet malt.  A touch of tartness and light barnyard funk.  Nice and complex without being overpowering.  Flavor is not nearly so complex.  Sweetish malts, a slug of yeast (complete with standard Belgian fusels and esters), a tiny bit of tartness and funk, with some floral hops on the very back end.  Mouthfeel is quite creamy.  This is a good beer, though I wish it was either full on sour or none at all.  The hint of tartness just makes me want more, and that is where the beer suffers.

Cloudy straw colored pour. Ginormous head with huge lacing. Smells like applesauce. Including the cinnamon. Needless to say it is spicy. Big carbonation thinning out the mouthfeel. Sweet and bitter taste. Decent beer but a bit on the dry side. Which is to be expected, but still.

Had before but never rated. Though I am told this one changes depending on what year it is. Bought in the iconic orval bowling pin bottle.  bottled on Nov. 17th 2010. 6.9%abv. Super hazy dark yellow color to being almost brown. Big fluffy head that took a lot of patients to let settle. but left heavy lace.  First sense of aroma was candy sugar with some spice and pine behind that. Also maybe a little funky sweat smell in there. Taste is perfume and bitter with bitterness increasing int he finish greatly.

What can I say that has not already been said about this wonder of a beer: Orval is a beer in constant change: The one I drank yesterday was quite different from the one I drank two weeks ago: Yesterday  the hoppy bitterness was pulled into the background in favor of the sour but subtle funky brett  tones. The brew-date was almost eighteen months ago. If younger it is more often the attractive hoppy pine-tones that first hits the nose and the mouth. An extremely complex, lively and refreshing beer with a dry and very long tart-bitter aftertaste, that fills your mouth completely.
This beer has an aroma that reminds me of mens showergel, in a good way and has a sweet taste to it

This is the best smelling beer I have encountered to date.  Aroma is a combination of the best American Imperial IPA you have ever smelled and the best Flemish Sour you have ever smelled.  It is pure winning.  The flavor is incredibly hoppy, and its a nice dry, piney hoppiness.  Like a really heavily hopped Bohemian Pilsner.  There is also a subdued sweet malt presence throughout.  The sour brett characteristics come in after the initial hoppy punch.  There are sour, funky, farmhousey flavors, lots of orange and even a little grapefruit.  This is an incredibly complex beer.  The finish is War and Peace long and every bit as complex as the initial flavors of the beer.  The very lively, heavily carbonated mouthfeel adds to the complexity and the sheer circumstance of this beer.  This is one of the best beers on the planet.

The body is a cloudy orange brown color with a light tan head with very fine bubbles. The head retention is excellent, maintaining substantially throughout the experience.

The smell is of oranges, earth, and spicy goodness.

This beer is extremely creamy, with well attenuated pale malts, and vaguely soapy hops moving into leathery brett funk (moldy, but in a good way!). Rounding out the end is lingering funk and tannic astringency. The tongue is slightly warmed by alcohol alongside the aftertaste, which sticks around practically forever.

Ive heard Orval derives its complexity from the Brett yeast used at bottling, and its no joke. It really does add a new layer to something that might otherwise be just good.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2014 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: there is probably no other beer like Orval, it is hard to compare it to anything else, it is a Belgian Ale made with bretts, cannot think of any other beers that fit that description, completely different from the other trappists, sweet up front with spice, orange, lemon, yeast, hop, cinnamon, followed by a slightly sour, brett finish, dry, tart, bitter & acidic in the end but no extremes, everything is exceptionally balanced, you either love it or you wont get what just happened /// upped score again from 4.6 to 4.8 - this might be the most brilliant beer out there. Tried it many different ages, I like this as fresh the most. Brilliant hop profile on it when fresh, earthy, touch blue cheese, almost Sorachi Ace-like blended with brett. You could almost pass it of for an IPA, it combines just so many different styles it seems - it is completely in a league of its own. Couple of months old it has leaves, earthy notes in the profile. Begins thinning out latter on, brett cleaning up once 1.5 + exchanging it with light oxidation notes. 2007 vintage - 5 years old, noticeable oxidation, light funk, near tang, peal, very clean, light, almost geuze-like notes, very clean, light, tad too much oxidation becomes apparent for me but still very good. // keep drinking this regularily // changed score to 5 because it is freaking Orval ///////////////////////////// //////////////////// Decided to review this one again. 4 bottles @ home. 38 days old. Pours a bright dark textbook amber maybe a touch less dark than usually with a huge collapsing bubbly off-white head, gorgeous. Nose is full of those lovely cheesy Orval hops, candied orange peel, faint pine resin with a lovely sweet candy sugar background, cookies and sweet malts. Tastes slightly more alcoholic than usual with lots of the same lovely cheese / hops, candy sugar, sweet cookies, sweet malty background, faint green olive, light herbs, cinnamon, sweet white bread, Chinese pasty, more ornage peel, slightly biter. Thick, chewy mouthfeel but this one isnt as thick as Orval often is. Sooo good. Only beer that I session. I have been know to drink a lot of lambiek as well.

Bottle at Laundromat. Lovely light pale color, foamy white fingerthick head. 
Spicy aroma with citrus, honey, cream, sulfur? Dry taste with fruit, apples, citrus, some candy. Good body.

Tämä yksilö on ehtinyt kypsyä vuoden verran pullotuksesta. Orval on väriltään tumman amber ja omaa erittäin runsaan ja valkoisen saippuamaisen vaahdon. Oluen tuoksussa on mausteisuutta, hivaa ja hedelmäisyyttä. Maultaan Orval on mausteinen, hiivainen, hedelmäinen ja hieman katkera. Kuivahko ja suuntuntumaltaan miellyttävä olut.

Bottle 330 ml. Cloudy dark golden pour with a big off white head, of long duration. Aroma of banana and yeast. The taste seems slightly bitter with hints of citrus. The aftertaste is slightly bitter with notes of yeast.

Bouteille 330 mL (5) - Belle couleur orangée avec une montagne de mousse qui se dissipe peu à peu. Goût dépices dans un beau corps quelque peu sucré. Bonne amertume en finale. Bière spéciale que je conseille à tout le monde.

Banana, hop, and yeast aromas. Lightly smooth palate with a dry crisp finish. Flavors of bread, yeast, hops, banana, and citrus. Very drinkable beer that would pair well with many different types of food.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2013 Bottled on 03/02/2011, served in a Westvleteren chalice. Pours clear orange-amber, with a massive foamy off-white head. The nose is over-ripe banana, dried pineapple, fig, nutmeg, fruit cake and more subtle notes of grass and hay. The taste is barnyard, hay, grass, leaf, tart citrus fruit (tangerine, peach, grapefruit, lemon pith), saltiness, brett definitely evident and lingering alcohol warmth, with a bitter-dry finish. Med-full body, mod carbonation and voluptuous mouth-feel. Really nice mouth-puckering tartness to it. Complex, yet still subtle and classy.
Excellent beer to make a beef stew with. I... dont care much to drink it. Oh well.

Orange/copper and cloudy with a huge head. Nose had yeast, fruit, Brett...cherry pie. Taste had a soft malt character, it was fruity but with a firm bitterness. An old enough bottle to have hips missing/a little oxidation, but young enough to keep the Brett character minimal.

0.33l bottle. Orval pours a semi clear dark orange body with a massive neverending fluffy and beautiful white head leaving big lacings. Fantastic nose with hops, chocolate-like notes, peach, some spices I cant figure out, citrus and yeast. Tastes are quite similar to the nose, medium bodied silky and smooth body with medium carbonation giving first off hints of alcohol then it glides over in to different parts: first a fruity refreshing flavor before the malt balanced the whole thing, then it ends in a dry, bitter, yeasty and flowerish finish. Beautiful in many ways.

11.2 oz bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours with a very big, light, and fluffy which is very slow to dissipate; it has a orange-brown color which is hazy/thick in appearance.  The aroma was extremely pleasing with hints of sweetness and fruit.  The palate was deceptively lighter/thinner than it appears and smells it would be; it has a fresh and sprite feel to it and is dry.  The taste was light and lively with hints of fruit (orange), but once again, it is deceptive compared to its aroma and appearance - almost to the point of feeling like I was tricked, but I dont mind because of the fresh taste with the hints of fruitiness. There is a slight bitter finish and the taste is very dry - almost too dry for me, I feel like I am missing out on some flavor, like it should be there but isnt.  I enjoyed the beer; the dryness was intriguing and an enjoyable change of pace at first, but the novelty wears off with each sip. Definitely worth a try.
Bottle 33cl to trappist glass.  Almost blond, lighter than other trappist beers.  Moderately hoppy aroma.  Beautiful foam, which clears quickly.  Initially light taste, but intense dry aftertaste.

Poured into trappist glass from bottle.  Golden orange with a fluffy, thick white head.  Smells sweet and citrus, with some doughy undernotes.  Taste is the same - sweet, citrus, a bit of doughy bread.  Finishes a bit bitter and very dry.  Not overly thick.  Med/high carbonation.  Very good, but a bit behind other trappists brews.

poured into tulip glass for tasting. upon uncapping the bottle, the tremendous volume of co2 rolled out with a swoosh. slowly poured into my tulip( I have heard reports of aggressive pours making 5+ finger heads). pours a beautiful dark golden orange color with hoppy notes and brett in the aroma. taste is very balanced malt to hop profile, leaning more toward the maltier side of the equation. no attributed extreme sour character from the brett, very well accented. the lingering palate left on the tongue is semi-dry, and a slight bit tart as well. second trappist product ever consumed.
Golden blond pour with frothy white head. Fairly intense fruity, floral, grassy aroma up front that leaves a somewhat sour aftertaste.

Appearance:  hazy butterscotch, very small head.  Aroma:  bitter and floral.  Taste:  slightly sweet maltiness with piney/floral hops, hint of peppery spice.  Finish:  lingering, medium bitter/floral hops.  Notes:  A little too bitter for my taste, but nice with a whole-grain baguette.
Hazy orange brown with a wonderful and huge head. Aroma is spicy. Flavor is very bitter and speciel from there yeast.
Holy apples batman, this is one fruity beer, i really like it but i can see why some dont. Very fruit nose and body almost to point of taking away from being a beer
Yellow/orange colour with strong head. Complex citrus aroma. Heavy bitterness. Fruity, citric taste. An excellent beer.
Boisson belge de tradition, elle rentre selon moi dans le top mondial, et est une vraie découverte! La preuve que le Val dOr a du potentiel :)
Another beer in Belgium I was shocked I had yet to rate.  Pours hazy orange with a off white head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast and fruit.  Nice sweet flavor and a solid beer.

11.2oz Bottle. Trappist Glass. Chilled. Pours a cloudy golden amber color. Fluffy long lasting off-white head. Aroma of floral hop, citrus, orange peel, clove. Taste of spice, bready malts, clove. Lively, smooth palate. A medium body. A very delicious beer. It looks and tastes great. Dry character, which I like. Well balanced. I would certainly drink again.
Orangy-brown pour with nice foamy white head. Aroma si citrus hops, sweet yeast, and slightly sour. Crisp, slightly bitter taste. Hoppy. Good but not as amazing as it was hyped.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2014 Pours a slight hazy amber/orange with a big lasting off-white head. Aroma is kinda hoppy with grass, subtle belgian fruityness, brett, herbs, hay, dryness, caramel and some citrus. Taste of bread, brett, orange peel, citrus, caramel, hops, herbs and a maltprofile in perfect balance due to the bitternes. Dry and bitter end on this one and the palate is very suitable! definitely a "drink all the time beer". A stylish bottle also. - Fridge fashion all the way yall !

2009 bottle. Cloudy orange pour with huge frothy head that almost spilled over the glass.. The aroma is barnyard funk from the brett, hops, and yeast. The flavor was a lot more subtle than the nose and was what one would expect from a good belgian. The finish was very dry and a little tart which I liked. Overall this is a pretty solid beer.

Copper color with a creamy off-white head.  First thing I notice in the aroma is the earthy, barnyard quality from the yeast.  Very nice.  Nutty malt with fairly noticeable hop bitterness on the palate.  Finishes dry.  Has a little acidic twang on the palate as well.  I like this beer, and I enjoy the fact that Orval is doing things a little differently than other Belgian abbey beers.

33 cL bottle at home poured into a Karmeliet glass.  Amber brown beer with a very lively head.  Fine, sweet, slightly malty aroma, very attractive and rich.  Tastes, sweet, mild and subtle.  Very pleasant, and you wouldnt know it was 6.2%.  The sweetness is less apparent as more sips are taken and the dry flavour sets in.  Has character and is a fine tipple but is a little too dry for me.
big big head.  pours gold. citrus and mild floral nose. taste continues floral notes with spice and hoppiness.  shorter dry finish.

Orval, my 4th Trappist brewery tasted (5th if you count St. Bernardus), comes in a 11.2 fluid ounce brown, mini 750ml Belgian/French styled/shaped bottle with a trout holding a ring in its mouth on the label. Bottled on 22/01/2009, best before 22/2014. Definitely when I find this a little cheaper at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee I will buy a few to cellar. This bottle is lightly chilled.

This is a fizzer, pours (sediment and all) unlimited off-white head with large bubbles into my Duvel glass. The head recedes fairly quickly leaving huge lumps of lacing behind. not the best looking Trappist ale. The beer itself is a hazy oranginsh brown, caramel colored almost. Ive heard with a sediment free pour this is actually a very clear brew.

Smell is the best Ive encountered with a Trappist ale. It has a potent farmhouse saison style scent with some fruity sourness, a nice dose of yeast twang, some tropical fruit, white raisin, lemons, and a hint of spice. A very exotic smell, and a good one indeed.

Taste carries over with all the above scents as flavors, and more. It seems even fruitier and more saison-like, tart with a tad bit of cloying bittersweetness in the finish, the cloying taste lasts only the first sip. The spices and yeast are a bit more pronounced in the taste as well. It has a slightly bitter aftertaste with a hint of sour green apple and a bit of hops. It is smooth drinking with the right amount of carbonation, a bit of wateriness mid-drink, and a dry finish. It is whole heartedly complex in taste, scent, and mouthfeel; the appearance seems to be the least flashy/unique attribute to this beer.

The alcohol is hidden pretty well, you get hints of it here and there but nothing overpowering. It warms slightly as it goes. Nothing that would prevent me form at least having another despite the 6.9%abv.

Overall this is a fine Trappist ale, not the pinnacle but on the upper tier. It is the most unique and possibly the most complex one I have had so far. This is also beer #250 tasted for me, hoorah.
The true King of Beers (or Archbishop perhaps?), my favourite beer. Strong hop presence, lively carbonation, dry and just the right body balance.
Very complex, dry, beautiful head. I dont think I can say much that hasnt already been said, except that this is one of my favorite new finds, which you really have to taste.
UPDATED: SEP 30, 2013 A beer that used to be hard for me to describe because there used to be nothing quite like it.  More and more ales seem to try to be like this, nothing quite gets there.

Bottle served in a tulip. Pours slightly hazy deep orange with a monster off-white head. Excellent retention and rocky lacing. Complex aroma. Cheese, orange, peach, and grass... and we are just touching the surface. Light sweet, light bitter flavor. Medium-light body, croily texture, and a bitter, dry finish.

11.2 oz bottle; bottled on 1/6/2010, opened 2/5/2011. Aroma is that amazing Belgian standard. Aroma is an amazing mix of earthy barnyard, something rotting, and leather. Appearance is equally impressive: big white airy foam, outstanding lacing. The flavor, for me, is vexing. One part of me wants to dislike this beer for being dry, rough on the mouth, and bitter on the finish; on the other hand, I love it for its complexity, the chewy finish, and its uniqueness compared to the other Trappists. I really dont know if this beer deserves a 3 or a 5...

This was pressurized for sure. There isnt anything that gets you ready to drink a beer more than the sound of it opening. Big what head that faded slowly. Dull Brown color and clear with small bubbles. The aroma wasnt typical Belgian. I got bubblegum and hops straight away. Combined with the banana qualities, the aroma was quite enjoyable. I really loved how Orval stands out amongst the other Trappists. You can really taste that extra step. 

The finish was dry. Maybe it was the carbonation but my tongue was left feeling tingly and numb.
Très bonne bière et assez alcoolisé. Elle est excellente. Je vous la conseille, elle se déguste avec sagesse.

Bottle.  Lovely aroma of musky, earthy, slight floral notes and fresh compost.  Amber/light copper colour, big buffy head that lasts the whole way to the bottome with gorgeous lacing.  Taste is dry, bitter, but with a rich organic flavour, loamy, leather, tobacco, old wood, washed rind cheese and finally a tart finish with a slightly sour almost astringent aftertaste.  Effervescent in the mouth, light in body with a somewhat chewy texture.  There is so much going on here I feel like a liquored up barnyard is rioting in my mouth.

Sexy bottle.  Very attractive light plum color with a frothy head.  Aroma is hoppy dry and old hay, and some very subtle vanilla-ish spices.  They initial tatse is dry and not sweet at all.  Clean finish with a lasting dry/sugary/ bread flavored hoppiness .  Its a great effect when millions of tiny bubbles numb down your tounge for a split second before the flavors catch up. The end of this brew is nice and juicy and leaves me wanting more.  Too bad, 5$ a bottle is pretty steep... BTW, I think basement temperature is the way to go with this one, it really lets alot of aroma out.
very strong aftertaste, very belgian look to it, nice strong taste, but an overall enjoyable beer
Nice cloudy orange/yellow color, huge fluffy head. Nice citrusy smell to it, very clean. Nice little bite to it as well, outstanding.

My favorite!

This is the finest trappiste. Most complex beer. 
Full malt beer but not that sweet, actually bitter.
Unique bottle. I like the story/tell from the well and how the monks obtained the logo (fish and ring).
Nice cloudy orange/yellow color, huge fluffy head. Nice citrusy smell to it, very clean. Nice little bite to it as well, outstanding.

Beautiful clear orange with a huge white head that lasts until the final zip. Aroma is light sour, sweet, fruity, spicy, yeasty and hoppy. Flavor is medium sweet, light sour and moderate bitter. The finish is dry. 300111

Hazy pale orange body with a white very long lasting rocky head and great lacing. Great citric spicy and floral aroma. Somewhat watery and smooth with soft carbonation palate. Fruits, sweet bitter and dry flavour.

Well I guess I dont see what all the hype is about. Yes the presentation of this beer is quite a site, but the taste is lacking. Very bitter finish and is giving me a memory of swallowing pool water. Its weird because from the pour to the smell I was loving it and then the taste is short and dry and the end of the gulp leaves my tongue a little ruff. I will finish the drink, but probably wont buy another. Marijnrutten said it right red like sunset. Nice head retention.

Really nice orange brown color with unbelievable head, thick and frothy, and leaves a thick coating of Belgian Lace. Aroma is floral, grassy, and some tropical fruits - maybe green mango? Taste - Belgian yeast up front, but it is more subdued and gentle that a lot of Belgian Ales. Nice fruity notes, some sweetness from malt, but has a very enjoyable dryness. To me it makes it much more drinkable than other trappist ales. I could actually have a few of these. Light bodied and heavily carbonated, soapy mouth feel, astringent tannic finish, but in a good way. Finish is long and complex, and develops into bread and cereal notes at the end. A very good beer.

Bottled on 1/6/2010, poured into an Orval Chalice. Pour is a hazy, yellowish brown color with a small white head.  Head sticks around and laces nicely. Smells floral, almost like straw up front. Perhaps a bit of alcohol underneath with some banana. Sweet taste up front, Belgian yeasts, some banana.  Definitely some hops detected, along with a warming alcohol sensation as you drink. Dry and light, a lot of carbonation on this one. Extremely drinkable. Really goes down smooth.  Would be my preferred Pale Ale...but it isnt as readily available as some other, quality pales.

Bouteille de 33cl. Jolie couleur orange, trouble, mousse assez abondante de tenue très correcte. Quelque chose de végétal, une pointe dacidité avec une amertume soutenue, le tout très agréable en bouche. LOrval joue un peu la timide mais elle a du caractère. Originale mais cest loin dêtre ma trappiste préférée. Trouvée à Intermarché - Montigny en Gohelles.

So far one of the best trappists beers Ive tasted IMHO. The good aroma component is balanced. The bad point is the serving temperature and how the storage has been held: it greatly suffer suboptimal conditions, heavly affecting the resulting aroma.

Bottle 33cl (Bottled: 28/10/2010). 
Color: red/gold like a sunset with a white/beige head that sticks to the glass.
Aroma: sour, citrus, hops, vegetal.
Taste: sour, bitter.
Aftertaste: Bitter and long. 
Texture: between watery and creamy. 
This beer hides its aromas and tastes good!

UPDATED: APR 27, 2011 Poured from a bottle into a belled glass. Appearance is a hazy copper with an enormous head. Areoma is malty, sour, sweet, bready, and fruity. Taste is sour apples up front that moves on to grapes and yeast. Lots of carbonation. Tingly mouthfeel. This is wonderful.

Whoa, puffy cloud head on top of a beaut misty orange beer, truly great looking beer. Aroma is a mysterious mix of barnyard, honey mint-spice and sourness. dry in the mouth and even puckering on the side, but really good. Hop finish is dry and long. Amazing, complex beer.

A beautiful beer. The pour is a murky golden orange body with a thick two fingers of off white head. Aroma is earthy and slightly sour with sweet malty notes. Mildly fruity aroma and taste with a hint of citrus and apricot. Slightly sour taste as well. Such an easy to drink Belgian. Love it.

Pours a hazy orange with a huge white head that sat for what seemed forever, aroma is full of spices, flowery hops and some sour and funk notes to top it off, the flavor is very sharp with the spices and distinct yeast with a little bit of funk mixed in as well, the mouthfeel is a tad dry but it totally works with this beer, sooooo good.

From a 330ml bottle on 21/1/2011. Pours a murky golden orange, with some yeast sediment.  The head on this one was massive, and I had to let it settle for quite a while to down it without experiencing a carbonation explosion.The aroma is primarily sour apples, spices and a little musk lolly. Taste wise, there is a touch of spicy sweetness up front, but its dominated by a tart, sour apple taste, and is exceptionally dry (has definite wine like qualities). Perhaps I just got a dud bottle (which is rather lovely from an aesthetic standpoint), but this proved to be a massive disappointment given its score on here. There was something bordering on unpleasant about this one.
Really good beer. Flowers in aroma. Taste is quite dry, still interesting and unique.

Wow, let me just say, what a head on this beer, absolutely amazing, I had to pour it into two different glasses to make it all come out of the bottle. It just calls... "Drink me".... "Drink me".... A floral, hoppy aroma, maybe a slight brett character, extremely complex, interesting. First sip is quite floral, not quite sour but it seems to be getting there. Great stuff, I think I picked up an older bottle, a bit more booziness to it. Excellent!

Bottle @ Home. Pours hazy golden orange with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma of green apples, yeast, spices. Taste of green fruit, funky yeast, white pepper, spices, lots going on. Medium body, soft carbonation, e´refreshing bitter finish. Unique and refreshing beer. 160111

Un classicone che avevo bevuto più e più volte ma ho riassaggiato solo di recente. Una delle migliori birre mai bevute, eccellente anche restringendo il campo alle "trappiste", le sbaraglia quasi tutte. Fantastica, poi, abbinata con il pesto genovese.
case from brewey- smoooth and complex with sour overtones.  very drinkable and refreshing
Classic oral bottle from the brewery.  Great thick head.  Very complex for how smooth it is.  Drinkable and awesome.

Astonishingly foamy and massive head sits atop a very foggy amber.  First big aroma that hits me is apple.  Thats a surprise! A ton going on here.  Funky yeastiness initially, then a touch of alcohol, then a bright, fruity, apple-tinged note, then it moves sweeter.  Finish sour and bitter and lingering.  After a while theres a peppery note.  All without being harsh or aggressive.  Tasty.

Pours amber with a great bubbly white head that doesnt dissipate quick.
Great hoppy aroma.
Tastes bitter and dry.

Ive drunk Orval from as young as 2 months to 7years old. Evolves quite fast, would suggest to leave it at least 6 months. At its best after about 2 years. From 5years on it transforms to a completly different brew wich goes more to a port (less carbonation, richer and fruitier taste, less bitter, almos no head at all).

11.2oz bottled on Sept 7, 2008, enjoyed over 2 years old and probably warmer than I shouldve.  Oh well.  Pours hazy orange/amber with a gigantic foamy, bubbly, and fluffy off white head that a Duvel tulip couldnt contain.  Takes forever to recede and leaves rings of foamy, bubbly lacing and a rocky island behind.  Aroma features the most authentic bubblegum aroma Ive encountered, very grassy, floral and herbal, spices, some lemon, a bit of orange, as well as some funk buried underneath.  Complex and strong aroma.  Flavor is fruity apples, lemon, orange, pear, bubblegum, some spice, some tartness up front, then a bit of caramel sweetness in the middle transitioning to a touch more spice and an overall dry finish.  Mouthfeel is light to medium, low carbonation, a little creamy and sometimes sticky.  My first Orval, unique, definitely.  I can dig it and now want to try a fresher one for some comparison.

341ml bottle. 6.9% ABV. Enjoyed at 12degC. Pours murky orange-brown with big foamy and resilient white head. Grassy, spicy, sweet, sherbet-like and funky/wild/sour aromas. Light-medium body, medium-high carbonation. Sweetness initially overshadowed by the bitterness, sour notes and complex yeast flavours. Finishes semi-dry and satisfying.
Milky yellowish color.  Smells like some weird bread and yeast.  I love the flavor.  Its weird and delicious.  Neat beer!

I had this beer many times, especially when I was in Belgium. Despite it is a Trappist beer, it is not too much strong as alcoholic graduation. Fruity, a little bit creamy, long finish with no persistent froth. I also felt the caramel taste. Its a beer for slow tasting. Very good!
Pours beauty hazy light brown with lush head; smells of molded earth and apples; taste is bitter earthy moldy and mildy fruity with full palate on the finsh
Bottle shared with Miver on New Years Eve.  Light hop and yeast aroma, golden body with thin head.  Flavor is of dry, crisp hops... dry finish. An excellent Belgian.
Bottle.  Dry and sweet fruits.  Spice.  Unique aroma. Might refer to it as that Orval aroma.  Warming alcohol. Clean yeast. Fluffy lively carbonation.  Beautiful long dry finish.  Exquisite.
The aroma is is sweet as and floral, the appearance is a orange / amber with a thick lasting frothy head.  The taste is clean and smooth, the beer is very smooth and easy to drink, overall very nice.

11.2 oz. bottle. Pours a cloudy, amber-orange with a huge frothy off-white head that lasts throughout. Quite effervescent. Amazing lacing. Aroma of fruits, citrus, grapes, and bubble gum. Taste is sweet malt with a pronounced hop character. For me, this is quite complex with oranges, grapes, and bubblegum. A little spicy, and a bit earthy. Medium to full body. Lively carbonation. Crisp and refreshing. Short, dry finish. Easy to drink. Great choice for my 100th rating.
11.2 oz bottle Gold color, great lacing. Great aroma from dry hopping. Incredibly complex. Only gets better with age. Perhaps the best beer in the world.

Bottle sample. This is one of my favorites of the Trappist beers. Pours a dark cloudy gold, wonderous beige head great lacing. The aroma is of fruit an hops. Taste is hoppy and of grape, very palatable. This is one beer I cannot have enough of, I could drink this all night. There is only one problem I have with this, and that is every time you uncap a bottle it just foams right out, which could be considered good and bad, just messy.

Cloudy dark yellow pour, large bubbles.  Aroma of nutmeg, banana, "Christmas" spices.  Large bubbles in the mouth, with a tight taste, opening up to citrus as it warms to the right temperature.  The friendly aromas dont come through strongly in the taste, however, otherwise Id like this one even more.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2013 Bottle. Cloudy orange brown with an off white head. Aroma i is medium with notes of citrus, hops and yeast. Taste is also citrusy hoppy with a medium yeasty backbone. Refreshing and easy for a belgian.

Aroma: Citrus, malt and coriander. 
Appearance: dark amber, orange. 
Taste: Sweet, a bit sour and hops with a dry finish. 
Palate: High carbonation, good body. 
Overall: Complex beer but very drinkable. 20/20.

dull, dense orange with a ripping stream of carbonation coming from all angles of the glass. huge off-white head that will not die down.  spicy, oily hop aroma. leather almost barn,stable like scents. definitely a pale. bitter, earthy hop flavor with a chalky, fruity yeast character in the finish. not sweet, almost more of a pear fruitiness. champagne like carbonation. crisp bubbles.

Nice head.  Clear dark golden colour. Smells like trappist i.e. unfiltered and yeasty. Taste is crispy, bitter and definitely more hoppy than I remembered. Orval really deserves a place my list of beers to have later on.

Pours a pale orange/amber producing a mammoth of a frothy head. This is one of the biggest heads I have ever seen. No lace. The aroma first reminds me of white wine. There are a lot of green grape notes, with a funky peppery yeast quality. More sweet fruits tickle the nose with a solid alcohol lift. The flavor has a peppery spice base that lends to a gentle complexity of fruits, namely grapes, lemon, and apple cider. Quite tart surprisingly. The body is superb, as most Belgians seem to perfect. It is light and airy with a zippy carbonation giving wonderful drinkability. This honestly is not what I expected at all. A fruity, tart, white wine like pale ale, seems unique to say the least, but is really quite enjoyable.

Pours very bubbly, golden in color, with a thick head. Aroma is fruity, mainly peaches and apricots. Definitely picking up some spicy yeast. Sweetness is moderate. Slight off-putting metallic taste. Light bodied, smooth, with late hop bite. Good, but I was hoping to really love this.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2010 One of the best of the Belgian beers in my opinion, the strongness and malt-covered sweetness goes down your tounge slowly, as the after-taste leaves a fruity aroma as most of the Belgian strong ales do.

Cloudy orange pour with super lively carbonation so liveley I could not pour it into a glass. Intensely huge off white head that never went below 3 fingers. The aroma is a slightly sour cherry/yeasty sourness confection with a medium bubbly mouth-feel but muted by the head. The lemony/s taste and smell is in fact quite refreshing.  lot of sediment in the glass. some what disappointment of a beer, I will rate it again maybe a bad bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2012 Bottle:
Big off white foamy head on top of a light cloudy dark orange to amber colored beer. Head disappears slow and leaves a quart open thin off white lacing.
Yeasty, some brown sugars/toffe, dark fruits like prunes and a light sour tint in the smell. Also a hint wood, pepper and a light hint of malt.
Taste is a fine mix of yeast, brown sugared malts, light sour, spicy, malty, bitter and more bitter, fruity, apple and a light hint of grass. Just very well balanced and damn tasty!
Medium to lower carbo, soft light spicy mouthfeel, medium to full body and a creamy texture. Such a freaking good beer.
-------& rerate (always taste different) Nice fruity, bit like ipa fruity, with a nice sweet wood yeasty touch. Soft and creamy. Good firm head that stays up all the time.
Every bottle tastes different, but all equally tasty and balanced. Cant go wrong here.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Let me put a stake in the ground right here, I like this beer.  Is it the best beer going? No.  Is it in the upper echelon? Definitely.  Pours golden with a large fluffy white head, bunches of carbonation, somewhat cloudy.  Great nose, citrus, floral, yeast, bready, all with some mild funkiness, barnyard.  Medium-full body, smooth, full carbonation, bitter and crisp.  On the tongue, its all there, cherries, fruits, malts, yeast, funky, barnyard.  Only thing missing is the kitchen sink.
Amber in color, with a thick head that lasts.  Spicy, rich aroma.  Very good taste - dry, bitter, and flavorful

same bottle as pictured. pours golden yellow with decent white head. sweet aroma of brown sugar maybe. the sourness is well balanced with the sweetness. highly carbonated like most in its style, which im not a fan of. definitely a great beer if your a fan of this style

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 Bottle 330ml @ fonefan
Pours cloudy golden with a off-white head. Taste is light sour and bitter with soft carbonation. 
Bottle 330ml @ Patricks Pub og Restaurant, Kristiansand
Pours cloudy orange with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, berries and a little brett. Taste is light sweet, light bitter and light sour with a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

3/25/10 bottle.  Blunted gold color with heavy carbonation.  Huge, rocky head.  Unique aroma that is dry, somewhat tart , and slightly hoppy.  Taste is light bitter hops up front followed by tart and a crisp, dry finish.  I also pick up on some background caramel notes as the finish winds down.   Quite tasty.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2015 06/12/2010 - 33cl bottle @ home
A little cloudy amber to copper coloured beer, white creamy solid head, adhesive. Aroma: hop bitters, slightly bretta sour and yeast. Taste: strong hop bitterness, a little tartness like green apples and a bready yeast note. Aftertaste: dry bitterness, still the slight tart note. MF: nice carbon, medium body. One of my favourites.
Note: so I finally got around to taking some notes for the trappists. Ive been drinking them for years and usually when I did not felt like sampling something new and taking notes. Tasted them with 2 friends for a trappist review article in the student society magazine.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2013 Bottle. Hazy orange colour with large head. Aroma is fruits, spices. Flavour is fruits, spices, is a bit dry. Bitter aftertaste. 
Re-rate: Pours amber in color with a foamy off-white head. Notes of citrus and lemon in aroma, quite pleasant. Lemon, some peppery spices with a slightly bitter finish in taste. Some sweetness also in form of wild strawberries in aftertaste. Nice, not a sign of that harshness I remembered, a bit of aging does wonders to this beer. Smooth. Delicious. Drinkable.
8-4-8-4-16=40

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2012 Bottle. Medium fluffy white head, excellent retention. Hazy amber body. Champagne, yeast, pine, aromatic perfume, juicy hop, some biscuity malt, orange peel, walnuts, brown sugar. Rather sweet, some bitterness. Tangy mouthfeel, moderate carbonation, extra dry finish. 8 4 7 3 17 Bottle conditioned. Bottled on 12/10/2011. Pours a deep gold with a large lively white head. Belgian ale yeast, hops, minerals, stilton cheese (mouldy), strawberries, some perfume, juicy tangerine.  Gives the taste buds a kick. Hoppy and bitter with some spiciness and a sweet touch towards the end. Dry on the finish. Refreshing. Prickly carbonation. 8 4 8 4 16

Golden yellow with a very large white head that stick around awhile.  Aroma is grainy and yeast with clove and spices and light grassy hops.  Taste is very spicy with plenty of yeast along with grains, pepper and light fruits.  Finishes up yeasty with a but of peppery spice and light hops.  Just dont get the appeal here.
Cloudy amber, huge fluffy head. Aromas of citrus, spice, yeast, malt. Tastes of spice and citrus, some yeast, finishes malty and dry. Nice, but I expected a more pronounced body.

The only one of its kind thats dryhopped. The color is goldlike and has a nice creamy white head. I can taste a bit of honey. It tastes and smells spicy, very complex. Not every is fan of the beer, but i certainly am!

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2014 pours hazy golden with a frothy off-white head, very good retention and strong lacing. leathery bretts, spicy lean maltiness, dust, very yeasty, very fruity - peaches, tropical fruits. lively carbonation, light body, bone dry, lightly astringent and bretty-spicy finish. excellent!

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2012 Pours yellow-gold with a nice white head and a good deal of lacing. Initial whiff is earthy funk, hay, green apples, and lemon rind. Slightly hoppy. Taste brings forward the funk in a not so unstrained way. Something about it just doesnt balance. This is about a year old, and I think the hops and the funk just might be quite out of balance at this point, with the semi-aged hops detracting from the overall package. Mouthfeel is dry and well carbonated. Drinkability is average; nowhere near Westvleteren Blonde. Ill have to get a fresh bottle and see if it fares any better.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-24-2010

Bottle from Warners bottleshop. Had heard so much about this beer, but have to say thought it was a bit overrated, but it was just not to my taste. A bit sour from the citrus flavours, strong Belgian yeast flavour comes through. Decent, but not for me.

It looks a bit like unfiltered honey, hazy with fluffy well-sustained off-white/tan tinted head. Smells mildly of citrus, some juicy banana and mild spice and florals. Its got a spicy, pilsner-like flavor; dry and biscuity with a touch of orange peel.  Delicious and well-balanced.
Same bottle as pictured. Aroma of banana and other fruits. The best Trappist I have had so far.
This is the best trapist ale, I have tried , its quite nice. Notes of banana, in the aroma and the taste. Very nice offer, recommend a taste
As many Belgian beers served from a nice bottle. Tastes a bit fruity, and lasts not for long - it is just to good to save...

Pours a lovely cloudy, almost milk chocolate brown, lots of fluffy white head with pronounced lacing. The aroma is very complex with the dry fruit notes that are common in Trappist style ales, yet it has a pronounced citrus note due the the hops. The palate is full bodied, with nice carbonation. The taste is also very complex with fruit notes such as raisins, but also has a roasted chocolate notes, the hop flavor also comes through, and lingers on during the after taste. Very, very, very good beer.
Very complex beer. The smell is indescribable. The taste is also very complex, very spicy. The water that is use to brew is very unique this is really a great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 An unclear dark orange beer with nice head.Aroma,fruits,malt,light caramel,cucumber,vinegar,spices.Taste black tea,grapefruit,grass,unriped grapes,coriander,spices.Dry,very brutal champagne.A very complex beer.

Bottle poured into a tulip.  Very effervescent, producing large amounts of fluffy white head.  The lacing is like no other; sticky and thick all over the glass.  Aroma is mostly Brett, and just slightly sour.  Flavor is light and crisp.  Brett pretty much dominates this beer.  There is some nice, mild bitterness on the end.  Honestly, not the most flavorful beer, but I can see what it is people love about it.

Poured from a .33L bottle a dark orange with a large white head that faded quickly but left nice lacing around the glass. Aroma of hops, grass, herbs and spruce. Flavor is full bodied and hoppy with notes of grass and herbs. Not a bad beer but a little hoppy and dry for my liking.

What a nose!  Caramel and toffee with a cough-drop like sweetness, wafting around wonderfully.  However seemed to lose its consistency and character once in the glass and in the mouth.  Wonder if the bottle I drunk from here in New Zealand was poorly shipped?  Great start poor finish.
TONS of head. I only poured a little and the entire glass was full of foam. Looks good once it subsided. Nice floral aroma. This is an intense Belgian beer
Bottled, from Presporska pivoteka, Bratislava. Dark orange color with large white head. Aroma, citrus with spices. Taste, starts orange, continues with spices, dry finish. Excellent beer.

I had never had a Trappist-brewed beer before this.  My experience with Trappists begins and ends with Thomas Merton.  That said, the sweet, almost honey taste to this helps smooth out the taste which leads to a soft sense of well-being and cosmic pondering.  A must for all beer fans to try.

Appearance is big white head, pale though deep copper-gold colour. Aroma is bretts with the horse blanket, green apples, yeast and fresh. Taste is green apples, dry, a small acidity coming with some wild yeast-notes. Dry finish with good bitterness.

Illata citrusos, gyümölcsös és komlós, nem olyan erőteljes, mint egynéhány IPA esetében, de mindenesetre mosolyt csal az ember arcára, olyan jó érzés fölé hajolni. Színe vörösesbarna. Krémes, felvert tojásfehérjéhez hasonlatos habja van, ami nagyon sokáig kitart, még a legvégén is marad a pohár alján.  Akárcsak az illata, az íze is igen összetett és hasonló jegyeket hordoz. A gyümölcsök enyhe édességét és a citrusok frissességét érezzük először, majd megjelenik a komló és az egész átmegy kellemesen keserűbe. Ittam már jobb belga söröket, de ez is kiváló, és szerintem különleges is.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2011 2004 vintage @ kulminator 
head: creamy, white 
colour: amber 
smell: malts, candy, bubblegum, yeast, bit of oranges 
taste: bubblegum , citric, malts, vintage, yeast, spices, bitter and dry end

Nice amber pour and a big frothy head. Very effervescent. Nose is fruity orange, tangerine, cantaloupe, pineapple, caramel, a bit of brett. Delicious indeed. Taste is all the same components, the brett a bit less obvious, but it still makes a great note. No doubt this is a classic.

4 oz. @ SIB 2010.

I remember not liking this one nearly as much as I would expect considering how much it is praised.

Notes:
"Smells estery. Pours cloudy bronze. Tastes like Pinesol. Uber bubbly. Not worth 3 tix."

11.2oz bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours deep brown with a thick, lacy, beige head.  Aroma of Belgian spicy yeast, hops, caramel.  Flavor about the same.  A little dry with a hint  of alcohol on the finish.  An incredible beer, and its better fresh in Belgium.

330 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a hazy, deep amber/orange with very large off-white head.  Nice floral and yeasty aroma with moderately sweet, moderately sour fruit and light spice.  Taste is very yeasty and fruity (banana, sourish apple) with modest spicing.  Sour, dry finish; active carbonation.  Very nice, although I respect it more than I love it.

Bottled on 22/04/2010, best before 22/04/2015.  Let bottle warm slightly before pouring, Poured from an 11.2 oz. bottle into oversized red wine glass.  Still waiting on my orval goblet.  Huge off white bubbly head formed almost overflowing the glass, as I let it sit it stuck to the glass and fell slowly on the sides leaving a large head in the middle, almost like a an egg.  Dark orangey brown color.  Very spicy aroma.  Tastes exceptional, I detect some orange. Tart and dry.  Not as strong as the smell might indicate.  Ive been told the beer should be at its peak right now, it tastes like it could use a little more time to mellow to me.  Very light on the tongue but I can feel it starting to kick in.  I wouldnt be able to drink too many of these, it is more of a treat or an after dinner drink.
hoppy caramel malt aroma. lovely tan color with pillowy white head. lively carbonation coats the mouth giving a creamy texure. slight hop bitterness.

After seeing thread after thread about merits and downfalls of this beer I figured it was about time to try.  However to counteract buildup in my head I decided to drink on very ho-hum tuesday while watching tv.  Pours a drity copper color with huge soapy head that doesnt go anywher anytime fast.  Aroma is huge of wine, grapefruit sourness, yeasts, and lemongrass.  taste is spicy, of green grapes, honey, more wine, cranberries, and more yeasts.  Finish is dry and bitter and seems to last and last.  Really great for such easily attainabale brew.
Nose of cranberry, sour hops, late bite, feel is mild yet broad, carb is medium, taste is mild alcohol, bitter hops, weak yeast and late iron. All around theres a distinct taste of cranberries.

Orval poured out a fabulous gold with a generous head which took a few minutes to fade. The pour into my chalace produced aromas of spicy fruits with the typical yeast and the added brett. The alcohol does make its pressence known and leaves a long finish with a slight bite. Delicious and smooth.

Bottle. Quite foamy, so little smell at first. Foam has a nice consistency. Smells (eventually) quite strong, mostly bitterness. Nice amber color, a bit hazy. Taste is quite bitter, and I sense a little sourness as well. Also in the smell, as the glass gets emptier. Not stunned by the taste.
Palate; quite a full body, lively carbonation. Still, cant find me in the other reviews. Perhaps just not my kind of beer. Will try again someday.
citrus, amber, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, oily feel, bitter, long finish.
Meh.  After the build-up this got from the beer-store guy I was really disappointed.  A one-dimensional beer - and not for me.

Assaggiata in bottiglia da 33 cl.
Aspetto splendido, colore oro e schiuma eccezionale, densa e persistente. Il profumo speziato domina gli aromi. Il gusto è pieno, intenso, leggermente salato su un corpo cremoso e ricco di aromi. Il finale vede un amaro in crescendo, duraturo e sottile, piacevole al palato

poured into Trappist glass, straw amber cloudy color, massive thick head that completely coated my glass and retains through my entire drink, aromas of hay, floral, citrus, honey, wine, dusty attic, right combination of bitter hops and malt sweetness, palate is near perfect, 6.9% ABV is there but just right again, dry finish, bravo!

Pours an orange brown color with small white head.  Aroma of grapes, spice, raisins, and alcohol.  First taste is intense grapes and wine, finishes with a hint of mint.  High amount of carbonation, medium bodied, and I cant get over the aftertaste of mint.  The aftertaste is those little pink mints, not a bad taste, but not typical for a beer?

Bottle: Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Terrific retention on this brew - I notice that it is fairly carbonated as well - and still is far into the pour -Aroma is Belgian yeasts, citrus, lemongrass ; This bottle was listed at 6.9% for what thats worth. Medium mouthfeel - i think this is a fantastic blend of spices, citrus, lemongrass, a bit of barnyard/yeastiness - it just meshes really well. And yes, it finishes dry - I havent been a big of fan of that farmhouse character but I think Im really coming around

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2015 31st December 2005  Early amateur rating warning! Mid brown beer - lighter than the Chimay and Rocheforts this evening but really nothing special.  2010 note - one of the first beers I rated when I had no idea of its reputation, several thousand beers later - still struggling to understand the reverence its held in! 18th February 2015Chelmsford Winter Beer Festival. KEGS. A bottle shared by TDTM82. Cheers Tom! Light haze on this amber beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light and semi dry, decent fine carbonation. Touch of gueuzey wet wood, clear but mellow brett. Light semi dry finish. Not bad. 3.4. 2007 Bottle also courtesy of Tom - cheers mate! Almost clear amber beer, good pale cream colour head. Palate is smooth with good fine carbonation. Airy malts. Brief savoury note. Decent brett but not overpowering. Mild dried fruits, light floralness. Finishes crisp with a little carbonated sting. Much livelier than the 2004. 3.6
Pours cloudy copper/orange with a long lasting off-white head. Smells great, spice and fruit. Very dry; complex flavours with some sourness to it with a bitter finish. Very highly carbonated.
By far my favorite Trappist beer.  The initial aroma was wonderfully fruity and delightful.  Very complex flavor.

Although a huge trappist fun myself,I can say that this is the dullest Ive yet tasted.Of course it has a pure taste and the aroma fruits soothen your mood, as any strong belgian ale,but to be honest the palate is quite disappointing for a trappist...A very good beer,yet not great...
Pours a hazy orange with a thick white head. Citrus, spicy, light malt in the nose. light sour taste, citrusy hops with a dry finish. tasty
Orval of 2004: Sour smell. Sour and dusty taste with a head that stays pretty strong for the age.
UPDATED: OCT 14, 2010 A wonderful orange color. A big foam. Nose with a hop/herb/spicy. Palate with a complex hoppy taste. Not american hops :D

Pours a hazy apple-cider pale orange. Decent airy looking head. Aroma is relatively mild for a trappist. Apricots, raisins, caramel. Flavor is definitely "belgian". An array of fruits. Peach and pear with caramel and spices...esp. cinnamon. Sweet and strong. A bit overcarbonated though, but still very good.

Pours a light copper color with big foamy head. Aroma of apples, dried fruit, yeast. Flavor was fruity with notes of bread and clove and a nice dry hoppy finish. I think the finish is what makes this beer so appealing and allows itself to be paired with a variety of foods. Nicely done Belgian!

12oz bottle pours a hazy copper with a huge white head. Aroma is sour cherries and apples, yeast, floral, grass, and spices. Taste is very dry and sour with bitter aftertaste of alcohol, slight spice. Not digging taste, aromatic flavors not coming through, just awful sour/dry/bitterness that makes me gag.
Lovely looking beer with enormous head. Apples, farmyard and hay in the nose. Fruity and hoppy palate with sour finish. Great beer with food.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2011 In bottle; pours a golden orange color. Aroma was sweet (citrus and spice). taste was OK (was hoping for more). Citrus, honey and orange notes. Good beer but better Belgium beers out there for sure. UPDATE (Jun 15) - in bottle. aroma a little honey and orange. The beer was better than I remembered last time. Overall, nice very

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2011 Bottle. Hazy orange body, huge head. Sweet and unmistakable funky/yeasty aroma. Taste has apricot, honey, some cloves and sweet white grapes. The level of hop crispness varies with age. A truly fascinating beer that develops its character while ageing. A mellow masterpiece. I love the bottle shape too.

Opaque amber in the glass, huge frothy head with unique sculptural qualities as it settles. Intoxicating aroma of tangy fruits, such as green apple and white grape, combined with hints of clove and fresh pine tree sap. Flavors of spicy hops, wild yeast, and more fruit... peach, apricot, apple. A complex blend of tastes with lots of zing.

Always thought it was cool that this is the only beer they make at the orval brewery.  Quite a unique beer, you could call it a Belgian amber. Extreme carbonation out of a bottle.  smooth caramel and malty flavors, nothing too extreme on the estery side.  Well balanced and quite tasty
I think Orval is a beer that doesnt taste like anything else, and I also think its delicious. As someone below said, you either love it or you never drink it again.

botle poured in tulip glass. delightful spicy aroma. thick frothy head with plenty of retention.Orange-amber and cloudy in appearance. subtle sweetness in taste. medium-full body. light bitter finish. This is a great beer and very pleasing to drink.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2011 330 ml bottle @ Olutravintola Malja. Rated @ 28.5.2009.
Pours an orange colour with a very frothy head. Fruity malts on the nose with notes of citrus and spices. Sour flavour with peaches and floral hops. Medium bodied with a very slicky mouthfeel. Very good.
330 ml bottle. Bottled 09/09/2010.
Pours a hazy orange colour with a massive, foamy, white head. Leaves a strong lacing on the glass. Aroma of lemon, peaches and sweet malts. Flavour of sweet fruits such as peaches, mild dried fruits, spices, sweet malts and floral hops. Medium bodied with a foamy mouthfeel. Warming, fruity, hoppy finish. Very refreshing brew once again.

This is the only beer I have ever tasted that has an absolutely unique taste. It has a strong flavour that dissipates after a few seconds to leave a nice soury/bitter taste in the back of your mouth. Definatly not for everybody, I dont even think its an acquired taste! You like it and love it , or youll never drink it again.
Bought after a recommondation from Ølbutikken. My toughts are: Sour, very dry, crazy white head, sour. I think its a copy of Arrons Ambrosius.

Beautiful pour. Thick billowy head. Dark hazy orange.  Aroma is slightly peachy with some earthy spiciness.  Very distinct flavor. Earth, leather, some fruit.  Finishes mildly bitter.  Tastes like no other beer Ive had.  Fantastic.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2013 330 ml bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a big, white, foamy head and has a quite hazy, pale, orange appearance. The aroma is huge. Theres a lot of yeasty notes, sourness and some fruity hops . The taste is very special. Dry and sweet with a bitter ending and heavy acidity over the whole spectrum. Mouthfeel is dry with a lot of carbonation and a full body. Truly a well made, balanced beer. Really interesting stuff.

Re-rating 2011-08-26. 33 cl bottle. Appearance as earlier. Quite bretty aroma with notes of mint, horseblanket, yeast, herbal/noble hops. Taste is quite dry, medium bitter and quite hoppy overall and a bit bretty. Medium bodied with quite high carbonation. Mm, balanced stuff.

Re-rating 2012-06-22. 2006 vintage bottle at Mikkeller Bar. Clear, amber liquid with medium to big off-white head. Aroma is funky sour with notes of apples, barnyard, lemons, almonds and paint thinner. Taste is dry and light bitter with leathery, fruity funk. Medium bodied with low carbonation. The nice dry hops and fresh funk is gone. A lot worse than a 6-8 months old bottle. 4/6/6/3/15 => 3.4

Re-rating 2013-04-04 (5th annual Orval Appreciation day(s)). 9 months old bottle. Appearance as before, grade rests. Great head retention. Aroma is very fresh and complex with loads of elegant brett (barnyard, horseblanket and tropical fruit) along with some minty hops, apples and bready malt. Delightful to smell. Taste is dry and light to medium bitter with malty notes of bread and biscuit as well as some balanced funk. Medium bodied with medium to high carbonation. Up aroma by one. 8/4/7/4/18 => 4.1
330 ml bottle a young bottle a dark orange colored beer with a white head aroma yeast spices fruits and some malts taste spices fruits some yeast and malt a very nice beer

Whoa this one exploded into the glass. Probably shouldnt have transported it in a backpack hah. A nice and cloudy, reddish-maple colour. Proportionate and fairly long lasting white head. Aroma of caramel and bread, with subtle notes of alcohol and prunes. A balanced flavour. A little sweet, a little tart, slightly salty and a hint of bitterness. Medium/thin body and texture, soft carbonation, long and mellow finish. Overall, a very enjoyable beer.

Bottle, pretty cold around 40 or 45 degrees.  Pours a deep orange, very carby, thin, airy foam that quickly dies down.  Foam settles as a lasting thin sheet of teeny bubbles.  Aroma is light alcohol, woody orange rind, dry grapefruity aroma at the end, sort of like fruit pulp smell.  Taste is very clean, dry, complex fruitiness.  Dry, lightly bitter finish makes it hard to figure out what fruits are in there.  Flavors are like dehydrated apricots, grapefruit, woody / early apple.  Grassy sour slowly fades into the aftertaste.  Light bitternes almost like an english bitter.   Leave it on the tongue for a long while and in addition to getting a numb tongue, you get a taste of vanilla.  Nice little bright sour edge that surfs on the carb.

Bottle. Tasted approx 6 months after bottling date. Huge rocky white head, opaque dull amber colour. Smells funky, with earth, herbs and a hint of lemon. Taste is yeasty and unexpectedly dry (as the lemon hints at a sour ale flavour). Long, bitter finish.
Pours a cloudy medium yellow, nose is floral and dusty, taste is extremely dry, peppery, and herbal.
Bottle. At this point in time, this beer is not for me. I dont appreciate the funkiness, acidity, yeastiness or the texture.

Delicious fruity sweetness smell right when the bottle is opened, golden, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, lively, complex finish with notes of fruit

Overall:  Interesting beer with a fruity flavor and aroma.  Absolutely amazing beer that I can always count on to tickle my taste buds!

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 I dont get it. I keep getting this beer recommended to me each time I walk up to the counter at my local liquor store with Westmalle, Chimay, Kwak, Triple Moine, etc...so I figured it must fit in nicely. No, nope, huh-uh, Ill pass. Maybe I got a bad bottle, but it was like drinking potpourri. UPDATE: Figured I would give this one another chance, 10 months later. Well, it still tastes like potpourri with a nasty aftertaste. I dont get the praises this swill gets.

I really like this beer.  I buy it in Brussels at the Carrefour by the 4 pack.  It was introduced to me by a friend and I liked it right off the bat.  Good color, good taste very intriguing, cant put my finger on it, I just got back from a beer fest in Brussels and already drank them all, but if I remeber correctly from earlier, the aroma, was raisins, and bread to me. The whole experiece is great overall, Im surprised to see it rated 99, although I love all the trappist beers from Belgium and since Im 2 hours away, I am truly lucky to be so close and it seems like Im spoiled with all the AMAZING beer around me. I cherish every moment of it because i return to the states in February and this beer will be much harder to find. Lastly, great beer, I like it alot, but I only get it about 3 times a year. If you can get your hands on it, I think you will enjoy it.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 Looks are spot on with a creamy big head and cloudy brown, tea-like colour. Nice bottle as well. Balanced aroma with leaves, spices, yeast. Taste is both complex and never too sharp. Many layers with dry earthy feel at first, followed by a rich bitterness from the hops. The carbonation makes sure the taste stays too further develop. After all, it seems, all aspects are simply perfect. One of the best beers Ive ever had. (Rating re-indexed)

Orvall is arguably the most recognizable and respected of all the Trappist breweries, save perhaps for Chimay.  Orval is immediately identifiable by their unusual bottle shape.  It looks like a small brown bowling pin.  

12 ounce bottled pulled into a rudimentary glass chalice.  I poured this one slowly and tossed out a bit to avoid having the beer overpowered by the yeast cake on the bottom of the bottle.  The beer is tangerine in color, more orange than I remember.  Its the color of sun tea.  Small bubbles make up a larger rocky head.  Nice lacing that looks a lot like dish soap.  Solid inch worth of head on this one, even with my conservative pouring efforts.  Smell is amazing, intoxicating.  I get some light hits of yeasty clove and bananas to start things off, before things get a little more hefty.  Theres a strong fruit presence here, with some cherry standing out for me.  Im also getting a distinct apple presence.  Combined with the malt profile its almost like smelling a hot apple pie.  Theres also some clear earthy barnyard funkiness going on.  Mouthfeel is light, almost to the point of effervescence, and theres very little in terms of bitterness.  

I havent had Orval in quite some time.  My first real drink in a long while just takes the concept of Trappist beer and turns it directly on its ear.  Huge amount of dry and musky Brett yeast can be found through out the beer, adding an incredible amount of flavor.  Hop character is relatively muted, though its there up front.  Reminds me of pear cactus.  While theres a ton of things going on, the beer remains an absolute joy to drink.  The light body makes this a very quaffable beer, though the flavor profile encourages you to meander.  As the beer warms it offers you more, as the brett notes start to highlight more of the caramel malt profile.  

Those with a patient palate will find that this beer offers a level of enjoyment few others can match.  For me, its so good it borders on ridiculous.  Theres really nothing to fault within this beer.  Impecablle, simply incomparable.  Highly recommended.

Bottle, 33 cl. Hazy golden to blond-orange coloured beer with medium white head. Aroma is fruity, hoppy and herbal & spicy. The smell overall is very specific and fantastic. The beer also has a rather unique taste. It is sharp & grassy at first and overal hoppy, surrounded by some malts, making the beer milder and a fruity background taste. You also taste spices, the finish is hoppy and bitter. This is a beer you need to learn to drink: because of its explicit taste you dont like it that much at first, but when you get used to it and learn to know the beer, you discover which a fantastic beer you are drinking.

Amber color, off white head.  Aroma is fruity, almost to the extent of a kriek beer.  Taste is on the sour side.  This one was not quite what I expected - have been looking forward to it for a long time, I think I will give it a second try another time.

Aroma: Smells of citrus,herbs, 
Appearance: golden, orange, cloudy, frothy, white foam, 
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, fizzy, thin feel, 
Overall: This is a fantastic beer, great aroma, nicely brewed.

Pours red/brown with off white head that is frothy and lasting. Nice grass, citrus, and lemony hops complements some funky barnyard and earth in the aroma. Taste is creamy, a bit of hops leading into a funk middle with a dry bitter finish. Great brew

Poured orange. Head bubbly head. Aroma of citrus, grass and mustiness. Nice texture, lively carbonation. Citrus flavor. Hoppy bitterness. Slight Belguim yeast tang. An almost wheaty undertone which I cant put my finger on exactly. Long and dry finish.  Definitely adds to the complexity. Really great.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 Le liquide a une couleur très singulière avec des teintes brunes et orangées.  La mousse est crémeuse et a une bonne rétention.  Une petite dentelle est observée.  Le nez est complexe avec un savant mélange de houblons très parfumés, de fruits acides et de levure épicée.  Au goût, de bonnes notes amères provenant des houblons accompagnent une levure au caractère âcre.  En bouche, le liquide est de moyenne corpulence avec une effervescence active et appropriée.  En finale, le liquide laisse derrière lui des notes acides et une amertume juste à point.  En résumé, unique et toujours intéressante.

Hazy amber coloured pour with an  off-white, whipped creamy head on its top.
The smell is fruity and vinegar liked.
The start is sharp, mouthfeel is nicely slick, flavours of apples and grapes.
The aroma is of caramell, citrus, wheat and light spicy notes in the back.
The finish is vine dry, hoppy and resin-liked dry at last.
Overall a nicely balanced, enjoyable belgian stuff.

Love the bottle.  Poured into wine glass.  Creamy head that lasts through the last drop.  Aroma is subtle but fresh.  Tastes of fruit, citrus,  and biscuits and the hops give a great balance on the finish.  A great Trappist ale.

Aroma: Gorgeous floral, fresh grass, yeasty and earthy, rich malt and candy sugar. 
Palate: 
Flavor: Distinctly earthy, bisquity, a little tart grapefruit, toasted, dry caramel. These flavors sail on into the dry finish. A firm, sharp bitterness supports the flavors.
Comments: The flavors and mouth feel is drier than the sweet nose suggests. The palate is also deceptive as the full, rustic flavors are carried on a relatively light-medium bodied ale.  A great choice for a staple beer--one to always have on hand for yourself or company.

Day two tasting (recapped and refridgerated immediately after initial pour).

Aroma: Rich, roasted caramelly malt, floral, yeasty and candy sugar notes.
Flavor: Orange, caramel, yeasty biscuit, with underlying green apple tartness. The finish transistions from caramel to burnt grain.
Comments: This held up well and evolved.  As with wine, this is a sign of a sturdy, well-made drink.

Talk about hype, this seems to be the goto belgian beer that guys that dont drink a lot, love saying its one of their favs. Ive had this before, but never reviewed it, so this is what I got. 
A: Deep amber color, thick off white head.
S: Big tart and tangy, with some funky notes on the end.
T: Big bitterness, balanced with some dank musty flavors in the mix.
M: Big bubbly carbonation, i guess typical of the style. 
D: Style benchmark, and this is a very good beer, but overall not an everyday belgian pale.

Bottle. Aged and "new". Stellar brew, my first and favorite of the Trappist. The aged deeps and mellows with an intricate blending of the spices and the malt.. Deep Amber-honey with a fruity tan head. I am very happy the princess lost her ring.. good fish!

Slightly hazy amber color with some small bubbles emerging, reminding me of champagne. Big sustaining cream colored head. Aroma is very complex with a lot of herbal notes like lavender, juniper berries, thyme, peppercorn and spearmint but I also pick up hay, raisins and orange peel. Taste is tart with green apples, juniper berries, yeast and spearmint. After a while I sense some citrus notes that I guess comes from dry hopping. Again, the small bubbles on your palate is reminiscent of the sensation you get from champagne. Never had a beer that taste just like this one...so quite original.
Bottle. Poured an amber color with a huge white head. Aroma was biscuits, bread, rasin, and dried fruits. Flavor was dough, fruitsm and malts. Medium body. A great beer.

4 months old bottle. Pours dark orange with a big creamy head. Aroma is bitterness from the hops, oranges, spicy and yeast. Taste is again bitter (floral), very thirst quenching and perfectly balanced out by some malty sweetness. Medium bodied and pleasant soft carbonation round off this great beer that is the ultimate brew for a hot day on a sunny terrace.
In my opinion, this is the less favorable trappist. The taste is nothing special and more bitter than the other trappists. After one gulp, you wont have the need to drink again.
Dark copper pour from bottle.  Huge, fluffy white head.  Aroma is oranges and mint.  Taste is fruity, with notes of pears and apple pie spices.  Smooth finish.  Really, really good.
More tart and hoppy than I expected.  More complex than it first lets on.  Good stuff. Serving: Bottle
Bottle:A special orange-colored abbey brew that tastes very dry and hoppy. Certainly this is a classic in the beer world.
Huge head on top of a copper coloured body. Hoppy but not that full-bodied, with citrusey notes that create a bit too sharp a tang to really be pleasant. OK but disappointing.
caramel, toast, bread, hay. This beer is a great representation of the trappist ale. Super dry. Super bready. A little spice. Great with hard cheeses.

Finally got around to rating this. Huge white head and could smell it when it hit the glass. The nose is amazing as always. Funk, and fruits. Taste is crisp and dry. Carbonated mouthfeel. One of my favorite beers.

This beer has unimpressed me in the past, but this time I gave it another shot at a "first" impression and am logging the rating. Starts with an over-the-top beige foam tower filling 9/10 the glass then condensing in a more suitable copper body. Clean sanitized yeastiness in the nose, nothing to interesting--as if it was stripped of all yeast funk. The body again showcases this sanitized antiseptic flavor with hints of soapiness. Muted hops, mostly lacking in flavor.  Dryish. Incredibly underwhelming and pretty poor in quality. Still, my rating is probably too generous.

A tall but quickly diminishing soapy head sits on a hazy amber ale.  A little swish raises the head back to its original height.  First to the nose is a funk of yeast and a champagne-like aroma of perspiration.  Then a smell close to grape cola and a light spicing.  Dry hops, lemons and apples round it off.  Sweet yet tart in taste with spice and funk.  Flavours of dried fruits and foliage with just a touch of juniper berries.  Carbonation is effervescent; the body is medium thin.  Finishes on the spice and funk, cleaning the palate with a tart lingering note.  Well balance and so very drinkable.

Pours a murky amber colour with a big rocky off-white head. Aroma is of hops, herb and spice, and some yeast. Taste is okay, slightly sweet but seemed somewhat watered down, nothing really jumps out. Light-medium body, smooth mouth feel and flat carbonation. Good beer, nothing objectionable but overall average.
A pretty standard Belgian ale , the only thing that really stands out is it is more hoppy than most Belgians.

gold with a slight red hue, cream head. aroma of citrus, hops and horse blanket. taste: bitterness at first followed by dry hops. hops are the distinctive element. orange peel and biscuit sweetness. My regular tiple.

This would be my first run in with this well known gem.  Bottled on 12/30/09, poured a hazy amber with a huge white, frothy, rocky and thick head.  My glass was full of rocky foam, sticky.  Aroma was of some sourness, caramel sweetness, some bread but overly sour.  Flavors included an intense sourness, somewhat puckering.  Some fruitiness left an impression as well.  Subtle bite in the finish.  Drank extremely smooth, didnt get much hop profile in the aroma or flavor.  Either way it was enjoyable, just not what I was expecting.  Ill have to give this another try in the near future.

Bottle. Light amber colour, slightly hazy, with a big frothy, off-white head. Very nice aroma with a subtle sourness, manifested by yeasty characteristics, coupled with notes of apple tart and some citrus. Also some caramel, bread and a nice hop profile. Taste is quite dry and sugary sweet and has a touch of yeast and bread, as well as flowers and fruits, orange and spices. It has a nice bite and and grips your tongue nicely. Some sourness. Low carbonation, medium duration. Very interesting.

[Bottle] Pours a bright golden color with a lasting cap of white, pillow-like head. Initial aromas of yeast, citrus, biscuits and light fruits. The taste is fruity, and with a weizen character. Some banana, cherry and apple spice notes. Lingering spice and some earthiness as well. Fantastic body/palate here. Quite flavorful and highly drinkable at the same time. It was good to finally sit down and rate this one.

Aroma: bread, hay, nuts, basement aromas. Very earthy and complex.
Appearance: brown, reddish hue. Clear with frothy head.
Taste: medium sweet body with light bitter tones and very pronounced bread and earthy tones. Very pleasant, alcohol taste comes a little in the back but not overpowering. You realize its there after you take a sip.
Palate: thick texture with medium carbonation and long bread finish.
Very good beer. One of the seven Trappist Belgium brews. Worth your money.
Très bonne bière trappiste. Goût distinctif et bien équilibré. Belle couleur et belle mousse. Logo de la truite ayant trouvé la bague de Mathilde selon la légende dOrval. Site web orval.be
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Spicy sweet & sour aroma. Cloudy medium brown colour with a good head. Complex flavour, dry fruity and spicy with bitter aftertaste. Nice bottle.

aroma is fruity and bright. reminded me of a lambic. a sense of oakiness to it as well. 
pours an orangey brown, and cloudy. head is light and recedes quite quickly.
light-med sweetness, and medium bitterness and lightly sour.
medium body, a really dry beer that ends with a lingering sweetness that makes u sip again. 
enjoyable. not my favourite trappist but it is very unique and different. worth a try

11.2oz bottle.  Great, golden orange pour with reddish hues.  Big, frothy, off white head compliments and very beautiful, aromatic nose consisting of yeast, spices, orange citrus, and slight banana esters.  A floral hop profile compliments a perfectly balanced body with spices, citrus, yeast, dark fruits, slight bitterness, and lively carbonation. This is beer.

From a bottle.  Pours hazy orange with a large white head that slowly dissipates.  Highly carbonated with loads of bubbles rising to the surface.  Aroma is fruity and spicy with bubblegum, belgian yeast, and maybe some banana.  Flavor is juicy fruit, some funk, and finishes with a nice spiciness.  This bottle has been in my cellar for about 8 months and is delicious.

330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy orange with a large head.  On the nose, theres yeast, bubblegum, banana and some hops.  Orange on the taste to start, sweet with a dry, bitter finish.  Not drunk something like this before!
Very slight yeasty aroma, with a hint of malt, fruit, and spice. Very nice, huge head that hung around for a while. Dry, spicy taste.
11.2 oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a huge white head.  Smells of yeast with a bit of sweetness. Smooth, dry, and light bodied with a bit of malty taste.  Clean finish.

Like smelling a meadow complete with flowers and a slight grassy note.  Pillowy tan head sits on a very slight hazy orange beer. Flavor is sweet but finish is dry.  Has cherry notes against strong hop bittering.  Some dusty/musty character.  Lively carbonation.
Nice beer,  I get raisins and cidery prunes,  A little thin tasting.  Nuce white head, deep copper color.

Bottled 03/08/2009.  What an outstanding beer!  Cloudy unfiltered orange hue with a massive foamy off white head that settles down to a medium sized head that is fully lasting, good lacing.  Wonderful array of interesting aromas - especially the yeasty aromas; moldy oranges, cheese, horse blanket.  Citrus spice and bread with a hint of banana.  The flavour profile is also interesting and very complex -  with varying degrees of sweet, bitter, sour, even some salinity, and umami at the end of the glass (is that from the yeast sediment ?) it has it all. Carbonation is just right, mildly peppery, I would like it more if it had more body, finishes dry.  Oh yes this is a wonderful beer. I only wish it lasted longer or had come in a larger bottle!

33 cl bottle. Pours dark amber with an ample off-white head. Aroma is fruity with notes of spice. The flavour is complex and balanced, sweet malt, fruit (tangerines), cinnamon, trappist yeast. It finishes dry and hoppy. Very enjoyable beer.

Beautiful hazy burnt orange colour with a long lasting foamy off white head. Aroma is slightly funky with plenty of bready yeast. The sour funkiness comes out more in the flavour and you can really pick out the brett character. Very enjoyable. A nice gateway beer to lambics.
Morbida, intensa, equilibrata con una schiuma infinita. Sentori di luppolo, agrumi, caramello. Asciutta e bevibilissima. Ottima!

Pours hazy orange-bronze with billowing, dense off-white head that lasts the length of the glass. Floral aroma with yeasty bread and some sour funk. Well balanced in the mouth, very dry with funk and malt and bitterness all playing well together to make a wonderful mouthful. Abundant carbonation and pleasant bitterness keep it very clean and light. Might be my favorite Trappist.
hay, brown,  taste is similair with aroma. medium body, oily feel, average carbonation, foam disappeared quickly!

Bottle. Aroma is hay, earthy, citrus. Taste is similar to the aroma. Amber color with white foam that disappears quickly.  Sparkling with quit a lot of sourness,  pretty refreshing. Some bitterness in the finish.

schiuma abbondante, ambrata luminosa con tonalità arancione, naso di lieviti belgi, profumo poco delicato, subito molto amara, calda con sentore di alcol, molto secca, frutta secca, fichi secchi,
specialità difficile, solo per amanti delle birre amare,
