si dice che ogni bottiglia di orval sia diversa, ne troverò di meglio. 

abundant foam, amber luminous with orange tonality, nose of leavens Belgian, not delicate scent, quickly much bitter, warmth with sentore of alcohol, much dry, yields sand bank, fichi buckets, specialty difficult, single for lovers of the bitter beers, one says that every bottle of orval is different, I will find some better.

Bottled 29/04/09, $6 @ Binnys. So heres the second most-rated beer I havent had yet (#1 is Rochfort Trappistes 10.) No special occasion, just rating #1977, and thats the year I turned 18 and could drink in Iowa. Pours a darker yellow with a thick, hilly yellowish head. Nice Belgian sweetness fills the air immediately. Taste has some nice drinkable qualities, but I can see how some people cant take to it. Note quite as sweet as the nose, but showing a little dryness. Firm and tiny carbonation bubbles. A bit of spiciness that keeps this from being just another malty beer. Should really be experienced in a group, so everyone can contribute their impressions toward a consensus of what this is about.

From the bottle (bottled on 5 Aug 2009), it pour orange-brown with a thick head. Aroma is plums, leather, and apricots. Lots of malt up front with tastes of raisins, bubble gum, and some kind of barnyard flavor with a light finish of alcohol. The hops quickly dissipate any sweetness that may occur from the Belgian yeasts.   Mouthfeel is carbonation dissolving to medium body.  Perhaps I got a bad bottle, but Im having difficulty determining why this one gets such high ratings.

This is an exception amongst the trappists. The bitterness is excellent when chilled.  One can drink it (with moderation) as a thirstquencher.
This beer really changes over time, it is remarkably different (fuller) after 6 or 12 months.
Fortunately widely available.

My hundredth rating!  Pours up clear orange with lots of head.  Had to pour the beer in parts to avoid overflowing the pint, even pouring down the side of the glass.  The foam is akin to the kind on the top of a root beer float in texture and body.  Not a lot of aroma, and not a lot of taste.  Its very light.  Am I getting a cold or something?  Im definitely enjoying this beer, but I cant say what it tastes like.
Really fruity, nice soft malt and hop charicter... Brett accentuates fruityness... Yum

If you dont like this beer you are not drinking it correctly pure and simple.  I have been to the monastery twice now and I have had this beer with bread and cheese made by the monks there for breakfast.  You have to drink this beer cold and in a goblet.  No other glass will do.  Smell the beer a couple of times first with your eyes closed and then take a drink.  I love beer generally - all types but this beer is an experience.  You just have to do it right.  And if you have the means, it is worth your time to make the pilgrimage.  The only ding I give this beer is the palate.  It is a bit light in my opinion.  Just a bit more mouth feel would make this the ultimate experience.
why does this beer rate so high? maybe i just dont appreciate belgians. its pretty good. must be a reputation thing.
bottle. great name and logo! nice fruity taste, longer aroma, pleasantly bitter.
#675! A cloudy deep orange pour with thick foamy white head. ABV 6.9%. Scent is sweet citrus and floral. Taste is complex, I get some grapefruit and spice with a dry finish.

this smells amazing: pretty strong banana-y smell, a sweetness that isnt cloying, (weirdly, a leathery background), and spice (cloves? i dont think thats a spice, but thats in there too). cloudy gold with a a huge head. flavors settled more as it warmed up, loved the dryness and (always) the booze at the end.
Very nice cloudy amber colour.  Thick foamy head that rises fast and reduces to frothiness slowly.  High carbonation.  Spicy aroma.  Lingers on palate.  Good beer.

Birra affascinante unica nel suo genere.Al naso prima che i sentori orientati verso lerbaceo ne prendano il possesso,si sviluppa un particolare sentore fruttato di albicocca,che fa presumere lassaggio di una birra dolce.In realtà la birra è ben orientata sullamaro e sul floreale derivante probabilmente dalla luppolatura a secco.

Very complex aroma with fruity esters, spicy notes, hops, banana and clove. Medium golden color with medium clarity, a persistent frothy white head that imparts fine lacing. Outstanding flavor with multiple layers of hop bitterness, fruit, spice and bubblegum. Very dry on the palate with some nice alcohol warmth. The profile says 6.2%, bottled at 5.2% can go as high as 7.2%. My bottle says 6.9% abv. Overall this is an incredibly enjoyable Belgian Trappist ale that gains extra complexity due to the addition of the Brett. I took it out of the fridge a good twenty minutes before tasting and rated it high, but as it warmed up more throughout the tasting and the aroma and flavor opened up more, I had to revisit and increase some of my scores. May I have another please?

Coppery color with a yellowish white head. Aroma of aged fruit. Very dry flavor of hops, spices, and a hint of unsweet fruitiness. Very crisp finish. Strong bodied, but does not weigh heavily on you as a higher alcohol beer would.

(11.2 oz bottle @ 6.9 ABV)  A fragrant Belgian ale with ripe banana and bubblegum aroma. Thick creamy head with a light amber color and modest carbonation. The taste does not meet expectations. Dry, but can have a metallic or slightly medicine aftertaste. Alcohol is not well hidden.

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured with a murky, amber color with a respectable tan head that reduced to minimal lacing. Fruity aroma with banana, peach, apple, grapes. Nice hoppy kick, that mellows into a vinous, somewhat acidy taste. Medium dense oily body, well carbonated with no taste of alcohol. Honey-like sweetness, with a dry, hoppy finish. Really nice.

Upon first smell I was really excited.banana, bubblegum, along with bread and caramel assaulted my nostrils.  The head was huge rocky and frothy atop a hazy amber liquid.  The taste is where I was slightly let down.  With such an awesome look and smell I expected this beer to taste incredible.  Instead it tasted good.  Obviously thats not a bad thing, but the texture was not exactly what I wanted and the bubbles were a bit abrasive in the beginning.  Orval is a great beer, its just not my favorite Belgian.

Aroma:  bubblegum and bananas.  Cloudy amber-orange with tall, puffy light beige head.  Lots of retention.  Minimal lacing.   Taste is tart, cidery, banana and yeast.  Watery, too.  Medium-light mouthfeel, foamy.  Metallic / medicinal (benzocaine) aftertaste.  Disappointing.  Not at all what I was expecting.  Maybe Ill retry someday.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2010 A - Spice, with bubblegum aroma and wild yeast
A - Orangey brown and hazy, with pillowy white head
T - Sour, with a bitter finish...quite mellow and dry
P - Soft carbonation with a thin texture
O - Admittedly, trappists are not my favourite beers, but this is alright

Golden with a hint of amber, slightly hazy, big white head, fades relatively quickly.... funky, slightly tart aroma, slight barnyard, a slight touch of lemon... spicy, dry, medium light body, lingering dry finish... not nearly as funky in the flavor, touch of barnyard, drys out so fast, flavors fade quickly...

Pours a beautiful dark golden to light amber with enormous white head that remains long, and laces well.  Nose has the traditional barnyard/brett, but a lighter and more approachable take on that.  Some ripe apples and candied nuts are noted as well.  On the palate the wild flavors come through as well, with some suggestions of black tea, and a musty/musky old wood chest in the attic sort of flavor.  Finish is musty as well.

Orval bottle with bottled on date of 24/04/2007, best before 24/04/2012.
Poured into a duvel tulip glass.
Pours a huge pillowy offwhite head that slowly retreats. Color is a red tan hue. Smells of tart fruit and the belgian yeast. Taste is very smooth and lighter than I would have expected. The carbonation bubbles all around your mouth. Slight bite on the tongue is the first flavor I pick up followed by the taste of fruit. Finishes with a slight bitterness.
I was looking forward to trying this after reading all the good reviews. My only negative is that I wish it had a little heavier mouthfeel to it.

A-pours a hazy golden orange with dark yellow edges and a thin bubbly white head.

S-tons of brett, yeast, notes of pepper and corriander, lemon rind underneath with a light herbal hop presence in the back.

T-brett right up front, hints of sour lemon, yeast.  notes of a peppery spice and corriander.

M-medium body, grainy on the palate with a slightly syrupy texture, very dry finish with good carbonation that allows it to finish crisp without the bite.

D-insanely drinkable, all sorts of things going on working in harmony, world class beer!

6.9% bottle. I honestly do not see what all the hype is about. Caramel colored brew with a frothy white head. Strong aromas of dough, spice, and booze. Tastes slightly of wheat, some spice, and a bit of fruit. A dry finish with a somewhat unpleasant bitter aftertaste. Noticeable carbonation, slightly boozy taste. The finish is so abruptly dry that it kills any type of flavor momentum it was building up till then. Not my thing.

The initial aroma is very yeast-y. Its smells like rising dough. Its a dark gold color--pretty cloudy--with a thick, foamy head. Its astringent, yet floral with a unique taste. The carbonation is fizzy, which leaves a burning sensation in the back of the throat. While its not an amazing beer, its worth a taste.

Pours a deep amber with a massive white head.  Nose is wonderful.  Belgian yeast and lots of barnyard.  Flavor is belgian yeast with a bit of citrus (grapefruit) and some bread.  Very fizzy mouthfeel with a dry finish.  Nice beer.
Bottle @ Home. aroma is citrus, amber orange color with a nice head lively carbonation with medium body. A very tastefull beer. had this one over 30 times ( not in one day of course).

An amazing murky orange amber hue, with a cloud like cream head. Aroma was citrusy and yeasty but a bit faint. The taste was like a medium dry white wine, with a faint hop tatse. The taste really is lacking. Its good but not as good as I hoped.

330 mL bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a Trappist glass. Pours hazy amber with a 1.5 cm off-white pillowy head. Head has great retention and laces well. On the nose, aromas of banana, yeast, pear, pepper, and clove with a hint of hops and pepper. Flavour starts out with a light sweetness and a moderate acidity. The sweetness soon fades, replaced by a moderate bitterness. The finish is long and dry, with an alcohol-peppery finish. On the palate, light-medium in body with a dry texture and lively carbonation. The finish is also lightly astringent. Overall, a fine Belgian ale but too dry for my taste. 2010-05-22
Nice head (off-white) that was very creamy. The body was a opaque orange brown. Aorma was very citrusy and quite hoppy.A very complex pleasure.

Pours a GORGEOUS murky amber with  HUGE foamy head.  Absolutely GORGEOUS beer.  Once the foam dies down a bit, the aroma has all the hallmarks of a traditional Belgian with notes of warm bread, caramel and malty goodness.

The flavor changes a lot as it warms up and it changes for the better - some sour notes even seem to come out.  This is definitely one you want to let sit for a few minutes before drinking.   Overall the  palate is similar to the nose.  There is a nice but not overwhelming bubbly carbonation that creates an interesting dry finish.

Very very nice interesting beer and something that I will DEFINITELY be drinking again soon.

Poured a hazy brownish amber with a large off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, spicy, malty with a little yeast.  Orange and other citrus notes.  Taste is sweet and malty like a wheat beer with a spicy finish.  Reminds me more of a belgian white than a trappist ale but its very good.

Pours orange-amber with an enormous, long lasting off-white head. Nose is lemons, lemons, and more lemons, with a little alcohol and spiciness. The flavor is roughly the same....very citrus dominated and sweet, but with a quick, dry, and more orangy-tasting finish. The hops are quite subdued. A tart trappist with some witbier-like characteristics...not sure if I like that or not.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2011 33 cl bottle, pours hazy golden with a nice head that has solid retention and nice lacings, lots of carbonation, aroma of fruit, brett, dough and malt,  taste is fairly dry with notes similar to the aroma, pretty smooth mouthfeel, super allround beer.

Pours yellow/light brown with a huge white head, good lacing and carbonation throughout the entire tasting. Aroma is of bananas, spices, a little bit of hops. Taste is a slight tinge of alcohol followed by a dry and mellow finish. "Dry and fruity like Joan Baez, whom my father thinks is one hot bitch and my uncle thinks is the antidote for Cialis"

Bottle. Hazy golden orange colour with a huge foamy off-white head. Sweet fruity aroma with notes of citrus, spices and malt. The flavour is sweetish malt, grapefruit, citrus and spicy yeast. Finish is dry and slightly bitter.
Pours a reddish brown in the glass with an exquisite white head. Nose and taste of raisins, lemongrass, citrus and some other fruits. Rated 1/15/2000

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2011 Pours orange/yellow with off white head that is frothy and lasting.  Nice grass, citrus, and lemony hops complements some funky barnyard and earth in the aroma.  Taste is creamy, a bit of hops leading into a funk middle with a dry bitter finish.  Great brew!

Pours a amber copper that has a little haze.  Aroma consists of apple, pepper, citrus and yeast.  Taste is spicey, not quite sweet and not quite bitter.  Light to medium mouthfeel with a dry tart finish.  Very nice.

Pours a dark cloudy orange with a big rocky off white head.  Aroma is fruity and spicy with a bit of bubblegume and some funk.   Flavor is surprisingly bitter and tart, lots of fresh fruits, some cotton candy, citrus and spice.  Light bodied with aggressive carbonation.
Bottle 330ml.Color hazy orange with big head. Aroma fruits, bread. Taste cherries, alcohol, bitter, reminds wine.Great beer.

Bottle. Had two bottles of this beer, bought at different places with different exp. dates. The one I drank yesterday(the older one) was more amber-coloured than the other and had a stronger aroma. Complex taste of fruits, hints of white wine. Really enjoyed this beer, Im sure going to drink lots more of this. Beautifully shaped bottle too.

11.2oz bottle.  Hazy orange-tan color, with a massive off-white head.  Sweet Brett, hop aroma.  I really find different nuances in this beer every time I have it.  This bottle is coming off very fruity and funky to me.  Lots of underlying wheat flavors.  Such a unique mouthfeel.  Not quite sour, but very reminiscent of Lambics.  Somewhat sandy on the palate, the hops deliver a straightforward bitterness.  Incredible depth.  Fruity Belgian yeast notes.  Wow.  An absolute masterpiece of a beer.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2011 Bottle. Poured a murky amber with some orange undertones and a huge white foamy head that was mostly diminishing but had fantastic lacing. 

The aroma was heavy of a straw like malt, a moderate floral hop and a moldy scented yeast with notes of dried fruit (raisins), a hint of spice and some citrus (lemon and maybe orange) with a mild alcohol tinge. 

It tasted a malty, a little bitter and slightly sour with a hint of a peppery spice in the beginning and finished lightly bitter and yeasty with notes of fruit, citrus and a slight alcohol tinge at the end. The flavor was left to linger for a while, leaving a light sourness on the palate.

Mouthfeel was light to medium in body and a little oily in texture with the carbonation being quite pronounced, almost prickly in feel.

Overall a fantastic Trappist Ale, I can see now why the Monks only brew this one beer.

Bottled 07.01.2010 from Alko. Poured dark orange color with a enourmous frothy white head. Aroma is sour fruits and hops. Well carbonated. Flavour is fruity, hint of strawberry and apples, with some citrus in there also.  Ends very dry. Read alot about this classic beer, now I had the opportunity to try it. Maybe not lived up to all my expectations, but sure worth a try, and I will definitely try it again. Enjoyed it bit too cold I think, next one perhaps has aged a little more.

30.04.2010, 0,5l Bottle. Golden colour with white head. Aroma is malty with a very dry bitterness. Both aroma and aftertaste is totaly dominated by the dry hops. Aftertaste is also dry and bitter, and it lasts. Nice.

Bottle from LCBO. Pours a clear copper blonde color with a dense thick foamy head. Strange aroma of sour oak, cherries, and bready Belgian malts. Flavors are extremely dry and complex with a lightly tart finish. Perhaps Im not as attuned to this beer as the general community. I feel its a strange beer overall, not really sure if I like it as much as the average suggests I should.

Holds a nice thin frothy head while body is a deeper copper. Aroma is nice, a sweet mix of spice and malt with a sweet folral perfum. Taste is somewhat confusing- a fizzy champagne like character and dryness with a slightly thicker body midway through also having a cereal quality that I cant put my finger on, guessing that it was from the yeast. Definite hints of spice and delicate hops. Finishes crisp and light.  The beer did get markably better in both taste in palatte the more I drank. At first I was almost put off by it, but by the end of the beer I liked it.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2011 33cl bottle. Pours a cloudy light amber color with a huge soapy white head. Good lacing. Long lasting foam. Very funky smelling with a lingering floweriness and light bready notes. Taste is hoppy, a bit vinous, with a decise barnyard flavor to it. Medium bodied. Very complex brew. One of the all times best.

Pours a dark cloudy brown with thick white fluffy head. Highly carbonated. Aroma of yeast, citrus, raisins and mild hops. Rich mouthfeel, taste of dough, citrus, sweet with a nice mild hop backround to balance it out. Pretty damn good beer, with great balance

A- This is one beautiful beer. Cloudy translucent pale yellow body that pours with giant 3+ finger white head that slowly settles to 1 1/2 finger and with great retention. Plenty of lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Floral hops are noticed first followed by Belgian yeast and a peppery spice-somewhat of a funky ale yeast strain.

T- Initial taste is dominated by carbonation but lots of Belgian yeast and hints of peppery spice can be detected. The finish is a kick of bitter hops and peppery spice that was surprising to me considering the style. Lingering is a mild hop bitterness and hints of yeast and peppery spice.

P- High carbonation and medium weight body heavy in yeast and alcohol. Not as smooth as I expected on the swallow.

O- I am probably harsh since this is a style that I like and it just didnt live as far up to my expectations. It is actually good and easy to drink overall but it doesnt stand out to me. I would it buy it much more often if it were more affordable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-13-2007 05:42:15

11.2 oz bottle into Trappist glass. 2007 bottle. Funky aroma--smells like a sour ale. Brett, anyone? Perfume-like scent comes out after sitting for a bit. Pours yellowish brown with nice creamy lacing and a long-retaining off-white head. Taste is sour and a bit medicinal at first (this goes away fairly quick). Maybe a tad watery; fully carbonated. Nice aftertaste. This is the strangest Trappist Ive ever had. If one were to personify all the Trappist ales and put them in a line, Orval would be the one with the tattered robe adorned with spiked tassles and a pierced nostril. You just know theres a mohawk hidden underneath that hood.

Bottle pour into trappist glass.  Aroma is top notch, candied fruits and toasted sugars.  Pours a light bronzy copper with an excellent citrus tinged head that lasted throughout.  Much dryer than the aroma would hint.  Taste is citrusy, alcoholy, a slight flavor of scotch, surprising bitters.  Aftertaste is actually much nicer than the taste itself.  High carbonation makes and nice Belgian weight make for a pleasant mouthfeel.  An ale I would definitely like to reinvestigate as my palate develops.

This was my first Trappist.  Shocked, surprised to say the least.  Slightly hazey orange gold with large foamy head.  Fruity, sweet citrus taste.  Enjoyed it more as I progressed.  Alcohol content not overpowering.  Every bottle seems a new experience.  Complex for sure.  Amazing.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours a medium amber with a large frothy off-white head - great retention.  Nose is sweet but with a hint of sourness.  Hoppy orange and spice aromas.  The taste is sweet and light but very complex, with yeast, fruit, and lots of spice.  The finish is long, dry, and spicy with some more earthy yeast.  Overall a really interesting and tasty beer.

Bottle.

A - Hazy light copper orange with a huge frothy, creamy white head. Excellent retention with a good thick lacing left.

S - Complex smell. Good mix of tangy and funky smell. You get a lot of tangy and zesty orange and lemon along with some pear. There is a slight alcohol and winey smell as well. A bit of pepper smell comes out. The Brett funk comes out a lot as well with a bit of horse blanket smell. A good, complex mix of citrus, tangy, sweet, spiced, funky smells. 

T - Quite different from the smell. A good amount of medicinal and metallic taste are upfront. There is also a bit of lemony citrus zest along with that. There is a strong funky Brett taste in the background as well. Even fainter is a bit of herbal hops, a bit of pepper, and some white wine like flavors. Interesting and complex, but I didnt find it incredibly enjoyable. I did like it better the more I drank though.

M - Light to medium body with above average carbonation. Fairly creamy but a bit drying at the end.

D - Well the taste was interesting, and I kept wanting to drink more to discover more flavors and get a better handle on the beer. It went down easy and was somewhat refreshing, but the taste wasnt great, and I probably wouldnt drink a number of these in a night. 

Notes: Bottled on 06/10/2009. Very interesting beer that is completely different from the other Trappist beers. Definitely had a funky Brett taste, I was just hoping for a bit more fruity taste to go with it. Not a bad beer, but i might get some getting used to. I did start liking it better the more I drank it.

Appearance: Hazy orange/amber colour, big white head, lacing.
Aroma: Spices, yeast, lemon, vinegar, hops, fruits, sugar, peaches, not too strong but extremely complex.
Flavour: Cider, hops, big bite, vinegar, yeast, lemon, wheat? Spices, leathery extremely complex and layered,
Mouthfeel: Lively yet smooth.
Total: This beer is hard to wrap your head around it is elusive and enticing, this truly asks the question are you worthy?
hazy light brown with big white head.  strong funky yeast aroma.   very dry and sour with a little citrus.

Bottle pours cloudy orange with huge fluffy white head.  the aroma is sweet and floral, probably one of the nicest aromas Ive ever enjoyed.  Unfortunately the taste doesnt match the aroma, sour and citrusy with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2010 Hazy amber in color with very rich fluffy white head leaving pretty lacing on the glass. Sweetish malty and yeasty aroma with fresh fruits. Re-rating and appreciating the taste even more. Complex beer and great flavor indeed. Sourly malty in the palate and finishes very quickly with a grassy dry bitter/sour aroma.

Poured into an Orval goblet:: This bottle is dated from 19/01/2010.Drank just a bit above room temp. As Orval is poured a foamy ,creamy beer head rises and straight up resembles  clouds . Drank from its own Orval goblet its a beautiful sight.  Glowing orange beneath this amazing foamy beer head. Orvals aroma is stunning. Makes me think of Spring time and my bel amour. Fragrence, hops, perfume ,flowers,spices , oranges , musty funk, scrumpy cider tangz. The beer is very flavousome to drink.   Uncomprimisingly dry , bitter and with a big dose of funky  , its complex and soothing at once.  Sessionable and exciting every time.   Sublime everytime.

The intense aroma of banana is immediately apparent and delicious. The golden orange color carries a beautiful huge head when poured in the proper glassware. Definitely the dry character described is the most pronounced part of the flavor, with subtle hop undertones from the dry-hopping process.
Thanks to fata for this beer. Orange color with large rocky head.  Nice citrusy taste with banana.  Very dry aftertaste.  Thisvery complex. I also tasted somepeppery in there.  Very Nice beer

Bouteille 33 cl achetée chez Bier-Bienne (CH). En robe de bure orangée limpide, elle pétille agréablement et a une mousse abondante et légère. Le nez est dominé par lamertume, puis lacidulité, le fruité et les herbes. Goût intense de houblon, amertume bien là, piquante avec un parfum dherbes, un régal. Ampleur extraordinaire et caractère complexe, elle restera sèche mais exceptionnelle.

Bottle. Orange brown yellow blended into a sunset with big frothy white head. Aroma of lime, gummy bears, grass, light vinegar. Like a dry white wine with mango, white grape and pear fruits. Taste is earthy and apple sauce without cinnamon and other fruits with bitter tart finish that lingers. Palate is wild bubbles and yeast tingle on the tongue which loses carbonation almost completely by the end of the beer.

Time to get on this classic monolith of a beer. Pouring: big, soap-bubbly head topping off a nice looking light brown body, just about as deep in color as you can get and still passing it off as a blonde ale... Smell is great; grassy and floral, with a fruity hop aroma and hints of bread and pine in between. The first taste gives me something I can only describe as a dry-hopped bun flavor, a very complex and original combination. The palate is all right, without being very notable. As I progress, faint citrus tones start to come up. Some yeast as well, without going all tripel on me. Fresh and tasty, and such a counterpart to the usually sweet, dark Trappist ales. Bitter floral hop aftertaste, perhaps a bit more than I like. Still, Orval is a monolith in the world of beer, not to be underestimated.

The aroma is very nice, green apples, citrus, brett (relatively mild here), some barnyard.  The appearance is hazy amber color, strong white head.  The flavor is considerably more funk, sour, light fruit (peach, apple), dry white wine.  The finish is tart fruit, resiny hops, lingering.  The mouthfeel is carbonated, the body is thin/medium.  Excellent.  A beer that actually lives up to its buzz - amazing!!
Pours hazy yellow and brown with a huge white head. The aroma is peachy with a hint of yeast. Flavor is dry, a bit peachy. Unlike anything Ive tasted before. Quite nice.

Had this while celebrating WVUs win over Kentucky in great 8.  Poured  brown with a nice off white head.  Aroma has alot of malt sweetness and lots of dark fruit aromas. Taste is nice and dry with lots of fruit through out. Nice dry finish with a slight alcohol burn towards the end. Very good.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 11.2 oz. bottle (bottled on 14/11/2006)  Pours a slightly hazy dark golden color with lively carbonation and a large fluffy white head.  The aroma is big and complex.  Fruity (citrus, apples), floral, Brett, pale malts, white wine and yeast.  The flavor is quite a bit more funky than the nose would indicate.  It is more herbal with quick hints of citrus,white wine and pale malts.  The brett character is present.  A dose of bittering hops adds to the finish.  The finish is dry, bitter and slightly peppery.  Some sour funk lingers long into the finish.  Medium bodied and truly a unique beer that I dont know if I have the palate to do justice.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2011 330 ml bottle. For me this beer seems to taste different every time I drink it, depending on what I had before, food and general daily form. Therefore I  decided there where no point in rating this, its just what it is.  
Anyway this is my 2000 rating so I change my mind and will try to put down a few words in celibration. Its a bit unclear orange body with lots of small bubbles and a thick lasting white head. Aroma is not strong, but very nice. Its mainly citric fruity with a pleasant funky Bret stamp. Usually I manage to identify citric fruit, sometimes it seems to be more grapefruit and other times oranges. I can smell a delicate hint of spices, maybe coriander of maybe something else, there is yeast and also hints of older hops. Bret is always present, sometimes more acidic than other times, but never very strong acidity. Flavor has a lot in common with aroma, and always feels very refreshing and quaffable. Mild malt, sometimes hint of caramel, fruity like citrus, mild, dry bitterness, spices, refreshing acidity and a soft and balanced finish with bitterness, acid and sweetness in harmony. Pure magic!
Bottle. Orange brown unclear color, big white head. Malty hoppy and pepper nose. Aroma is spicy and citrusy, dry finish. Taste is light sour and a bit bitter. Very complex beer.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 Bottle. Pours an orange honey color with an inch and a half of smooth, creamy beige head. Lots of carbonation trails throughout the glass and solid lacing. Aroma is sharp and funky with lots of Belgian yeast, lemon and pears. Taste is dry and tart upfront with some citrus, yeast, malt and grassy hops notes. There is a strong sour note throughout that gives it a unique character along with the heavy carbonation. It finishes with a warm alcohol kick and a dry, earthy aftertaste. The overall flavor is jarring at first but gradually becomes more pleasant towards the end of the bottle.

330ml Bottle  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma  Big Belgian yeast aroma.  Sweet malt with lots of banana and pepper.  
Appearance  Amber in color, Slight Haze with a fluffy lacey head. 
Flavor  Big flavors malty sweet with banana and pepper through out the brew. Has that dry fruit flavor lingering.  Tad paper like to me.  
Palate    Super Dry finish with a nice Belgian Mouthfeel. 
Overall  As to style this is the shizzle.  As to my type not even.  Hops are bitter with the peeper flavors too much. Has a nice lace and a good sour finish also.  Here is to one of the top beers in the world.  Sorry not my style but I can see why there are legions following this brew.

Pours an excellent clear amber with a decent, sticky head. The nose is initially malt heavy, sweet with banana and spices, as well as some darker fruit and fudge, vanilla, tobacco and just a whiff of cabbage. Mouth is pretty thin, but with a tangy kick, leads with sweet, bicuity malts characterized by some banana with some sour but refreshing lemon tartness and grapes on the swallow. Alcohol is present, but not overbearing. Unfortunately I poured this one cold so initially it had no aroma to speak of, but as it warms the nose becomes more sweet and complex. Additionally, the malt sweetness becomes less evident in the mouth giving way to the light, sour character.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 Fresh: Gives an enormous frohty off-white head that leaves some lacing . Pours a murky orange-brown. Aroma is sour and a bit funky, some ctirus and that typical belgian spicyness. Complex dry taste with some sourness, earthy, grassy and some funk. Medium body and lively carbonation. Overall a strangely refreshing beer.

2004 bottle at Kulminator:
Aroma: 7 Appearance: 4 Taste: 7 Palate: 3 Overall: 15
Unclear golden colorer with a big white dense head. Smells like a farm! Some goat pee and wet horse, but in a good way. Flavors are mellowed out compared to a fresh Orval. It has changed a lot over its six years of age, in a very interesting way.

Honestly?  Not my favorite trappist, though Ill give it a fair review.

Malty citrus notes in the nose.  Pours a light color for a trappist with a thick, creamy  head.  Notes of heavy hops, citrus, and light malt on the palate.  Good, unique, interesting trappist brew.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2012 Hazy brown/copper/orange pour, thick tanned head.
Aroma is very hoppy and fruity with funky red fruit, huge raspberry, some citrus, hint of spice, all covered with a very subtle brett note. Just loverly.
Flavour is very dry, lightly sour fruit, mildly bitter hops, lightly sweet fruit, in that order, fading into each other oh so smoothly.
Very nice balance, best brett use ever, awesome stuff.

Orange color, big white head; aroma of sour fruits and floral hops; medium body, smooth, lively carbonation; flavor is also of sour fruits like apples and citrus backed up by some delicate sweet malty tones still never stealing the show, which, by the way, has a pretty dry hoppy finish. Actually, this may not be the most complex of trappist beers, but what it has to offer is in just great balance as you would expect from the brewery making only one beer to public. And mine was still very young so I would be curious to find out what good would a little aging do to this.
Sour trappist ale with dry finsih. Toasted malts and earthy palate but good drinkability. Very original

11.2 FL OZ champagne shaped dark brown, bottled on 05/08/09.  Great looking bottle with nice weight.. Pours huge escaping cloud of off white head leaving a hazy dark burning amber of ale underneath.   Aroma mixes sweet with a little grass meets leaves funk .  Taste a little touch of orange covered with a meduim sour maltiness and a bit of alcohol. Carbination is lively and the texture is smooth with a nice quick bitter finish.

330ml bottle 
Appearance: Slightly hazy orange/amber with a nice fluffy white head, leaving lacing in the glass 
Aroma: Brett, lemons and spices 
Taste: Spices and citrus up front and then some sourness and hops in the finish 
This is a very nice beer. Enjoyable to drink, crisp and clean.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2012 A copper brown beer with a big and blond head. Aroma is very delicious, lot of bananas, green apples, yeast, spicy and some overcooked  fruits. Flavour is complex, sour and almost raw green apples, yeast, sourness, bananas, dry bitterness, spicies nad herbs. The flavour is more balanced and smoothier with yeast and individual nuancees are not so strong. Quite easy to drink with balanced carbonation. Orval is very complex beer with interesting nuancees and challences; classic.
Pours amber with a large white head. Aroma is light caramel, brett, light hop, horseblanket, grapefruitseest and fruity notes. Flavour is grapefruit, horseblanket, some sweetness at first.

Bottle. Pours a hazy semidark orange with a huge, I mean enormous rocky, bubbly tan head leaving substantial amounts of itself on the flass wall as it slowly recedes. Looks gorgeous. Aroma is a nice blend of sweet, sour and funky, most of the latter. Barnyard, some cheese, dusty notes, with a slight citric acidic tinge, some hard to pin down sweetness beneath it all, with a bit of alcohol as well. Sweet at first, a pretty big bitter and lemony sour dryness quickly hits, and rounds it off. with yeasty funk notes lingering for a while. Light in body, this sparkly brew is a refreshing and drinkable one, not one you need to delve into with full concentration, but one you easily could if you wanted to. If anything, Id want it a bit less dry in the finish and the alcohol a bit toned down as its a fairly pronounced when it warms.

Fairly strong aroma of orange, lemon and vanilla with some citrusy hops in the background. This is not a pretty beer. Color is cloudy orange brown that makes me think of dishwater. Murky or dirty but it does boast a thick, rocky white head that is somewhat impressive. The flavor is primarily bitter and acidic but quite light and enjoyable. Whatever malt is present is light and overshadowed. The palate is thin and somewhat astringent. This is a good beer overall but Im still disappointed because it doesnt feature the complexity that ive come to expect in a Trappist ale.

Bottle 330ml. Delicious and different. Aromas of apple, yeast, and caramel. Taste is great, it starts sweet with some sourness, and it has a long bitter finish. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Orange, bubbly, with a big frothy head.

Sampled in its 330ml brown "bowling pin shaped" bottle. This Trappist strong ale pours a beautiful orange-red colour with a big foamy head. Good retention and lacing. Sediments float at the bottom of my chalice glass. Aroma is spicy and slightly sour. Lots to be found, but I have a hard time writing the smells. Taste is kind of weird... or different. Some bitterness here and there, mixed in with some tart. Also, some lemon, and quite dry. The bitterness is like something I have tasted at the dentist a couple of time. Still, a good strong Belgian ale, but not my cup of tea. P.S. This brew has a 5 year shelf life.

Pour a murky tan with tons of rocky creamy head with good long-lasting lacing.  Watch a warmer pour with this one as it WILL spill over. Aroma is moderate bread with light hops and a strong leather, barnyard earthy dusty smell.  There is also a slight coriander funk to it.  The different aromas are all evident in the taste as well with the inital flavor more sour and the finish more bitter.  The finish last quite a long time.  Palate is medium full, very dry, with lively carbonation and a chalky lightly alcoholic feel.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a huge white head. Beautiful lacing around the glass. Hoppy aroma with notes of sweet fruit, orange peel, spices and bread. Flavours are very complex, which carry on from the aroma. It has a acidic and tart character, then ends with a dry and bitter finish. Medium body with strong carbonation. An unique and interesting trappist beer for the senses.

Bottled, 6,2%. Pours hazy orange with large, lasting, frothy off-white head. Taste is slightly sour and light. Palate has medium body, long finish. Aromas are surprisingly sparse, has sweet citrus, leather and hay.

Out of a bottle into a trappistes goblet. Bottled on 04/29/2009 opened 02/28/2010. Beutiful burnt orange color with an inch thick froathy white head. Nice head retention. Aroma is of brett. Taste is bitter with a dry finish. Interesting brew.

33cl bottle. Hazy golden to orange color with a big creamy white head that leaves some beatifull lacing. Aroma is complex and malty with some fresh orange peel and some musty dust from the brett. Taste is malty with fresh orange peel and a nice dry hoppy taste. Aftertaste is bitter and very dry.
A unique beer!

Bottle from Kvickly, 6,2 % ABV. Rating #268.  
Yellow-brown opaque beer with enormous cream-thick, but airy head.
This beer in clearly unfiltered and has parts from the fermentation which glues itself on the sides of the glass. Beautiful.
Aroma is eweet and sour aroma with berries and great amounts of hops. Maybe there is some green apples too. Very appealing. 
Flavor is sour with obvius impression of hops, but mostly bitter hops. Notes of pepper and other indefineable spices are in there too.
Nice bitter finish, but not such an exciting beer as the appearance and aroma promised. I must admit that I am a little bit dissapointed from this famous beer. Some yeast-flavor hides in the complexity too.
Medium body, powerful carbonation.

HAzy dark golden body with thick white head. Lots of laces. Some apple and sourness on aroma, hops too. Sour beer, quite thinner than I expected. Some apple is present. Bitterness in firt rush, then disappearing.
Was very smooth and has a hint of being heavier then a normal belgium, but was still delicious!

Sour wine and champagne aroma. A nice, sour funk. White wine grape and ripe green apples. Intense dude.

Hazy honey-golden color. Nice, pure white head. Deep and cloudy. Head is thick and puffy.

The flavor is darkly sweet, hints of dark grape. Sour as hell with a hint of vinegar (but thats not a bad thing in context). Still dark, but with more funk notes than Bootsy Collins.

Thick and sticky feel, akin to a gritty red wine. Lots of Bretts in this, I would think. A good, darkish beer. Quite good, although not as transcendant as I had expected.
Pours a cloudy reddish amber. Earthy nose with lemon and lime. Lightish on the palate with more citrus. Classic profile and quite nice.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2017 Bottle. Pretty darn solid. Im still not a huge wild yeast fan, but this is the closest I have come yet. Nose is funky, saddle blanket yeast with some intense earthy notes and mild fruit. Flavor was also funky, light hops, some hints of sour fruit. Light to medium in body and  quite dry. I enjoyed this beer more as I made my way through it. (3.9, drank in NYC c. 2009/2010)Bottle at home in London - picked up from Selfridges. Bottled in 2012, best by 2017, drank in 2013. Yeah, damn solid stuff. Not totally taken over by the brett - which I love - so still has a bit of bready sweetness. But it does have a decent dose of funk to it, so Id say its somewhere in the middle between totally sweet and bready and totally funked. Excellent beverage. (4.3)Bottle at home in London, 13 days before leaving Queens Gardens. Bottled on 15 January 2015. Fairly dry, not too funky, with nice leathery character, some melon, maybe citrus and berries. Lively carbonation that lends the beer a massaging texture. Wonderful juice. (score: 4.4, drank on 18 January 2017)

Not quite as hoppy as the Orval of the mid 80s as I remember. Murky amber with a great pillowy white head. Aroma is musty fruit and tart. This also describes the taste. My bottle is dated 29/07/2009. At todays date its fairly young but very tasty. I will age the rest of the bottles and enjoy them as they progress.

Bottled 7/29/09.  Pours a cloudy amber with a thick white head.  Aroma is very earthy with an underlying hint of banana.  Taste is musty with slight hops and a tingley mouthfeel.  Nice carbonation.  Good stuff.

Bottle in our NYC hotel room during Chinese new year.  Yes yes, took me far too long to actually have one of these, so I hope its worth the wait.  Bottled 05/08/09, so fairly young.  Pours a very hazy dirty brown amber with a large dense white head.  Lots of young brett, bread, apples and pears,  Medium bodied, large sharp bubbles, bready, sweet, a bit of toasted corn, caramelized packing peanuts.  Finishes with a bit of musky toasted malt.  Tasty, and definitely something worth drinking, but if I had it blind, I doubt Id go into the ludicrous fervor that the Orval name seems to generate.

Provdatum: 2004-11-06, Göteborg
Tilltalande öl!
Vacker bärnstensfärg med viss grumlighet. Stort vitt skum. 
Doft av citrus och jäst. Kraftig eterbeska..

Pours a honey color with a thick and chunky off white head with tons of lacing.  Lots of citrus and brettanomyces in the nose.  Flavors are citrus, light spice, and wild yeast.  Nice and crisp with mild carbonation and medium body.  Slightly tart finish.  What an excellent beer.
Great, light trappist with a little herby touch to it. Loved it. Perfect combination between low percentage and enjoyable taste.

Orval 
Trappist Ale
Pours hazy honey colored with a thick white head that lasts and lasts. Good  looking beer. Aroma is fantastic. Yeast, white wine grapes, a bouquet of flowers. Wow. Unfortunately the taste is not as good. The taste is much the same as the smell, but dialed way back with a dry finish. I felt like I was drinking champagne with less alcohol. Similar mouthfeel. It is a decent beer on aroma alone. The taste makes it good, but not great. I

Pours a hazy dark amber body topped with a billowing, off-white head that leaves some lacing on the glass. Aroma is spices, yeast, some citrus hop and fruity esters. Flavor is spice, yeasty, some light sweetness, a bit earthy and grassy. Mild, lingering hop bitter as well as an earthy under tone
getting a lot of sour off of this.  as it warms I start to get some spice notes, maybe pepper.  almost gose like in taste.

(bottle from Coaltrain in Colorado Springs, sampled 2/10/10). Clear copper color. Huge off white head, which is mostly diminishing. Aroma of light fruit esters, with a very light sourness.  Flavor of light earthiness, light bitterness, and very light malt. Avg duration. Slightly dry finish with a very light sourness. Thin texture. Heavy/fizzy carbonation. Good lacing.

POurs cloudy copper with reddish hues.  Effervescent.  Large, off-white head.  "Big foam".  More sudsy than dense.  Brett and mild funkiness in the nose.  Pretty interesting.  A bit sour with some funk.  Scrubbing bubbliness.  Finishes sharply and dry.    Pretty tasty.  Would probably buy again if I was in the mood for something like this but am not sure what the hype is about.  Hopefully Ill learn at some point.

A: Amber orange in color with 2+ fingers of foam (that lasts forever).

S: Yeasty, a little funky, some tart apple.

T: A bit tart, yeast, with a mild funk, and not necessarily bitter or sweet in any way that I can tell.

M: On the lighter side, pretty effervescent and dry

D: Could have quite a few of these...
Thick dirty white foam. Orangish brown in pour. Thins out and gets whiter at the bottom of the glass. Smells spicy and yeasty. Peppery fruit salad. Vinaigrette dressing. Tastes yeasty. Spicy Brett.

11.2oz bottle from Central Market.  Pours a hazy dark amber body topped with a billowing, off-white head that leaves some lacing on the glass.  Aroma is spices, yeast, some citrus hop and fruity esters.  Flavor is spice, yeasty, some light sweetness, a bit earthy and grassy.  Mild, lingering hop bitter as well as an earthy under tone.  Medium mouthfeel with very active carbonation.

The aroma has a moderate tartness, with a dark raisin-vanilla flavor.  Alcohol esters are also present.  The golden orange orb body is bubbly throughout, that seems to just never fade, like a million jetisoned yeast reactions in forever suspeneded animation.  The head is decadent emerging from over the rim of the glass like the Matterhorn.  It fades, but not much.  A great looking beer.  The flavor is full of barnyard flavors, notably Brettanomyce yeast.  There is a great spicyness in citrus hops.  The body is medium, the texture is more on the sticky slick side, the carbonation is adequate, with a moderate to heavy degree.  The finish long and robust.  A real treat.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2010 Good flavor and aroma..  Golden color and light colored head that lasts longer than expected.    Expected a little more from this beer considering the hype.

Vertical tasting of a fresh and a relatively old vintage. 
The older one bottled on 13/03/2007, the younger is from 08/10/2009. 

Appearance: The younger one is a cloudy golden with much more weaker-airy head than the older one has. The older one is more attractive with lively, effervescent look and huge white, cottony froth.
The 2007 ones definitely better in head lacing and retention. While the older vintage is a lot more closer to deep copper but doesnt seems to hazy or muddy.

Aroma: The 2009 is a lot more intense in the citrusy hop profile with invinting brett-yeasty tartness. The older sample is more mellow on the dry-hoppy profile, but theres some really nice molded-cheesy yeasty profile with moderate tartness and slight lactic hint, maybe lactobacillus(?).

Flavor: The younger is insanely effervescent - even after 20 minutes of air-conditioning. Barnyardy, earthy bretty notes instantly. Then follows a serious dry hoppy peppery-citrusy tartness. Dry, quenching finish. 
The older one shows more depth in the bretty, tart, moldy character, but some dry hoppy resins also detectable.
Moutfeel/Palate: Not surprisingly, the younger one is lot more refresing with lively citrusy hop oils, resins, fizzy carbonation and medium body.
The 3 year old vintage is a somewhat stickier bodied with smooth texture and soft carbonation. 
Overall: First of all: ORVAL is a word-classic beer with no manner of doubt. This a hop-oriented quenching, fizzy, easy-bodied ale, and doesnt age as well as youd expect.
There is no huge malty, sweet backbone, but the wild-yeast strains could do a very amazing job during the bottle-fermentation.


--> 2007
Aroma	 Appearance	 Flavor	 Palate	 Overall
8/10	    4/5	          8/10	   4/5	  17/20   ->> 3.8


--> 2009
Aroma	 Appearance	 Flavor	 Palate	 Overall
9/10	    5/5	          9/10	   4/5	  18/20   ->> 4.5
Dark amber, white head - very thick.  Aroma of candy, sweetness, and tartness.  Palate is very crisp and carbonated with a somewhat spicy taste.  The Belgians might be growing on me.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market, poured into Chimay Trappist Glass. Nice hazy orange color with a generous, pillowy off-white head. Aromas are mostly hoppy: citrus zest, spice, yeast, and potpourri. The taste is quite bitter (grapefruit and orange pith) but not unpleasantly so. The yeasts and malts definitely take a backseat to the hops, especially in the finish. Not bad.

really nice, but surprising taste from this one. kind of dry-champagne-like flavor, a little rough in the palate, really good, just not what i thought it was going to be like, I was expecting more of a chimay taste, but this was very dry, maybe too carbonated. i enjoyed it, but compared to other belgians, whether actually belgian or belgian style, i probably wont do it again.

Pours a cloudy orange. Huge sudsy head. Aroma is heavy citrus, malt, spice,hop. Taste is citrus spice hop malt licorice grass. very smooth. Moderate carbonation. Although you can feel the alcohol, there is no real tickle from it. Finish is hop bitter  dry slightly oily. A very fine and unique drinking experience.

Strong, pillowy white head, hazy golden orange color.  Sublte hoppy, dry fruit-orange peel, barnyard-farmy aroma.  Extremely dry tasting, leaves you thirsting for another sip; the fruit and hop notes are subtle in the taste as well.  A bit of earthiness toward the end and a lingering dry, hoppy taste.  Wonderfully simple and complex to me.
Nice opaque amber color. Goes from fruity to spicy to a dry and hoppy ending. Nice beer, although a bit "watery".
UPDATED: AUG 12, 2011 Sweet aroma.  Slight gold appearance.  Taste is like many belgian ales, hoppy and slightly sweet. A tasty beer.

Location: Somehow I have not rated this beer, so Im using a 12 oz bottle via jcos to create my rating, 2/1/10 


Aroma: Lots of citrus, some orange, other fruits, a good amount of spice, and some yeast

Appearance: Hazy orange color with a large creamy white head that leaves some lace

Flavor: Taste is citrus sweet with some spice and a good amount of hops in the finish

Palate: A medium bodied beer with an above average carbonation and a nice mouthfeel

Overall Impression: 
I cant believe this is my first time rating this beer.  Crazy stuff...  Anyway, this is a really good beer, and a beer that I have perhaps underestimated...

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2013 While the taste is good, and the palate also isnt bad at all, it lacks a bit of "power", for me it seems there is a bit to much water inside. Besides that, a very decent beer. 

Edit: tasted at 02 oct. 2010 a 6 years old bottle. Nice light orange amber coloured. Good big head that stills holds nice. Smell is sour fruity, earthy. Taste is a bit soapy, earthy, yeast, sour-sweet. Not bad, but expected a bit more from aging this beer. Not my favorite trappist for sure.

Edit 2: Another fresh one that was not my thing at all. Refreshing and watery. Not my kind of beer.Have to re-taste again one day 

Edit 3: Another aged, but only 2.5 years. Good smell, decent taste. But not a still not a fav for me...

I am not sufficiently trained to describe technically what I appreciated in that beer, however I can tell its among my favourites.... Its definitely intense and long lasting and this is what Im looking for.

12 oz. bottle, bought at Cervezería Seny in Madrid.  Dark golden appearance with light yellow head.  Fruity, yeasty aroma.  Taste is very dry, tart, and not very sweet.  Hoppy aftertaste.  Lively carbonation, medium full body.
Overall:  a surprise for me!  After smelling this Trappist ale, I was expecting something much sweeter, but it was not so.  Not my favorite, but a very good beer that is interesting to drink.  Also I like the bottle shape. Orval=oval.

Bottle. Bottled on 06/07/2005. Poured a murkey brown color with a nice off white head. Aroma is tons of malt sweetness and lots of dark fruit aromas. Taste is nice and dry with lots of fruit through out. Nice dry finish with a slight alcohol burn towards the end. Very good.

birra adorabile, completa, vinosa astringente allinizio poi si esalta con i cereali che la rendono dolce come un frutto maturo fino a chiudere con linvasione damaro del luppolo, meraviglioso il colore dopo averla versata nel bicchiere con i lieviti che danzano nel calice, la schiuma è densa, quasi crema nella consistenza e nel colore, persistente.

Pours dark orange with a rocky head.  High carbonation level with lots of tiny bubbles.  sour taste with a fair amount of hops.  The taste lingers around long after you swallow.  Not much alcohol.  Finishes dry.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 A classic Trappist beer. An amber beer of citurs hops and ligh zingy texture. A little sharp on the mouth feel and balance is very good. I hear this beer is best after 1.5 years but not entirely sure. I had mine poured from 33cl bottle into a round goblet glass. The Orval lingers in your mouth and has a long dry finish. Consumed in some Hackney drinking den with Ang, 23rd January 2010. Edit - 9th March 2010. Classic. A stonker. A big head. A white foaming head. Amber texture is not as prominent as the younger version. An intense beer. Lovely. Thick malty guey texture. A lovely beer for all events. Forced to up rating due to the significance of this improvement in Belgium aged for a little while. Cheers MesandSim for changing my mind.

Pours a gorgeous deep dark red, with a light white head which leaves lace all up the sides of the goblet. The flavors are strong but balanced. Full fruity flavors that I couldnt put my finger on...maybe blueberries?? The fruityness is balanced with full yeast/doughy flavors. One Masterpiece of a Beer!

Pours a gorgeous ruby red grapefruit color with a cracking head that lasts the duration of the glass and leaves lacing all over the place.  Awesome looking, good start.  Nose is incredibly funky with something like sour cherry tartness bringing up the rear.  Taste is similar, lead-in is tart and somewhat funky while the back is substantially funkier with grassy notes and a lot of spices.  Exceptionally dry, nice and creamylike on the front, moderate carbonation.  A very good beer, not sure why people talk about it all the time on the forums.

[Pint, Pivo - York, 12/01/10] Aroma is of grass, spices, oranges perhaps. Bitter, spicy (black pepper?), fruity taste, with a hint of sourness in the finish. Medium bodied. Lively carbonation with a slick mouth feel.

feel odd... I really didnt fall head-over-heels on this beer... and I love belgians..

Im getting some honey in the nose, a mild carbonation, sweet malts and a bit of bitterness at the end.

For 6.9% Im getting a bit of alcohol in the taste... more then I expected for something that is only 7%.

Overall I enjoyed the beer, there is quite a bit of complexity to it, maybe I need to revisit this when Im more experienced with reviewing belgians - but for now Im glad to just have had only a single bottle.

Bought at Amsterdam very cheaper than Brazil. I paid 1.85 Euro when in Brazil is 10.00 Euro. Cloudy Amber with a permanent fluffy white head, that is pretty nice. Aroma is too complex like fruity, spicy, some grass, hops and floral and something else that I couldnt get it. Flavor is quite spicy, grassy and some balanced dry sweetness with a medium carbonation.  Mouthfeel is long and quite  sweet dry. Nice one.
Bottle dated 04/22/2009. Pours a cloudy amber with huge white head that seems to never go away. Aroma smells of hops, fruit, and grass and tastes the same. Very easy to drink and finishes dry.

Finally I am able to enjoy this much-talked about offering from the Trappist Monks at the Abbey of Notre Dame DOrval!  Bottled 01/22/2009.  From bottle poured into tulip offered at Ciceros restaurant in University City, Missouri.  Sizeable white, foamy head with moderate carbonation.  lacing and yeast hovering throughout finish.  Cloudy orange/amber color.  At one year in age it does have the more heavy hop presence than if aged longer.  Aroma of citrus and floral hops, lightly spiced with sizeable, bubbly head.  The taste - from the mouthfeel through the finish - wow!  I have yet to taste a beer with more liveliness on the palate - the flavors literally explode in dance within.  And I must say I am very pleased with the flavor, so already I know I am going to be one of those who simply love this beer!  The finish has a bitterness and dry feel but in a most pleasant way all way to the aftertaste.  I am hooked, I am sold.  This beer deserves all the accolades it receives.  Those who do not like it must either not appreciate a good beer of this style, or the beer was somehow skunked before consumption.  I now wish I had ordered a second!  Cheers!

Cloudy amber pour with a huge head that stays and stays lacing as it goes down the glass. The aroma hits you immediately with fruit, spices, some hops. Flavor is very well balanced with the fruity, sweet and spices up front followed by a nice bitter hop finish. Extremely dry and refreshing.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2010 Serving date: 2009-01-20. Served in snifter. Bottled 2008-06-20, best before 2013-06-20. 

The beer is amber-colored with red hues, and a bit hazy due to the bottle conditioning and the rather large amount of yeast in the bottle (left most of it in the bottle, though). It develops a big, bubbly and uneven head, despite poured in a quite wide-bodied snifter. The head is almost white, with a light yellow/orange shade, and settles very very slowly. It actually never disappear. Instead it leaves a thick coat of foam. Rocky and airy lacings clings to the glass. This one really pleases the visual faculty.

The smell is of lemon, grass, weeds and sweet, fruity aromas, coupled with a pleasant note of yeast.

In the taste, lemon peel is mixed with yeast and very faint notes of unripe tart fruits. A hint of pine needles is there as well. Then, a taste of grass and hey enters the picture together with a very mild barnyard funkiness (horse blanket?). Just before the finish, it develops a sharp twang - perhaps a result of hops. The finish is tart at first, then develops a subtle bitterness leaving a long and dry sensation in the mouth. Overall, the taste of this beer is really great with levels of complexity. Basically every sip offers something new. However, the true highlight is the balance between the different flavors - everything is composed in a precise and very pleasant manner.

As with the taste, this beer offers a rather unique mouthfeel. At first, with the plentiful foam playing an important part, its quite smooth and full. However, this quickly changes into a a medium, almost light, body with the lively carbonation providing a sharp and crisp feeling to it.

This is a fantastic beer with an original and unique profile. A true masterpiece from start to finish.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 Smells a little grassy, with some barnyard from the Brett. When you sip it, the carbonation explodes into your mouth. It is quite delicious with a distinctive yet clean aftertaste. Really a good and interesting beer.

The aroma is a floral, grassy, citrusy blend on the nose with a smooth pale taste of full hops, slightly bitter, but finishes dry, very easy to drink and could have more of this, great belgian beer, no other belgian compares to this style.

Pours murky orange with a large white head. The aroma is lemon with some brett-funk. The flavor is quite a bit of citrus as well as some funk. The finish is quite a bit of hop bitterness. Medium mouthfeel and high carbonation. This is a very unique beer that everyone that is into craft beer should seek out and try.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2016 Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a high, mixed-grained, pillowy, lacy, off-white head. Nose is lemon, tangerine, cardamom, coriander, honey, spritzy white grape, apple, and bright stone fruit. Taste -- what kind of crack was I on when I first reviewed this six years ago? Starts out with honeyed sweetness, toasty grain, and bright stone and citrus fruit; then cuts it with a quick dry-hop bitterness and loads of herbal depth. Dry, yet nuanced and complicated; easily one of the best if not the best Belgian gold ale Ive ever had. Finish is long, elegant, and almost pastry-like in its depth and complexity. One of the greats.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2011 Pours a hazy dark orange with a monsterous head and some strong lacing.  Aroma is very refined and balanced consisting of  orange peel and yeast.  Somewhat waxy mouthfeel.  Taste is rather tart with more orange peel and fruit juice.  Very dry finish.
buonissima belgian ale.floreale e aromatica con un bel retrogusto amarognolo nel finale.bevuta sul posto è sicuramente piu affascinante e buona.

Pours orange with a thick creamy white head. Earthy smell, notes of yeast, hops, spices, coriander. Very dry taste, highly carbonized. Mellow aftertaste which is almost candy sugar-like. This is a beer unlike all others. Definately one of the best Ive ever had. Low ABV but hits damn hard! (Only 6.2% ABV)

bottle from SAQ. poured into trappiste glass. murky orange colour with a huge creamy white head that leaves an unbelievable lacing. a bouquet not quite like any other beer ive had. orange peel, coriander, lots of yeast, just marvelous. taste starts off a bit sour, like grapefruit, then goes mildly sweet and then a very peculier hops finish. this is unlike the other trappists ive tried, because of the finish. at 6.9% abv, the alcohol is barely noticeable. goes down nice and smooth and leaves you wanting more. i cannot say enough good things about this beer. an experience all in its own.

From a 330ml into a snifter.  Pours with a TON of white head which dissipates in a couple of minutes leaving mild lacing.  Color is murky brown.  Im having a hard time smelling much of an aroma but whats there smells of yeast and some grass.  Mouthfeel is medium but with way too much carbonation.  Taste is very dry and biting.  Black pepper and yeast dominate with grass, under-ripe green grapes and some funk bringing up the rear.  Its growing on me a bit as I drink it but Im not really sure I love it.  Good beer, but just not my cup of tea.

Pours a cloudy golden with a thick white head that takes its sweet time to go away. Earthy smell, as with a lot of Belgians. Taste is a little bit of citrus with earthy spice notes and a bit of yeast. Very smooth drinking with a clean, crisp, almost dry finish.
Very fruity, citrusy aroma which hits me every time I take a new sip. Nutty appearance. Overall fantastic flavor, not overwhelming. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2010 330mL bottle, also bottled 01/2009.  This one wasn’t so ridiculous.  Decent acidic funky aroma with some hops.  Slightly malty and fruity with some sharp flavours similar to citrus oil and blue cheese.  The medicinal flavour that ruined the last one is only very subtle in this one.  Light bodied, heavy carbonation with a dry finish of citrus oil.  Still pretty hard to drink but this time around it gets 7 4 5 3 11 = 3.0.  Final scores averaged.

Previous: Dec 29, 2009.  330mL bottle, bottled 01/2009. Pours an effervescent cloudy amber-gold with a large, fluffy and persistent head which gives some nice lacing.  Aroma is acidic, almost vinous, fruity (particularly banana), with some cheese.  There’s a faint malty and hoppy flavour that’s almost immediately overpowered by volatile medicinal flavours which particularly reminded me of spearmint toothpaste.  Almost one dimensional.  Mildly sour and bitter.  Medium bodied and smooth on the palate with the aforementioned toothpaste finish.  This one certainly didn’t live up to the anticipation. 5 4 3 3 5 = 2.0

My first rate after reading Rate Beer for years. I had to go with Orval as its one of my favourite beers. I dont really need to add what it tastes like, instead, Ill write my Orval history: the first bottles I didnt get, then one day, a hot sunny day in the back garden, I opened a cold bottle and all of a sudden it made perfect sense. A few months later came a 9 month old bottle and it was even better. What an awesome beer. A beer for any occasion. At the same time familiar but always different, always interesting, always so drinkable.

Has a bitter, malty smell.  Pours a nice pillowy head with a nice carbonation level.  Has a sweet note to start, but turns bitter and malty through the dry finish, notes of spice as the beer warms.  The pillowy head stays and fills the palate, has a medium to full body that works well with the carbonation level.
Aroma is nice and a little tartness coming through on the nose.  Awesome taste.  Smooth and hoppy dry finish. Great brew

botella, 1 año en bodega.
aromas azufrados , y madera
algo de frutos rojos.
poco aroma a lupulos, y algo de levadura, algo avinada.
buen color naranja, brillante, liquido claro, y buen cuerpo, bastante amplio
mas seca que amarga.
buena carbonatacion, algo exagerada
muy buena en general, para alguna ocasion, no habitualmente.
acompaña buenos quesos fuertes
This is a spicy belgain trappist ale with a full white head and an orange glow to it. Deffinately one of the best to be had!
Big white lasting head with thick, spotty lacing atop a opaque amber body.  Vanilla nose transitions into sweet floral herbs and hops. Solid brew.

Bottle from redlight redlight.  This beer is so good it defies logic.  It is simultaneously smooth and a flavor explosion.  Anyone who loves great beer has to try this beer and probably already has.  When Mary Magdalene washed the feet of Jesus Christ the sweat from between his toes probably smelled and tasted like Orval.

This is a beautiful beer. The aroma is incredible. Spicy Belgium and a sour subtle
component that really draws me in. Nice hoppy and clean. Just not bretty enough for me. I sure wish they would make more beers for the public.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2015 12/09 Orange, viscous pale beige head. Yeast and a riot of hop and spice aromas. Barely ripe nectarine fruitiness and citric bitterness. Complex sour/ dry/ brett finish. Has a sense of being just tamed rather than being fully domesticated. Alive and exciting.   [7/11] Im gradually succumbing to the cult. Cascades of spicy, fruity and yeasty flavours. Tingling dry finish. Its the liveliness that really charms, though.  [4.7] [5/13] A 3/11 bottle. Still looks a treat and the aroma holds up pretty well, although is less vibrant. Oxidised notes hold some charm. Fruit is duller, citrus flavours subdued, still a bretty tang. Looks like the 12-18 months Ive been drinking them at is the sweet spot for me. 4.0, leaving score unchanged.[7/13] A 9/12 bottle. How is it _still_ possible that about 1 in 10 of these turns out to be the best beer Ive ever had? Large head, outrageous sheets of lacing. Bursts of nectarines, zingy brett, dry, peppery finish.Bottled mid Feb 2015. Pours clear. This young it actually fits in the glass. Head is retained to the last. Fruity, just a little bretty, dry, quite bitter and very hoppy. So much for the 12-18 months sweet spot, this is another ridiculous one. Up.

Wow this one didnt live up to the hype. Im wondering if I may have gotten a bad bottle. I opend this and poured with good carbonation, light hop aroma. Little to no taste present??? All I get is almost a seltzer water taste with a light waxy semi citrus finish? Not what I was expecting from the reviews. Will try again in a few months to see if there is a difference. I cant imagine this is what people are into.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Pours a hazy orange with an extremely thick foamy head, as if it exploded into the glass, even while I was pouring very gently. A strong hoppy citrus aroma fills the air as if I just opened up an imperial IPA. But there is more to the aroma, some leathery blue cheese smell that sounds but is not anywhere near disgusting. Flavor starts off very bitter with hops screaming for attention. Then gently becomes more subtle, somewhat creamy and fruity like a good peach yogurt but then shifts back again for an insanely dry finish. The huge amounts of carbonation allow for a lovely mouthfeel. Wonderful beer.

Pours a cloudy amber body with a rich foamy-rocky kind of off-white head. Very impressive head retention and lots of lacing. The aroma has some floral hoppiness, some nice citrus notes, hints of apple, some caramel and that peculiar brettanomyces smell. The taste starts with a good hop bite, followed by some fruitiness and caramel sweetness. Quite pithy and dry, with a lemon/grapefruit zest to it, as well as some spiciness and some "leather funk" from the yeast strain. The finish is moderately bitter and dry, with some subtle citrus notes. The mouthfeel is pretty smooth, although there is some crisp carbonation. Orval is most certainly an oustanding Trappist beer, quite unique in its style and one of my all-time favourite Belgian beer.

Hazy orange pour with large cream head.  Smells fruity and floral with a bit of banana aroma leading out the fruit smell.  The taste begins with a fair amount of spices leading to a more pronounced fruit taste.  Finishes with a transition into the taste of hops and leaves that aftertaste.  Mouth feeling is consistently light during the entire experience.  Tasty and refreshing.

(br-btl pu/wh-lbl gl-txt, 11.2oz, 6.2%)

gl-opq, huge-wh-hd(with peaks!), ^eff, 

bright-fruit musty-hops funky citrus aroma, 

T1 fresh light Ts  sweet funky co2 
T2 sharp-bitterness lambic-sour fruity sweet (juniper/sage/?) co2 
T3 malty §buttery §saddle 
Tf maltier funkier richer 

awesome, unique! (wows me every time)

See, those monks, theyre nice fellas. They brew genious in beer. As I opened the bottle, the beers aroma flew gently to me, saying almost "youre gonne love me". The aroma was quite fruity, with damasc, banana and some berries. There was some nice barley malt aroma with it, more wheat aromas and little oat-malt-like aromas as well. The clover that came along was really good, joined with some cinnamon. Hoppy fella, the aroma.

This beer looks great: its opague dark orange mixes with the clear beige foam gently. And, let me say, what a foam: consistent, perfectly sized and quite regular inspite of being quite fluffy.

Into the mouth it came softly, going very swiftly in the whole mouth, filling it quickly with its taste. The fruits come nicely, damasc, banana, berries and some might say something of apple. Along with the fruits there was cinnamon, clover, herbs, little wood, faint barley, and faint grainy. Also quite hoppy.

The aftertaste is nicely bitter, with wood, damasc and herbs. 

What a beer!

Intense fruityness.  Bananas seem to hit me first.  Strong aroma.  Murky orange in color with a thick, light tan head.  Intense, full-bodied mouthfeel.  Carbonation is evident on the palate.  Complex fruity flavors.  Has a slight hoppy bitterness to the aftertaste.  Overall, very nice but not my favorite Belgium beer.

Nice frothy head needs to be poured very gently preferably two or three times without upsetting the sediments. Amber in colour. Great aroma reminds me of mature banana and a slight bubblegumy background.
At first impact a nice sweetness biter/spicy hop flavour, yet finished of with a salty flavour reminiscent of sea water beers.
Definitely a beer that I will drink again.

Pours a slightly hazy brilliant orange-gold color.  Large foamy head.  Very strong bouquet; fruity, earthy, yeasty.  Palate is very dry and clean w/ ample carbonation, little to no sweetness.  Flavor of fresh hops, yeast, wheat malt and grass.  Interesting, not my cup of tea but still respectable.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2016 Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours copper and enormous fluffy off white head.  This beer is well carbonated and has a nice dense fluffy head and some lacing.  The taste in general is complex for a lighter colored beer and effervescent.  In particular there is some tart fruity notes, has a spicy hoppy character, and some yeasty/breadyness.  (At four years old taste is Brett, a little spice, and pretty dry)
12 oz bottle from US Liquors.  Cloudy brown/yellow color, big foamy head.  Yeasty, fruity, almost musty aroma.  Flavor is also fruity/yeasty and tart with a dry crisp finish.
spruce, citrus, floral, color orange amber, light haze, rocky white head, good lacing, smooth crisp taste medium sweetness, medium sourness, lively carbonation, light body, long finish,
hay, citrus, spruce, leather, orange, cloudy, rocky head, tan foam, light sweetness, very bitter, medium sourness, full body, sticky, lively, bitter, astringent,

330 ml bottle - date of 2-2-08; clear, bright orange with frothy white head lingering; huge nose of floral spice, lemon zest, bananas and pears; delightfully soft texture with nice bretty zing; nothing here is overly aggressive, though you can feel the strength of the brew going down; mild fruit, some brett, full bodied; touch of tart with pears, peach and pineapple; more spice in the nose fir sure; a unique, delicate and subtle brew; very nice and one I should buy more of

bottle - Before all the tomatoes start heading in my direction I tried this beer 3 times before rating thinking it was just me. I just cant bring myself to really like this beer. The appearance and aroma promise great things, lots of bready spice and citrus notes, but the flavor really killed my expectations, way too bitter (for my taste). In my opinion way overrated, but since Im a neophyte at rating Ill try again in the future.

Has a nice brown pour with minimal foam around the rim of the glass. The aroma is that of dried fruit and spice. Somewhat carbonated, it could have just been a bad bottle, but still enjoyable. The taste is sweet and a little tangy.
Bottle from the Eastchase Majestic.  Opaque orange pour.  Dry citrus aroma with bread.  Tart, fruity flavor.  Aftertaste lingers.  Tingling mouthfeel.

Bottle, 33cl, from Vinmonopolet, Oslo. BB 20.07.2014 (probably consumed way too young!). 6.9% ABV. Hazy copper/amber colour. Big, long-lasting head. Complex aroma, dry but also some sweetness, herbal, some unripe fruit, apple/banana. Fizzy carbonation, slick texture. Taste is initially a bit sweet with well-balanced malt, yeast and hop elements, then an almost geuze-like dryness takes over. Long-lasting bitter ending.
Hoppy, slightly sour nose. A nice hoppy flavour and a lot of bubbles. Nice bitter and full aftertaste.

Pours honey brown with 1/2 thick foamy off white head.  Bright honey aroma with lots of citrus, specifically lemon.  Dry finish.  Taste combines citrus, coriander, wood and a faint candy sugar.  Very much enjoyed.

Pours a copper / golden colour with a humongous off-white head. Aroma is yeast, hops and a little fruity. Creamy, dry mouthful. Flavour is quite mild - citrus, orange, malt, with a yeasty aftertaste. Quite nice, but overrated.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2010 Re-rated on 3-5-2010.  330 mL bottled on 09/23/2008.  Pours hazy orange-brown and a big two finger off white head.  Big, funky Brett aroma, lemongrass, sour apricots, peaches, oak.  The Brett is more subdued in the taste with tart peaches/apricots, coming in with the yeasty flavor.  Quite a taste explosion.  So complex for a small beer.  Lemongrass, floral, nectary...  Light to medium bodied with a frothy mouthfeel and a low-medium level of carbonation.  Very drinkable.  Tastes absolutely nothing like the beer I had several months ago (which I did not care for).  I understand why so many love this now, though it may be hit or miss.

Smells lightly of maltiness and fruit, banana slightly. Very unusual colour, reddish orange, coppery but not quite golden. Nice head retention. Very nice malt flavour complemented by citrus fruit flavour at the end, the yeast is sooo smooth on the palate. Quite nice, a bit of an unusual aftertaste, Im told its the betton-nemyasis yest, theres no way I spelled that right. Quite a nice brew.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy orange/amber with a beautiful thick head. Aroma of yeast, citrus... and very flowery. Taste is citrus, bananas and a little spice. Also, has a small but pleasant bitter aftertaste. Medium carbonation. Excellent beer!

Very nice, totally golden liquid with a slight orange tint. Two-finger head of dense white foam with excellent retention and amazing lacing.

Smell is spicey and yeasty. Fresh baked banana bread. Slight notes of white fruits. Honey and floral notes mingle with hints of citrus. 
Not at all bold, but delicious smelling, and inviting, nonetheless.

This is a different kind of trappist ale. All of the regular expected characteristics are there. Nice spicey flavors. Hints of banana and cloves. Honey sweetened yeast notes. Nice floral/citrus notes.
Holding the whole thing together, though, is a funky sourness. Somewhat like a Flanders Belgian Ale. Very interesting, and very good.

As any good belbian ale should be, this one is smooth and creamy with lots of tight, tiny little bubbles.

This is a highly drinkable brew, but I would keep it in mind as an alternate, not as my go to for belgian ales. Extremely nice when you want something a little bit different.
Pours a cloudy orange with thick head. Aroma of yeast and citrus. Taste is lots of citrus with orange peel. Lots of carbonation with a small pleasant bitter after taste. Very good

Bottle .  Pour is a cloudy glowing orange with a foamy head,very carbonated. aroma is tart bitter and fruity. There are notes of hops and light citrus as well, but not overly abundant. A bit fizzy with dry finish. seems from other reviewers my beer was most likely exposed to heat with travel. dated from the early january in 09

Bottled on 02/20/08. Pours a full, vibrant reddish orange with thick, slightly foamy eggshell white. Some beautiful lacing throughout. Aroma of banana, wheat, lemon, brett, and a touch of strawberry. The aroma is like a hybrid of a sour ale and a hefeweizen. Subtle flavor profile of citrus, orange peel, aged cheese. Very dry with lots of brett in the finish. Its oddly addicting despite being so subdued.

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Pours honey golden orange with a thick, off-white head. Aroma of grapes, lemon, dry hops, soil, and hints of pepper. Medium bodied with a tangy, smooth mouthfeel. Great finish: slow and tart. Excellent sour ale.

Waw what a special beer, hazy ambré and fine white mousse. Aroma is malty, yeast and has hints of pepper, herbes, and sharp yeast. taste is crisp, malty and deliciously bitter with a slight sour accent. a great beer with a very speciale taste.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy rusty orange with a huge foamy off white head and leaves a thick lacing on the Trappist glass. Tart horse blanket aroma with hints of earthy yeast, wood and citrus. The flavor is sour yeast, sweet bread and a light taste of bitter hops. Medium body with active carbonation and a frothy dry mouth feel.
