Bottled on: 2/20/08.  Poured dark orange color with off white head.  Aroma faintly resembling orange peel or what orange liquorice might taste like.  Heavily carbonated with a very slight sweet taste followed by a  dry aftertaste.  Good, but I thought it was too heavy on carbonation.
Nothing new to say about this beer... a traditional belgian found everywhere it seemed in europe.  Fairly well hidden alcohol that steps up and hits you later.
Nice cloudy orange/yellow color, huge fluffy head. Nice citrusy smell to it, very clean. Nice little bite to it as well, outstanding.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Murky orange with a wheaty head that stays thruought the glass. Spicy and citrus nose. A bit of sourness, acidity, and spiciness in the taste. with a dryness in the end.

Ahhh, this is the life.... this beer has been a long time favourite, and still is. Nice copper/amber colour with a huge fluffy/rocky head. The smell is divine. Fresh bread, a little sourish, hops, a little fruit, very complex. Taste is even better, yeasty, hoppy, a little sweet and a little sour. Nice bitter finish. This is a beer for all occasions, and an all-nighter. It’s refreshing, tasteful, not too high in ABV and because of the fairly high carbonation it is not a gusher, but a real tasting beer. Excellent!

Bottle from Sams Clybourn. Okay, dont know why I waited so long, but here goes. Pour is a cloudy glowing orange with a foamy head, Chimay glass keeps it going. Nose is tart and fruity with peaches and sweet oranges, Bretty. There are some hop aromas as well, but not overly present. A bit fizzy with some candy flavors on the tongue, tartness and dry toasty flavors from the Brett. Pineapple and citrus as well. Pretty light, except for the caramel. Pretty nice beer with plenty to pull out and spicy. Excellent!

Man these monks know what they are doing! When i think of Belgium beers this is the taste that comes to mind. Very balanced, easy to drink. Has nice slight flavors of fruits and spices but still tastes like beer. It just seems more special since this is the only beer made at this brasserie.  Great all year round.

the head seems to scale the sides of the glass on pour. big. foamy and consistent.  looks like thick cloud cover viewed from an aeroplane, peaks and troughs, mountains and valleys; one of the best heads ive seen on a beer. Some great lacing to add to the mix (mushroom cloud, siciliy and pipe-smoking man all in the same glass.

smells of kids cough syrup and certainly makes my throat feel better. strong suggestion of cinnanmon and those bazooka chewing gums i used to have as a kid. penny chews and other sweet things.  this is my second bottle of the night and didnt get anywhere near as much nose or taste off the first.  is each bottle that unique?

good balanced carbonation, spicy, eccentric, complex - this beer is the cool kid at school, while not necessarily the best looking (tasting).

Each time i smell it i get something different; soap this time and something i cant quite put my finger on; hospital corridor? got a big smell of yeast towards the end of the glass (le chat?)

Fine beer all round, looks so god damn sexy.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 My first taste of Orval.  Pours with a massively foamy head that eventually yields to a small white ring.  Golden and slightly hazy with beautifully musty aromas of hay and lemongrass. Taste is spicier than expected, with yeast, hops and grassy notes.  Finish is extraordinarily dry and lingering.  Very light mouthfeel with loads of effervescence.  Amazingly drinkable.  Its a beer with amazing history, and one that still resonates strongly with modern brewers.

96% foam, settles to clear golden with an orange tint appearing line apple juice. The foam is dense. Balanced, prominent aroma of Belgian yeast, malt, and spice. Very enticing. Tastes like dark cherry malt,  very dark, fruity, some wood esters in there and some spice. Goes down very smooth, but burns the belly. Rather dry touch, mild tongue, but burns the back of the throat. Old leather aftertaste. Drinkablility is unsurpassed for this style or brew. And I’ve never seen such persistent foam and thick as this.

Bottle. Thick white head that had soft peaks. Golden hue that was difficult to see through. Tasted peppery/spicy. Somewhat unpleasant/medicinal aftertaste (I was told that I should have aged the bottle a little more. It was less than a year old). Overall, very good. I am going to buy another bottle and let it sit around for another year or so.
Bottle,  Large white head with a cloudy brown/amber color.  Perfume/resin with a good amount of alcohol present.  Medium bodied with a great complex flavor.
Quite hoppy. Recommended by Deepak at Kingdom Liquors. Tried 7/5/08. Amber color, fizzy head/body. Complex lingering after-taste. All-around average.
Very mellow Trappist beer.  Has a nice cinnamon/ spicy flavor to it.  This is a very unique beer.  Has malt and spicy sweetness in the aroma.  Very good.
UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 Gold bottom with a quick dissolve white foam. Aroma is very fruity. Taste is hoppy and dry. Very high carbonation. Spicy and sour finish. Unique.

Pours yellow and cloudy with some head. Aroma isn’t very strong, but definite yeast and fruit: pears and banana. Taste is not very strong but it’s a bit of fruit. I wasn’t as impressed as I was expecting after reading about this one.
Extremely rounded fruity aroma and flavours, all blending well together. Excellent beer.
Bottel 0.33 l. Bought Super Best Hilleroed. Yeast aroma slightly acidic. Amber brown colour with nice beige head. Hops bitterness and acidic fruits.
Very dry mouthfeel; spicy and malty tastes competing with the hops; complex fruit flavors; dark amber pour; thick head; excellent

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2010 Bottle dated January 08, so this is pretty young.  Amber brown pour with huge foamy head.  Woody earthy nose with hints of sour fruit.  Similar ok palate with hop bitterness present.  A relatively subtle beer but quite nice and the low alcohol makes for easy drinking.  Looking forward to aging one of these for awhile. Re-rate: tried a seven-year-old bottle, and wow! Beautiful palate. More mellow, friuitier, and softer. More subtle, but also more sublime.  Amazing.

Finally went ahead and tried this one.  Split a bottle with barleyPops.  Dark golden yellow pour, big white head.  Yeasty, estery aroma.  Plenty of fruity notes.  Flavor was similar with some subtle hop notes and sourness coming through as well.  Good, but not something Ill drink very often.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 330 mL bottle.  Pours somewhat hazy, just a bit lighter than amber.  Large head.  Aroma is sweet, some hops, banana, tart apple, a little bit sour.  Flavor is spicy apple, pear, with some bitter hops coming through and a bit of sourness.  Carbonation is rather high, but it works pretty well with these flavors.  An interesting experience.Rerate after trying again 8/24/08, as my numbers for this were clearly too low on first rate.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2009 12oz bottle from G&G, poured into a snifter. color is a cloudy gold wth a big, fluffy head. aroma is excellent. fruity, wth peach, apricot, pear, and european hops. the hoppy aroma is very pleasing. flavor is unique with a hop spicyness and a fruity character that blend together nicely. the malt bitterness lasts nicely. definitely a unique beer from a special brewery. one of my favorites.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2015 Appearance: Light brown. Cloudy. Lots of head, longlasting.
Aroma: Very fruity.
Taste: Fruit and berries. Bitter. A bit sour aftertaste.
Info: 330ml bottle, 24/3-2006, 94/300, 55/500

2015 re-rate (2.8->3.5):
Appearance: Bottled 20/4-2011. Dark red-brown, clear. Nice amount of off-white head.
Aroma: Nice fruits, lots of it.
Taste: Lots of dark fruit, slight bitterness. Nice.
Bought: ?, 330 ml, CHF ?.??
Info: 11/7-2015, BB: 20/4-2016
Bottle @ Mondial 08.  Fruit and floral nose with fine hop balance.  Citrus, sour, carmel, and a bit of spice.  A classic must try beer.

12 oz bottle, bottled on 9/13/07. 6.9% alcohol by volume. Pours a deep red-orange with thick, fluffy head. Nose is pears, citrus, spice, and candy sugar, a bit fruity and floral as well.  Taste is a bit sour, a bit dry, yeasty and sour fruit. Palate is stange: seems light but also sharp, almost like a champagne, but also creamy and very satisfying. This is a unique, excellent trappist ale, which was an absolute pleasure.

A really unique Trappist-beer. Very bitter beer, nice spicyness and a bit sour alá Lambik. This is a beer wich I have never tasted anything similar to. 

Another one of those "must-try-beers".

Poured a murky golden amber color with a dense off-white head that hangs 
around nearly to the bottom of the goblet. The nose is of citrus rind, corriander  
and floral hops. The taste starts malty with spicy floral like 
flavors and citrus zest. Next comes vanilla and caramel with some green apple? 
Somewhat vinious, but in a good way. The finish is earthy and very dry. 
This is an amazingly complex, balanced beer. Its light yet it seems fuller. 
Smooth and creamy, but not heavy. Great drinkabilty.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2009 (11.2oz bottle from Central Market on June 23, 2008 - bottled on June 20, 2007 - aged 1 year/3 days) Popped the cap, poured into my snifter a golden-orange color, turning yellow toward the stem of the glass.  Thick, foamy head with a few bubbles lining the edges of the glass.  Smell is wonderful - fruity and floral with hints of yeast, malt, and hops.  Palate is unique... taste is hard to describe, fruity, spiced, slightly pungent, almost as if it were a sour ale, very enjoyable.  Yes, a bit dry, but redeeming.  Lets say its lusciously dry.  Light hops and sweet malt hover in the back of the throat.  THIS is why I like beer... every one is unique, and I look forward to beers like this the most.  Exemplary!
from a bottle. Great amber colour with a full head. A peppery caramel flavor. Just great!

Another fine example of the Trappist art of brewing I never had one which was not wonderful. very aromatic full head and  excellent on the palate.  Smooth with a high taste of hops. I believe it is paramount not to serve too chilled.

cool looking 11.2 oz. bottle.  poured a hazy honey gold with a huge dense foamy head.  aroma was some yeast with apples and pears.  flavor was more of the same with a subtle sour bitterness.  I liked the flavor but the carbonation was too overbearing for my liking.

bottle.  murky light tan color with a huge off white pillowy head.  aromas of flowers and sweet bread.  flavors of tart grapes, raisins, light floral bitterness, some boozy notes.  very full complex flavor.  Has a slight but distinct note of sour funk that sharpens as it warms.  sharp and slick on the palate, very carbonated.  Great stuff.

Bottle. At refrigerator temperature-likely a bit too cold-pours cloudy amber to big creamy head, and aroma is slight-a little sharp. Taste: yeasty bread, toasted caramel, nice slightly sour-bitter after taste. Alcohol quite noticeable. Mouthfeel is smooth and full, like an after dinner cordial.

Bottle. Huge soapy white head, visible carbonation in the beer, nice hazy bronze color. Funky nose with lemons, spice, and a lot more I cant describe. Weird, tasty mix of fruits and funk blend in the flavor. Berries, alcohol. hoppy bitterness, medium sourness, and much more. Confusing, complex beer, but wonderful balance and fun to drink. Goes down easy, but has so much going on Id probably feel different about from one beer to the next.

11.2 oz bottle, bottled on 4/24/07, best before 4/24/2012, and purchased 1/26/08.  Pours a clear golden orange (the second pour makes it nice and cloudy) with a monstrous fizzy and rocky big bubbled white head that retains fairly well and laces the glass.

The aroma is fruits (pears?) and alcohol with some yeast funk, wood and some slightly metallic and floral hops.

The flavor is yeast funk and slightly sour fruits, with some mild bitter hops.  Its pretty subdued but nice.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with tons of sharp carbonation.  It mellows out a bit as it sits.

Overall, a nice beer that gets better as it warms and more has been drunk.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2010 Bottle, Kegs & Barrels.
Bottled on March 2007.
Pours a very nice looking hazy amber with thick rocky off-white  head that laced the glass. Aroma of berries, apples with caramel. Flavor of berries with faint sweetness with slight cinnamon note and a dry, hop bitter finish, brett. Med-high carbonation with med-full body. Over all, this is an excellent beer. This beer is my new friend.......

2nd: bottled 01/2009: Pours a murky dark burnt orange with large, fluffy fizzy head. This one is filled with bret! Not bad at all!.

Now this is something. Pours hazy golden colour. Aroma has notes of nearly everythang, apples, berries, yeast, caramel, u name it. Slightly sour aroma continues across the tasting, giving an reminder of sour berryful taste. Probably Orval would should be tasted a one or two more times before final rating (and also a bit more matured) but at this moment I would say that this is an interesting and excellent beer indeed.

a regular at my uncles, i enjoyed this one many a times at austrian sunsets. quite a staple for any beer nut, this dark amber beauty is just a classic. definitelty one of my favourites just for the fact that it not the usual slashhammer like its heavy relatives, Complex, dry and fruity, this offers a taste expiriece you can ponder over a few hours without getting bored, or absolutely hammered!
deep grassy nose with decent floral notes and exotic stewed fruits. Spicy in flavour, almost mulled characters. good bitterness at the tip of your toungue. and a lovingly lingering aftertaste as soft and kind as the setting sun over the bohemian hills...
A complicated beer. Dark orange color, thck head, yeasty. Finish is a little bitter. A solid Trappist ale.

A beer that I have heard so much about but have had quite a bit of difficulty finding. This well sought after trappist pours a hazey orange body with an overflowing fluffy white head. It leaves an incredibly stick resin on the glass. A sweet fruity aroma of melon, orange and bananna. Flavors of bananna, fish and cherries. An incredibly taste beer, happy i could find it in Lisbon. :)

This rich, orange beer pours with a delightful, billowing head with a very pungent, flowery aroma with hints of nutmeg and a little citrus.  The flavor is amazing, fruity, flowery, with enough bitterness to balance out, and a delicious spicy belgian yeast character of nutmeg, cinnamin, and orange peel.  I will definitely buy this again.

Somewhat overpowering medicinal quality which was surprising at first but found somewhat pleasing later.  Decent balance with alcohol content and hops but the head was out of control.  Had to wait for 10 minutes for it to calm down..  Dont think its something Id buy again.

I had this beer in Old Chicago in Sioux Falls SD cost $8.50 a bottle what a horrible beer.  Tasted like I accidently sprayed cologne in my mouth.  They should have paid me to drink it even then I wouldnt have.  0.5 is too good of a rating for this beer stay away from this one.

A very yeasty aroma with touches of wild yeast turns into a trappist beer, which is not like any of the other. A tad alcoholic, a bit acidic and rather hoppy in the end. Slightly related to an IPA in the bitternes, but not as close as I though when I fist had it.
I liked this, but I feel its a bit overrated.  The beer looks fantastic, but the flavor isnt as deep or powerful as I expected.  Maybe I had a bad bottle.

A decent beer, but for the price of $5 a bottle I would rather drink rochefort trappistes 10 at $2 a bottle more. This needs more alcohol content and more flavor. Rochefort trappistes 10 is legions better.
Bottled from Liege. Murky Dark orang color, thck head, proper lacing. Nose is yeast. Nice  yeasty flavour, Finish is soury bitter. Very nice
A lighter Belgian ale with a sweet flavor and wild yeast.  This reminded me of a few saisons Ive tried.  Some good carbonation with a smooth, bubbly aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2009 Bottle:  Its not my favorite of the trappist beers, but a well balanced and decent tasting belgian ale.  However, it seems bland on the aroma and flavor.  Definitely nothing offensive, but I dont pick up on much that makes me want to return.  Ill probably try it again one day.  Maybe Im missing something,
Hm.  This is an ok beer, but it doesnt seem to  stand up to other trappist ales I have had as far as aroma, appearance, flavor, or palate.        It got much better as it warmed to room temperature.

~Pours a cloudy golden honey color with a big creamy white head.
~Strong sweet scent of fruit, spices(cinnamon) and yeast. Very nice and pleasant scent.
~Mellow spice flavor, light sweetness. Complex taste. 
~A bit dry, some bitterness and acidic notes in the finish.
~The aroma is amazing. Its hard for me to distinguish all the flavors because i burnt the roof of my mouth earlier, but from what I got it taste great. Extremely nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2008 [1y old bottle] Dry aroma is sour apple, citrus, spices, yeast, hops. Dry and sour flavor is quite complex; fruits, apple, apple pie, citrus, spices, grass, hops, yeast and maybe some wood also.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2008 Rerate Dec 09 2008.  Jesus is this a well balanced beer.  Everything you could ever want in a beer all wrapped up.  Bret yeast hops malt all wrapped into one picture perfect beer.  wow.

Blury orange colored body. Nice fruity aroma, quite sweet. Little head, I was hoping for more. Tastes very belgian.... The flavour is alkohol-sweet, fuity, malty, with dry finish. I like. Why havent I tried this earlier? Nice bottle as well. (Blårock 050608)

11.2 oz. bottle at West Bradford Grill...pours an unfiltered peachy brown with a fluffy 2-finger foam. aromas of peach, apricot, and a heavy doughiness. flavor is dry, complex, and pleasantly bitter with a tart bubblegum, a solid and intriguing blend of maltiness and hoppiness with citrus, light-skinned fruit and a hard-to-place malty flavor reminiscent of cut wood. a pleasant chewiness to the mouthfeel. finish is bitter, dry, and long-lasting with a predominance of grapefruit peel.

[1201-20080307] 330mL bottle. Sweet pineapple yeast aroma. Cloudy, brown body with a long-lasting foamy off-white head. Sweet plasticy boozy yeast flavour has a hint of fruity lemon peel. Medium body is thick. Interesting, want to re-rate later.

strong full aroma of citrus and good stuff., looks great wih the large head. is muddy though, but looks very appealing. taste is a letdown grass and weeds dominates and not much under that to balance. perhaps it was the great food i had just before. anyways - unbalanced and sort of a mouth full of (knee high)grass feeling. its a subtle thing. aroma is GREAT
Bottled. Long time no see, matey! Hazy orange-brown body, tiny white head. Aroma very subtle, fruits, plum, raisins. Taste very full, extreme finish. Hard to describe, excellent to drink.
Pours a hazy murk brownish red with a nice active tan head. Aroma of citrus, malt, yeast, spices. Flavor is floral spices, bitterness, fruit, a little sourness. I think im starting to get this one.

Bottle.  Looks good in the class with a mild but pleasant aroma.  Flavor was a little disappointing - a bit bitter but couldnt pick out too much complexity in the brew.  Palate is nice, with very fine carbonation.  Overall enjoyable, but prefer the other trappist beers.
Nice amber color with a good foam. Flavor of orange, flowers and malt. Typical trappist bitterness. Loverly beer.
Pours ligth amber/orange with full fluffy sustained head.  Aroma is yeasty, floral, citrus and pepper.  Flavor to match.  Been a while since Ive had an orval and it stands up to memory.

Hazy orange pour with a thick fluffy white head.  Very aromatic.  Intense sour and spice aroma.   Citrus, clove, and cardamom.  Maybe even some floral and honey notes.  Slightly sour bitter flavor with lots of fruit.  Citrus fruit and spice.  Very bitter finish that lingers.
From a bottle poured a nice coppery color with lots of head.  Nice flavor sweet with a lingering finish.
UPDATED: AUG 17, 2013 Poured a golden orange with a creamy, rocky head and some lacing.  Well balanced with citris notes and a little pepper.  Great beer, but not one of my favorite Trappists.
pours hazy orange/copper with large pillowy white head that just wouldnt quit.  aroma is fruity, yeasty and perfumy.  flavor is malty and yeasty, my wife says it tastes like her grandmas perfume.

Got this one at Tanks Taproom in Tampa.  Pours a dark orange with a huge frothy head that lasts all night.  Huge noseful of dark fruity esters.  Tastes like raisin, plum, and is overall very sweet with a slight alchoholic finish.  Great dessert beer.

Bottled on 12-27-2007 Sudsy-soapy aroma.  Brillant appearance; head stays attached in my trappist glass.  The orange peel flavors are pronounced and real. Great with the Chimay grand clasique cheese.   Nice midpalate attack that  smooths out. But! Dissapears on finish.  Overall this just wasnt as exciting as I hoped, especially considering the price tag.  Five Dollars for one 12 oz bottle!!!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 Bottle...  Poured a brilliant, hazy copper with a frothy head that lasted through the whole drink.  Bubbles kept rising from the bottom to the head.   Aroma is pleasant with faint hops that mesh with clove and tart citrus.  Palate is wonderful, just enough thickness for the realization of it being a beer, but smooth enough to go down easily.  Most notable are the citrusy hop flavors that lend towards peppery malt and spices and herbs. Some alcohol presence towards the finish.

This beer pours a cloudy orange with a big white frothy head!  The aroma is citrus, sour  fruits.  The flavor is a little different from that; dry yeasty and although sour fruit flavors come through, I expected it to me more lively and zesty.  This was not a disappointment though, I really like this one.  Cheers!

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 33cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark orange cloudy golden with a thick creamy white head. Smells of caramel, clove, bread, sweet juniper, spice and malt. Tastes of sweet spice, juniper, flowers, grass and caramely malt. Nice belgian trappist ale.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2008 0.33l bottle.

Pours deep amber, creamy head that quickly dissapears.

Taste is very enjoyable, sour and lemony, with a bit of hops.  Some carbonation.  

All in all very drinkable.

11.2 oz bottle, poured amber orange with large foamy white head.  Aroma is nice, fruit and citrus.  However, smells better than it tastes.  Being a Belgian, I expected a sweet flavor.  Instead, it was citric, bitter, and sour.  Not very tasty to me.  Fizzy mouthfeel.  A disappointment.

Very good.  

Clouded amber pour with a pillowy whitish head.  Very straightfoward--nose is citrus and the taste is hoppy, citric, sour, and has just a hint of malt.  The carbonation is heavy, but in a good way.  Finishes crisp and dry.

6/2007. Slightly cloudy golden amber orange with a nice, foamy white head.  Simple, citrus aroma.  Bitter tea leave flavor with grapefruit and light malt. Plenty sour with bright carbonation.  A second sharp bitterness at the end.  Pretty dry, like a fine champagne.  Not really for me, but I can tell why some love it.
bottle. a bit hazy, golden orange color. Spicy and hopy and dry finish. Good beer.
nice complex flavor from a 2005 from mcbackus @ sunseed coop this a beer you need to try more than once i did not care for it the first time but loved after trying again

330 ml bottle. Minimal head and some lacing. Reddish orange and a bit cloudy liquid. Aromas are fresh hops with some grass and citrus fruits and lots of spices. Quite malty flavor and finishes as a bit sour with bitterness. Flavor is somewhat bitter with some malty sweetness. Medium bodied and livey carbonated. Great beer with diverse aromas that are in perfect balance. One of my favourites.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2013 From a bottle. Colour is beautiful amber with a creamy head. This beer grows on you. The first couple of times you taste this magnificent beer youre not easily impressed. It isnt until after a couple of tries that you appreciate the incredibly long dry finish and get hooked. The palate itself is fruity, bitter and utterly complex, I do not know a beer with a similar taste. This trappist beer is underrated as far as I am concerned, maybe because trappist lovers expect more alcohol, but real connoisseurs will love it.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2009 33 cl bottle. Appearance is perfect with a large beautiful foamy head over the hazy orange body - extremely nice too look at. Aroma is great - funky, acidic and a bit fruity with sour apples, citrus and barnyard. Flavour is just as good as the aroma with nice funky notes of sour green apples, some barnyard and citrus. Medium bitterness. Its also got a very nice hoppy character, which makes it unique among the belgians Ive head. Perfect balance between funk, acidity and bitterness. Mediumbodied. Mouthfeel is overall very dry, not extremely mellow and filling maybe, but for this beer I cant imagine it to be more perfect. Overall this is an amazing beer. Probably one of the absolute best trappist and a must-try for everyone. The quite low ABV makes this very drinkable. I love it! Totally unique!

11.2 oz bottle date 07/05/07 into goblet. Pours hazy orange with significant, but diminishing head. Smells of sugars and bananas,and maybe cloves. Very tart and dry. Taste is hard to explain for me. Very nice carbonation feel in the mouth. Light taste that cuts sharply. This was my first Orval.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 4/23/08 notes:  11oz bottle.  Pours with a large, healthy white head and a beautiful cream orange color.  The aroma is of orange peel, lemon, and candy sweetness.  I really enjoyed the crispness of Orvals flavor:  a surprisingly well blended concoction of citrus fruit (orange, lemon), sugar, and some malty sweetness.  Great aftertaste of fruit and slight bitterness.
Update 11/09:  taste the brett a lot more this time around, accompanied with lemony spritziness and light toasted toffee.  Almost a saltine cracker, maybe even fresh cracked peppercorn components as well.  Fascinating brew to drink, Saison complexity, layered atop a perfectly noble Belgian Ale.  If anything, the prickly mouthfeel is so intense that it hampers drinkability.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2008 (Re-rate at Pikkulintu on 2008-10-09, bottled on 05/09/2007) Amber. Hazy. Medium sized quickly disappearing head. Sour, malty, yeasty and fruity nose. Medium bodied and dry palate with medium carbonation. Raisin, sourness, hops, sweetness and bitterness in taste. Long lasting a bit sour and bitter aftertaste.

(Bottle at Hilpeä Hauki on 2008-04-25, I didn’t check the BBE date) Amber and quite clear. White medium sized head. Sour and fruity nose which contains at least apple aromas. Taste contains sour milk and hop bitternes. Some sweetness from malts. Mostly dry palate. Nice and different.

Drank this at the hard rock cafe bangalore.  Pours a beautiful orange with a half inch head.  Aromas of citrus.  Taste is very complex with the hops becoming apparent in the finish.  Cannot feel the alcohol - excellent beer, totally unique.

Tasted more times. Yesterday again.
Bottle, 33 cl.
Color = amber, good off-white head. Great aroma, fruity, spice. 
Flavour is also top, good bitterness.
Quality, pours light brown with a large head.  It has an aroma of champagne, spices, citrus, and lemon.  Taste: sweet and dry.  Good Stuff.
Pours unclear orange with a creamy white foam. Aroma and taste is fruity orange, malts, yeast and spices. Fine mouthfell. Thumbs up to the munks!!

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2009 [bottle] Pours cloudy, hazy gold with a huge, rocky off white head. Tart aroma is huge, and noticeable from a few feet away. Lots of apple, lemon zest, and some orange and grapefruit in there as well. Taste is quite striking. Very tart, with lots of citric hop notes, lemon, yeast, and a slightly underbalanced malt sweetness. Very light on the tongue with a remarkably dry finish.
Everpresent fizzy head..slight carbonation. Burnt caramel, wet hops, bitter tangy taste on the tongue. Complex.

The beer was highly carbed and the head lasted to the end of the glass.  Aroma was slightly fruity, citrusy with little or no hop aroma present. 

At first sip, I thought it was candy, it had a nice, sweet, fruity presence.  Then as I settled into the beer the hop bitterness and yeast spiciness began to shine through.

There is a solid alcohol presence but it is not overwhelming.  I found that after one beer I did not feel it all that much as I do with some of the stronger Belgians.

I thought this beer was a lot like Duvel, although without the same hop presence that Duvel has.  The yeast character was very simlar in both beers.
Holy moley.  Tastes stronger than it really is.  Super complex taste, buried deep in a light, cloudy body.  Nice frothy head.  Basically amazing.  Dunno if I could do more than one.
UPDATED: OCT 22, 2008 Bottle. Really citrus dominated aroma with lots of grapefruits.Mouthfeel is a bit sour and really dry. Flavor consists of bananas,citrus and a sour finish.
UPDATED: SEP 20, 2014 Theres something to be said for always wanting a bottle and never having to worry about running out.

Has a cloudy orange appearance with a thick, bubbly head. Aroma is of banana and caramel. 

Bubbles over the palate with bitter finish, somewhat like grapefruit.

bottle.  Pours a cloudy, orange-copper color with a huge off-white fluffy head which lingered throughout the drink.  Smell is lemon-rind yeast and some alcohol.  Taste is same as smell.  Mouthfeel is medium-to-thin with lots of carbonation.  Dry and tart.  I was not impressed with this as it was lemony, but so what and did not seem complex to me.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 color was very surprising based upon initial aroma gathered from the bottle, before the pour. one of the hoppiest trappists, thats for sure. some orange and musty animals in the nose which translates well to the pallete. aftertaste falls off a cliff at 80 mph, dry finish is severe and enjoyable.  palate character has elements of cider possibly: dry, muted/darkened fruit...all articulated to varying extents into the flavor.  

i remember many years ago when sam adams was the hoppiest beer i had ever had. at the time (pre 21) i didnt understand that that pine tree taste was hops, and now when im trying to expalin hops to someone that doesnt understand i use that beer as an example. well orval is one of the most perfect examples of brettanomyces. if you are unclear on what that means, drink an orval. you wont be disappointed

33cl bottle courtesy of Harrisoni.  This is awful. A kind of cloudy orange-brown colour with the smell of a lemon toilet cleaner. The initial taste is of a poor quality cloudy cider in which someone’s let a nail go rusty.  There’s no subtly anywhere. Let it linger in your mouth and it tastes of vodka mixed with oranges and burnt sugar. The finish is a combination of rough burnt sugar and what I imagine bile tastes like. Maybe the beers gone off but then again Harrisoni said I wouldn’t like it.

bottle served in a tulip glass. hazy amber pour with a thick off-white head. nose of lemon rind, banana, and some yeasty spiciness. very unique tart bready taste with some noticeable citrus and barnyard characteristics. nice dry finish that leaves some bitterness and alcohol warmth at the base of your throat. head lasts throughout the entire glass. interesting and quite different, and I am glad that I have tried it, but it isnt something that i could see myself drinking again.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2009 Cloudy amber appearance, filmy dense head.  Citrus aroma is prevalent but not overpowering.  Great flavor with balanced tart and sweet taste.  Peppy carbonation which lasted throughout the "session".   This is not overly high ABV at about 6% which is perfect in this brew.  I like the IPAs but this was a great diversion.
Bottle, as image shows.  Thick white head with massive bubbles hanging on the sides of the glass.  Mild but good spice taste.  Dry, some suggestions of alcohol.  Goes down bubbly and smooth.
Bottle. Amber colour with huge pale brown head. Aroma wheat, brett, hopps. Taste A little sour and malt. Dry and a little bitter taste. Not so impressed.
Large billowy white head that lasted.  Very dry finish and a mild subtle beer.  Pretty good and refreshing some fruity notes very delicate.

Bottled 11/04/06, consumed 04/24/08. Pours with a gorgeous fluffy white head topping a hazy dark amber body. Man, this is so good. Incredible brett nose with some spicy hops. Not sour at all, just wonderful rich mouthfeel and a bretty dryness. I got a warming sensation as I sipped this. Im very excited to try this at different points in its life, but this was some age on it.

Bottled 22/08/2007. Hoppy, fruity, phenolic aroma. Very big but loose head. Orange/amber color. Hazy. Apricots and vanilla. Some sulphury notes reminiscent of cat pee. Flowery hops. As it warms, oranges and coriander. Flavor is creamy effervescent medium big with creamy malt in the finish. Finally some dry bitterness and a hint of sourness. Not as wild as I remembered it to be.

Bottle, Fargo, ND. Hazy orange amber colour, tall head that reduces to soapy looking bubbles. Citrus hop aroma, tight carbonation with a warming spicey hop flavor. Long finish, slightly lighter body than expected, however a very nice beer.

A- Pours an Orangey Caramel Color with a massive head. Head has great body and excellent retention. Overall a beautiful brew.

S- The smell is faint however there are distinctive sweet flowery notes and a muted doughy smell. I detected a slight metallic tinge.

T- Starts off sweet and doughy and progresses to a slightly bitter taste. This finishes very smooth with no lingering flavors left on the palate. Exceptional blend of juniper and sweet doughy flavors.

M- Very smooth, a robust carbonation as well as a full body.

D- Highly drinkable. This beer finishes so smooth that it leaves me wanting more and more. Exceptional mix of flavors that is not overpowering. I could certainly enjoy a few of these in an evening if it was not for the lofty price tag.

Poured into a little Delirium glass that I jacked when I was in Brussels back in 06. Nice pour, ruddy gold with lovely carbonation. Solid head. Dry fruity taste, almost cidery. Spicy hops with a nice touch of sourness. Delicious, Id like to shake the hands of the monks who brew this stuff.

Bottle into Trappist glass.  Pours a beautiful orange, highlighted by the carbonation and a fluffy white head.  Absolutely beautiful to look at.  Aroma is very fruity, hints of hoppiness that arent evident in many other Belgian Ales.  A nice twist.  I agree with everyone whos noted the power of the aroma.  People at the other end of my table stopped talking to comment on it!  The flavor is slightly dry acidic, but the yeasts make  play, as does the citrus arena.  A little spice hangs around at the end, and the overall feeling in the mouth is a little strong.  As others have noted, the flavors change as the beer warms.  In my case, I sensed less of the citrus and more of the yeastiness, hop dryness, and spicy malty.  Frankly, I feel like I need to try this again because it was simply too much going on for my still-developing palate.
A very refreshing aroma, citrous and sour. Dark read/brown color. Dry taste with sour notes, fruity and hops. A wonderful beer.
I found this beer to be unexciting and I was very disappointed.  Nice color and aroma and apperance.  Flavor seemed more "sour" than other Trappist beers I have tried.  Not one of the best.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2009 Bottled on 8/8/07. Pours a bright orange color, slightly carbonated, with a thick pillowy off-white head. Aroma is amazing; quite floral, tangy, fruity, with some yeast and a perfume presence. Not quite as strong tasting as the aroma would indicate. Tangy fruits, hard cider, fragrance, some yeast but not as much as I expected. Quite acidic as well with a dry and sour finish. Light numbing on the tongue. Very complex as it seems I pick something different up with each taste. An interesting and unique brew. Re-rate, this time I tasted lots of melon, even some banana with yeast and a fragrant, tart, dry, numbing. This really is an amazing beer that just keeps getting better the more I have it.

Bottle. Pours orange with an off white head. Remarkable aroma, very close to a ten. Sweet orange and other fruits, almost floral hops but not quite, then cinnamon and nutmeg to round it out. Nice body, but the flavor doesnt quite live up to the aroma. Same spices and ripe, sweet fruit as in the aroma, but they just dont quite mesh as well. Still very good though.

...well, I have to say, this is one of the most complex, as well as expensive ales out there.  It is thick, very aromatic from the dry hopping, and also has a nice finish.  No real harsh or overwhelming aftertaste, nice and fruity.  Only bad thing about this is Im not rich...yet.  Drink one.
Bottle. Holy aromas - could smell this feet away. Nice thin malt flavour, dry. Good beer.
Nice head which quickly disappears.  Hazy bronze colour. Plesant malt flavour.  Fruit aroma, with hints of berries. Nice dry finish...who is buying the next one ?
Served at the Porterhouse, unfortunately very very cold :-( Hazy, unclear, tiny head, notes of spices, eau de cologne, dried fruit, hops, dry and bitter, very delicate beer.
UPDATED: SEP 17, 2010 Bottle. Huge head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are malt, hops and yeast. Very dry. Rerated at sep 17 2010. Nice sour brett.
hops hops and bretts. this beer is too dry for me. watery and lacking some body. overall taste and flavors are well balanced and much enjoyable

damn.....this beer is different...but very nice bret nose....and super dry...but not astringent.....and when it is gone...I want more...great malt flavor and the finish....leaves me wishing I had a case......great stuff

The beer pours a light amber, with a light white head that quickly reduces in size but stays well after this reduction. The head leaves a thick lacing that follows the beer only part way down the glass. The light nose of the beer smells of sweet fruit with a trace of yeast. The beer is light a bubbly on your tongue almost dancing as it slides down your throat. The sharp bite of the carbonation and alcohol almost over powers the light taste of malt and yeast. The beer finishes with a quick yet sharp carbonation inspired fruitiness.

This one is a stands out from the other trappist beers that I have had. It pours a hazy orange/brown with a thick creamy head. Nice floral aroma with a funky yeast and citrus in the bouquet. The brettanomyces yeast imparts a wild and funky flavor. Sour and tart with a citrusy and floral hops. Unique and complex, refreshing and effervescent. Medium body and a smooth mouth feel. Tart dry finish that leaves you wanting more. Great beer with a big price tag [5 bucks +deposit] for a 11.2 oz bottle that I could drink a lot of.
Pours a deep orange with a big beige head.  Aroma of yeast, spice,  and bread.  Taste is of spice, citrus, and heavy yeast.  Finish is dry and bitter (hops), with a very heavily carbonated body.

Bottle. I know its just my opinion, but I think this beer is over rated. It starts off good. Has a really pleasant aroma, almost of a floral nature. Looks ok. Has a nice head that goes away rather quickly. The taste, ok this is where it goes down hill. It is way too sour, bitter and dry for my taste. I can see this being a wine lovers beer. Recommended for those who like dry beer.

Burnt honey nose, slight floral notes.  Pale amber color with a fluffy long-lasting head--great lacing!  Some sweet/sour flavor,  toasted biscuit malts, with some spicy hops.    Fully body, huge carbonation, and the finish is slow, complex, and has a late burn from the alcohol.  Great beer, seems it will age nicely...

Pours a cloudy amber color with an extremely thick, foamy head that lasts.  Lots of thick lacing.  Sweet yeasty aroma typical of the style, although perhaps not as strong as some.  Nice fruity taste, although not as sweet as the aroma would have indicated.  A hint of nutmeg flavor.  A nice crisp, hoppy bite with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  A little different from other Trappists Ive had, but an excellent beer nonetheless.

For a trappist theres not much aroma to speak of. In fact "for a trappist theres not..." epitomizes the beer. It is delicious but doesnt stand out in the style for me. The yeast is interesting and produces some subtle fruity flavors, pears and stale citrus. The head is huge and the carbonation is heavy making it a faster drink than most of its style. Pretty good.

330ml, bottled 4/1/2006.  Dark, hazy orange/amber with a fluffy beige head.  I can see how some people get so excited about this beer.  Nose is probably the most disappointing part, fairly subdued at a slightly chilled temperature (which I feel the rest of the beer is best at).  That said, I did find some yeast, and lemon drop.  Some bitter fruit, lemon, lime, nutmeg, cinnamon.  The mouthfeel is the best part, with some serious acidity and dry finish along with ridiculous carbonation makes this fairly unique.  Coats the palate and results in a very long finish.  An excellent and unique beer.
The aroma is excellent, and the hoppiness sets it apart from many of the other belgians I have had. I cant put my finger on it, but something in the finish throws it off a bit for me.

This is the beer that first made me curious about lambic.  A friend of mine brought a couple of them over and we drank them out of goblets.  He told me that the dry perfumy taste comes from a wild yeast strain called Brett and not from the hops.  There is something about this beer that makes it great.  It is not a lambic, though.
Contains the nice thick head Im used to seeing with belgians. Aroma is sweet and fruity with a faint scent of ammonia? Not my favorite- but still a good beer nonetheless.

Pours a nice gold into the glass with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is spicy and sweet.  Flavor is crisp, spicy, with more bitterness than I was expecting.  Like most belgian beers I  really like the mouthfeel.

Perfectly cloudy amber colour with a thick white head that settles down to a cloudy 1/2". Sweet, but slightly alcoholic aroma. Taste is fresh, spicy, with a bitter but dry finish. Quite carbonated. Looks great, tastes nice, overall a beautiful beer experience.

Bottle courtesy Boboski. This is such a classic beer. Pours a cloudy amber with a thick white head. Aroma is fruity hops and sour yeast. It just has a dry aroma. Taste is light dry and sour with hints of fruit. Finishes dry and bitter. Amazingly elegant.

Not my favorite of the trappist breweries, but an amazing brew still.  Pours golden with a voluminous white head, highly carbonated.  Slightly sour aroma, very sweet and candy-like.  Flavor is not quite as bitter as I expected, and the hopping is a bit more subdued as well, but the malty character leaves a dry but sweet finish to this wonderful brew.

9/25/07 Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a massive white head. Aroma is sweet citrus with spicy yeast background. Flavor is fruit, belgian spice, and a little herb. Very smooth and drinkable. I was expecting big things from this, but it didnt quite meet my expectations. Still a good beer, though.

Poured from 330ml bottle a slightly has tannish orange with a large frothy white head.  Aromas of floral hops and fruit, sort of like cider and lavender with a yeasty bread edge.  The flavor starts off with a slightly sweet caramel wheat bread taste and then quickly moves on to a sour cherry, citrusy corriander and ends with a little dry bitterness.  A nice acidity hits the tongue from the high carbonation along with a slight pucker from the sour notes.  A great beer, very distinctive with lots of flavor.
Bottle from the Orval cafe. This is a beer I will always seek out and return to. It never fails to captivate. Unique and wonderful.

11.2oz bottle.  Pours a hazy creamsicle orange with a billowy white head.  Aroma is sweet and spicy, with a predominantly cider-ish smell complemented by additional hints of floral hops, caramel, and yeast.  Taste is creamy and full, with a somewhat sour and dry flavor of dark fruit, hops, and maybe some tart berries as well.  Not my favorite Belgian by a longshot, but still a fairly distinct one.
Tasted 3/24/08.  330ml bottle.  Apparently vigorous pour yeilds thick billowing head. Nice retention.  Good hue.  Nice bret flavor.  Crisp and fresh.  Bitter and sour.  Tart.  Good when fresh.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2010 330mL Bottled on 4/24/07. Drank 3/24/08. Very hazy burnt orange with a massive white head. Aroma: Start orange citrus and sour, with a yeasty spice kicking up to tingle the nostrils, followed by dirty feet. Lots of prickly carbonation. Flavor: Finishes w/ a sort of flat with taste reminding me of feet wrapped in burnt leathery bacon. Finish is pretty dry. 7/5/7/3/14-3.6

05/09. 330mL bottle with just over a year on it. Very similar experience. Very leathery. Definitely feet wrapped in burnt leathery bacon, but I liked it more this time. 7/5/7/4/14-3.7 

7/2/09. Bottled 14 months ago. Less leathery than the last one of this batch. Too carbonated. Fruitier. 7/5/8/3/15-3.8

6/3/10. Bottled 30/12/2009. Excellent aroma. Less brett allowing some bready, almost caramel malts to come through. Some nice fruity-pineapple, other stuff. 9/4/8/4/15-4.0

From bottle:  Deep golden to orange in color this poured a thick white head.  The nose has a nice sourness to it with scents of corriander, citrus fruit, orange marmelade, clove and cinnamon.  In the mouth it is medium-bodied with a lot of carbonationand an herbal edge that is more noticable than in the nose.
Den er overraskende...på den gode måde. Lidt frugtig i smagen og behagelig krydret

Fredagsbaren på Biologi, Aarhus
Bottled
Orange with white top
Very bitter
Spicy and orange notes

UPDATED: APR 8, 2010 33cl bottle. Pours golden with a fluffy pillow like head and beautiful Belgian lace inside the glass. Delicate perfume aroma of orange, citrus, spices, bread and horseblanket notes. The flavour is intriguingly complex and almost appears to take on a different character each mouthful. A little tart. Dry and bitter finish. Damn the bottles finished already. A true Belgian Ale. Edit: Ive gone back to Orval on many an occasion and every time is something new and exciting. I personally enjoy around the 2 year age mark when the brett has made its mark and its a superb balance between funk, fruit and spice. Its just a really fun beer. To drink it in Belgium is the epitome of what beer is all about. Yeah.

Pours with a huge head the sticks around and never really goes away. Color is a slightly hazy golden amber color. Smells like Big Red Chewing Gum i.e. cinnamon. I get a little hops and maybe a touch of alcohol but the main overwhelming taste is cinnamon. A huge amount of lacing is present. Taste is different, I get a very effervescent bubbly palate with a slightly tart flavor and a very dry aftertaste with a slight alcohol presence.

Strawberries, cherries, and peaches in the aroma.  The head was big and white, the beer itself was a medium orange color.  The first thing that hit me when I drank it was that it wasnt well balanced, the alcohol feel on the tounge was a little bit too much.  After it warmed a bit (I think it was served too cold), the fruit flavors came out and it became more enjoyable.  Ill have to try this again in the future to see if maybe my rating thats lower than most is due to handling issues.

A fresh and fruity nose on this very different trappist-beer. You clearly taste the brettanomyces that makes it a plessure to burp. Its hoppy and crispy and stays with you for a looong time... gotta go for one more...

Pours a lighter golden color than one normally expects in a Trappist offering.  Shows you right away that this is not really a Belgian Strong, but more aptly described as a Belgian Ale.  Fluffy white head looks gorgeous in the glass.  Aroma is a lighter sweet fruit and malt.  The citrus aroma is of mild hoppiness, but very different than the rich hops aroma that youd get from a lager.  It is crisp and clean on the palate - dominant flavors are fresh light fruits.  Delicious brew.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2009 330 ml bottle - pours a glowing apricot hue with a good sized fluffy whitish head.  Typical of a Belgian, but excellent looking nonetheless.  Aroma is absolutely stunning - bursting fruity hops dominate, along with apricot, sour cherry, raspberry, plum, peach - all sorts of really fresh light fruit.  The hopping almost seems similar to some American West Coast IPAs.  Fantastic.  Flavour is a notch lower than the aroma, but still very good.  More of the fruit flavours coming through, but with a very dry quality to the brew, and a mild bitter finish.  There is also a sort of barnyardy/meadowy quality at the back of the palate that lasts forever.  Excellent beer, one that I am going to surely stock up on, as it is only a seasonal release here.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 Hazy orange with a low but dense head. Quite extreme perfumation in the aroma of orange and mandarin. The flavour is spicy and at the same time quite hoppy leaving a complex perfumy-sour feeling and a special yeast feeling. The beer tickles all the way through with a lively carbonation. Its so special that I cannot help to adore it! Furthermore both the bottle and the glass are pieces of arts in themselves.

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours an amber colour with a big foamy head about two fingers high. The head settles down to a thin "roof" after 1-2 minutes.
The flavour is spicy and tastes like oranges and malts.

Bottle @ Eulogy:  Poured a golden amber color with a thick head.  The aroma was of hops and citrus.  The flavor was that of orange, spice, some hops and malts.  Overall, I see why this is such a favorite.

Hazy orangey yellow with thick & foamy pale head. Nose is fruity (passion fruit, carambola, strawberry?) and freshly tart. The dry-hopping really shows itself. Flavor crisp, softly tart, peppery with rawish yeast. Finishes very dry (chalky)  and intensely perfumey in its complexity. Medium bodied with strong but smooth & foaming carbonation. Unique and intense.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 I think this is a beer that you love it or hate it. For me Ill tasted it for the first time, more then 20 years ago. I didnt liked it at all. It was to bitter for me. I even thought it was rancid. After many years Ill had another try. even then it wasnt not my taste. So for about 2 years ago, Ill treid it a third time. I started to like it. For now I like this dark orange clear colored beer very much. It has a large light beige foamy head. It has an aroma of grapes, citrus, an also very hoppy. This is already complex. The taste is complex as well. Again a lot of hop bitterness, fruits, flowers and some spice. A different but good and very tastfull combination. Its more than a good beer. 
And for everyone give this beer a second and even a third change.
08/03/08 - ratings: 8/10 - 5/5 - 9/10 - 4/5 - 18/20.
Today Ill give a new rating about this great bear. The aroma and taste of this beer are so complex and great. Every time you taste it, it gives a new experience. All the aromas and flavors of this beer are great.

Pours a beautiful golden/amber.  Smells of citrus and spice.  Flavor is crisp, complex and pleasing.  Hoppier than I expected.  Tastes like orange, spice and malt.  Finishes with a very pleasant bitter.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 Pours a lovely amber/red.  Nice hoppy aroma. Some peppery taste in this one, probably from the hops. Quite nice, not very complex though.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2008 11.2 oz bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours a golden hazy color with one finger white head.  Scent of hops and some spiciness.  Flavor was somewhat disappointing.  I personally wasnt a fan of the intense hop flavor with the complex flavors typical of a trappist ale.  Also, the alcohol was quite present in the taste.  Overall it was a decent beer but not up to the level of Chimay, Rochefort, etc. in my opinion.
Golden in color with a thick head.  Hazy to the point where I am unable to see though it.  Slightly sour smell and taste.  Taste is good but I cannot quite distinguish it.
UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Excellent beer! Nice aroma of yeast. Bananas and figs? Huge head. Taste is wicked good. This was a treat.

11.2 oz bottle, bottling date stamped 25/09/2007, so very fresh. Hazy dark  honey color. Yeast sediment remained firmly settled in bottle. Smells like tanned leather, wet straw, orange pith. The brett character is much more mild than I remember it being. Could be that it is a young sample. It does taste a bit "green". Some alcohol vapors evident. Malt body is quite attenuated, little residual sweetness, slightly astringent-watery finish. As it warms, aroma is opening up, some nice floral hops. A very nicely done, unique trappist ale.

Pours cloudy tangerine with a massive light brown head. Aroma of cotton candy and hops -- very sweet, but with some off hues. Left my tongue watering. Taste caught me off guard. Mouth is bombarded with sour and spiciness and shrivelling hops. Complex: Theres a web to untangle here. Ginger, nutmeg and allspice all surfaced. Body is a little too watery. Leaves a very dry tongue and some lingering hops. I want another one for aging.

330ml, fun looking bottle, 6.9% a/v

Pours a darker then average murky colour, between a rich gold and rich brown. It has a very tight light tan head which readily laces. The aroma is dark stonefruit, burnt sugar, and summer flowers. The taste is complex and gorgeous, there is a good hit of cinammon in there, along with the stonefruit, and some nice caramel flavours. The mouthfeel is very full with small lovely bubbles on the tongue.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2008 First rating (plan to rate again)...bottle...Poured a nice golden-orange w/ a white head. Nose of florals, spice, citrus, tiny bit of pine. Flavor was similar...definite florals and spice up front and that mellow to produce a hit of caramel (very slight) and some citrus. Not too bitter, a little dry, but certainly not "cotton" dry. Very refreshing. Classic! Id love to age a few and see how it changes.

Pours a light amber with fluffy white head that lasts a long time.  Aroma of yeast and a slight sweetness (malty).  Flavor is slightly yeasty and bready.  A little astringent with some yeasty esters.  Medium to light body.  A nice trappist.
Golden orangey colour, cloudy, large head. A little bitter taste with some citrus. Lots of carbonation. Not really my type of beer but I may come back for more as it is interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2010 Bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville. Pours orangish-brown with a massive head so big my Duvel glass couldnt accomadate the bottle in the first pour. A very sour earthy bitter yeasty aroma. Bitter, earthy and highly complex taste. I got some definite flavors of mint and tea. Interesting.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2008 Pours deep gold with a frothy, lasting one finger head.  Aroma of citrus, spice,  and grass.  Assertive bitterness.  Starts like a Belgian blonde and finsihes like an IPA (somewhere between England and the US).  Really unique beer.  I cant say Ive ever had anything quite like it.  Not at all what was expecting.
Bottle, like on the picture. Nice blond beer, large head. hazy, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, sticky, average carbonation, astringent,

2-year-old bottle. Poured yellow-gold, white persistent head, slightly cloudy. Nose is spciy, estery, yeasty. Flavor is bitter (brettanomyces?), horse-blanket, acidic, lemony. Finish is dry, yeasty and complex. Refreshing, carbonated mouthfeel.

Bottle.  Pours a medium amber color with a nice lingering foamy head  great lacing.  Nose is light hops, citrus, yeast and spices.  Palate is spice, dried fruit  apples, pears, bananas maybe? Drinks like a trail mix.  A great dry finish.  A very nice Belgian.

Bottle from LCBO. Hazy, deep orange in colour with a large white head. Smells and tastes of hops and citrus. Moderately bitter, with a long aftertaste. Pretty good all around, but its not my style, so I wont be drinking again.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Pours hazy orange with off white head.  Aroma of hops, malts and some funkiness. Flavor is slighly bitter and finish is dry. Medium body with effervescent carbonation. The more of this I drink, the more I want to drink. A great brew.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 bottle.Sampled at the Burp Castle with Andrew and Streets. Pours a hazy murky brown body with thick frothy head. Aroma is wheaty and almost tart. Mouthfeel is very dry, so dry it verges on tart, with notes of wheat - almost like a Brett-treatment to a wheat ale. Solid Belgian ale. Very subtle and delicate, nothing over the top.

200th beer on ratebeer ...bottled 7/5/07 .... cloudy with a huge head .... light hop and malt aroma .... highly carbonated ... slight soapy mouth feel .... complex to the point where Im confused (I may be thinking too hard, I think Ill just relax and try to enjoy the BEER) ... aroma is awesome ... flavor is hoppy but not very bitter .... the finish is crisp and clean ... the malts are not overpowering ... this beer is very drinkable .... I could definitely drink a lot of these and not tire of the taste ... this is probably my top Belgian to date

A unique trappist! Brown amber coloured. Changes over the years in taste. I had a bottle brewed 22/11/2007 tonight. Slight fruit taste, the bitterness is on the loose. A littke bit of citrus, but not too many. Complex flavours. A smooth and delicious beer...

Pours hazy golden brown with fluffy white head.  Aroma of abundant citrus, cola, spice, yeast.  Nose reminds me of a lambic without the funkiness.  Hmmm... I dont know quite what to make of the flavor:  citrus, dried fruit, spice, yeast, earthy dry-hopping definitely apparent.  Flavor is sweet, sour, and bitter at the same time- extremely unique.  Short, dry finish leaves you wanting more.  I would have really enjoyed this one had the flavor lingered a bit more, but what is there is beautiful.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2011 330ml bottle from the LCBO. Pours a hazy light brown, with a large white head. Aroma: Loads of hops, very dry, spicy, some cinnamon, yeast. Taste: Wow, now thats different. Very complex, starts out a little sweet with all of the above mentioned aspects, but becomes intensely dry and bizarre. Lots of complex fruity esters in the finish and aftertaste. The dryness is so strong this brew virtually vanishes from your tongue. Very rough mouth-feel initially, makes way for the desert. Banana, apple, cinnamon, apple crisp, yeast, its hard to fully describe. It is what it is. Lingering bitterness turns into mild sweetness, apple pie like. Sourness becomes more evident as it goes along, which is the only thing really holding me back from liking this one a lot, as I have issues with sour ales. Will age and revisit. There may be just a bit too much hype around this one. NEW RATING: Ive got more used to the characters in this beer and can really appreciate it a lot more now. I love the Bretty dryness, very puckering and sour yet with some decent malt body behind it. Hoppy to the max which I also love.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2008 Re-rating.  MASSIVE head.  It explodes out of the glass!  Good retention, too.  Lots of carbonation.  Fruit and floral aroma.  Flavors are very spicy and fruity.  It is dry and well hopped with some caramel and yeast.  Smooth and creamy.

Purchased at Top Foods in Woodinville, WA.  Bottling date: 3/27/2007.  Pours a cloudy orange/amber color with white foamy head that lasts for a while.  Taste:  A slight hint of lemon, with mild hops and a dry finish.  In the most simple of terms, this is one excellent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Sweet distracting vanilla candy fragrance. Big head, very appealing head, visually stimulating when you look closely.  I hate to focus on the head but it goes rocky after a few minutes and it then gets darkly dotted stained from the drippings off the bottom of the bottle.  Perfect carbonation greets the palate and you can see it constantly rolling in the brew, quite entertaining. Very nice balance of hops and malt land on the taste buds. Not over  the top except for the level of enjoyability. In my humble opinion, this is a fine example of what beer should be. Friendly in every respect. Exquisitely beauteous. This could be the perfect session brew if it wasnt for the mild bitter linger, which may I say is quite humble!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Light brown with a small head.  A little more hoppy and fruity than other trappist ales.  Pretty average all around, I would have it again, but not if I had the option of a Chimay Bleu or Rochefort.

Raw chicken. Unmalted barley, yeast and water. Yeah I know its not a good start. Jamaïcan jerk spice and alcohol. This starts to be wild for a monks brew.

I cant remember how many Orval Ive had in the last 8 years. A 100, for sure. But its still is perfect. Styrians Golding in dry hop ? Who give a damn, its so good.

Hail those monks that praise for brew

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2008 bottle from a trade with the cheeseman. pours a slightly hazy amber with a big off white head and a little sediment. aromas are hoppy yeasty belgian goodness. flavours are great with typical belgian ale characteristics significantly enhanced by the added hops. the brett has added a welcomed touch and dryness i dont normal associate with belgian ales. all of these factors come together to make this the best belgian ive had. im glad i finally got to have one of these and i wish ive had more. (this beer did become availible in my area and i picked up a case. everytime i have one i have to go back and re-rate this brew higher. stuningly good and deserving of a place in my top 10 brews.) thid beer is perfect

Bottled on 2/8/2008.  I tried and like all the attainable trappist brews, but this one stands apart for me.  It has a nice body thats right in the middle and a dry finish that I enjoy.  This is a beer you can sip and enjoy or down a few and feel refreshed.  If it was cheaper and easier to get, I would always have some handy.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 For rating #2100, picked up a single bottle at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, Minnesota. Pours a hazy orange copper brew with a thick off-white head that has some excellent retention and sticky lacing. Aroma of fruity orange and coriander with some multi-grain malt, some yeast and a light candy sugar with apple cider. Taste is medium bodied, some carbonation that is soft with flavors of coriander, multi-grain malt, some flowery and grassy hops, and a touch of herbal spice. Finish is semi-sweet, a slight alcohol warmth with mild bitterness and coriander aftertaste that really makes this beer memorable. Prosit!
Hazy copper pour with a beautiful thick white head.  Malty aroma.  Sour and hoppy flavor with a chewy palate.  Dry, yeasty finish.  Excellent beer.

Bottle. Fruity (oranges), coriander, wine, sweet, light yeasty, malty (bread). Cloudy orange - red body, large creamy - foamy white head, fully lasting. Light acidic and sour, average duration. Dry and creamy on the palate, medium body, soft carbonation.
Best beer ever !! Machel Jackson also gave it a very high rating so... Very special intense taste, bitter, low alcohol.. beautifull bottle...

Courtesy of Dragonstout. Pours a reddish orange with a large whipped head. Fluffy lacing. Aroma is mostly apple. Tastes of light semi tart fruit. Has a dry earthy taste. Floral and lemon taste on the back end. I dont see what the hype is about this. Yeah, its made by monks, big deal.
Bière sans comparaison à aucune. Il faut la boire vieillie en cave de 3 à 5 ans.
Bottle. Orangish color with a white head. Fruity aroma with a nice apple, pear taste. A decent beer.

(Bottled On: 27/06/2006 - Labeled as being 6.9% abv).

Appearance: Pours an orange-amber body with a tall, foamy white head.

Smell: Complex aroma filled with notes of citrus, pears, apple cores, gentian, sauvignon blanc, and a second-hand horseblanket store.

Taste: Flavors of unripened pears, piced citrus, and bitter herbs. Dash of white wine. Sour and funky throughout. Hops come through now and again amongst all the various tastes. Finishes peppery and exceedingly dry. Lingering tongue-numbing sourness in the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Spritzy, lightly prickly carbonation.

Drinkability: Certainly one of the more unique Trappist beers out there, Ill give it that.

Poured to a thick head with aromas of malts and hops. Initial flavor of hops and ended with fruity accents. Bitter finish. Almost like an IPA, yet subtle in its bitterness. Not as astringent as some American IPA.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 Initial review, 2-24-08: 330 ml bottle. Bottled on 1-24-2006. Poured into a Corsendonk tulip glass. Wonderful, complex, floral, zesty, farmhouse ale-like aroma. Sour apple, cider, honey, candy sugar, salt, and lemon scents. The smell is subtle, and it could stand to be stronger. Pours a hazy brass to light copper. An enormous quantity of tiny bubbles furiously gushes to the surface from the center of the glass in a champagne-like fashion. The effervescence lasts for a long time. Large amount of thick, uneven, long-lasting, cream-colored head that looks like whipped cream. Orval looks amazing! This is one of the best appearances on which I have ever laid eyes. Produces long-lasting, thick, extensive lacing. Complex, subtle, dry taste. Pear, milk, lemon-flavored carbonated water, apple, and champagne flavors. Dirt-hops dryness in the start and finish. There is an additional, great component to the finish on which I cant put my finger. That description fails to do the flavor justice. The taste is simply Orval. The taste is so complex as to be almost indescribable. I wish the flavors were stronger, because they are excellent. Long, parchingly dry aftertaste. Medium to full body. Fluffy, creamy, and lively in the palate. The liquid expands to fill the mouth. Awesome, unique texture. Easy to drink and refreshing. Orval is one of the best looking and feeling (in the palate) beers Ive ever tried. I would give the appearance and palate 6s if I could. The very good smell and taste are merely nice bonuses. Orval truly is one of the best beers in the world. Having had one bottle, I can tell that this is the kind of beer that will produce different sensations and insights upon each tasting. It has something for the fan of almost any type of beer. If I could drink only one beer for the rest of my life, I might have to choose this one! 8/5/8/5/18  4.4

Supplemental review, 4-19-08: Roughly 3 oz. pour from an 11.2 oz. bottle, consumed at a beer tasting on 4-12-08. Bottled on 9-13-07. Spicy aroma features clove, coriander, rotten apple, cinnamon, and apple cider scents. Pours a very hazy orange / amber. Effervescent. Large amount of uneven, off-white head. Produces thick lacing. Subtle taste. Farmhouse flavors. Dull sweetness. Light to medium body. While still quite good, this bottle of Orval didnt blow me away like the first one I rated did. Ill keep the original rating as the official one, but if I were to rate this one, it would be as follows: 9/5/7/4/15  4.0

Bottle. Hazy orange with fizzy head. Aroma is pungently hoppy with some metallic tinge. Flavor similar, overwhelmingly bitter and hoppy, but not at all like an IPA. Somewhat like a very bitter version of a Witbier. No noticeable malt to speak of. Plenty of carbonation. I didnt care for this beer much at all, despite its monastic origin. Had a hard time finishing it. Very different from the other dubbel/tripel types of Belgian Ales that Im more familiar with, but I think Orval fits the description given by the brewers and is probably good for those who like this style, just not for me.

one year after bottling date.  pours brown-orange with a porous white head.  intense carbonation breaks head into cobwebs.  musty, slightly fruity smell.  taste is dry as a bone and tart with bitter edge.  apple and pear notes comes through as it warms, but they are subtle - the dry, bitter qualities are dominant.  a great beer that was a treat to drink, but there are other belgian style brews that are less expensive and comparable in taste.
pours light amber color with lots of head.  lots of carbonation.  decent taste with what i believe is correander.  i pretty good beer, but probably not one that i would purchase again.
By far the best Trappist that I have tried which is 6 of the 7 available. In the process of cellaring 4 cases to see what Orval is really capable of.

Pours a wonderful honey yellow color with ample fluffy white head. High head retention with good lacing as well, still had a creamy head after ten or more minutes. The nose is filled with sour muscat grapes, funk, hay, leather, earthy hops, and a touch of lemon. The nose is a little decieving. The flavors start out with a bit of bitterness up front, quickly followed by a distinct funky flavor... but where is the sour grape detected in the nose.  Finish is relatively dry with some hops at first, then giving way to a more subtle muscat flavor. I love this beer, but do wish there was a little more carry over from the nose to the palate.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2010 bottle BB 4/24/12. i look forward to trying this in another four years... pours a cloudy brown iced tea color with a wispy white head. it leaves behind some spotty lacing on the glass. aroma is a complex mixture of  caramel, funk, mineral, citrus, grass and yeast. the flavor is alive and evolving every time i go back for another sip... little to no sweetness, lemon, slate, pale malt, wood, leather, grass, a dry funk,yeasty spiciness, on and on. every time it is something new on the palate. a very light texture with airy carbonation gives it an amazing mouth feel. words dont do it justice...
two years feels real good...

Ive waited for such a long time before rating this beer, for I felt my description would not do it justice. With humility, here goes: hazy copper, pouring the beer in its own chalice forms a 2 inch lasting compact foam; the carbonation is high while being controlled. The nose is fruity (lemon), a touch flowery (rose), peppery, a bit funky, yeasty and perhaps there is a touch of green olives pits. The complexity of its aroma is astonishing and appetizing à souhait! As for the flavor, I cannot think of any beer featuring a better balance, tart enough to make it mouthwatering, hops being one of its numerous attributes, superb complexity in its bitterness while  it is never overwhelming and finishes dry. Actually, the lenght is so good you wonder if itll ever ends. As for the palate, silky smooth. This is the one and only beer that grows on me: every time I have one, the pleasure I have keeps increasing. My one and only complaint may be its glass: while it is indeed beautifull, I hardly ever manage not to spill some of this gold liquid for the glass is so wide. I cannot think of any other beers that features such complexity and drinkability. If you find it too bitter, you may lay it down for about 2-3 years, it mellows a lot.

Hmmm... Not as crazy about this one as others.  Very nice looking beer with a nice white pillowy head.  Smells grassy and citrusy and a bit funky. Really dont care for the taste of this.  Very yeasty and grassy... I like the dark Belgians better.
I would like to try this one again soon. I was very cloose to buy one again yesterday. It is very good.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 bottle (dated 8/29/06)....gushing pour that just about spilled everywhere.  cloudy orange brown appearance with a thick and frothy milky white head....nose was rather earthy and grass with a little bit of lemony zest....flavors that started off somewhat tart but quickly evolves to a more earthy grassy hop note.  malts become more pronounced as the beer warms to room temperature.
Pours a light amber color, with a large white head. Aroma of candy sugar and spices. Taste of sweetness and slovey spice.

Very interesting brew. Pour was huge, hard to get into the bottle with a huge pillowy head and nice lacing. Color was pale orange. The aroma was spicy, peppery. The flavor was incredibly complex. Almost like a saison, a witbier and a sour all in one. Mild fruityness with a touch of barnyard funk and a sour aftertaste reminiscent of a flemish sour. I cant say that I was totally in love with it, but its definitely unique and a beer that everyone should have eventually.

Pouring the Orval slowly into an oversized wineglass produced a full, billowing off-white head. The beer is a orange-copper color with some haziness. Spicy, malty aromas are released during the pour and picked up by the nose immediately. Theres a pleasing peppery smell, along with some faint fruitiness. The taste is an earthy blend of yeast and a light, bready malt. A light sweetness is present, which balances the hop bitterness. A fruity aspect appears as the beer warms. The finish is somewhat astringent, but pleasant. Bottled 07/05/2007, labeled 6.9% ABV.

Bottle.  Funky.  Cloudy orange color with a fizzy white head.  Powerful nose with hops, citrus, spice.  Tastes of hops, citrus and spice.  Noted for is dryness.  This beer was almost champagne-like.  Very enjoyable!

Pours a cloudy orange with an off-white head.  Light, uninteresting floral aroma.  Flavor is lightly hoppy, citrus with a pronounced spice (cinnamon).  The beer seemed a bit flat, and the flavors just didnt mesh.  Plalate is fizzy with a dry finish.  Overall, this is one of my least favorite trappist brews.

12 oz bottle, served lightly chilled and poured into the widest mouth glass I could find (no trappist glass but hey).

Pours a light cloudy orange with a big puffy white head. Smells of citrus with hints of banana, spice and yeast. The taste is intense and complex but lighter than most belgians Ive tried. Lots of fruit, citrus but also notes of cheese and spice. The finish is extremely dry and slightly bitter which is very welcome in this style. A fantastic beer.

Egy igazi különlegesség ez a sör!Érdekes "zavaros" opálos színű kemény habbal rendelkező főzet.Már az első kortyra érezni hogy mennyire komlós!Ezt szeretem!Enyhén savas és könnyű testű ital.Egyik kedvencem!

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2009 Bouteille de 33 cl en forme dune petite quille. Arômes complexes de houblon floral ainsi que de levure. Robe orangée, belle effervescence qui crée une mousse abondante. Très vivante en bouche, le houblon étant très présent. Il sagit dune bière originale alliant une levure typiquement belge à un houblonnage important rappelant les bières anglaises ou américaines. Excellent!

Cloudy caramel. Flowery. This is a trappist for pansies like me. Goes down easy and only kicks in during the aftertaste. Not necessarily a GOOD tasting beer but the flavors are interesting. Really not as fruity as stronger trappist beers Ive had. This is a good intro trappist for those who are trying to get into the style. As far as being a beer it is good. However not really a tasty beverage.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Bottle. Pours a cloudy effervescent yellowish orange with a billowing stack of fluffy white cloudy head. Lacing is like cotton and wont budge. Aromas of banana, plum, clove, and some distinct smoky qualities are present. Definitely gotta swirl it around to get all she can offer. Flavor is always great and unique. Artisan cheese, wood, hair, clove, squash. Bananas and cloves are present but not nearly as impacting as I expected from the nose. Smooth as velvet, spicy finish. Highly drinkable. One of the more enjoyable and unique Trappist beers youll stumble across.

Orange with an exploding bubble bath head, likes of which I have never seen.  Like walking into a flower shop, with slight citrus and metals.  Cool bitter flavor that reflects the metals I detected.  Immaculate finish.  Only a couple of trappists have this one beat.

This is interesting and enjoyable.  It is light amber with a very huge light tan had that is long-lasting and leaves some pretty good lace.  The aroma is sweet grain, a little fruity, with hints of alcohol, lemon, honey and caramel, and sluightly meaty  It has similarities to a good malt-liquor aroma.   The taste is sweet at first, with an odd, but enjoyable and intriguing quality of fruit and pine sap with a light herbal bitterness coming through.  After a softish, sweetish start, it has a crisp finish with a taste of grain, toast, herbs and pine sap.  It also has a faint smoeky quality and a hint of sourness.  Its tasty  and intriguing, but has a dry, refreshing lightness to it as well.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2010 licht amber coloured body with a huches sparkling white head a spicy hoppy yeasty  fruity aroma a spicy hoppy yeasty fruity herby bitter taste with a herby alcholic bitter finish

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2008 Pours a cloudy amber, with a gorgeous foamy head. Sweet aroma with a little spice to it. The taste is sweet bread and intensely dry finish that lingers for a looonggg time. I immensely disliked this beer when i first had it a few months ago, but actually am enjoying it now.

Floral, peachy, wheat nose.  Pours a light amber color with a big puffy white head.  Tastes faint hop flavors that grow in the finish. Fruity and dry; a lot more bite than Chimay Red though.  Overall laces like a Belgian, tastes like a mass marketed Belgian, and finishes like a lager.  Decent in its class and excellent on its own.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2010 Hazy amber coloured beer with medium diminishing white head and only few carbonation. A Yeasty fruity aroma. Full sparkling palate. Finish is sweet fruity with a bitter ending.

This one poured a golden yellow color with a huge bubble off white head that slowly faded away. The aroma is very nice and inviting on this one. It has some earth notes in there along with the floral hops, spices, and some dry tart fruits. The flavor is very earthy as well with a good dose of funkiness in there from the brett. The floral hops adds a drying character that leads to a slightly sour taste. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with some good carbonation that lends to a dry, tart finish. This is a great belgian ale.
UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Very active head. Very dry taste. Great citrus aftertaste that masks the bitter hops very well. I enjoyed everything but the aroma.

Very complex.  If you read the descriptions of this beer below or above, almost all of it is accurate in some way.  A yeasty aroma with a definite wine note to it.  Flavor also has some wineinesss to it also!  Spicy citrus on the front, with an earthy hoppiness after the swallow.  You can tell this Belgian is dry hopped as the hops play much more of a role in this Trappist brew.

Rhode Island-Bottle.  Wow! This was the second time I tasted an Orval and the first one was like grean olives - not a good experience.  It had me wondering why the hell everyone raved about it.  I found out on this round.

Shared w/ dpjuart.  A beautiful hazy amber with a 1-finger fizzy head.  A sour bready and fruit alcohol nose.  Hits you sour at first, but then mellows out to a nice sweet caramel and cherry flavor.  Has a really bright one note bitterness.  Finishes with a dry bitter rye flavor.
