UPDATED: MAR 30, 2004 Re-rate:  much better the second time around, maybe my tastes have changed since the first time I sampled this, had a golden color, huge thick head, musty nose, nice hop profile, great balance, very complex flavors, a bit dry in the finish, very excellent Belgian ale

pours hazy orange with a ridiculously huge pillowy head.  perfumy, orangy, slightly spicy and yeasty aroma.  tangy citrus and fruity berry flavours dance around on the tongue, while anise and herbs play with the hops.  delicious.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Re-Rate 8/24/07.  Didnt note the batch number but damn was it a fine bottle, had the perfect balance of sourness and hops.  All beer should be this complex and tasty

RE-RATE 12/3/02: I think I need to drink Orval more often, every time I have one i just dont understand this beer, the black pepper flavor is too much

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2004 (Re-rate) Pours a huge head and orange-amber body. Aroma of melons, spice and perfume. nteresting spiced flavour with strong taste of grapefruit and lime. Finishes tart and acidic. Nice.(Original) Full marks for extension on this head.. keep going, Baby! A likable aroma and great finish (4.2)

Strong citrus-fruit and floral aroma hits as soon as the bottle is opened. Pours a cloudy orange amber, slightly lighter than good apple cider. Beautiful off-white head extends more than 1/2 and inch above the top of the glass. Leaves lace with each sip. Mildly sweet citrus flavor along with tart apples balanced perfectly with a clean, dry finish and just the right amount of carbonition.  My bottle was 6.9% ABV rather than the 6.2% listed here. Leaves you feeling warm and cozy.
UPDATED: SEP 17, 2003 Cloudy yellow gold with a decent head. Good hop aroma and spiced flavour, dry and a great aftertaste. The strangness of the Orval is enjoyable and odd.

I think the reason this beer gets such high marks is not because its actually that good, but because its very distinct. Ive never had anything else like it. And because its so distinct, its also very memorable, and memories of other things will stick to it. Maybe you drank this for the first time at a wedding, or the day your first son was born. Whatever it was, the next time you taste it, all those memories will return vividly. Anyways, I thought this was good, but not perfect. Soapy, citrus, leather, spicy, herb, a bit of everything in here.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2003 I missed the licorice aspect of this one, but did notice how dry and wonderful each sip was. There is something special about drinking beer in a wine glass that just makes the whole experience classy...just tell the girl you are with that it"s wine and she"ll love it.
pale orangy amber ,expansive creamy tan head. Great natural carbonation.Sharp heady nose.Tangy and effervescant. Long finish

Copper bronze color. Gargantuan frothy head leaves a topographical map of mountain ranges in my glass. The lace is slumping from the very edge. Medicine/disinfectant smell at the onset subsides into a citrus and wild flower aroma. Hints of Tropical fruit, i.e. bananas, watermelon, guava, tart berries, carambola, and papaya with a touch of sweet-tarts candy. Very dry, as this brew sucks the moisture from the palate leaving a lingering fruitiness.

Champagne-like palate with similar amounts of bubbles. Hints of raisins and pears, with a definite hop presence. Licorice comes out after a few sips. Due to situational exigencies, I drank this one warm. I think it would have been better slightly chilled. This beer is dry throughout, but the finish was especially so. Winelike character.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2007 ***Re-rate*** Bottle... This beer rocks!... Tried this beer again a couple times and Ive decided I need to keep several of these in my beer fridge all the time. Terrific beer. So complex. So complete. So different from bottle to bottle; year to year, but always a terrific experience. Bumping my score up from 4.0!***... Bottle... This beer rocks.... Im adjusting my score from a perfect 5 to something lower. This was one of the first Begians I tasted and was "a little" overwhelmed and was probably "a lot" drunk.
Still a great beer. Very complex. A must try for any beer lover!
Strong hints of fruit in the aroma.  Murky-orange in colour.  Has a nice sweetness to it.  Orange and floral taste.  Real smooth finish.  Truely one of the best beers on earth.

The aroma was very pleasant with hints of sweetness and hoppiness, but truthfully the aroma and taste itself was very disappointing compared to some of its counterparts. The taste was very citrusy, mildly hoppy which caressed the tongue with minimal carbonation. The appearance was very appealing with head that you could balance a quarter on. Overall however it lacked something that i expected from such an expensive belgian dry to make it a spectacular beer. Definitely not something i would snub my nose at, but not a spectacular, distinguishing taste.
Almost perfect.  Belgian yet dry.

Third rating  That wonderful lasting this time more yellow than beige head. Belgian cow/horse barn, ripe silage yard, spicey ginger/corriander and celery aromas. More robust young citric spicey gingery flavours than I remember previously.
Second rating July 14 2002 4.0: Its the fourth one of these and its quite different again. This time I I got a faint fruity perfumed soap aroma and flavour. Majestic amber clear with a medium-small light tan head but no lace at all on the sides of the chalice. Light hops and yeasty woody aroma with hints of horse barn but still not that complex. Its definitely the lightest bodied of all the trappistes. Nicely balanced bitter sweet palate and loverly crisp clean bitter dry finish. But..... its still the poorest of the Trappistes. Picks up several points over my previous rating by being served in a quaint roadside cafe in the small Belgian town of Mol. 
First rating: 7 April 2002 3.5

Beautiful orange colour with big, lasting foamy head. Fresh hopsack and cookie dough aroma that is also somewhat grassy and citrusy. Light, creamy, effervescent mouthfeel. Wonderfully complex blend of moderately sweet and slightly tart flavours w/ prominent notes of orange and lemon zest, fresh flowers, and bandaids. Finish is warm, dry, alcoholic,  medicinal, and perfectly bitter. Im not sure if it is  my #1 beer on Earth, but it is close.

Blond body with an enormous head. Huge aroma mixed fruits and hops with malty undertones. Bannana and apple are the predominant fruit flavors that are complemented by a decent amount of hoppy biterness. The alcohol leaves a nice kick in the palate, as do the hops. A very good beer.

This one was strange at first sip. Than i got 1/2 way through the glass and than POW, what a beer. I think I will need to drink more than 1 to fully appreciate this beer. Golden in color, complex, aroma was sooo nice. I need to buy more of this. Great beer

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2004 Update: Now I remember the old magic.  I had this one far too cold last year, which lead to a poor rating and which was a terrible mistake.  Now I experience the lemon, wood and hint of lactic sourness, ending with this incredible fullness: no particular note of flavor ringing out, rather, everything orchestrated perfectly.  Oh, and to describe the palate adequately would be to write paragraphs, and I would rather drink my Orval.  Awesome.  Old: 3.5I remember liking this one a bit more in the past.  My recent sample had one of the best noses in the game, but the flavor was dry and lacking.  If I can ever have it live up to the aroma, I'd have a major winner.  Will try again.

Got this brew by mistake and was pleasently suprised.  A nice fruity/tangy nose with a big foamy head.  The beer still held enough carbonation.  The taste was sweet and slightly bitter, and the finish was citrusy.

At first taste, it was like the usual banana and spices and somewhat harsh. As it warmed up it turned into a different game altogether. The hop pressence (thats the best description i can procure) seeped through and mixed with the banana and spices for this unique experience. The finish had this qyuick breath of awesome christmas spice and was replaced with bitterness. Really good beer, not somehting for every day/week but a nice treat.
Wow, this is a high quality beer!  Enormous head with a very floral aroma, strong yeasty taste.  Very long finish with a wonderful aftertaste.  A great beer.

May have been biggest head ever. The foam was very stiff and rose over the top of the glass about 1.5 inches and wouldnt have budged in a hurricane. I get Juicy Fruit gum in the aroma underneath which slinks a cigarette smoking man playing baseball with a big eraser in his pocket. To interpret that, underneath the juicy fruit smell and flavor was something that reminded me of cigarettes, wood, and pencil erasers (especially after youve just erased something.)

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2003 This fantastic beer pours a light copper color with a massive white head that lingers. The aroma is full of herbal spices, yeasts, and hops. It has a medium body with moderate amounts of carbonation. The flavor is hoppy and spicy up front, and the finish is wonderfully dry and spicy with hop and yeast notes. What a great beer.

Bottle dated 21-06-2006.  It took quite a while to pour this all into the glass as the head was massive and rocky.  Lots of orange in the nose with a tangy must smell in the background.  The initial flavor is of orange rind that turns into an almost orange liquer sensation as it warms.  Almost fizzy on the tounge as you drink it.  I found an unplesant bitterness that mellowed as the beer warmed.  As I said in the tasting chat room, this is one of those beers that I didnt really like but I would suggest everyone try it once.  As said before, Ill try agian in a year and see if I like it better then.

RE-rate: wonderful!!!! I swear every time i have this, i like it more and more. Dry, nail-polish, candy sugar, citric, woody aroma. earthy and dry, citric (orange skins), with a touch of monk sweat (as another rater mentions), interesting stuff, also noticed a salty sea water flavour, with a bit of candy sugar flavour floating around, dry and hoppy finish, i  reckon this is tops, sexy.

Bottle date 11/01/07 - Bright orange color, large head with staying power. Aroma is orange with a touch of banana and a little musty. Initial taste is vinous and very tart and sweet and sour. Very complex tastes, orange peel, grapefruit, malty and dry, champagne and salt. Flavors mellow as it warms. Incredibly complex beer. Definitely not for everybody, but world class. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth.  Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Cloudy orange, with a fluffy cream-colored head that seems to stretch for miles. Lasts quite long as well. A musty smell, like red wine or champaign. First sip is sour, but not neccessarily in a bad way. Salty. Kind of mediciney. Mix champaign, cough syrup, and salt, and youll have a decent approximation of what Im tasting. Worth trying once, but just doesnt do it for me. Ill try it again in another couple hundred beers and see if I change my mind.

Hugh white head w/ a complex nose of orange & hint of banana. A slightly sweet taste w/ a bitter finish. I just don t like it. I tasted this in the tasting chatroom w/ several others who noted the sour taste too; however, this taste may be more pleasing to their palates.

RE-RATE: Exactly the same ratings as before, without even looking!  One of my all-time faves.  Phenomenally complex flavor: fruits including plums, grape, apples; woodiness; ever-changing flavor from start to finish.  ORIGINAL RATING: Beautiful, long-lasting head, which contrasts nicely with the amber beer.  Prominent grape in the smell and flavor as well as hints of some other fruits...plum, pears.  Cloudy due to yeast.  Very well-balanced, a little bit wine-ish in the mouthfeel and palate.  Quite nice!!

This is a beer that I feel I should like more than I did.  At first there was almost no complexity but soon very strong flavors (particularly banana) began to emerge.  I dont care for banana, but if you do, I think you will like it.  Beautiful amber color, nice mouthfeel, large (almost TOO large head).  I was surprised to see that it was only 6.2 % ABV, it felt stronger.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2006 Bottled at May 24th, 2005 - tasted at August 8th, 2006  Clear, amber body.  Off-white creamy head thats so typical for Orval.  Its like a white cream cake from the top.  Very interesting aroma of flowers, hops, liquor, caramel, ... Lightly bitter initial flavour which becomes more bitter to the end with a lot of subtleness in it: nice complexity and balance.  Very enjoyable and still rather simple. 
People always laugh at me, when I say that according to me this (along with a good gueuze) is the perfect substitute for a pilsener, but I really mean that, because of it great taste and its rather low alcohol contents.

Glowing copper color and a dollop of creamy head.  Pickly nose and a spicey flavor.  Wasnt able to get much out of it till it warmed to room temp where it produced a wonderfully delicate floral brew, laced with anise, white pepper, and flowers.  Will have to re-rate.

Probably the least appreciated of the Trappist Ales.  A very hoppy example that places it in a league of its own.  Probably my favorite Trappist beers.  Foamy, thick head that sticks to the glass as if it were cobwebs made of sugar.  Pleasant hop aroma and attractive orange/golden display.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2010 Wonderfully foamy, frothy, and long lasting head with big and small bubbles. Hazy and rusty orange-amber. Bright, fresh-smelling nose was full of yeast, with nippy elements of barnyard and band-aid. Prickly carbonation; smooth texture. Malts were lightly toasted grains; gentle yet flavorful. Bitterness slowly built and lingered pleasantly on the tongue. Interesting, malleable mineral flavor. Interesting spices. Very pleasant beer. Every time I revisit this beer I rate it higher.
Slightly different taste than a typical Belgian.  Almost had a champagne like taste to it.
It needs to be tried. This is a very different trappist ale, and needs to be repected because of this.
Not crazy about this one. Too funky for my taste.
For me this kind of belgian beer is a joke. I like strong beers with complexity, yeast and alcohol. If I want weak beers I stay at home.
Very hoppy for a Belgian.  Not my cup of tea...or beer for that matter.  When I want Belgian, I look for complexity.  This is kind of dry in that field.
Excellent beer.  Orange/amber color (a bit hazy, may have been yeast) with large white lacey head.  Spicey, citrusy and yeasty aroma.  Smooth, slightly sweet, spicey flavor.  Hides the 6.9% ABV well.

Caramel-like in appearance with a huge bubbly head that left a ton of lacing.  Yeasty nose with more spice than fruity tones also noted some leather.  Taste is surprisingly un-sweet for a beer with candi sugar added.  Its good but not great.  I have tried this beer on many different occasions and I just dont get the hype that it receives.
UPDATED: AUG 19, 2004 Cloudy light amber color, very large and thick  head. Aroma of strong citric sourness and candy. Flavor is sweet, sour, somewhat bitter and acidic.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2003 Very bitter. Actually the most bitter Trappist Ale i've tried. It's very different from the others. Not very much alcohol. It has a very dry, acidulous, and almost astringent taste. Strong and very bitter palate. Nice turbid dark amber colour. It contains a very unique taste of Sage.

This is definently one of my favourites

Re-rate, 18 Sept 2002

I had a 1 year old Orval yesterday.
When I opened it, it went fissssss a long time. Then I put ti tin the glass, I was very surprised, as the color was clear, later came the remains of the yeast, and the known orval colour was back.....

This beer is my first 5...

wasnt crazy about it the first couple of times i had it but just keep liking it more aand more and there is something about just popping into the newsagents in belgium and buying it that really feels right. so ridiculously salty and sharp

The best beer I have ever tasted. You dont just drink Orval, you experience it. Sweet, candy like, and  flowery. Flavors that you cant even describe, other than you really like them. Mouthfeel is similar to eating pop rocks as the flavors explode on your tongue. If only it were not so expensive.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2012 Almost ten years later I have come to re-rate this brew.  My pallet has changed over the years and today I have realized that this may be my favorite beer of all time.  At least my most reliable brew.  I love everything about this beer, from the aroma, the mouthfeel and the finish and subtle funk from the brett makes my heart flutter.  The bottle Im tasting now is about 2 years old and now I want to venture out and find different vintages  so I can taste the differences in age.   Original rating from 2002- 8/3/8/3/16 3.8 overall....  A very tasty and unique brew.  I read the reviews and I had to get some of this stuff.  A semi-fruity aroma masked by a fluffly pillow of foam.  The flavor is like none other.  IT goes down smooth.  Try this beer.

Pillowy head that never went away.  Initial medicinal aroma on opening that turned me off a little.  It got better as the beer breathed and warmed in the glass. Nice orange color and very smooth taste.  It deserves its high praise.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Yeah nice, but not in the elite league of trappists for my money.  I think it was the finish that turned me on it - the alcohol came through too strongly.

Some nice things about this beer - the dry astingency it finishes with, the sunset color and beautiful lace, the raw power of the thing.  But Im with my husband - rocket fuel indeed!  May have been injected with Pine Sol.

"Cheap 70s cologne" nails this stuff, Joe.  The perfumy aroma keeps going in the mouth, harsh and fiery and full of pine, yeast, lemon, and insect repellant.  Once and awhile a nice lighter, candy sweet malt flavour rises into the action, but mostly the thing is dominated by the rocket fuel burn of the opening perfume and overexcited carbonation.  I am not a fan, boys, but more credit to you all for finding ways to love the edgy complexities of this brew.  Oh, and I DO appreciate the sticky lasting lace and the rich orange amber hue ...

Pours with a rich marshmallowy head.  The color is a head-on meeting of orange and peach.  Balanced a little heavier towards the malt than hops.  Hops linger on the tip of tongue.  A very solid beer which reminds me of apple picking for some odd reason.

WOW!  Got the opportunity to enjoy with some belgium strong cheese in Brussels - a great compliment.  Wondefully large head, notes of several fruits (plums, apples, apricots) woven perfectly with just the right amount of malt.  Beautiful

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2004 Very impressive! Hazy brown in color and a light brown head. Aroma is bitter or sour with light spices and apples dominant. Tastes of sour apples and is bitter but not overwhelming. Finishes well. Highly recommended to all. **Re-rate - Been a while since I had this. Based on my previous rating, this is a different beast or my tastes have changed. Bottled 28.01.2003, nearly one year old. This has almost a geuze like nose. Hay, barnyard, tartness and a plethora of funkiness. I also have to add that there is a litterbox odor in this to make this go total Parliament Funkadelic in the aroma department. The best way to say it is, if someone handed me this without letting me know this was Orval, I'd think it was a geuze. There some fruit in the taste but an enhanced taste of the aroma as well. Dry mouthfeel and finish. Eclectic beer. Worthy of all the praise it receives. Maybe I'll get a case of this....
gigantic head with a plateau in the middle, very distinctive and I want to say clovey
Nice. Smelt like a tripel, tasted like a cross between a wheat beer and a Belgian golden ale. Great yeasty flavours. Started to develop Biere du Garde-like characteristics when it warmed.
Dark blond, slightly milky. Small head. Sour fruity, geuzy aroma. Lively, slightly sour, bitter taste. Nice.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 One of my absolute favorites, i always have a few bottles of this at home. The yeast, the sourness, the hops its all just in perfect harmony, and that at only around 6%. Superb. Aging: Compared a fresh sample with 2 and 5 year old samples. In time, Orval seems to lose its bitterness, while the aroma becomes more sour. It becomes smoother, but less outspoken. I personally prefer a fresh bottle compared to the aged ones, although imho a 5 year old one is better than a two year old. Perhaps aging more than 5 years will make it better, but for the time being ill stick to drinking fresh ones :-).

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2006 sour/bitter, spicy taste. I dontknow what to think of this beer, first time I drank it, i was disappointed. Now however I think I give this ale the benefit of the doubt; the taste is complex and I love that in a beer. Aroma is a little tripel-like. Beautifull colour with a nice head.
<rerate>Aroma is yeasty, quite fruity, bit spicy (pepper) and a hops. Initial taste is slightly sweet, becomes more bitter towards the finish. Finishes dry. Nice balance of yeast, hops, fruitiness. Good quality yeast in it.
what a disappointing beer! I expected much better from a trappist beer. What a bad finish! I wouldnt like to try it again.

Re-rate: Hazy orange/light amber colored. Beautiful head and lace. Aroma is insane with barnyard, stinky cheese,herbs,light doughy malt and citrus. Almost medium bodied,almost creamy with  flavors of orange peel,lime,spices,flowers, and more I cannot even describe. This beer plays alot of games with your senses. Looooong dry and bitter finish. Drinkability is off the charts. Very complex and addicitve. I like this twice as much as i did the first time I had it(about 320 beers ago) so I think this (at last in my case) needs a more mature palate to appreciate whats here.
The only dry hopped Trappist.  If you like hops and Trappist beers, this is great.  At only 6.9% you can drink several.  There is also a Orval green, but only available at the Abbaye
My buddy aceofhearts said Id enjoy this and I did.  Worth a try guys.

Sweet cloveness and spiceness and everything niceness. The foam on this is like no other. Its as if you could tell the future by reading the patterns left in the head of a freshly poured Orval. Yet, it drifts away after impressing to let you enjoy the full power of the the  beer. Youre left with an enticing golden lake with a slightly frothy top. Then it starts, the light white cake like overture, the hops that lurk around the edges and tease without infringing. An accessible one of a kind brew that should not be dissmissed lightly. Be sure to let it warm for the full spectrum of experience.

A truly fine beer.  Flowery almost sweet smell, full amber color, and extremely complex albeit extremely drinkable.  Typically I find that beers that are complex are not very drinkable (you can only have 1 or 2 in a sitting).  This simply isnt so with the Orval.  You could easily enjoy a dozen of them and not be sick of them.  On the other hand the flavor beautifully blends caramel, spice, citrus, and many other flavors.  The only drawback to this beer is the high cost, but Im willing to pay for quality.
One of the best in the world.  A barrage of flavor, earthy, fruity, spicey, must have more.

Excellent.
Smooth, subtle, very unique.. one of my favorites thus far.
For those who have claimed this is a strong beer, or that the abv is easily discernable, I have two words for you: YOU ARE A MONKEY. I could hardly notice any alcohol at all, and its a hefty 6.9% (not 6.2%, as it shows above).
Very impressive.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2004 Bright orange colour.  Light beige head is very thick, and often makes fun mountainous shapes.  The room fills with perfume, medicine, noble hops, tangerines, horseblanket.  Fun stuff.  Bitter body brings a strong citric component, and these are complemented by warming pale malts, an underpinning of alcohol and a sour, bretty finish.  Vibrant, funky, alive.  With amples doses of malt, hops, yeast, brett, alcohol, a nature that is challenging yet comforting, a potency that can satisfy with one bottle or with four, Orval is truly a pleasure for all of your senses.  In short, Orval is beer.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2009 8/2/02: I said a bunch of stuff about peppery spice, rose petals & perfume..and how it was one of the best beers I have ever had..Re-Rate 8/3/02: I mentioned the violet mist that permeates throughout your veins..the refreshing intoxication of complexity..Re-Rate 8/23/02: I resorted to the ingeniousness of simplicity..There is a world out there with oceans of orval, and the fish are in control..

Fragrant,Orange color, frothy. Somehow reminds me of Christmas dinner. Rich full bodied, and a little bitter, simply put one Awesome Belgian Ale. Extremely Recommended, Local store only had two, now they have none.

Not bad... reminded me of a gentler, ale version of cantillon iris with its gorgeous reddish-orange color and spicy, floral and citrus aroma. not quite as robust as many trappist ales, yet has a nice gentle lemon, orange flavor with hints of tang and spice... doesnt really knock you on your ass, which is a good thing... refreshing, refined and pretty good, although not as strong as other trappists as i noted before. the kinder, gentler, trappist ale. not for everyone though.
Big fragrant aroma, cloudy orange color.  I agree that it tastes of orange peel with a little spice.  The alcohol is hidden like an fat girl behind a brick wall.  A unique beer that is very good.

This beer speaks volumes to me about how important it is to develop ones palate, before one can appreciate some of the worlds finest beers.  A year ago I would have hated this.  Gorgeous, fluffy, everlasting head, and a murky, butterscotch body.  A tantalizing, absolutely unique aroma:  fragrant perfume, oiled leather, very floral (roses, lilac) but not really fruity.  Honey and grain...what else?  I could sniff this beer for hours.  Has the flavor profile to match.  Prominently tannic, but with so many underlying subtleties.  Smooth malt pokes through from time to time, as gingerbread or apple.  The finish is sublimely dry, perfumy, and hoppy.  Elegant lacing stuck to the glass long after Id finished.  Simply a phenomenal beer, and a worthy choice for #100.  Next time I run across this Im gonna stock up.
Very fragrant Belgian Ale.  Nice light floral and citrus tones in the taste.  Nice finish.  A very good beer with a nice wheaty feel to the brew.

This is such a strange beer. Most people I know either love it or hate it. A person I was drinking with took one mouthfull and ran to the sink to spit it out. Im a little surprised the standard deviation for this one is just 0.63. That said, I like it. Quite estery with bananas and some light smokiness. Quite bitter for a Belgian. Yeasty. Some sour and medicinal undertones.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 Re-rate 8/15/02 bottle date 10 08 2006, Head was huge, and took a while to die down, on a murky-cider body.  Huge musky/citrus/pepper aroma.  Orange taste, starts slightly sour and bitter and ends dry as a bone.  +0.3 from 6 months ago, most beers go down a little for the second rating. Not this one. First rating:  Bottle says 21 06 2004, drank on 1/13/02.  Has a head unlike any other that I've seen.  The aroma is hard to describe, yet great.  The taste is orange, yeast and very bitter. This is a very complex beer that I'll need to try again.  I don't like the grainy aftertaste.

Jesus Christ Bananas! This is the king of belgium Trappist ale! Whit not-so-lasting head, light brown and very unclear color. Slightly bitter and very distinct aroma that i cant quite place. The taste is full, complex and very bitter. Hints of hop and malt. Careful when you pour it so you dont disturb the residues on the bottom though :-O
Lucky me, i have just accuired 15 bottles on my trip to Bruxelles :-D

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2003 A murkey honey color with a thick rocky cream colored head. Carmel nose with Jasmine tea undertones. Very prominent hop flavor up front, finishes crisp and dry. I sure liked this one!

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2004 Pours a thick cloudy dark amber color with a huge frothy and creamy beige lasting head that leaves clingy sheets of lace in my glass, nice malty and sweet, spicy aroma. Sweet and fruity sugar flavors, nice and smooth creamy soft mouthfeel, full body with lively carbonation, finishes with a pleasant spicy aftertaste.
Pours with a nice pale body and full head. Very light fruit with helping of leatheriness or horsiness. A good beer for those with the acquired taste. But not for me.

Wonderful, tart, orange aroma as soon as its poured from the bottle.  Hazy color with specks in it.  Basic, with sour and slight malt tastes.  Good, but nothing overly complex.  Slight alcohol in the aftertaste.  Very good.

Orange color with excellent white lasting head.  very high carbonation.  fruity aroma is very nice.  the flavor is fruity followed by some great spicyness.  I will be drinking more of this one soon i hope.

Bitter orange aroma that carries over to the flavour which has a sour fruitiness. This sour is better for me than most other sour beers as it is a pleasant fruit sour rather than oppressive vinegar sour, if that makes any sense. Also appearance point for the beautiful teardrop bottle.
Orange colour, huge and lasting white head. Excellent complex aroma. Flavour is less great (imho): yeast, citrus, hops. Ends with a dry, sour and very bitter finish.

Boy, this is quite different than I remember.  This was the beer that got me into beer.  3 or 4 surrepticious underage sips at the Blind Pig in Champaign, IL during a summer spent doing research at the Univ. of Illinois during some concert I dont remember, was the pebble that turned into an avalanche.  Surprisingly light on the tongue.  Orangey orangey orangey flavor, with firm hop aroma and flavor.  Surprisingly english in its malt character.  Very nice beer.
Not the best Trappist ale, but certailnly very good.  Crisp fruity taste with a decent alcohol kick.
Slight citrus aroma with a hint of hops.  Body reminds me of a dry hefeweizen.  Finishes slightly dry.

Bottle dated to 01 08 2005.  A snow caped foam head on an orange body with a stream of rising bubbles sending forth a fruity aroma that includes pears and cider.  Remarkable for its lack of sweetnenss.  It is exceptionally dry and as previously noted is tonic water-esque.  Grainy malt character and hoppy bitterness.  Compared to its Belgian bretheren, I did not care for this beer.

Looked and smelled like a German dark wheat. Did not taste like one. This was the last bottle of Orval at the store, so I figured I had better grab it (not an old bottle, though - exp. 10/08/06). This definitely has nothing in common with the other Trappists that Ive tried, and the first few sips had me agreeing with the raters who disliked this one. It didnt get a whole lot better. Dry and thin (for a Trappist), and loaded with pepper and bitterness. Its probably an acquired taste - Ill try again when the store gets some more bottles. RERATE 4/2/02 (exp. 6/12/06): Not so peppery this time, and more drinkable. Bitter, bitter, bitter, and the dryness makes it seem rather thin. Leaves a slightly parched feeling in my mouth. Maybe its growing on me, but I still dont love it. 4/11/02: Third bottle. Have to say that this stuff becomes addictive. 5/13/02: Now number two on my desert island list. Some beers really grow on you. 7/20/02: Did I really say that this smelled like a wheat beer? My RateBeer education continues...
Poured a dark golden color with a nice white head. Aroma of candy sugar but the sweetness was not overpowering in the taste. nice hop finish. This is a very enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 (3/17/08, 33cl, bottled 3/27/07) Enormous rocky off-white head atop lightly hazed amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange, yeast, bread/pastry, perfumy.  Taste is medium sweet, spicy, orange/herbal, some bread.  Light-medium body, lightly chewy, acidic, quite drinkable.  (8/4/8/5/16) 

(3/31/04):  Clear amber body (at least it starts clear, the bottom of the bottle provides nice cloudiness for the end of the bottle) with medium beige head.  Aroma is spicy/perfumy and somewhat sour/lambicish.  Taste is herbal, spicy, with light sourness.  Doesnt compare to the quite inviting aroma.  Medium-full body.  I like, but dont love. (8/5/6/4/13)

(7/18/02): Good, but not great, beer.  Perfumy, yeasty and fruity smell.  Complex malty orange flavor that finishes bitter. (7/5/7/4/15)

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2007 Rerate June 2007: poured  slightly dark orange with a thick fluffy, light beige head. Moderately yeasty aroma with some banana and hops. Light pepper. Flavor is fruity, crisp, dry, peppery. Slight bitter finish. Still a good beer which I revisited after all these years. 

Long lasting head, very nice orange color. Nicely carbed. Aroma like bubblegum and banana. Very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2004 Pours with a golden orange body holding a thick, fluffy, white head that has small bubbles and is mostly diminishing.  The end of the bottle adds deep brown clouds of color that gives the body the impression that the sun has set.  The aroma is all sorts of crazy.  Banana, white pepper, lemon and orange zest, clove, lively yeast, hay, and a variety of other spices.  Maybe a touch of pineapple juice as well.  The mouthfeel is very soft and full.  The flavor is complex, but not nearly as outstanding as the aroma.  Not quite as sweet as the aroma suggests, but still quite amazing.  A lot of bitterness in the finish.  The is one great beer that continues to get better every time I drink it.  The complexity is unbelievable, almost like a saison, and it makes this just one hell of a beer.

This is one great looking beer, excellent lace and colour, aroma of apricots and bananas was quite promising. Alas, but an empty promise, delivering only a light bodied thin and sweet/sour apricot flavour. Not what I expected at all, I may have to try it again.
good but not very good for a trapist
Great fruity, flowery and herby aroma. The flavour is quite complex and bitter. Nice dry and bitter palate. A different trappist.
I was suprised by this one. Something sweet, something fruity. A very nice beer

Mmm.  Number one hundred.  Heard this was Oakes favorite so I thought I would make it my 100.  Beautiful color.  Long lasting thick head.  Maybe a little out of my league for the details still but had very great fruit charteristics.  Maybe a little sour or bitter.  Apricot taste or green apple?

Beautiful amber hue with substantial whipped head. Aroma fruity and floral with hoppy traces--not overpowering, however.  Flavor is delightully balanced between hops and complex malt/fruit profile, also enough body to augment high carbonation---this brew has layers of quality!  Finish is spicy dry with fruit hints--reminds me of dry pear wine.  Most interesting stuff...
Creamy head that provides moderate lacing.  A dry beer that has great complexity.  Evident citrus / spicy character with moderate to high carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2017 Engulfed in a whirldwind of wild flowers and citrus fruit Then deposited on moist earth to frolick with a few herbs Minute caramel drops spread out minutiously on every bubble Making love in a field with my bien-aimée

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 Aroma was a bit hoppy but not very strong. A bit fruity. Last pour (dregs) gave more bubble gum aroma. Beautiful golden copper color with huge white head that lasted and gave a lot of lacing. Palate was medium-heavy, with medium carbonation.  Tastes: bitter, spice, pepper, yeast, woody. Last pour gave some more character. Had long after taste. A nice Belgian ale with definitely more character at the end of the bottle.
After many tastings recently, Im upping my rating to 4.7. If I had to drink one beer for the rest of my life, this would be in my top 5 final choice competition. Regal, sublime, a work of art.
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2004 Not unlike Chimay White in flavor.  Very malty with a kick of alcohol (odd, for only 6%).  Good stuff, but the alcohol's fairly noticeable.
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2010 BottlePours murky, pale brown with a pillow-y head. Acidic aroma. Lively mouth feel. Flavour is very dry with loads of pine, wood and hops. Long, bitter finish. A unique beer.

Okay, this is only my second Belgian. It has a wonderful light orangish amber color to it. Creates a nice light head, maybe due in part to its colorful bubbly nature. This of course gives it a slightly fizzy taste. The aroma is different a mixture of citrus and others that almost imparts(to me at least) a bubblegum smell. It has a nice body to it and a good finish. I am more a fan of stouts/porters, but still quite enjoyed this.
A bit thin, and the alcohol stood out far more than usual for 6.2.
A very wonderful trappist ale. Whodve thunk that Belgian monks could make something this wonderful?
Nice color and aroma.  Interesting fruity taste - a little too heavy on the alcohol taste.
A superb Belgian abbey ale. The aroma is equal to the best, and the taste is excellent, with a peppery quality I dont usually associate with Trappists.

Very pretty color, and thanks to the head it took me over a minute to pour. Not the best beer I have ever had but it was definitely unique and I enjoyed it. Belgian Ales are still new to me but I always appreciate them. Cloudy amber color. Complex aroma with candy and grapes in the nose. Malty, vinous, spicy flavor that stayed interesting throughout. At $4.50 a bottle I probably wont be trying this one often but it should be on everyones list. I had a pleasant buzz at the end too.
So much has been written about it--my drivel will add nothing.  A perfect beer.

Very good beer.....I feel like this is the perfect beer for someone who has never had a trappist before.  It maintained all of the good belgian characteristics...smelled of grapes, yeast, and alcohol, cloudy color, nice head, nice fruity taste, subtle hop finish.....but it wasnt too overpowering.....crisp taste that is very refreshing and flavorful all at once.  It had a very unique bottle shape too.

Ah, Orval...its been too long since we last saw each other.  Hence, a re-rate!  Hazy orange-rosy color.  Quite a voluminous head and enough carbonation to render it sparkling., along with unbeatable lacing.  Aroma is very complex and strong, having an overall spicy, yeasty, hoppy character, with herbs, leather, cheese, and even a tiny bit of acidic white wine aroma.  Flavor profile is equally complex, with fruitiness from malt (slightly citrusy), some pepper, dill (??!!), a tad of woodiness, and  that unique, artisinal unmistakably Orval-y blend of hops.  Finish is quite dry indeed.  So very unique.  So much flavor development, even long after youve swallowed.  An unquestioned world classic.

Orange and creamy w. persistent head as advertised. Incredibly rich and weird mixture of aroma and taste. I noted, whiskey, sawdust, pepper, leather, funky cheese - yeasty, fruity, hoppy, sweet, yet dry. Very drinkable, with much less bitterness than some have said. Quite a bit of alcohol burn hits you in the nose, though.
A classic.  The taste is mysterious and elusive, and I always seem to find something different when I get a bottle.  In my book that makes it a great beer.
the first sip hit me immediately, tasted exactly like a stick of Juicy Fruit gum...nice combination of sweetness and bitterness
Absolutely delicious.  Nice sweet/fruity finish, with an almost bitter taste at first.  I really enjoyed this and would easily drink it again, although it is a bit expensive where I am.
One of the better belgian ales, but it is really not to my liking. Stale! Yuck!

Not so much alcohol, but this beer is liquid bread.
I tried it several times, and I can tell you that drinking it in its own glass is 100% different.
It is a true belgian trappist, with its own complexity and style.
Please give it a try.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2014 Great appearance, cloudy gold w/ a huge whip cream head. Palate was light, bitter, sour, middle was dry, and finish was watery, dry. I didn?t think this beer had an enjoyable flavor, and I was pretty dissapointed in this one. Maybe I got a bad bottle, but this is by far the worst trappist I?ve had, and honestly it tasted like mop water! Orig rate 05/02/02...2.2. Nice sour like brew with prune and cherry with a dry like complexity. I wasnt ready for this 12 years ago.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2005 Head is initially large, frothy, creamy, rocky, off-white, fully
lasting. Body is hazy medium amber, dense tiny/small particles, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately yeasty (horseblanket, barnyard), moderately hoppy (grass, herbs), lightly malty (toasted grain, light bread), with notes of cedar, apple, apricot, orange peel, dried pineapple, mango, clove, bandaid, etc. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, heavily bitter. Medium body, velvety/creamy texture, lively carbonation. The Trappist thats unlike any other Trappist. Ive rated this numerous times, and every time I have it, I bump up my score a bit.  This is one of the most visceral, bitter, funky, capricious, unique, rustic, and unusual beers you will ever have.  So damned compelling, perplexing, and singular...how do you rate something like this?  The bigger question is...fresh or aged?  Well, my 2.5 year old bottles are a little better (to me) than my 1.5 year old bottles, so Im thinking aged.  But both are mid to high 4s, and its all I can do to keep from going out and buying another 12-pack to dump in the cellar.  Time and time again I come back to this and time and time again I am amazed and its diversity and charm.

BIG HEAD (the ale). Dont pour to fast for gawlds sake.
Onto the official speak... Im getting Cooking Apples,Band Aid(not old rockstars, but sicky plasters),toffee, burnt witch embers-still hot, bitter, ear waxy.. (Im starting to wonder if our beer is off cause everyone else loved it!). Its like cheap cider. Its definately off...  ohh hang on... looking at what everyone else has written: Its a sour, bitter, clean band-aid dipped in off cider...  I suppose it could be mistaken for orange and pepper.....
Hmmm another one will sort out the ambiguity.
..........
Yes much Better 2nd time around.

Starts with a wonderful aroma of belgium yeastyness and a hint of orange spice. The Taste starts out with a peppery spice that blends into tastes of orange, hops, and malt, and ends with a crisp hoppyness that leaves you yearning for more.  This trappist ale certainly is not like the others, but is definatly is one of the best.

I always hear Belgian beer drinkers rate this very low on their scale,but I think that this one of the most unique beers in Belgium <biting my tongue> it really is though,afterall in a land where bitterness,hop flavor and aroma take a backseat to exotic yeast strains this is cleary a different breed. A Belgian I.P.A. if there ever was one,although Im not saying it is ;)
One of my personal favorites.  The yeast and brettanomyces make this a firm bodied light ale with a great hopsack aroma.  A head that does not stop and rich malt flavors.

Mine is slightly cloudy, with little gas with a rich head. This beer has a smell of oranges about it.  Its very bitter, whilst tasting aswell as smelling of oranges, with loads of pepper.  One of the most interesting beers ive had.  It was recommended to me by the owner of the beer store, and I must thank him greatly.  After its initial surpise this beer becomes morish ands more flavoursome than most others.  This beer stands out in my beer hunting as being lovely and unique.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2004 What a wonderful, beautiful beer. One of the few TRUE Trappist ales. Dry, hoppy, mildly bitter, and absolutely one of the best beers on the planet.  They should make a perfume from the aroma...
An Intersting beer, ill drink another bottle before making anymore comments...

Very unique!  Interesting combination of the hops and the dry, sourlike flavors typical of wild yeast.  Amber color with good head.  Dry mouthfeel.  Id like to try this again, look for a re-rate in the future.
I was very suprised by this beer. Very fruity for an amber beer, not to bitter, lots of flavors.
Trappist with a beautiful head. Bitter and slightly sour tasting trappist. Very round mouthfeel. Misses the complexity of most other trappist products.
Nice big sticky head, orange in color. Taste is spicy orange and the finish is hop dry and bitter. Complex!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003    Great aroma and body, although I agree that the aftertaste is somewhat medicinal and tends to bite a little, especially towards the end. Not as smooth as I would have liked it and a little too dry. Fantastically complex however and worth another try. Re-rate, 4/12/02-- Again, I can't get past the medicinal flavor in the finish. Nice malt body however, certainly a beer that is in a league of its own taste-wise.
Good head. hints of citrus and wood. very dry on the palate but smooth and spicy. not as full in flavour as other Trappists beer but easy to drink.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2003 Cloudy orange color, great creamy head and a clinging lace.  Robust tart aroma with hints of wood, citrus fruit, and other light fruit, with a touch of yeast.  Big spritzy body with a solid yeastiness that compliments a very bitter (for a Belgian)hop bite.  Dries quickly in the quasi-finish but comes up a touch juicy towards a further end.  Leaves a bit to be desired I think, I maintain that there are better trappistes.

Orange peel beer without a hint of sweetness, but with a fruity and quite acidic bouquet, this beer has a big head, bitterness is the key here, as the unique, perhaps even peculiar aroma and the dry, somewhat woodish finish are very much on the bitter side – but let’s not forget the graceful, unique curvature of the Orval bottle!
Smells of yeast and citrus. Copper in colour, tastes of bread. A very complex pleasure. Wonderful!
Not bad, it has a wine taste with a bitterness that resembles a citric fruit.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2008 Creamy, lasting head. Aroma: hops and grapefruit. 
Taste: a bit tart, citrus and hops. A long, bitter finish. 
A very good and complex beer, but I prefer them a bit less bitter.
Re-rate: Flowery hoppiness in the aroma. Strong oily hoppiness in the flavor. Citric and tart, vanilla. Long citric hopbitter finish. I have to boost my rating, because this is truly a great beer.

tasted july 2008, 1986 bottle. Still lively in the bottle. Honey and plastic in the aroma. Still some reamining hops in the flavor, citrus and leather. Has become thin and tart. Past its peak, but still a very special beer. (8 3 6 3 13 = 3.3)

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2003 Very dry with almost no sweetness. Citrus, wheat like, orange/lemon flavors.    The head on this beer NEVER went away during the 20 minutes that I spent drinking this one. Thats impressive.  Also a wonderful cloudy copperish appearance. Didn't really meet my expectations for a $5 a bottle beer. Too hoppy.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2004 Re-rate (4/09/04): Always interesting to come back to something that knocked me over when I was a newbie after developing the palate.  Nose of sawdusty wheat, mold, alcohol, anise, citrus, and pepper.  Pours into my MIGHTY HAMM'S goblet a cloudy pale honey.  The short lived white foamy head has no lacing.  The flavor - though balanced - is thin;  starting sweet with a warm middle and finishes tart and peppery.  The medium dry body is fizzy and feels astringent.  Not bad, but certainly not all that.  [Origianal rate (3/15/02): 9 5 8 3 17 (4.2)].   A bottle of this was my introduction to trappist ale, I wasnt disappointed.  This brew
pours a hazy medium dark amber with tiny body particles.  The huge off-white creamy
rocky head is fully lasting with excellent lacing.  The fresh and highly complex nose is
fruity, spicy and earthy - with hints of straw, perfume, citrus, dough, plums, dates, cask
wood, coriander, clove, and pepper.  The heavy alcohol aroma dissipates if this brew is
allowed to breath for 5 or 10 minutes.  The taste is well balanced with a lightly acidic
bitter-sweet start and the average duration finish is the same.  I didn't get all the flavor that everyone else is talking about.  I'll have to try again at cellar temp and see if I get more umph. This brew has a smooth and
creamy dry medium body with soft carbonation that finishes moderately astringent.  I am
excited to try more fine brews from Belgium, but if the prices are similar to what I paid for
this one ($4.49 for a 11.2 oz bottle), I may have to get a second job.
Big thick creamy head that lasts. The carbonation is abit overwhelming at first. Highly recommended.

Wonderful huge thick creamy and lasting head. Appearance is cloudy with a bright orange-brown color. Aroma is a true explosion with black pepper, herbal and spicy notes. Flavour is very complex too with dominating orange peel, hop and sage, ending in a long dry bitter finish. Medium bodied.
I enjoied it at room temperature with a tortellini and parmesan dish. One of best beer in the world.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015 Re-Rate, Dec 2003 - not to change the numbers, but I felt I needed to clarify why I like it so much (because I have just enough ego to believe that all of Ratebeer, nay, the entire online community is waiting for my opinion). Orval is a clear Orange with a thick, luxurious off white head. Smells of oak, pepper, and wine, as well as fruit (bananas) and Salt risen bread. Flavors are like an oaky merlot and strong black pepper, with some grainy, smoky flavors. It is inconsistant - which a huge part of its appeal, by the way - so different bottles will sometimes have a fruity, sweeter flavor and feel. Dry crisp hops throughtout, and finishes assertively. Unique and a joy everytime. Update 2/27/05 - Tried a bottle with a date of 4/97. It was still tasty, but the hop crispness was rather muted. Still big musty, fruity notes, and some medicianl flavors, too. Edit, 01/20/2015 - its perfect. I should give it a 5

this was nice. nice color, huge head stayed for entire bottle.  had that tart/peppery taste. the bottle i had may have been getting a little old - could taste/smell the alc. by the end.  One of the better belgians ive had (although im just getting interested in them, maybe will have to re-rate this later)
Had it at a belgian bar one night, I dont really remember this beer or much of that night. But I know I liked it.

I have had this on several occasions and still cant figure out what is so wonderful about this beer. Cloudy and golden brown in appearance with a sort of pungent aroma. Very dry with an unenjoyable bitter finish that lingers way too long for my palate. Give me any of the other Trappists over this, sorry guys.

Ivr tried this 3 times and am still not sure whether I truly like it or not. Its a bit over carbonated for me, but I can get past that. Its got a bready flavor, hoppy. I think I need to let the next one mellow a bit. It seemed somewhat young. Still its worth a try, probably more than once.
Sweet, fruity, perfumy aroma, entirely unlike the taste.  Very hoppy and spicy, slightly earthy.  Very interesting beer.  I look forward to trying it again, but regret the price.
Orange coloured very lively beer. Perfumy and very complex smell. Tastes of orange peels, and finishes bitter.
Great head here.  Scent is musty and orangey, flavor is nicely full of yeasts and citrus.  Finishes hoppy and dry.
Orval is a classic!, orange, wheaty nose with a head that lasts the whole glass. A good introduction trappist beer to first timers. Looking forward to my next.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 Pours a hazy blondish gold, large frothy head that leaves plenty of lacing. Flavor of brett, peppery, some date and citris. Strong finish, nice balance. By far my favorite of the Trappistes.

Best before date June 2002.Strange but pleasant aroma, intense orange colour. Lively condition and big fluffy white head. Citrus-hop body with hints of sourness and a hoppy dry bitter finish. Proof that a pale hoppy beer with (relativly) low alcohol can be world class.
medicinal, anise, dry, foamy, floral, these are the flavors that come to mind.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2004 Sept 2003- 3.2
Soft red rose aroma , touch of hops  , flowery , soft and lightly spiced . Decent amount of carbonation in my glass, poured huge thick head. Amber colour. Very clean, bitterness well pronounced with very light Belgian ale feel added to it. So soft, smooth. Excellent texture . Later you will notice some peach , pear like flavours all well drenched in hop juice . You must love it this dry hopping  . Warming finish . World class . Outstanding .

Thick creamy robust head that lasted the entire beer.  Powerful fruity apricot orange aroma with a slight mustiness that fillled my kitchen.  Bitter tea taste with a hint of Grand Marnier and finishes bone dry.  A truly wonderful beer.  This is my idea of an ideal Calfornia IPA even though this is not an IPA.

Superb Belgian, best of type Ive had in a while -- if you can put these great Belgians into a type.  As different from Rochefort and Rodenbach as it is from Rolling Rock!  Great winey/wheaty nose and color (head is nice, but lasts a might too long, maybe) are followed by a flavor that is perhaps closest to an APA, but fuller and stronger and with *something* I cant quite define.  The finish too is uncategorizable, with a strong spicy zip that many may find unpalatable, but for me was a thrill.  Must be had.
1/11/02 rerating.  Have to give it a 5 for appearance.  Wondered if this would break through into my top 10 on a second shot; it hasnt.  But, its a challenging beer, and Im up for a few more rounds!

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2003 This is just the most unique beer I've ever tried.  Golden orange color with a huge, billowing head.  Intense aroma featuring hops, must, acid, yeast, oak, some banana pudding and many other things.  Flavor is complex and intense as well.  Starts with a slight sweetness and yeastiness that morphs into an acidic sour woodiness in the middle. It finishes intensely dry with a hefty chunk of hops. The carbonation dances on the tongue.  I just say "wow" every time I drink one of these.
A nice beer

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2009 Update: What an outstanding aroma and great tastefull bitterness this beer has. Yum! Original: I loved it. Im not familiar with the style, and the last time I had an Orval was 15 years ago (!), but I like the dryness, the hoppier character. The aroma was just a hair on the acceptable side of floral, yeasty, and I had a great experience. Now back to lecture preparation for tomorrow!

2009!! Wow, Ive had this beer a lot recently. In fact, I am having a perfect Orval experience right now, with a 15 month old bottle. The body conditioning so wonderfully lively, not over the top, and the brett is so perfectly sharp and clear yet natural and not overpowering. Very peachy aroma. This is occasionally a 5.0 beer.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
Not the best trappist...
But it is and it stays a trappist, that means really a try worth it.

Special taste, not to compare with one of the other trappists.  just different.

This is it! The reason I chose to delve deeper into all beers Belgian. Its bottle, color, head, aroma, taste, and long bitter aftertaste are just unequalled in my book! THE Trappist ale...just wish it wasnt so gosh-darned $$! One of lifes great luxuries!
Now this is beer. I wish more Belgians were as bitter as this. I love the bowling pin look of the bottles! Too bad I cant afford this often.

Medium-thick white foam over a copper-amber-honey color, some cloudiness.
Very elegant vinous-hoppy aroma, very outspoken and good freshness, truly outstanding.
Vivid herby-hoppy flavor, young tasting, quite lively.  Lengthy and hoppy finish.
Mouth-filling and long, but at the upper limit of acceptable hoppiness, in my taste.
An excellent brew, let there be no doubt about that, very different from the other trappist beers I have tasted, not unlike pale ale in some respects.  I wonder what ageing does to it.
Very long and dry. A remarkable individual beer. But not one of my top favorites. The aroma, and parts of the taste that gives you some medicine feeling...is a bit too though for me.

Amazing aroma and head.  Strong in flavor.
Surprisingly hoppy.

This is definitely a different tasting beer.  The aroma is wasnt that pleasant.  The taste made up for that.  It was strong with a tinge of sweetness towards the end.  Very nice beer, but I think Ill stick with Chimay.

I couldnt get past the cadaverous smell of paperwhites or narcissus to enjoy the beer.  Presents nicely, with tall, tall creamy head.  Im being charitable with the 6 rating on flavor, because Im sure that its an aquired taste.  Worst $5 I ever payed for 11.2 oz of beer that smelled like monks had been wrestling in a field of flowers.

Impressive presentation, generous sticky head, masculine but not musky aroma, slightly spice in the nose, some citrus, dry, very smooth finish, drinkable and luscious. Damn, I love this stuff like cheap 70s cologne. This rocks.

Re-rating, with improved score:  Previously rated as tasting of olive jar water.
Floral and citrusy hop aroma; Flavor also hoppy with a warming alcohol presence and funky orangey sweet maltiness.  Uniquely hoppy for a Belgian ale.  Finish is a bit sour and still reminds slightly of green olives.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2008 The magic begins as the huge, clumpy head morphs into a dense cream over the span of a couple minutes. Then the flavor, mouthfeel and aromatic experience. Snappy and dusty phenols, leathery astringency, peachy esters, soft and flowery Styrians, chewy Munich malt for added structure, sweetness and endless depth, and appetizing bitterness from the zingy and peppery nobles. Just an incredible beer. Truly an elite with few peers.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Very nice amber colour with a beautiful long head. Aroma of flowers and forest with a touch of vinegar. Strong bitterness, floral flavor. The finish is very long with maybe slightly too much bitterness for my taste.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2004 Strong aroma which is herbal, fruity and a bit yeasty. Hazy, orange/brown color, beige head. Very light sweet, very hoppy, herbal, grass, yeasty, little dry. Could use some body. I just can't seem to really start liking this one.
Pears? Unbelievable aroma!
Bad news! The most herby thing I have ever drunk!

Way more carbonation than any beer needs. Flavor was OK, an interesting light apple cider-like taste, with bunches of yeast. Has a strange acrid hop bite to it that I couldnt really get into (or maybe that was the carbo attacking my tongue).
A wonderful ale.  Great pear aroma.  Sharp and snappy up front, settling into a mildly fruity, hoppy finish.  Not as sweet at the finsish as most Belgians, which was appreciated.  Hoo-hah!
Such a refined drink. Extremely refreshing with a apricot-like aftertaste. The warmer it gets, the more floral it becomes.  The trappists have really focused their energy into this complex drink.
Excellent Belgian brew.  Must be served in the correct glass/chalice.
Great flavor!  Great Belgian example.

delicious stuff. 
nice tart flavours
very different from the other trappist ales
Spectacular color, Easily the best looking beer I have had.  Malt, spice and fruit flavors.  It is complex, but not my favorite.  I can see why others rave about it though.
Wow. Neat color, neat bitter flavor, neat beer. Not a good beginners brew, but rewarding if sipped slowly, in a cloistered room, after taking a vow of silence. Atmospheric, alive, and wonderful.
Wow! An unusual Belgian brew. Hops unlike any other Abbaye-style.

Beautiful copper color, and about the most perfect head I have ever poured. Smelled strangely like chewable cherry Peptobismol. Very fuzzy on the tongue (almost too much), not smooth at all, even, dare I say, harsh. Very medicinal, I could not get over the taste of artificial cherries (usually found in medicines that taste aweful). Slight alcohol taste underneath it all. Its depressing how not good it was, I was really looking forward to drinking it.

Extremely disappointing...this is Michael Jacksons favorite beer!? BEAUTIFUL golden brown with white, creamy head. Cherry, MEDICINAL flavor and scent, both of which were scarily reminiscent of cherry robituson. Even the after taste was cherry and medicinal, although slightly more tangy than the flavor.  In additon to the sickening, mediciny flavor, this was too damn bubbly.  It was so harsh, I could not finish the bottle.  This was more than disappointing...this was almost bad.
Likely the most beautiful beer Ive seen.  The aroma is acidic and flavor is very complex.  A strong cheese would go quite well with this.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2004 young bottle
Lemongras and nutmeg aroma.
Hazy orange-amber, sparkling champagne bubbles, huge off-white fluffy head.
Orangepeel flavors dominate, grape acidity, nutmeg and a spicy dustiness which increases as more yeast is added.
Exits on a spicy yeast note.
The particular bottle I had seemed to be quite carbonated which resulted in a bit fizzy mouthfeel.
Probably the best aroma of any beer i have tried with an equally nice appearance. Then it just was ok after that. Seemed to be lacking in flavor.
My first Trappist ale.  Did it live up to the hype?  Yes.  Will I buy another $8 bottle?  Probably not anytime soon.
nice bottle, great glass, but in my opinion not the best of the trapists.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2012 I need to re-rate this beer.   It really has grown on me.  Yeasty, spicy and slightly fruity profiles intermingle with a well-balanced foundation of freshness and richness.  Its high-class yummy.  Orangey. Still the best head in the business-- it is second to none.  Rich and thick foam, speckled with spice goblins, eventually settles into a solid meringue that doesnt leave your side.   Outstanding.  Beware the brewery-- especially a Trappist one-- that only makes one brew!

Maybe my mistake was having a Rodenbach Grand Cru preceding this, however it just didnt quite do it for me. There was a medicinal flavor that I just never quite grew to enjoy. Maybe that will change with a couple of more...
Deep amber/orange, cloudy body. Dry, bitter, fruity, citric. One of the best and most complex brews in the world.
I found the aroma waaaaay beter than the fluid. All that i expected from the aroma was missing from the fluid. The texture is nice.  It is too dry(flavorless) for me, sorry fans.

A very middle of the road Belgian ale, which makes it better than most American beers. Still, the lack of robust flavor is disappointing.  Chimay Cinq Cents is better.  Why does Michael Jackson think this is the best beer in the world?

This had an aroma to die for.  Very fruity, and it sported a huge head.  Flavor was quite tart, but not like a lambic; I believe it came from the champagne-like bubbles.  Wonderful flavor and aftertaste.  A must try.
Pours beatifully with a nice thick, creamy head.  Sweet, spicy aroma.  Tastes extrmely warming.  It doesnt live up to all the hype though.
Not the best Trappist ale Ive had, but right up there! Love that bitter after taste and the way the flavor rests on your tongue long after your last sip.

A lot of anitcipation went into drinking this beer.  I went to the Orval website and read the history of the monastary and the beer.  I have heard a lot about how great Belgian beers are and in general I tend to agree.  This is a fairly strong ale (6.9%), it has a light color and is pretty milky.  It throws a mean head, no matter how gently you pour.  The first thing I noticed was the citrus/fruity aroma.  Not a bad smell, but not what I had anticipated.  This is a pretty good beer, but not as great as Id hoped.  For the money, there are a lot of others Id rather drink.  This beer is quite similar to the Piraat Ale I had not too long ago.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2004 fantastic foamy head, orange coloured, strong and complex hoppy nose showing notes of orange peels, perfume, peanuts, vinegar and cream, smooth and slightly oily with a powerfull finishing bitterness, very long aftertaste of bitter orange and cream - this beer is a legend

I agree with PhillyBeer2112: This beer was a major disappointment.
Maybe Ive had some poorly handled bottles, but this beer is not worth $3.99 per 11.2 oz.
a true trappist ale, fabulous
